source_info.title: Heart attack
source_info.text:
【0】Causes \- Heart attack
======================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Recovery
7.  Complications
8.  Prevention</u>

【2】**Heart attacks are caused by the blood supply to the heart being suddenly interrupted. Without this supply, heart muscles may be damaged and begin to die.**

【3】Without treatment, the heart muscles will experience irreversible damage.

【4】If a large portion of the heart is damaged in this way, the heart stops beating (known as a cardiac arrest), resulting in death.

【5】Coronary heart disease
----------------------

【6】Coronary heart disease (CHD) is the leading cause of heart attacks. CHD is a condition in which the coronary arteries (the major blood vessels that supply the heart with blood) become clogged with deposits of fats such as cholesterol and other substances. These deposits are called plaques.

【7】Before a heart attack, one of the plaques ruptures (bursts), causing a blood clot to form at the site of the rupture. The clot may block the supply of blood to the heart, triggering a heart attack.

【8】Your risk of developing CHD is increased by:

【9】*   smoking
*   a high-fat diet
*   diabetes
*   high cholesterol
*   high blood pressure (hypertension)
*   being overweight or obese
删除7：<u>Find out more about the causes of coronary heart disease (CHD).</u>

【10】Lack of oxygen (hypoxia)
------------------------

【11】A less common cause of heart attacks is a lack of oxygen (hypoxia).

【12】If levels of oxygen in the blood decrease due to carbon monoxide poisoning or a loss of normal lung function, the heart will not receive enough oxygenated blood.

【13】This will result in the heart muscles being damaged, triggering a heart attack.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 13 July 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 13 July 2026</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Symptoms</u>删除1：<u>*   Next : Diagnosis</u>

source_info.title: Undescended testicles
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Undescended testicles
=================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Treatment</u>

【2】**Undescended testicles are a common childhood condition where a boy's testicles are not in their usual place in the scrotum.**

【3】It's estimated about 1 in every 25 boys are born with undescended testicles.

【4】In most cases no treatment is necessary, as the testicles will usually move down into the scrotum naturally during the first 3 to 6 months of life.

【5】But around 1 in 100 boys has testicles that stay undescended unless treated.

【6】The medical term for having 1 or 2 undescended testicles is unilateral or bilateral cryptorchidism.

【7】When to see your GP
-------------------

【8】Undescended testicles are usually detected during the newborn physical examination carried out soon after birth, or during a routine check-up at 6 to 8 weeks.

【9】See your GP if at any point you notice that 1 or both of your child's testicles are not in the normal place within the scrotum.

【10】Undescended testicles aren't painful and your child isn't at risk of any immediate health problems, but they should be monitored by a doctor in case treatment is needed later on.

【11】What causes undescended testicles?
----------------------------------

【12】During pregnancy, the testicles form inside a baby boy's tummy (abdomen) before slowly moving down into the scrotum about a month or 2 before birth.

【13】It's not known exactly why some boys are born with undescended testicles. Most boys with the condition are otherwise completely healthy.

【14】Being born prematurely (before the 37th week of pregnancy) and having a low birth weight and a family history of undescended testicles may increase the chances of a boy being born with the condition.

【15】Diagnosing undescended testicles
--------------------------------

【16】Undescended testicles can usually be diagnosed after a physical examination.

【17】This will determine whether the testicles can be felt near the scrotum (palpable) or if they can't be felt at all (impalpable).

【18】This physical examination can sometimes be difficult, so your doctor may need to refer your child to a paediatric surgeon.

【19】No further scans or tests are needed to locate the testicles if they can be felt by the doctor.

【20】If they can't be felt, part of the initial surgical treatment may involve keyhole surgery (a diagnostic laparoscopy) to see if the testicles are inside the abdomen.

【21】How undescended testicles are treated
-------------------------------------

【22】If the testicles haven't descended by 6 months, they're very unlikely to do so and treatment will usually be recommended.

【23】This is because boys with untreated undescended testicles can have fertility problems (infertility) in later life and an increased risk of developing testicular cancer.

【24】Treatment will usually involve an operation called an orchidopexy to move the testicles into the correct position inside the scrotum. This is a relatively straightforward operation with a good success rate.

【25】Surgery is ideally carried out before 12 months of age. If undescended testicles are treated at an early age, the risk of fertility problems and testicular cancer can be reduced.
删除7：<u>Read more about treating undescended testicles.</u>

【26】Retractile testicles
--------------------

【27】In most boys, the testicles can move in and out of the scrotum at different times, usually changing position as a result of temperature changes or feelings of fear or excitement.

【28】If the testicles move in and out of the scrotum and do not stay ascended, this is known as retractile testicles.

【29】Retractile testicles in young boys aren't a cause for concern, as the affected testicles often settle permanently in the scrotum as they get older.

【30】But they may need to be monitored during childhood because they sometimes don't descend naturally and treatment may be required.

【31】See your GP if you notice that your child's testicles are not within the scrotum. Your GP can carry out an examination to determine whether your child's testicles are undescended or retractile.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 26 October 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 26 October 2024</u>
删除1：<u>*   Next : Treatment</u>

source_info.title: Cornea transplant
source_info.text:
【0】Afterwards \- Cornea transplant
===============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  When it is needed
3.  How it is performed
4.  Afterwards
5.  Risks</u>

【2】**It's important to take good care of your eye after a cornea transplant to help ensure a good recovery and reduce the risk of complications.**

【3】After the procedure
-------------------

【4】Most people have to stay in hospital for a night after a full-thickness cornea transplant (penetrating keratoplasty). 

【5】You may be able to go home the same day if you have a partial-thickness transplant. 

【6】Your eye may be covered with an eye pad or plastic shield, which is removed the day after the procedure.

【7】When it's taken away, you may find that your sight is blurred. This is normal.

【8】There should not be serious pain after the operation, but there might be some swelling and discomfort.

【9】If you have had an endothelial keratoplasty – a type of partial-thickness transplant that uses an air bubble to hold the donated cornea in place – you may be asked to lie on your back as much as possible in the first few days after surgery.

【10】This can help hold the transplant in the correct place. The air bubble will be absorbed after a few days.

【11】Looking after your eye
----------------------

【12】Once you return home after the procedure, you'll need to take good care of your eye.

【13】Some important points to remember include:

【14】*   do not rub your eyes
*   during the first weeks after surgery, avoid strenuous exercise and heavy lifting
*   if you have a job that does not involve physical strain, you can return to work 2 to 3 weeks after surgery
*   if your job involves manual labour, you should wait for 3 to 4 months
*   avoid smoky or dusty places as this could irritate your eyes
*   if your eye is sensitive to light, wearing sunglasses can help
*   avoid contact sports and swimming until you're given clear advice that it's safe, and wear protective goggles when resuming contact sports
*   bath and shower as normal, but be careful not to get water in your eye for at least a month
*   do not drive until your specialist tells you it's possible

【15】You'll usually be given a patch to wear at night for the first few weeks after surgery to help protect your eye.

【16】For all types of cornea transplant, you have to use steroid or antibiotic eyedrops daily.

【17】These are normally required for several months, although some people may need to use them for more than a year.

【18】The drops reduce swelling and inflammation, and help prevent infection and rejection.

【19】Follow-up
---------

【20】At first you'll need to attend regular follow-up appointments. These should gradually become less frequent over time.

【21】If stitches were used to hold the transplant in place, these are initially left in place to allow the cornea to heal. They're usually removed after about a year.

【22】Your vision
-----------

【23】The time it takes for your vision to return after a cornea transplant can range from as little as a few weeks up to a year or more.

【24】This largely depends on the specific procedure used. In some cases, your vision may fluctuate between being better or worse before it settles down.

【25】It's likely you'll need corrective lenses (either glasses or contact lenses), even after your vision returns.

【26】In some cases, a small operation called arcuate keratotomy (AK) or laser treatment is used to correct vision problems after your eyes have healed.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 13 July 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 13 July 2024</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : How it is performed</u>删除1：<u>*   Next : Risks</u>

source_info.title: Alkaptonuria
source_info.text:
【0】Alkaptonuria
============

【1】**Alkaptonuria, or black urine disease, is a very rare inherited disorder that prevents the body fully breaking down two protein building blocks (amino acids) called tyrosine and phenylalanine.**

【2】It results in a build-up of a chemical called homogentisic acid in the body.

【3】This can turn urine and parts of the body a dark colour and lead to a range of health problems over time.

【4】Amino acids are usually broken down in a series of chemical reactions. But in alkaptonuria a substance produced along the way, homogentisic acid, cannot be broken down any further.

【5】This is because the enzyme that normally breaks it down does not work properly. Enzymes are proteins that make chemical reactions happen.

【6】One of the earliest signs of the condition is dark-stained nappies, as homogentisic acid causes urine to turn black when exposed to air for a few hours.

【7】If this sign is missed or overlooked in a baby or child, the disorder may go unnoticed until adulthood, as there are usually no other noticeable symptoms until the person reaches their late 20s to early 30s.

【8】Signs and symptoms in adults
----------------------------

【9】Over the course of many years, homogentisic acid slowly builds up in tissues throughout the body.

【10】It can build up in almost any area of the body, including the cartilage, tendons, bones, nails, ears and heart. It stains the tissues dark and causes a wide range of problems.

【11】### Joints and bones

【12】When a person with alkaptonuria reaches their 30s, they may start to experience joint problems.

【13】Typically, they'll have lower back pain and stiffness, followed by knee, hip and shoulder pain. These are similar to the early symptoms of osteoarthritis. 

【14】Eventually, cartilage – a tough, flexible tissue found throughout the body – may become brittle and break, leading to joint and spinal damage. Joint replacement operations may be needed.

【15】### Eyes and ears

【16】Many people develop brown or black spots on the whites of their eyes.

【17】Another sign in many adults with alkaptonuria is thickening of ear cartilage. The cartilage may also look blue, grey or black. This is called ochronosis.

【18】The earwax may be black or reddish-brown.

【19】Alkaptonuria can cause dark spots in the whites of the eyes

【20】Alkaptonuria can thicken the ear cartilage and make it look blue-black

【21】### Skin and nails

【22】Alkaptonuria can result in discoloured sweat, which can stain clothes and cause some people to have blue or black speckled areas of skin. Nails may also turn a bluish or brownish colour.

【23】The skin colour changes are most obvious on areas exposed to the sun and where sweat glands are found – the cheeks, forehead, armpits and genital area.

【24】### Breathing difficulties

【25】If the bones and muscles around the lungs become stiff, it can prevent the chest expanding and lead to shortness of breath or difficulty breathing.

【26】### Heart, kidney and prostate problems

【27】Deposits of homogentisic acid around heart valves can cause them to narrow, harden and turn brittle and black. Blood vessels can also become stiff and weaken.

【28】This can lead to heart disease and may require heart valve replacements.

【29】The deposits can also lead to kidney stones, bladder stones and prostate stones.

【30】How alkaptonuria is inherited
-----------------------------

【31】Each cell in the body contains 23 pairs of chromosomes. These carry the genes you inherit from your parents.

【32】One of each pair of chromosomes is inherited from each parent, which means (with the exception of the sex chromosomes) there are two copies of each gene in each cell.

【33】The gene involved in alkaptonuria is the HGD gene. This provides instructions for making an enzyme called homogentisate oxidase, which is needed to break down homogentisic acid.

【34】You need to inherit two copies of the faulty HGD gene (one from each parent) to develop alkaptonuria. The chances of this are slim, which is why the condition is very rare.

【35】The parents of a person with alkaptonuria will often only carry one copy of the faulty gene themselves, which means they will not have any signs or symptoms of the condition.

【36】How alkaptonuria is managed
---------------------------

【37】Alkaptonuria is a lifelong condition.

【38】A medicine called nitisinone is used to slow the advance of alkaptonuria in adults.

【39】Painkillers and lifestyle changes may help you cope with the symptoms.

【40】### Nitisinone

【41】Nitisinone reduces the level of homogentisic acid in the body. It’s offered at the National Alkaptonuria Centre, the treatment centre for all alkaptonuria patients, based at Royal Liverpool University Hospital.

【42】Find out about the National Alkaptonuria Centre and nitisinone treatment on the Alkaptonuria Society website

【43】### Diet

【44】A protein-controlled diet can be useful in reducing the risk of potential side effects when taking nitisinone for alkaptonuria during adulthood. Your doctor or dietitian will assess and advise you about this.

【45】### Exercise

【46】If alkaptonuria causes pain and stiffness, you may think exercise will make your symptoms worse. But regular gentle exercise can actually help by building muscle and strengthening your joints.

【47】Exercise is also good for relieving stress, losing weight and improving your posture, all of which can ease your symptoms.

【48】But avoid exercise that puts additional strain on the joints, such as boxing, football and rugby. Gentle exercise such as yoga and pilates might help in the early stages, while cycling, walking and swimming may be more suitable for advanced alkaptonuria.

【49】Your GP or a physiotherapist can help you come up with a suitable exercise plan to follow at home. It's important to follow this plan as there's a risk the wrong sort of exercise may damage your joints.

【50】### Pain relief

【51】Speak to a doctor about painkillers and other techniques to manage pain.

【52】Find tips for managing your pain levels about with 10 ways to reduce pain.

【53】### Emotional support

【54】A diagnosis of alkaptonuria can be confusing and overwhelming at first. Like many people with a long-term health condition, those who find out they have alkaptonuria may feel anxious or depressed.

【55】But there are people you can talk to who can help. Talk to your GP if you feel you need support to cope with your illness. You could also visit the AKU Society website, a charity offering support to patients, their families and carers.

【56】### Surgery

【57】Sometimes surgery may be necessary if joints are damaged and need replacing, or if heart valves or vessels have hardened.

【58】Your doctor may recommend:

【59】*   hip replacement
*   knee replacement
*   aortic valve replacement

【60】Outlook
-------

【61】People with alkaptonuria have a normal life expectancy. However, they will eventually experience symptoms, such as pain and loss of movement in the joints and spine, which can affect quality of life.

【62】Working and carrying out strenuous physical activity will usually become very difficult, and eventually you may need mobility aids such as a wheelchair to get around.
删除12：<u>Visit the AKU Society website for more information and support.</u>

【63】Sharing your information
------------------------

【64】If you or your child have alkaptonuria, your clinical team will pass relevant patient information on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

【65】This helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat this condition. You can opt out of the register at any time.
删除7：<u>Find out more about the NCARDRS register on GOV.UK</u>
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 10 March 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 10 March 2025</u>

source_info.title: Colchicine
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking colchicine
==============================================================

【1】Colchicine and pregnancy
------------------------

【2】Colchicine can be taken in pregnancy, although it is not prescribed very often. It's generally thought to be OK to take in pregnancy but there is very little information available about its use.

【3】If you are taking colchicine for gout or familial Mediterranean fever (FMF), contact your doctor for advice. They will be able to explain the risks and benefits of taking colchicine and help you decide what's best for you and your baby.

【4】Colchicine and breastfeeding
----------------------------

【5】Colchicine is not usually used to treat gout while you're breastfeeding. Your doctor may recommend a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) like ibuprofen, instead.

【6】For familial Mediterranean fever (FMF), your doctor may prescribe colchicine while you're breastfeeding.

【7】Although the amount of colchicine found in breast milk can vary it has not been linked with any side effects in breastfed babies.

【8】If your baby is not feeding as well as usual, or they're vomiting or have diarrhoea, or if you have any other concerns about your baby, talk to a health visitor, midwife, pharmacist or doctor as soon as possible.

【9】Colchicine and fertility
------------------------

【10】There have been some reports that colchicine can cause reduced sperm count in men if taken long-term. This is usually reversible when you stop treatment.

【11】There's no evidence to suggest that taking colchicine reduces fertility in women.

【12】Talk to your doctor if you think you may be pregnant, or you're trying for a baby. They may want to review your medicine to help decide if colchicine is the best treatment. They may decide that another treatment is better for you in pregnancy.

【13】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【14】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding
删除11：<u>More in Colchicine
------------------

【15】*   About colchicine
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 2 December 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 2 December 2025</u>

source_info.title: Chlamydia
source_info.text:
【0】Treatment \- Chlamydia
======================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Complications</u>

【2】**Chlamydia can usually be effectively treated with antibiotics. More than 95% of people will be cured if they take their antibiotics correctly.**

【3】You may be started on antibiotics once test results have confirmed you have chlamydia. But if it's very likely you have the infection, you might be started on treatment before you get your results.

【4】The two most commonly prescribed antibiotics for chlamydia are: 

【5】*   doxycycline – taken every day for a week
*   azithromycin – one dose of 1g, followed by 500mg once a day for 2 days

【6】Your doctor may give you different antibiotics, such as amoxicillin or erythromycin, if you have an allergy or are pregnant or breastfeeding. A longer course of antibiotics may be used if your doctor is concerned about complications of chlamydia.

【7】Some people experience side effects during treatment, but these are usually mild. The most common side effects include stomach ache, diarrhoea, feeling sick, and thrush in women.

【8】When can I have sex again?
--------------------------

【9】If you had doxycycline, you shouldn't have sex – including vaginal, oral or anal sex, even with a condom – until both you and your partner(s) have completed treatment.

【10】If you had azithromycin, you should wait 7 days after treatment before having sex (including oral sex).

【11】This will help ensure you don't pass on the infection or catch it again straight away.

【12】Will I need to go back to the clinic?
-------------------------------------

【13】If you take your antibiotics correctly, you may not need to return to the clinic.

【14】However, you will be advised to go back for another chlamydia test if:

【15】*   you had sex before you and your partner finished treatment
*   you forgot to take your medication or didn't take it properly
*   your symptoms don't go away
*   you're pregnant

【16】If you're under 25 years of age, you should be offered a repeat test for chlamydia 3 to 6 months after finishing your treatment because you're at a higher risk of catching it again.

【17】Testing and treating sexual partners
------------------------------------

【18】If you test positive for chlamydia, it's important that your current sexual partner and any other recent sexual partners you've had are also tested and treated.

【19】A specialist sexual health adviser can help you contact your recent sexual partners, or the clinic can contact them for you if you prefer.

【20】Either you or someone from the clinic can speak to them, or the clinic can send them a note to let them know they may have been exposed to a sexually transmitted infection (STI).

【21】The note will suggest that they go for a check-up. It will not have your name on it, so your confidentiality will be protected.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 01 September 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 01 September 2024</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Diagnosis</u>删除1：<u>*   Next : Complications</u>

source_info.title: Morphine
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about morphine
===============================

【1】How does morphine work?

【2】Morphine is from a group of medicines called opiates, or narcotics.

【3】It works in the central nervous system and the brain to block pain signals to the rest of the body. It also reduces the anxiety and stress caused by pain.

【4】When morphine blocks the pain, there are other unwanted effects, for example, slow or shallow breathing. It also slows down digestion, which is why morphine can cause constipation.

【5】How long will it take to work?

【6】This depends on the type of morphine you take.

【7】A morphine injection into a vein gives the quickest pain relief. It works almost straight away.

【8】Morphine tablets and liquid work in 30 to 60 minutes but wear off after 4 to 6 hours.

【9】Slow-release morphine can take a day or two to start working but the pain relief will last for longer.

【10】How will it make me feel?

【11】When you first take morphine, you might feel sleepy or sick. But this side effect will wear off after a few days as your body gets used to the medicine.

【12】You might also notice you are less alert. Do not drive, cycle or operate machinery if you feel sleepy or less alert.

【13】Are there any long-term side effects?

【14】Some people with conditions that need long-term pain relief may need to take morphine for a long time.

【15】If you need to take it for a long time your body can become used to it (known as tolerance). That means you need higher doses to control your pain over time.

【16】Some people can become more sensitive to pain (hyperalgesia). If this happens, your doctor will reduce your dose gradually to help these symptoms.

【17】It's possible to become addicted to morphine. For this reason, your dose will be reviewed to make sure you're only having the amount you need to control your pain.

【18】Your treatment plan may include details of how and when you'll stop morphine.

【19】If you're having treatment for cancer pain or other severe pain, your pain control will be carefully monitored. Speak to your doctor if you're worried about tolerance, hyperalgesia or becoming addicted.

【20】How will I know if I'm addicted?

【21】If you're addicted to morphine, you may find it difficult to stop taking it or feel you need to take it more often than necessary.

【22】If you stop taking morphine suddenly you may get withdrawal symptoms.

【23】These can include:

【24】*   feeling agitated or anxious
*   panic attacks
*   feeling your heartbeat (palpitations)
*   difficulty sleeping
*   shaking
*   sweating
*   body aches
*   feeling restless

【25】Talk to your doctor if you:

【26】*   are worried about addiction
*   need help with addiction
*   want to stop taking morphine

【27】Is morphine a controlled medicine?

【28】Morphine is a controlled medicine. This means there are strict rules on how it's prescribed and dispensed to make sure it's not given to the wrong person or misused.

【29】When you collect morphine your pharmacist will ask for proof of your identity such as your passport or driving licence. You'll also be asked to sign the back of your prescription, to confirm that you've received it.

【30】If you're collecting morphine for someone else, you're legally required to show the pharmacist proof of your identity if asked.

【31】How can I tell what type of morphine I'm taking?

【32】Ask your doctor or pharmacist if you're not sure what type of morphine you're taking.

【33】Standard tablets are known by the brand name Sevredol.

【34】Slow-release tablets are also known as MST Continus or Morphgesic SR. Slow-release capsules are also known as MXL or Zomorph.

【35】Are there other painkillers I can try?

【36】The type of painkiller that's best for you depends on what type of pain you have and the cause of your pain.

【37】If morphine does not get rid of your pain or it becomes less effective, discuss this with your doctor.

【38】Is morphine only used at the end of life?

【39】Morphine is not only used at the end of a terminal illness. It's the amount of pain you have, not the stage of your illness, that decides whether morphine is prescribed for you.

【40】Will it affect my contraception?

【41】Morphine does not affect any type of contraception including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【42】But if morphine makes you sick (vomit), your contraceptive pill may not protect you from pregnancy. If this happens, follow the instructions in the leaflet that comes with your contraceptive pill.

【43】Find out what to do if you're on the pill and you're being sick

【44】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【45】Do not drive a car or ride a bike if morphine makes you sleepy, gives you blurred vision or makes you feel dizzy, clumsy or unable to concentrate or make decisions. This may be more likely when you first start taking morphine but could happen at any time, for example, when starting another medicine.

【46】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【47】Even if your ability to drive is not affected, the police have the right to request a saliva sample to check how much morphine is in your body.

【48】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking morphine.

【49】Read more on the law on drugs and driving from GOV.UK

【50】Can I drink alcohol with it?

【51】It may be best not to drink alcohol while taking morphine as it may make you feel more sleepy or increase the risk of serious side effects.

【52】It's best to stop drinking alcohol during the first few days of treatment until you see how the morphine affects you.

【53】If you feel sleepy with morphine, stop drinking alcohol while you are taking it.

【54】Will recreational drugs affect it?

【55】If you take recreational drugs, such as cannabis, cocaine or heroin, while you're taking morphine, you're more likely to get the serious side effects of morphine including breathing difficulties, heart problems such as high blood pressure, seizures or fits and even going into a coma.

【56】Some recreational drugs, such as cannabis, will also increase morphine side effects such as sleepiness and dizziness.

【57】Taking heroin while you're on prescribed morphine is especially dangerous. You're more likely to get all the side effects of morphine, including addiction.

【58】Tell your doctor if you think you may take recreational drugs while you're on morphine.

【59】You can read more about the side effects of some recreational drugs on the Frank website.

source_info.title: Budesonide rectal foam and enemas
source_info.text:
【0】How and when to use budesonide rectal foam and enemas \- Brand names: Budenofalk, Entocort
==========================================================================================

【1】Always use budesonide rectal foam and enemas as a doctor or pharmacist has told you.

【2】Dosage
------

【3】The usual dose of budesonide rectal foam or budesonide enema is 2mg, used once a day for up to 8 weeks.

【4】Budesonide rectal foam
----------------------

【5】Budesonide rectal foam comes in a can with single-use plastic tubes (applicators) that you use to insert the foam.

【6】Each application gives a 2mg dose of budesonide.

【7】Try to use it at about the same time of day, either in the morning or in the evening before bed.

【8】Use the rectal foam after doing a poo. This is because the medicine works best when your bowels are empty.

【9】After you use the foam, try not to poo again for at least a few hours. For the medicine to work properly it needs to stay inside your bowel as long as possible.

【10】### How to use it

【11】1.  Read the instruction leaflet. The pictures show you exactly how to use the foam.
2.  If you're using it for the first time, remove the plastic flap (or safety lock) from underneath the dome-shaped pump at the top of the can.
3.  Wash your hands before and after using the foam.
4.  Push a new applicator onto the nozzle. This nozzle sticks out beneath the dome at the top of the can.
5.  Shake the can for about 15 seconds.
6.  Twist the rounded dome at the bottom.
7.  Put your index finger on top of the dome and turn the can upside down. It's important to keep the can as straight (vertical) as possible.
8.  Stand with one leg raised on a chair – or lie down on your side if you prefer. Gently put the applicator into your bottom as far as possible.
9.  Push the dome down fully once.
10.  Then release the dome slowly. The foam comes out of the spray can when you do this.
11.  Wait 10 to 15 seconds before removing the applicator from your bottom. This is important to make sure you get the full dose and to stop any foam spilling out.
12.  Twist the dome at the base and remove the applicator from the nozzle. This stops any foam coming out when you're not using it. Put the applicator in the plastic bag provided and throw the bag away.

【12】**Budesonide enemas**
---------------------

【13】This medicine comes as liquid and tablets that you mix together. Once made up, it contains a 2mg dose of budesonide.

【14】It's best to use budesonide enemas at night, just before going to bed.

【15】It's best to go to the toilet before using the enema. This is because it's more comfortable if you empty your bowels and bladder before using it.

【16】You may want to sleep on a towel or similar covering. This is to protect your bedding from stains.

【17】### How to use a budesonide enema

【18】You should have 1 bottle of liquid, 1 nozzle and enema tablets.

【19】1.  Check the instruction leaflet first. The pictures show you exactly how to prepare and use the enema.
2.  Take a bottle of the liquid and unscrew the cap.
3.  Remove 1 tablet from the foil strip and drop it into the bottle of liquid.
4.  Replace the cap and screw firmly back onto the bottle.
5.  Shake the bottle well for at least 15 seconds, or until the tablet has dissolved in the liquid.
6.  Remove the cap and screw the nozzle tightly onto the top of the bottle.
7.  The enema is now ready and should be used immediately.
8.  Wash your hands before and after using the enema.
9.  Lie on your side, with your bottom slightly higher than the rest of your body. You can use a pillow to lift your bottom up. You may want to lie on a towel.
10.  Put one of the disposable plastic bags provided over your hand (like a glove) and pick up the bottle.
11.  Shake the bottle and remove only the protective cap that covers the nozzle (do not unscrew the nozzle itself).
12.  Gently push the nozzle into your bottom as far as is comfortable. You can use a lubricant if you find this uncomfortable.
13.  Squeeze the bottle to push the liquid into your bottom. It's normal for some liquid to be left in the bottle afterwards.
14.  Remove the nozzle from your bottom.
15.  Put the bottle into the disposable plastic bag by rolling the bag off your hand and over the bottle, ready to throw away.
16.  Roll onto your front and wait for 5 minutes. This will stop any liquid coming out of your bottom.
17.  For sleeping, find a comfortable position that keeps the liquid in your bottom for as long as possible. The longer it stays there, the better it will work.

【20】How long to use it for
----------------------

【21】Your doctor will tell you how long to use budesonide rectal foam or enemas for. This will usually be for no longer than 8 weeks. Do not use budesonide rectal foam or enemas for more than 8 weeks without speaking to a doctor.

【22】If you forget to use it
-----------------------

【23】If you forget to use your budesonide rectal foam or enema, use it as soon as you remember unless it's nearly time for the next dose. In this case, skip the missed dose and take the next one at the usual time.

【24】Never use 2 doses to make up for a missed dose.

【25】If you often forget doses, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to use this medicine.

【26】If you use too much
-------------------

【27】Using too much budesonide is unlikely to harm you.

【28】If you're worried, talk to your doctor or a pharmacist.
删除11：<u>More in Budesonide rectal foam and enemas

source_info.title: Warfarin
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about warfarin
===============================

【1】How does warfarin work?

【2】Warfarin is a type of medicine known as an anticoagulant. It makes your blood clot more slowly.

【3】Blood clotting (thickening) is a complicated process involving substances called clotting factors.

【4】Clotting factors are made by the liver and help stop bleeding. They work with blood cells called platelets that trigger the clotting process to make sure your blood clots properly.

【5】To make some of the clotting factors, the liver needs a good supply of vitamin K.

【6】Warfarin blocks the liver from using vitamin K to make clotting factors. This thins your blood, so it takes longer to clot.

【7】How long does it take to work?

【8】Warfarin takes about 3 days to work fully.

【9】But it can take weeks or even months before you settle on the right dose.

【10】This is because everyone reacts differently to warfarin, so it's normal for your dose to go up and down when you first start taking it.

【11】You will not feel any different while you take warfarin. The only way to check it's working is to have a blood test to see how long your blood takes to clot.

【12】What will happen if I stop taking it?

【13】Do not stop taking warfarin without talking to your doctor.

【14】If you stop taking warfarin, your blood will start clotting at the same rate as before you started taking it, usually within a day or two of stopping.

【15】This means you may be at an increased risk of serious problems like strokes, heart attacks, deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism.

【16】Are there any other medicines for blood clots?

【17】Warfarin is one of the oldest and most commonly used anticoagulants.

【18】There are newer anticoagulants, such as rivaroxaban, dabigatran, apixaban and edoxaban.

【19】Warfarin does not seem to be any better or worse than newer anticoagulants at treating and preventing blood clots.

【20】But the newer anticoagulants may be more convenient because you do not need to have regular blood tests or be quite as careful about what you eat.

【21】Will I need to stop warfarin before surgery?

【22】Because of the risk of bleeding, your dose of warfarin may need to be lowered or stopped a few days before you have an operation.

【23】Tell the surgeon or nurse that you're taking warfarin.

【24】Also tell anyone else involved with your care, such as your anticoagulant specialist, so they can arrange any changes to your medicine for you.

【25】Will I need to stop warfarin before dental treatment?

【26】You can still go to your dentist as usual. But tell your dentist that you're taking warfarin before you have any treatment, especially if you need to have a tooth out.

【27】You may need to have blood tests before starting treatment to make sure your blood will clot enough to stop any bleeding.

【28】Before taking out a tooth, your dentist will need to know how well your blood is clotting. This will be checked using the international normalised ratio (INR) test.

【29】Most people do not need to change their warfarin dose.

【30】Can I have vaccinations?

【31】It's safe for you to have vaccinations, but tell the nurse or doctor that you're taking warfarin.

【32】If the vaccine is normally given by injection into the muscle, provided you're up to date with your blood tests and the results are within the target range, you can have the injection as normal into muscle.

【33】Or sometimes the injection can be given into the layer of fat underneath your skin. This is called a subcutaneous injection.

【34】It might help prevent bruising if you press on the injection site for 10 minutes after the vaccination.

【35】Can I have a tattoo or piercing?

【36】Having a body piercing or tattoo is not recommended while you're taking warfarin. This is because of the increased risk of bleeding and infection.

【37】If you still want to go ahead, talk to your doctor about your specific risks in case you need antibiotics or changes to your warfarin dose.

【38】And let the tattooist or piercer know beforehand that you're taking an anticoagulant medicine.

【39】Will it affect my sex life?

【40】There's no evidence that taking warfarin affects your sex life.

【41】Will it affect my contraception?

【42】Warfarin does not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【43】But you'll need to have an international normalised ratio (INR) blood test when you start or stop taking contraception.

【44】This is to check whether your warfarin dose is still at the right level or needs to be changed.

【45】Can I drink alcohol while taking warfarin?

【46】You can drink alcohol while taking warfarin.

【47】But drinking heavily, especially binge drinking lots of alcohol in one go, is dangerous while taking warfarin. The alcohol can increase the risk of bleeding.

【48】Can I take recreational drugs with warfarin?

【49】It's thought that cannabis can affect your blood tests and increase your risk of serious bleeding.

【50】It's not clear how other recreational drugs like cocaine and heroin affect warfarin. They could be potentially dangerous.

【51】Injecting while taking warfarin will increase your risk of bleeding.

【52】Talk to your doctor if you think you might use recreational drugs while taking warfarin.

【53】You can find out more about the side effects of some recreational drugs on the Frank website.

【54】Can lifestyle changes help reduce the risk of blood clots?

【55】You can reduce your risk of having a blood clot by making changes to your lifestyle, such as:

【56】*   quitting smoking
*   eating a healthy, balanced diet – but speak to your doctor before making changes to your diet
*   getting regular exercise
*   keeping to a healthy weight, or losing weight if you need to
删除11：<u>More in Warfarin

source_info.title: Addiction: what is it?
source_info.text:
【0】Addiction: what is it?
======================

【1】**Addiction is a common problem, but help is available.**

【2】Addiction is defined as not having control over doing, taking or using something to the point where it could be harmful to you.

【3】Addiction is most commonly associated with gambling, drugs, alcohol and smoking, but it's possible to be addicted to just about anything, including:

【4】*   **work** – some people are obsessed with their work to the extent that they become physically exhausted; if your relationship, family and social life are affected and you never take holidays, you may be addicted to work
*   **internet** – as computer and mobile phone use has increased, so too have computer and internet addictions; people may spend hours each day and night surfing the internet or gaming while neglecting other aspects of their lives
*   **solvents** – volatile substance abuse is when you inhale substances such as glue, aerosols, petrol or lighter fuel to give you a feeling of intoxication
*   **shopping** – shopping becomes an addiction when you buy things you don't need or want to achieve a buzz; this is quickly followed by feelings of guilt, shame or despair

【5】What causes addictions?
-----------------------

【6】There are lots of reasons why addictions begin. In the case of drugs, alcohol and nicotine, these substances affect the way you feel, both physically and mentally. These feelings can be enjoyable and create a powerful urge to use the substances again.

【7】Gambling may result in a similar mental "high" after a win, followed by a strong urge to try again and recreate that feeling. This can develop into a habit that becomes very hard to stop.

【8】Being addicted to something means that not having it causes withdrawal symptoms, or a "come down". Because this can be unpleasant, it's easier to carry on having or doing what you crave, and so the cycle continues.

【9】Often, an addiction gets out of control because you need more and more to satisfy a craving and achieve the "high".

【10】How addictions can affect you
-----------------------------

【11】The strain of managing an addiction can seriously damage your work life and relationships. In the case of substance misuse (for example, drugs and alcohol), an addiction can have serious psychological and physical effects.

【12】Some studies suggest a person's risk of becoming addicted is partly genetic, but environmental factors, such as being around other people with addictions, are also thought to increase the risk.

【13】Behaviours such as substance misuse can be a way of blocking out difficult issues. Unemployment and poverty can trigger addiction, along with stress and emotional or professional pressure.

【14】Getting help for addictions
---------------------------

【15】Addiction is a treatable condition. Whatever the addiction, there are lots of ways you can seek help. You could see your GP for advice or contact an organisation that specialises in helping people with addictions.

【16】You can use the following online directories to find addiction treatment services in your area:

【17】*   Alcohol addiction services
*   Drug addiction services
*   Stop smoking services

【18】To speak to someone anonymously about any type of addiction, you can call the Samaritans free on 116 123.
删除11：<u>More in Addiction support
-------------------------

【19】*   Drug addiction: getting help
*   Heroin addiction: get help
*   Cocaine addiction: get help
*   Advice for families of people who use drugs
*   Addiction: what is it?
*   Help for problems with gambling
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 9 June 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 9 June 2024</u>

source_info.title: Oxycodone
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about oxycodone \- Brand names: Oxycontin, Oxypro, Longtec, Reltebon, Zomestine
================================================================================================

【1】How does oxycodone work?

【2】Oxycodone is one of a group of medicines called opioids, or narcotics.

【3】It works by blocking pain signals from the central nervous system and the brain to the rest of the body. It also reduces the anxiety and stress caused by pain.

【4】How long does it take to work?

【5】This depends on whether you are taking standard oxycodone capsules, tablets or liquid, or slow-release tablets.

【6】Standard oxycodone takes 30 to 60 minutes to work, but this wears off after 4 to 6 hours.

【7】Slow-release oxycodone can take 1 to 2 days to work fully, but the pain relief will last longer.

【8】Are there any long-term side effects?

【9】Some people who need long-term pain relief may need to take oxycodone for a long time.

【10】If you need to take it for a long time, your body can become used to it (known as tolerance). That means you need higher doses to control your pain over time.

【11】Some people can become more sensitive to pain (hyperalgesia). If this happens, your doctor will reduce your dose gradually to help these symptoms.

【12】It is possible to become addicted to oxycodone. For this reason, your dose will be reviewed to make sure you're only taking the amount you need to control your pain.

【13】Your treatment plan may include details of how and when you'll stop taking oxycodone.

【14】If you are having treatment for cancer pain or other severe pain, your pain control will be carefully monitored. Speak to your doctor if you're worried about tolerance, hyperalgesia or becoming addicted.

【15】How will I know if I'm addicted?

【16】If you're addicted to oxycodone, you may find it difficult to stop taking it or feel you need to take it more often than necessary.

【17】If you stop taking it suddenly you may get withdrawal symptoms.

【18】These can include:

【19】*   feeling agitated, anxious or nervous
*   panic attacks
*   feeling your heartbeat (palpitations)
*   difficulty sleeping
*   shaking
*   sweating
*   body aches
*   feeling restless

【20】Talk to your doctor if you:

【21】*   are worried about addiction
*   need help with addiction
*   want to stop taking oxycodone

【22】How does it compare with other opioids?

【23】Oxycodone acts on different pain signals in the brain to some other opioids. This does not mean it's better for certain conditions.

【24】The pain relief and side effects which you can get from oxycodone will be different for individual people. A doctor may prescribe oxycodone if you have had side effects from other opioids.

【25】Will it affect my contraception?

【26】Oxycodone does not affect any type of contraception including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【27】If oxycodone makes you vomit, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy. Look on the pill packet to find out what to do.
删除7：<u>Find out more about what to do if you're on the pill and you're being sick.</u>

【28】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【29】Do not drive a car, ride a bike or operate machinery if oxycodone gives you blurred vision, or makes you feel dizzy, sleepy, clumsy or unable to concentrate or make decisions.

【30】This may be more likely when you first start taking oxycodone but could happen at any time, for example when starting another medicine or if a doctor increases your dose.

【31】Even if your ability to drive is not affected, police have the right to request a saliva sample to check how much oxycodone is in your body.

【32】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【33】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking oxycodone删除7：<u> GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.</u>

【34】Can I drink alcohol while taking oxycodone?

【35】It's best to stop drinking alcohol during the first few days of treatment, or if a doctor increases your dose, until you see how oxycodone affects you.

【36】Drinking alcohol while you're taking oxycodone may make you feel more sleepy or increase the risk of serious side effects.

【37】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【38】Grapefruit juice can affect the strength of the oxycodone in your body and cause more serious side effects.

【39】Oxycodone is not generally affected by any other food or drink, except alcohol. Drinking alcohol while you're taking oxycodone may make you feel more sleepy, or increase the risk of serious side effects.

【40】Will recreational drugs affect it?

【41】If you take recreational drugs, such as cannabis, cocaine or heroin, while you're taking oxycodone, you're more likely to get the serious side effects of oxycodone including breathing difficulties, muscle stiffness, low blood pressure and seizures or fits.

【42】Some recreational drugs, such as cannabis, will also increase oxycodone side effects and make you feel sleepy and dizzy.

【43】Taking heroin while you're taking prescribed oxycodone is especially dangerous. You're more likely to get all the side effects of oxycodone, including addiction.

【44】Tell your doctor if you take recreational drugs while you're taking oxycodone.
删除7：<u>Find out more about the side effects of recreational drugs on the Frank website</u>
删除11：<u>More in Oxycodone
