source_info.title: Phenoxymethylpenicillin
source_info.text:
【0】Side effects of phenoxymethylpenicillin
=======================================

【1】Like all medicines, phenoxymethylpenicillin can cause side effects, although not everyone gets them.

【2】If you're taking phenoxymethylpenicillin to prevent infections, your doctor will usually ask you to have blood tests. This is to make sure you're not getting any unexpected side effects.

【3】Common side effects
-------------------

【4】These common side effects of phenoxymethylpenicillin happen in 1 in 10 people. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【5】Feeling sick (nausea)

【6】Stick to simple meals and do not eat rich or spicy food while you're taking this medicine.

【7】Being sick (vomiting)

【8】Take small, frequent sips of water or squash to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee. Do not take any other medicines to treat vomiting without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.

【9】If you take contraceptive pills and you're being sick, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet for advice.

【10】Diarrhoea

【11】Drink lots of fluids, such as water or squash, to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee. Do not take any other medicines to treat diarrhoea without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.

【12】If you take contraceptive pills and you have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet for advice.

【13】Stomach pain

【14】Try to rest and relax. It can help to eat and drink slowly and have smaller and more frequent meals. Putting a heat pad or covered hot water bottle on your stomach may also help. If you're in a lot of pain, speak to your pharmacist or doctor.

【15】Speak to a doctor or pharmacist if the advice on how to cope does not help and a side effect is still bothering you or does not go away.

【16】### Mild allergic reactions

【17】Around 1 in 10 people have an allergic reaction to phenoxymethylpenicillin.

【18】In most cases, the allergic reaction is mild.

【19】You can usually treat a mild allergic reaction by taking antihistamines.

【20】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you have a mild allergic reaction and your symptoms get worse.

【21】Serious side effects
--------------------

【22】Serious side effects are rare and happen in less than 1 in 1,000 people.

【23】Call your doctor or call 111 now if you get:

【24】*   stomach pain
*   a high temperature and watery diarrhoea with blood and mucus in it – this could be a sign that your bowels have become irritated and swollen (inflamed).

【25】### Serious allergic reaction

【26】In rare cases, phenoxymethylpenicillin can cause a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis).

【27】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【28】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【29】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【30】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【31】Other side effects
------------------

【32】These are not all the side effects of phenoxymethylpenicillin. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.
删除5：<u>Information:

【33】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.
删除12：<u>Visit Yellow Card for further information.</u></u>
删除11：<u>More in Phenoxymethylpenicillin
-------------------------------

【34】*   About phenoxymethylpenicillin
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking phenoxymethylpenicillin with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 26 January 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 26 January 2025</u>

source_info.title: NHS-funded nursing care
source_info.text:
【0】NHS-funded nursing care
=======================

【1】NHS-funded nursing care is when the NHS pays for the nursing care component of nursing home fees. The NHS pays a flat rate directly to the care home towards the cost of this nursing care.

【2】Who is eligible for NHS-funded nursing care?
--------------------------------------------

【3】You may be eligible for NHS-funded nursing care if:

【4】*   you're not eligible for NHS continuing healthcare but have been assessed as needing care from a registered nurse
*   you live in a nursing home

【5】How will my needs be assessed?
------------------------------

【6】You should be assessed for NHS continuing healthcare before a decision is made about whether you are eligible for NHS-funded nursing care.

【7】Most people don't need a separate assessment for NHS-funded nursing care. However, if you do need an assessment or you haven't already had one, your integrated care board (ICB) can arrange an assessment for you.

【8】Find your local ICB

【9】Outcome of the assessment
-------------------------

【10】If you're eligible for NHS-funded nursing care, the NHS will arrange and fund nursing care provided by registered nurses employed by the care home. Services provided by a registered nurse can include planning, supervising and monitoring nursing and healthcare tasks, as well as direct nursing care.

【11】If you're not eligible for NHS-funded nursing care and you don't agree with the decision about your eligibility, ask your ICB to review the decision.

【12】The cost of NHS-funded nursing care
-----------------------------------

【13】NHS-funded nursing care is paid at the same rate across England. In May 2022, the rate was set at £209.19 a week (standard rate) and will be backdated to 1 April 2022.

【14】If you moved into a care home before 1 October 2007, and you were on the previous high band, NHS-funded nursing care is paid at a higher rate. In May 2022, the higher rate was set at £287.78 a week and will be backdated to 1 April 2022.

【15】You're entitled to continue on this rate unless:

【16】*   you no longer have nursing needs
*   you no longer live in a care home that provides nursing
*   your nursing needs have reduced and you're no longer eligible for the high band, when you would change to the standard rate of £209.19 a week, or
*   you become entitled to NHS continuing healthcare instead
删除11：<u>More in Money, work, benefits and social care
---------------------------------------------

【17】*   Paying for your own care (self-funding)
*   When the council might pay for your care
*   Work and disability
*   Personal budgets and direct payments
*   NHS continuing healthcare
*   NHS-funded nursing care
*   Benefits if you're under State Pension age
*   Benefits if you're over State Pension age
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 21 April 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 21 April 2024</u>

source_info.title: Budesonide nasal spray
source_info.text:
【0】How and when to use budesonide nasal spray \- Brand name: Benacort
==================================================================

【1】Always use budesonide nasal spray as a doctor or pharmacist has told you.

【2】Dosage
------

【3】Each spray usually contains 64 micrograms of budesonide.

【4】You'll usually use the spray once or twice a day, once in the morning and once at night. The usual dose is 1 or 2 sprays into each nostril.

【5】Follow the instructions that come with your medicine. Do not use more than the maximum number of sprays in 24 hours.

【6】You need to use the spray regularly for it to work.

【7】Changes to your dose
--------------------

【8】If you buy budesonide nasal spray without a prescription, you can use it less often once your symptoms are under control. For example, you might go from using 2 sprays twice a day to just 1 spray twice a day.

【9】If your symptoms get worse after reducing your dose, you may want to increase it again.

【10】If you have budesonide nasal spray on prescription, your doctor will tell you how often to use it and when to change your dose.

【11】How to use it
-------------

【12】If you're using a new bottle, it will not work the first time you press the spray. Pump the spray a few times until a fine mist comes out. You'll also need to do this if you have not used the bottle for a few days.

【13】Gently shake the bottle, remove the cap and keep upright. Pump the nozzle until it starts to spray mist.

【14】1.  Blow your nose gently.
2.  Put the tip of the nozzle into 1 nostril, being careful to keep it pointing towards the side of the nostril and not the middle (nasal septum).
3.  Spray once into your nostril (or twice if you are told you need to).
4.  Repeat steps 2 and 3 in the other nostril if you need it.

【15】After using your spray, wipe the nozzle with a clean tissue and replace the cap.

【16】How long to use it for
----------------------

【17】If you buy budesonide nasal spray from a pharmacy or shop, check the leaflet that comes with the medicine. It will tell you how long you can use it for. This is usually between 1 and 3 months. But If you feel no better after 7 to 14 days, speak to your doctor or pharmacist.

【18】Also ask your doctor or pharmacist's advice if you feel better before 7 days but are not sure if you can stop.

【19】If you're prescribed budesonide, your doctor may advise you to use it for longer.

【20】If you forget to use it
-----------------------

【21】If you forget to use your spray, use it as soon as you remember, unless it's almost time for your next dose. If this happens, skip the missed dose and have your next one at the usual time.

【22】Do not add extra sprays to your dose to make up for a forgotten dose.

【23】If you forget doses often, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to take your medicine.

【24】If you use too much
-------------------

【25】Using too much budesonide nasal spray is unlikely to harm you.

【26】Speak to a pharmacist or doctor if you're worried.

【27】Steroid cards
-------------

【28】If you're using very high doses of budesonide, or you're using it with other steroid medicines, tablets for fungal infections or tablets for HIV, ask your doctor, nurse or a pharmacist if you need to carry a blue steroid card, or a red steroid emergency card, or both.

【29】### Important

【30】If you need any medical or dental treatment, show your blue or red steroid card to the doctor, dentist or pharmacist so they know you're taking budesonide.
删除11：<u>More in Budesonide nasal spray
------------------------------

【31】*   About budesonide nasal spray
*   Who can and cannot use it
*   How and when to use it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Using it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 16 August 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 16 August 2026</u>

source_info.title: Hepatitis
source_info.text:
【0】Hepatitis
=========

【1】**Hepatitis is the term used to describe inflammation of the liver. It's usually the result of a viral infection or liver damage caused by drinking alcohol.**

【2】There are several different types of hepatitis. Some types will pass without any serious problems, while others can be long-lasting (chronic) and cause scarring of the liver (cirrhosis), loss of liver function and, in some cases, liver cancer.

【3】Symptoms of hepatitis
---------------------

【4】Short-term (acute) hepatitis often has no noticeable symptoms, so you may not realise you have it.

【5】If symptoms do develop, they can include:

【6】*   muscle and joint pain
*   a high temperature
*   feeling and being sick
*   feeling unusually tired all the time
*   a general sense of feeling unwell
*   loss of appetite
*   tummy pain
*   dark urine
*   pale, grey-coloured poo
*   itchy skin
*   yellowing of the eyes and skin (jaundice)

【7】See your GP if you have any persistent or troublesome symptoms that you think could be caused by hepatitis.

【8】Long-term (chronic) hepatitis also may not have any obvious symptoms until the liver stops working properly (liver failure) and may only be picked up during blood tests.

【9】In the later stages it can cause jaundice, swelling in the legs, ankles and feet, confusion, and blood in your stools or vomit.

【10】Hepatitis A
-----------

【11】Hepatitis A is caused by the hepatitis A virus. It's usually caught by consuming food and drink contaminated with the poo of an infected person, and is most common in countries where sanitation is poor.

【12】Hepatitis A usually passes within a few months, although it can occasionally be severe and even life threatening.

【13】There's no specific treatment for it, other than to relieve symptoms like pain, nausea and itching.

【14】Vaccination against hepatitis A is recommended if:

【15】*   you're at high risk of infection or severe consequences of infection
*   you're travelling to an area where the virus is common, such as the Indian subcontinent, Africa, Central and South America, the Far East and eastern Europe.
删除7：<u>Find out more about hepatitis A</u>

【16】Hepatitis B
-----------

【17】Hepatitis B is caused by the hepatitis B virus, which is spread in the blood of an infected person.

【18】It's a common infection worldwide and is usually spread from infected pregnant women to their babies, or from child-to-child contact.

【19】It can also be spread through unprotected sex and injecting drugs.

【20】Hepatitis B is uncommon in the UK. It most commonly affects people who became infected while growing up in part of the world where the infection is more common, such as southeast Asia and sub-Saharan Africa.

【21】Most adults infected with hepatitis B are able to fight off the virus and fully recover from the infection within a couple of months.

【22】But most people infected as children develop a long-term infection. This is known as chronic hepatitis B, and can lead to cirrhosis and liver cancer. Antiviral medicine can be used to treat it.

【23】In the UK, vaccination against hepatitis B is recommended for people in high-risk groups, such as:

【24】*   healthcare workers
*   people who inject drugs
*   men who have sex with men
*   children born to mothers with hepatitis B
*   people travelling to parts of the world where the infection is more common

【25】Hepatitis B vaccination is also part of the routine immunisation programme so all children can benefit from protection from this virus.
删除7：<u>Find out more about hepatitis B</u>

【26】Hepatitis C
-----------

【27】Hepatitis C is caused by the hepatitis C virus.

【28】It's usually spread through blood-to-blood contact with an infected person.

【29】In the UK, it's most commonly spread through sharing needles used to inject drugs.

【30】Poor healthcare practices and unsafe medical injections are the main way it's spread outside the UK.

【31】Hepatitis C often causes no noticeable symptoms, or only flu-like symptoms, so many people are unaware they're infected.

【32】Some people will fight off the infection and be free of the virus. In other cases, it'll stay in the body for many years.

【33】This is known as chronic hepatitis C and can cause cirrhosis and liver failure.

【34】Chronic hepatitis C can be treated with very effective antiviral medicines, but there's currently no vaccine available.
删除7：<u>Find out more about hepatitis C</u>

【35】Hepatitis D
-----------

【36】Hepatitis D is caused by the hepatitis D virus. It only affects people who are already infected with hepatitis B, as it needs the hepatitis B virus to be able to survive in the body.

【37】Hepatitis D is usually spread through blood-to-blood contact or sexual contact. It's uncommon in the UK, but is more widespread in other parts of Europe, the Middle East, Africa and South America.

【38】Long-term infection with hepatitis D and hepatitis B can increase your risk of developing serious problems, such as cirrhosis and liver cancer.

【39】There's no vaccine specifically for hepatitis D, but the hepatitis B vaccine can help protect you from it.

【40】Hepatitis E
-----------

【41】Hepatitis E is caused by the hepatitis E virus. The number of cases in Europe has increased in recent years and it's now the most common cause of short-term (acute) hepatitis in the UK.

【42】The virus has been mainly associated with the consumption of raw or undercooked pork meat or offal, but also with wild boar meat, venison and shellfish. 

【43】Hepatitis E is generally a mild and short-term infection that does not require any treatment, but it can be serious in some people, such as those who have a weakened immune system.

【44】There's no vaccine for hepatitis E. When travelling to parts of the world with poor sanitation, where epidemic hepatitis E may be common, you can reduce your risk by practising good food and water hygiene measures删除7：<u>

【45】The British Liver Trust has more information about hepatitis E</u>

【46】Alcoholic hepatitis
-------------------

【47】Alcoholic hepatitis is a type of hepatitis caused by drinking excessive amounts of alcohol over many years.

【48】The condition is common in the UK and many people do not realise they have it.

【49】This is because it does not usually cause any symptoms, although it can cause sudden jaundice and liver failure in some people.

【50】Stopping drinking will usually allow your liver to recover, but there's a risk you could eventually develop cirrhosis, liver failure or liver cancer if you continue to drink alcohol excessively.

【51】You can reduce your risk of developing alcoholic hepatitis by controlling how much you drink.

【52】It's recommended that you do not regularly drink more than 14 units of alcohol a week.
删除7：<u>Read more about alcohol-related liver disease and the health risks associated with alcohol.</u>

【53】Autoimmune hepatitis
--------------------

【54】Autoimmune hepatitis is a rare cause of long-term hepatitis where the immune system attacks and damages the liver.

【55】Eventually, the liver can become so damaged that it stops working properly.

【56】Treatment for autoimmune hepatitis involves very effective medicines that suppress the immune system and reduce inflammation.

【57】It's not clear what causes autoimmune hepatitis and it's not known whether anything can be done to prevent it删除7：<u>

【58】The British Liver Trust has more information about autoimmune hepatitis</u>
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 23 August 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 23 August 2025</u>

source_info.title: Blepharitis
source_info.text:
【0】Blepharitis
===========

【1】**Blepharitis causes swollen, itchy eyelids. It’s not usually serious and can often be treated by washing your eyelids every day.**

【2】Check if you have blepharitis
-----------------------------

【3】Blepharitis symptoms often come and go.

【4】Symptoms of blepharitis include:

【5】*   sore eyelids
*   itchy eyes
*   a gritty feeling in the eyes
*   flakes or crusts around the roots of the eyelashes
*   eyelids sticking together in the morning when you wake up
删除9：<u>Credit:

【6】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/256626/view</u>

【7】### If you're not sure it's blepharitis
删除7：<u>Read more about eyelid problems.</u>

【8】Things you can do to treat and prevent blepharitis
--------------------------------------------------

【9】### Do

【10】*   clean your eyelids twice a day to start with and then once a day as your symptoms improve

【11】*   continue to clean your eyes, even if your symptoms clear up

【12】### Don’t

【13】*   do not wear contact lenses while you have symptoms

【14】*   do not use eye makeup, especially eyeliner and mascara, while you have symptoms

【15】### How to clean your eyes

【16】1.  Soak a clean flannel or cotton wool in warm water and place it on your closed eyelid for 5 to 10 minutes.
2.  Gently massage your eyelids for around 30 seconds.
3.  Clean your eyelids using cotton wool or a cotton bud. It might help to use a small amount of baby shampoo in water. Gently wipe along the edge of your eyelids to remove any flakes or crusts.

【17】A pharmacist can help with blepharitis
--------------------------------------

【18】A pharmacist might be able to suggest things to help keep your eyelids clean, including:

【19】*   eye pads and wipes
*   eyedrops

【20】Find a pharmacy

【21】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【22】*   blepharitis symptoms do not improve after a few weeks of cleaning your eyelids

【23】Treatment for blepharitis from a GP
-----------------------------------

【24】A GP might suggest using an antibiotic cream or ointment that you rub on your eyelid if your blepharitis does not clear up after cleaning your eyelids regularly.

【25】If blepharitis has caused other problems, such as a lump of fluid under the skin (cyst), antibiotic eyedrops or tablets may be recommended.

【26】If your blepharitis is severe, or if you also have other eye symptoms, the GP may refer you to an eye specialist (ophthalmologist).

【27】Causes of blepharitis
---------------------

【28】Blepharitis can be caused by:

【29】*   a type of bacteria that lives on the skin
*   a skin condition, such as seborrhoeic dermatitis
*   the glands inside the eyelids not producing enough oil

【30】Blepharitis cannot be spread to other people.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 08 February 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 08 February 2025</u>

source_info.title: Elbow and arm pain
source_info.text:
【0】Elbow and arm pain
==================

【1】**Elbow and arm pain is not usually a sign of anything serious. If it does not go away after a few weeks, see a GP.**

【2】How you can ease elbow and arm pain yourself
--------------------------------------------

【3】To ease elbow and arm pain, try these things for a couple of days:

【4】*   put a pack of frozen peas wrapped in a tea towel on your arm – do this for 5 minutes, 3 times a day
*   take painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen
*   raise your arm if it's swollen

【5】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【6】*   elbow or arm pain does not go away after a few weeks

【7】Urgent advice: Get help from NHS 111 if your arm:
-------------------------------------------------

【8】*   hurts when you exercise but the pain goes away when you rest
*   is swollen and you have a very high temperature or feel hot and shivery
*   is extremely painful and difficult to move
*   tingles or feels numb
*   has been injured and you heard a snapping noise or your arm has changed shape

【9】These can be signs of a heart problem (angina), an infection or a broken arm.

【10】You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.

【11】Immediate action required: Call 999 if:
---------------------------------------

【12】*   arm pain has come on suddenly and your chest feels like it's being squeezed

【13】This could be a sign of a heart attack.

【14】Causes of elbow and arm pain
----------------------------

【15】Apart from an injury, these things can cause arm and elbow pain.

【16】Do not self-diagnose. See a GP if you're worried.

【17】Common causes of elbow and arm pain

| Main symptoms | Possible cause |
| --- | --- |
| Main symptomsJoint pain, stiffness, swelling, difficulty moving the affected area  | Possible causeTendonitis or bursitis  |
| Main symptomsPain, tenderness, bruising, swelling  | Possible causeSprains and strains  |
| Main symptomsPain, stiffness coming down from the shoulder  | Possible causeFrozen shoulder  |
| Main symptomsPain and stiffness in the joints  | Possible causeArthritis  |
| Main symptomsSwelling around a joint, a high temperature or feeling hot and shivery  | Possible causeJoint infection (septic arthritis)  |

【19】Information:

【20】Self-refer for treatment
------------------------

【21】If you have elbow or arm pain, you might be able to refer yourself directly to services for help with your condition without seeing a GP.

【22】To find out if there are any services in your area:

【23】*   ask the reception staff at your GP surgery
*   check your GP surgery's website
*   contact your integrated care board (ICB) – find your local ICB
*   search online for NHS treatment for elbow or arm pain near you
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 01 February 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 01 February 2024</u>

source_info.title: You and your baby at 12 weeks pregnant
source_info.text:
【0】You and your baby at 12 weeks pregnant
======================================

【1】Your baby at 12 weeks
---------------------

【2】Just 12 weeks after your last period, the foetus is fully formed. All the organs, muscles, limbs and bones are in place, and the sex organs are well developed.

【3】From now on, the baby has to grow and mature.

【4】It's too early for you to be able to feel the baby's movements yet, although they'll be moving quite a bit.

【5】You at 12 weeks
---------------

【6】You might notice you're a bit constipated. Not everyone gets constipation in pregnancy, but it's fairly common and can make you feel uncomfortable.

【7】Find out about common health problems in pregnancy.

【8】You may feel stomach pain or cramps from time to time. These are usually nothing to worry about, and can be caused by constipation, wind or your ligaments growing as your womb gets bigger.

【9】But if you have stomach pain that does not go away, is severe or you also have bleeding or other symptoms, you need to see your midwife or doctor.

【10】Find out when to get help for stomach pain in pregnancy

【11】Things to think about
---------------------

【12】Make sure you find out about all the health things you should know when you're pregnant, such as stopping smoking, avoiding alcohol, getting exercise and having a healthy diet.

【13】Antenatal screening tests are offered by the NHS in pregnancy to check if a baby has a higher chance of having a health condition, such as Down's syndrome. It's up to you whether to have screening tests or not.

【14】Find out what antenatal screening is and what's involved to help you decide what's best for you.

【15】Sometimes antenatal screening tests find something to indicate your baby has a higher chance of having a health condition. You'll receive support and advice from your midwife or doctor if this is the case, and they'll discuss your options and next steps with you.

【16】You can start thinking about where you'd like to give birth – at home, at a birth centre or in hospital. Your options will depend on your circumstances and what's available in your area删除7：<u>

【17】Start4Life has more about you and your baby at 12 weeks</u>

【18】You can sign up for Start4Life's weekly emails for expert advice, videos and tips on pregnancy, birth and beyond.
删除3：<u>Video: Giving birth at home or at the birth centre
--------------------------------------------------

【19】In this video, a midwife explains the alternatives for women who do not want to give birth in hospital.
删除1：<u>Media last reviewed: 4 October 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Media review due: 4 October 2024</u>

【20】</u>删除11：<u>More in 1 to 12 weeks pregnant
------------------------------

【21】*   You and your pregnancy at 1 to 3 weeks
*   You and your baby at 4 weeks pregnant
*   You and your baby at 5 weeks pregnant
*   You and your baby at 6 weeks pregnant
*   You and your baby at 7 weeks pregnant
*   You and your baby at 8 weeks pregnant
*   You and your baby at 9 weeks pregnant
*   You and your baby at 10 weeks pregnant
*   You and your baby at 11 weeks pregnant
*   You and your baby at 12 weeks pregnant
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 12 October 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 12 October 2024</u>

source_info.title: Morton's neuroma
source_info.text:
【0】Morton's neuroma
================

【1】**Morton's neuroma is where there's a thickening of tissue around a nerve in your foot that's been irritated or damaged. The symptoms can often be eased with treatments you can try yourself.**

【2】Check if you have Morton's neuroma
----------------------------------

【3】Morton's neuroma usually affects the nerves between your 3rd and 4th toes.
删除9：<u>Credit:

【4】MARK MILLER/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/458175/view</u>

【5】The main symptoms of Morton's neuroma include:

【6】*   a shooting, stabbing or burning pain
*   feeling like a pebble or lump is stuck under your foot

【7】Some people may also have tingling or numbness in their foot.

【8】The symptoms may be worse when you move your foot or wear tight or high-heeled shoes. It often gets worse over time.

【9】How you can ease the pain yourself
----------------------------------

【10】If you go to a GP, they'll usually suggest you try these things first:

【11】### Do

【12】*   rest and raise your foot when you can

【13】*   hold an ice pack (or bag of frozen peas) in a towel on the painful area for up to 20 minutes every few hours

【14】*   take ibuprofen or paracetamol

【15】*   wear wide, comfortable shoes with a low heel and soft sole

【16】*   use soft insoles or pads you put in your shoes

【17】*   try to lose weight if you're overweight

【18】*   avoid or reduce impact activities such as running and jumping

【19】### Don’t

【20】*   do not wear tight, pointy shoes, high heels, or shoes with thin soles

【21】### You can ask a pharmacist about:

【22】*   the best painkiller to take
*   soft pads or insoles for your shoes – ask for metatarsal pads

【23】Find a pharmacy

【24】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【25】*   the pain is severe or stopping you doing your normal activities
*   the pain is getting worse or keeps coming back
*   the pain has not improved after treating it yourself for 2 weeks
*   you have any tingling or numbness in your foot
*   you have diabetes – foot problems can be more serious if you have diabetes

【26】What we mean by severe pain

【27】Severe pain:

【28】*   always there and so bad it's hard to think or talk
*   you cannot sleep
*   it's very hard to move, get out of bed, go to the bathroom, wash or dress

【29】Moderate pain:

【30】*   always there
*   makes it hard to concentrate or sleep
*   you can manage to get up, wash or dress

【31】Mild pain:

【32】*   comes and goes
*   is annoying but does not stop you doing daily activities

【33】Treatment for Morton's neuroma
------------------------------

【34】A GP can:

【35】*   look at your foot to see if it's Morton's neuroma
*   refer you to a foot specialist if they think you need further treatment

【36】### Treatment from a foot specialist

【37】Treatments from a foot specialist, such as a podiatrist or foot and ankle surgeon, may include:

【38】*   specially made soft pads or insoles – to take pressure off the painful area of your foot
*   non-surgical treatments – such as using heat to treat the nerve (radiofrequency ablation)
*   steroid or alcohol injections, or foot surgery – if you have very severe symptoms or other treatments are not working

【39】Referral to a podiatrist on the NHS may not be available to everyone and waiting times can be long.

【40】You can pay to see a podiatrist privately.

【41】Find a podiatrist

【42】Causes of Morton's neuroma
--------------------------

【43】Morton's neuroma is caused by an irritated or damaged nerve between the toe bones.

【44】It's often linked to:

【45】*   wearing tight, pointy or high-heeled shoes
*   doing a lot of running, or other sports or activities that place pressure on the feet
*   having other foot problems – such as flat feet, high arches, bunions or hammer toes
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 12 January 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 12 January 2025</u>

source_info.title: Orthodontics
source_info.text:
【0】Orthodontic treatments \- Orthodontics
======================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Orthodontic treatments</u>

【2】**There are many different types of orthodontic treatment. The best treatment for you depends on the exact problem you have.**

【3】The first stage of any treatment is to assess the current position of your teeth and how they're likely to change over time.

【4】This often involves taking X-rays, making plaster models, and taking photographs of your teeth.

【5】You will then be given a treatment plan. This may suggest more than 1 way to treat the problem you have. Talk to your orthodontist about your options.

【6】Orthodontic appliances
----------------------

【7】Orthodontic treatment uses appliances to correct the position of teeth.

【8】The 4 main types are:

【9】*   fixed braces – a brace you cannot remove which is made up of brackets that are glued to the front of each tooth and linked with wires
*   removable braces – usually plastic plates that cover the roof of the mouth and clip on to some teeth; these can only be used to achieve very limited tooth movements
*   functional appliances – usually a pair of removable plastic braces that are joined together or designed to interact together and fit on to both the upper and lower teeth
*   headgear – this can be used with other appliances and is usually worn at night

【10】In more severe cases, treatment may involve fixed braces plus surgery to move the jaw. This treatment is done in hospital.

【11】These treatments are outlined in more detail on this page.

【12】You can also find more information about different orthodontic treatments on the British Orthodontic Society (BOS) website

【13】### Fixed braces

【14】Fixed braces are a widely used type of orthodontic appliance.

【15】A few days after a fixed brace is fitted, you'll be able to eat a normal range of foods. But you should avoid certain foods and drinks, such as toffee, hard sweets and fizzy drinks, as these can damage the appliance and your teeth.

【16】If you're using a fixed appliance and you play a contact sport such as rugby, you should wear a gum shield to protect both your mouth and the appliance.

【17】Fixed braces are usually made from metal, so they will be noticeable on the front of your teeth.

【18】Many private orthodontists offer ceramic or clear braces, or metal braces fitted to the back of the teeth, although these are usually more expensive.

【19】### Removable braces

【20】Removable braces can be used to correct minor problems, or as part of fixed-brace treatment.

【21】They can also sometimes be used to discourage children from sucking their thumb, but this is not available on the NHS.

【22】These braces should only be taken out of your mouth for cleaning or as a precaution during certain activities. Your orthodontist can advise you about this.

【23】### Functional appliances

【24】Functional appliances can be used to treat problems with the position of the upper and lower jaw and teeth.

【25】Most people need to wear them all the time. It's very important to follow your orthodontist's instructions about how and when to wear the appliance. If it's not worn correctly, the treatment will not work.

【26】It may be necessary to remove your functional appliance for cleaning and while you're eating.

【27】### Headgear

【28】Headgear is used to correct the position of the back teeth or to keep them in position while the front teeth are being treated.

【29】Most people only need to wear headgear in the evening and during the night. You will not be able to eat or drink while wearing headgear.

【30】Other treatments
----------------

【31】There are other types of braces available privately, such as aligners, or invisible or lingual braces that fit onto the back of the teeth.

【32】You'll need to talk to your orthodontist to see whether they can be used for your problem. The cost of these braces is usually higher.

【33】### Retainers

【34】Retainers are used at the end of a course of orthodontic treatment. They hold straightened teeth in place while the surrounding gum and bone adjusts to their new position. Retainers can either be removable or fixed.

【35】Under the NHS, your orthodontist is responsible for your care for 12 months after usual treatment ends. After this period, you'll have to pay privately for continuing care, repeated treatment, and any replacement or repair of retainers.

【36】It's likely there will be some tooth movement if you stop wearing your retainer. Changes in the position of your teeth can continue throughout life and are normal.

【37】The only way to have permanently straight teeth is to wear a retainer as advised.

【38】### Removing teeth

【39】In some cases, it may be necessary to remove one of your teeth to correct the position and appearance of nearby teeth.

【40】Results
-------

【41】You're likely to achieve good results within 6 to 30 months of starting treatment as long as you:

【42】*   take care of your teeth and gums
*   wear your appliances as instructed
*   follow your orthodontist's advice about what to eat and drink
*   wear your retainer every night to maintain the results; your orthodontist will talk to you about exactly how long you need to wear this

source_info.title: Rosuvastatin
source_info.text:
【0】How and when to take rosuvastatin
=================================

【1】Always take rosuvastatin as instructed by your doctor and follow the instructions that come with your medicine.

【2】Dosage
------

【3】Your dose of rosuvastatin will depend on why you need it, your cholesterol levels, and other medicines you may already be taking.

【4】The usual dose for adults is:

【5】*   to prevent heart attacks and strokes – 20mg, taken once a day, although sometimes a lower dose is prescribed. If you have very high cholesterol and are at high risk of heart attacks or strokes, a specialist may prescribe 40mg a day. This dose is not suitable for everyone
*   high cholesterol – 5mg to 10mg, taken once a day. Your doctor may increase your dose every 4 weeks up to 20mg a day

【6】Ask your doctor or pharmacist for advice if you're unsure how much to take.

【7】### Doses for children

【8】The maximum dose for children is 20mg a day. Your child's doctor will work out the right dose of rosuvastatin for your child. This will depend on why they need it, their age and any other medicines they are already taking.

【9】How to take it
--------------

【10】You'll usually take rosuvastatin once a day. You can take it at any time, but it's best to take it at the same time every day.

【11】Rosuvastatin will not usually upset your stomach, so you can take it with or without food.

【12】Swallow rosuvastatin tablets whole with a drink of water.

【13】How long to take it for
-----------------------

【14】You'll usually take rosuvastatin for life. The benefits of the medicine will only continue for as long as you take it.

【15】You may want to stop rosuvastatin if you think you're having side effects. Talk to your doctor first to see if it really is a side effect of rosuvastatin or an unrelated problem. Your doctor may decide to lower your dose or change your medicine.

【16】You will not get any withdrawal symptoms. But stopping rosuvastatin may cause your cholesterol to rise. This increases your risk of heart attacks and strokes.

【17】If you want to stop taking your medicine, it's important to find another way to lower your cholesterol.

【18】If you forget to take it
------------------------

【19】If you forget to take a dose of rosuvastatin, take it as soon as you remember. If you do not remember until the next day, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time.

【20】Never take 2 doses at the same time. Never take an extra dose to make up for the forgotten one.

【21】If you often forget doses, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to take your medicine.

【22】If you take too much
--------------------

【23】Taking an extra dose of rosuvastatin is unlikely to harm you. Talk to your pharmacist or doctor if you're worried or if you take more than 1 extra dose.
删除11：<u>More in Rosuvastatin
--------------------

【24】*   About rosuvastatin
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking rosuvastatin with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 9 March 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 9 March 2025</u>

source_info.title: Lisinopril
source_info.text:
【0】How and when to take lisinopril
===============================

【1】Always follow your doctor's advice, and the instructions that come with your medicine.

【2】Dosage
------

【3】The dose of lisinopril you take depends on why you need the medicine. Take it how your doctor tells you to.

【4】To decide your dose, your doctor will check your blood pressure and ask you if you're getting any side effects from your medicine.

【5】You may also have blood tests to check how well your kidneys are working and the amount of potassium in your blood.

【6】Depending on why you're taking lisinopril, the usual starting dose for adults is between 2.5mg and 10mg, once a day.

【7】This will be increased gradually over a few weeks to the usual dose for your condition:

【8】*   high blood pressure – 20mg once a day (the maximum dose is 80mg once a day)
*   after a recent heart attack – 10mg once a day
*   heart failure – 5mg to 35mg once a day
*   diabetic kidney disease – 10mg to 20mg once a day

【9】Doses are usually lower for children. The doctor will work out the right dose based on your child's age, weight and why they need this medicine.

【10】Your child will usually start on a low dose of lisinopril. This dose may gradually increase depending on your child's blood pressure and other symptoms.

【11】How to take it
--------------

【12】You'll usually take lisinopril once a day.

【13】Your doctor may suggest that you take your first dose before bedtime because it can make you dizzy.

【14】After the very first dose, you can take lisinopril at any time of day. Try to take it at the same time every day.

【15】You can take lisinopril with or without food. Swallow lisinopril tablets whole with a drink of water.

【16】If you're taking lisinopril as a liquid, it will come with a plastic syringe or spoon to help you measure out the right dose. If you do not have one, ask your pharmacist for one. Do not use a kitchen teaspoon as it will not measure the right amount of medicine.

【17】Changes to your dose
--------------------

【18】You'll probably be prescribed a low dose of lisinopril at first so it does not make you feel dizzy.

【19】This will usually be increased gradually until you reach the right dose for you.

【20】Speak to your pharmacist or doctor about your dose if you're worried about side effects of lisinopril.

【21】How long to take it for
-----------------------

【22】After a heart attack, you usually take lisinopril for 6 weeks. Your doctor will then decide if you need to keep taking it for longer.

【23】For high blood pressure, heart failure and diabetic kidney disease, treatment with lisinopril is usually long term, even for the rest of your life.

【24】### Important

【25】Take lisinopril even if you feel well, as you'll still be getting the benefits of the medicine.

【26】If you get ill while taking it
------------------------------

【27】Contact your doctor if you get ill, such as a high temperature, sweats and shaking or severe diarrhoea or vomiting. Your doctor may advise you to stop taking lisinopril until you recover and are eating and drinking normally.

【28】If you forget to take it
------------------------

【29】If you miss a dose of lisinopril, take it as soon as you remember. If you do not remember until the following day, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time.

【30】Do not take a double dose to make up for a forgotten one.

【31】If you forget doses often, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to take your medicine.

【32】If you take too much
--------------------

【33】Taking more than your prescribed dose of lisinopril can make you feel dizzy, sleepy and give you a pounding heartbeat (heart palpitations).

【34】The amount of lisinopril that can lead to an overdose varies from person to person.

【35】### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【36】*   you take more than your prescribed dose of lisinopril

【37】Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111

【38】If you need to go to A&E, do not drive yourself. Get someone else to drive you or call for an ambulance.

【39】Take the lisinopril packet or leaflet inside it, plus any remaining medicine, with you.
删除11：<u>More in Lisinopril
------------------

【40】*   About lisinopril
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking lisinopril with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 17 December 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 17 December 2024</u>

source_info.title: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
source_info.text:
【0】Symptoms \- Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
========================================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Complications</u>

【2】**The symptoms of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) are caused by the growth of fluid-filled sacs (cysts) in the kidneys.**

【3】Although ADPKD is present from birth, it may not cause any obvious problems until the cysts have reached a size where they significantly affect how well your kidneys work.

【4】In most cases, this does not happen until 30 to 60 years of age.

【5】The growth of the cysts can eventually cause your kidneys to increase in size.

【6】The kidneys of older adults with ADPKD can get much larger than those of adults who do not have the condition.

【7】Problems caused by ADPKD
------------------------

【8】The growth of cysts in your kidneys can cause a wide range of problems, including:

【9】*   pain in your tummy (abdomen), side or lower back
*   blood in your urine (haematuria)
*   high blood pressure (hypertension)
*   kidney stones
*   urinary tract infections (UTIs)
*   eventually, loss of kidney function (chronic kidney disease, or CKD)

【10】### Pain

【11】Pain in the abdomen, side or lower back is often the first noticeable symptom of ADPKD. 

【12】This can be severe, but is usually short-lived, lasting from a few minutes to several days.

【13】Common causes of pain associated with ADPKD include:

【14】*   a cyst becoming larger
*   bleeding into 1 or more cysts
*   a kidney stone
*   a kidney or another part of your urinary system, such as your bladder, becoming infected (a UTI)

【15】### Blood in your urine

【16】Blood in your urine (haematuria) is another common initial symptom of ADPKD.

【17】Although it can often be a frightening symptom, it's not usually a cause for concern and most cases will resolve within a week without the need for treatment.

【18】But you should see a GP if you notice blood in your urine so that other possible causes, such as a growth in your bladder, can be investigated and excluded.

【19】### High blood pressure

【20】Many experts consider high blood pressure to be the first effect of ADPKD, but as it often does not cause any obvious symptoms, it's only usually detected during routine testing.

【21】Symptoms only occur when blood pressure reaches a very high level, which is rare. 

【22】In such circumstances, symptoms can include:

【23】*   a persistent headache
*   blurred or double vision
*   nosebleeds
*   shortness of breath

【24】See a GP straight away if you experience these symptoms so that the cause can be investigated.

【25】Untreated or poorly controlled high blood pressure is a major risk factor for a number of serious health conditions, including heart attack, stroke and kidney failure.

【26】### Kidney stones

【27】Having ADPKD puts you at an increased risk of developing kidney stones. 

【28】Smaller kidney stones may pass out of your kidneys without causing any symptoms.

【29】But larger stones can get blocked in your kidney or the tube that connects your kidney to your bladder (ureter), causing problems such as:

【30】*   intense pain in the back or side of your tummy, or occasionally in your groin – the pain may last for minutes or hours, with pain-free intervals in between
*   feeling restless and being unable to lie still
*   feeling sick
*   needing to pee more often than normal
*   blood in your urine

【31】Get advice from 111 or ask for an urgent GP appointment if you think you may have a kidney stone.

【32】### Urinary tract infections (UTIs)

【33】Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are broadly classified into 1 of 2 groups: lower UTIs and upper UTIs.

【34】A lower UTI is an infection that develops in your bladder or urethra, the tube that carries urine out of the body.

【35】An upper UTI is an infection that develops in your kidneys or ureters.

【36】ADPKD does not increase your risk of developing lower UTIs, such as bladder infections (cystitis), but it can mean that any lower UTIs you do develop could spread to your kidneys and become potentially serious upper UTIs.

【37】Symptoms of a lower UTI can include:

【38】*   cloudy urine
*   a need to urinate more frequently, either during the day or night, or both
*   pain or discomfort when peeing
*   an urgent need to pee, where holding urine in becomes more difficult
*   unpleasant-smelling urine

【39】Symptoms of an upper UTI can include:

【40】*   a high temperature
*   uncontrollable shivering
*   feeling sick
*   being sick
*   diarrhoea

【41】Get advice from 111 or ask for an urgent GP appointment if you have ADPKD and you think you may have a UTI. You may need treatment to stop the infection spreading into the cysts in your kidneys.

【42】Chronic kidney disease (CKD)
----------------------------

【43】Most people with ADPKD will eventually lose a significant amount of kidney function.

【44】Loss of kidney function caused by kidney damage is known as chronic kidney disease (CKD).

【45】CKD does not usually cause symptoms until it's reached an advanced stage, known as CKD stage 4, when around 75% of kidney function has been lost.

【46】The most advanced stage of CKD (stage 5) is called kidney failure or end-stage renal disease.

【47】This is when dialysis, where waste products and excess fluid from the blood are removed, is essential to keep the person alive.

【48】Symptoms of kidney failure include:

【49】*   poor appetite and weight loss
*   swollen ankles, feet or hands (oedema)
*   shortness of breath
*   an increased need to pee, particularly at night
*   itchy skin
*   feeling sick
*   in men, erectile dysfunction
*   in women, absent periods (amenorrhoea)
*   difficulty concentrating

【50】Kidney failure rarely happens suddenly, and treatment options should have been discussed and a treatment plan chosen before this stage is reached.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 23 February 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 23 February 2026</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease</u>删除1：<u>*   Next : Diagnosis</u>

source_info.title: High blood sugar (hyperglycaemia)
source_info.text:
【0】High blood sugar (hyperglycaemia)
=================================

【1】**High blood sugar (hyperglycaemia) is where the level of sugar in your blood is too high. It mainly affects people with diabetes and can be serious if not treated.**

【2】People with diabetes can also have blood sugar that's too low. This is called low blood sugar (hypoglycaemia).

【3】High blood sugar levels
-----------------------

【4】If you have diabetes, you can find out if your blood sugar level is high by having a blood sugar (blood glucose) test.

【5】You may have regular tests by your care team or GP surgery, or you may have tests you can do at home.

【6】Types of diabetes test and high blood sugar levels.

| Type of test | High level |
| --- | --- |
| Test done by a health professional to check your blood sugar level over the last 2 or 3 months (HbA1c test) | 48 mmol/mol or over (6.5% if you're given a percentage) |
| Test done by a health professional after not eating for a few hours (fasting glucose test) | Over 7 mmol/L |
| Home test done after waking up or before eating | Over 7 mmol/L |
| Home test done at any other time | Over 11 mmol/L |

【8】### Important

【9】These blood sugar levels are a guide. Your levels may be different depending on your age and the type of diabetes you have. Check with your doctor or care team.

【10】Symptoms of high blood sugar
----------------------------

【11】Symptoms of high blood sugar usually come on gradually and may only start when your blood sugar level gets very high.

【12】Common symptoms include:

【13】*   feeling very thirsty
*   peeing a lot
*   feeling weak or tired
*   blurred vision
*   losing weight

【14】Causes of high blood sugar
--------------------------

【15】Common causes of high blood sugar in people with diabetes include:

【16】*   being unwell
*   feeling stressed
*   eating too much sugary or starchy food
*   being less active than usual
*   missing doses of diabetes medicine

【17】You can also get high blood sugar if your diabetes medicine is not working well, you're taking certain medicines (such as steroids) or you recently had an operation.

【18】How to lower your blood sugar
-----------------------------

【19】If you have diabetes, it's important to try to stop your blood sugar level getting too high.

【20】### Do

【21】*   take any diabetes medicine you've been prescribed, as advised by your doctor or care team

【22】*   avoid eating too much sugary or starchy food

【23】*   try to find ways to manage stress

【24】*   exercise regularly

【25】*   lose weight if you're overweight

【26】*   follow advice from your doctor or care team about what to do while you're ill (sometimes called "sick day rules")

【27】### Don’t

【28】*   do not skip or change doses of your diabetes medicine unless advised by your doctor or care team

【29】Non-urgent advice: Speak to your care team or GP surgery if:
------------------------------------------------------------

【30】*   you've tried to lower your blood sugar but your blood sugar level is still high or you still have symptoms
*   you have symptoms of high blood sugar and you have not been diagnosed with diabetes

【31】Problems caused by high blood sugar
-----------------------------------

【32】It's not usually a serious problem if your blood sugar is sometimes slightly high for a short time.

【33】But high blood sugar can cause serious problems if it stays high for a long time or gets to a very high level.

【34】It can lead to:

【35】*   permanent damage to the nerves in your hands and feet (peripheral neuropathy)
*   permanent damage to your eyes and problems with your sight (diabetic retinopathy)
*   life-threatening conditions such as diabetic ketoacidosis

【36】If you have high blood sugar, your doctor or care team may ask you to test your blood or pee to check for ketones. A high level of ketones is a sign of diabetic ketoacidosis.

【37】Urgent advice: Call your care team immediately or get help from NHS 111 if:
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

【38】You think you have high blood sugar and:

【39】*   you're feeling sick, being sick or have stomach pain
*   you're breathing more quickly than usual or your heart is beating faster than usual
*   you feel drowsy or are struggling to stay awake
*   your breath has a fruity smell (like pear drop sweets)
*   you feel confused or have difficulty concentrating
*   you have a high level of ketones in your blood or pee

【40】These could be signs you're becoming seriously unwell.

【41】You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 26 May 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 26 May 2025</u>

【31】Problems caused by high blood sugar
-----------------------------------

【32】It's not usually a serious problem if your blood sugar is sometimes slightly high for a short time.

【33】But high blood sugar can cause serious problems if it stays high for a long time or gets to a very high level.

【34】It can lead to:

【35】*   permanent damage to the nerves in your hands and feet (peripheral neuropathy)
*   permanent damage to your eyes and problems with your sight (diabetic retinopathy)
*   life-threatening conditions such as diabetic ketoacidosis

【36】If you have high blood sugar, your doctor or care team may ask you to test your blood or pee to check for ketones. A high level of ketones is a sign of diabetic ketoacidosis.

【37】Urgent advice: Call your care team immediately or get help from NHS 111 if:
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

【38】You think you have high blood sugar and:

【39】*   you're feeling sick, being sick or have stomach pain
*   you're breathing more quickly than usual or your heart is beating faster than usual
*   you feel drowsy or are struggling to stay awake
*   your breath has a fruity smell (like pear drop sweets)
*   you feel confused or have difficulty concentrating
*   you have a high level of ketones in your blood or pee

【40】These could be signs you're becoming seriously unwell.

【41】You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 26 May 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 26 May 2025</u>

source_info.title: Sotrovimab (Xevudy)
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot have sotrovimab
==================================

【1】Who can have sotrovimab
-----------------------

【2】Sotrovimab can be given to most adults, and children aged 12 years or older who weigh at least 40kg.

【3】You may be eligible for sotrovimab if:

【4】*   you're in the highest risk group below
*   you've had a positive lateral test (you can order free NHS lateral flow tests on GOV.UK or call NHS 119)
*   you have had COVID-19 symptoms within the last 5 days

【5】You may be at highest risk of getting seriously ill from COVID-19 if you have:

【6】*   Down's syndrome, or another chromosomal condition that affects your immune system
*   certain types of cancer, or had treatment for certain types of cancer
*   sickle cell disease
*   certain conditions affecting your blood
*   chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage 4 or 5
*   severe liver disease
*   had an organ transplant
*   certain autoimmune or inflammatory conditions, such as rheumatoid arthritis or inflammatory bowel disease
*   HIV or AIDS and have a weakened immune system
*   a condition affecting your immune system
*   a condition affecting the brain or nervous system, such as multiple sclerosis, muscular dystrophy, motor neurone disease, myasthenia gravis, Huntington's disease, Parkinson's disease or certain types of dementia
*   certain lung conditions or treatments for lung conditions

【7】This list is a summary and does not cover everything.

【8】If you're unsure if you are eligible, speak to your GP or hospital specialist who can advise you.
删除7：<u>Find out more about people at the highest risk who are eligible for COVID-19 treatment on GOV.UK</u>

【9】Who may not be able to have sotrovimab
--------------------------------------

【10】Sotrovimab is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell your doctor or nurse if:

【11】*   you have ever had an allergic reaction to sotrovimab
*   you are pregnant, trying to get pregnant or breastfeeding

source_info.title: Cerebral palsy
source_info.text:
【0】Treatment \- Cerebral palsy
===========================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment</u>

【2】**There's currently no cure for cerebral palsy, but treatments are available to help people with the condition be as active and independent as possible.**

【3】Children and adults with the condition are cared for by a team of healthcare professionals, who will work with you to come up with a care and support plan.

【4】This plan will be continually reassessed as the person's needs change. As people with cerebral palsy grow older, they may need different care and support.

【5】For example, bone and joint problems can get worse and this may affect movement.

【6】It's important to continue having regular check-ups with your care team all your life.

【7】If your symptoms change or get worse, you should see your doctor.

【8】The charity Scope has information about ageing and cerebral palsy

【9】Physiotherapy
-------------

【10】Physiotherapy involves exercises to help maintain and hopefully improve movement.

【11】It's one of the most important treatments for cerebral palsy.

【12】The main goals of physiotherapy are to:

【13】*   encourage movement
*   increase strength and stop muscles becoming weak
*   stop muscles shortening and losing their range of movement (contracture), which can be painful and affect how the bones and muscles grow

【14】A physiotherapist may also advise on walking aids (such as a walking frame or walking sticks) if needed, and arm or leg braces called orthoses to support the limbs.

【15】Speech and language therapy
---------------------------

【16】Speech and language therapy can help people who have trouble communicating.

【17】A speech and language therapist can provide exercises to help practise speech, or teach an alternative method of communication, such as sign language or using pictures.

【18】The therapist may also be able to provide special equipment, such as a computer or device that generates speech.

【19】Younger children may be given a device similar to a laptop that's covered with symbols of everyday objects and activities. The child presses a combination of symbols to communicate.

【20】Occupational therapy
--------------------

【21】Occupational therapy involves a therapist identifying problems that you or your child have carrying out everyday tasks.

【22】They can advise you about the best way to do activities that involve complex movements, such as going to the toilet or getting dressed.

【23】Occupational therapy can be very useful in boosting your child's self-esteem and independence, especially as they get older.

【24】An occupational therapist can advise adults with cerebral palsy on independent living. This can include advice on housing, getting a job, benefits, and technology like computers and gadgets that can make it easier to do things.
删除7：<u>Read more about occupational therapy</u>

【25】Medicines
---------

【26】Medicines that can help relieve several of the symptoms of cerebral palsy include:

【27】*   medicines for muscle stiffness, such as diazepam or baclofen, that can be taken as tablets or liquids – baclofen can also sometimes be given using a small pump inserted under the skin, which allows the medicine to trickle into the area inside the spine
*   botulinum toxin injections – injections that relax certain muscles or groups of muscles for a few months at a time
*   a medicine called melatonin for sleeping difficulties
*   anti-seizure medicines for epilepsy
*   laxatives for constipation
*   painkillers for pain or discomfort
*   medicines to reduce drooling

【28】It's unlikely you or your child will need to take all of these medicines.

【29】Speak to your care team if you have any questions about a medicine that's been offered, including why they recommend it and what side effects it might cause.

【30】Treatments for feeding problems
-------------------------------

【31】Some people with cerebral palsy have difficulty swallowing food.

【32】This can be serious because it can mean they're at risk of choking or developing a chest infection as a result of accidentally inhaling food.

【33】Long-lasting feeding difficulties could also lead to malnutrition.

【34】Treatments for swallowing problems include:

【35】*   swallowing techniques and exercises taught by a speech and language therapist
*   making dietary changes, such as eating soft or liquid foods
*   a feeding tube in more severe cases

【36】A feeding tube can either be passed into the stomach through the nose or directly into the stomach through the skin of the tummy.
删除7：<u>Find out more about swallowing problems</u>

【37】Treatments for drooling
-----------------------

【38】Drooling is common in people with cerebral palsy.

【39】It's not usually serious, but the excess saliva can irritate the skin around the mouth, which may increase the risk of the skin becoming infected.

【40】Treatments that can help with excessive drooling include:

【41】*   techniques and exercises taught by a speech and language therapist
*   anticholinergic medicines – tablets or skin patches that reduce how much saliva is produced
*   botulinum toxin injections into the saliva glands – injections that can help relieve drooling problems for a few months at a time
*   surgery to redirect the saliva glands so saliva runs towards the back of the mouth, rather than the front

【42】Surgery
-------

【43】Some people with cerebral palsy may need surgery to help with movement difficulties or other problems.

【44】Surgery can be carried out to:

【45】*   restore movement to parts of the body if they're restricted by a tight muscle or piece of connective tissue
*   repair a hip joint that's popped out (dislocated)
*   correct curvature of the spine (scoliosis) – find out more about treatment for scoliosis in children
*   treat problems with bladder control (urinary incontinence) – find out more about surgery for urinary incontinence
*   make walking easier by reducing stiffness in the legs – this operation is known as a selective dorsal rhizotomy (SDR)

【46】If surgery is suggested, speak to your care team about the results you can expect, what the risks are, and what the recovery period might be like.

【47】For some types of surgery it can take months or even years for the full benefits to be achieved, and extensive physiotherapy may be needed to help with recovery.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 31 May 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 31 May 2026</u>

source_info.title: Mirabegron
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking mirabegron \- Brand name: Betmiga
=====================================================================================

【1】Mirabegron and pregnancy
------------------------

【2】Mirabegron is not usually recommended in pregnancy. There's not enough information available to say whether it's safe or not to take this medicine during pregnancy.

【3】If having an overactive bladder greatly affects your day to day life, talk to your doctor. They may suggest alternative treatments.

【4】Mirabegron and breastfeeding
----------------------------

【5】If your doctor or health visitor says your baby is healthy, you can take mirabegron while breastfeeding, although other medicines that we know more about might be better.

【6】It's not known how much mirabegron gets into breast milk, although it's likely to be a small amount.

【7】Talk to your health visitor, midwife, doctor or pharmacist or call 111 as soon as possible if you have any concerns, including if your baby:

【8】*   is being sick or has diarrhoea
*   has constipation
*   has signs of a urinary tract infection, such as being irritable, a high temperature and pee that smells different from usual

【9】Mirabegron and fertility
------------------------

【10】There's no evidence to suggest that taking mirabegron will reduce fertility in either men or women.

【11】However, tell your doctor if you're pregnant or trying to get pregnant. This medicine is not usually recommended in pregnancy.

【12】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【13】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

source_info.title: Sertraline
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take sertraline
==================================

【1】Who can take sertraline
-----------------------

【2】Most adults can take sertraline.

【3】Children aged 6 to 17 years can also take sertraline, but only for obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD).

【4】If you have diabetes, sertraline can make it more difficult to keep your blood sugar stable. Your doctor may recommend that you monitor your blood sugar level more often for the first few weeks of treatment with sertraline and adjust your diabetes treatment if necessary.

【5】Who may not be able to take sertraline
--------------------------------------

【6】Sertraline is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell your doctor if you:

【7】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to sertraline or any other medicine
*   have a heart problem – sertraline can make your heart beat faster or cause an irregular heartbeat (arrhythmia)
*   are trying to get pregnant, already pregnant or breastfeeding
*   have glaucoma – sertraline can increase the pressure in your eye
*   have epilepsy or are having electroconvulsive treatment – sertraline may increase your risk of having a fit or seizure
删除11：<u>More in Sertraline
------------------

【8】*   About sertraline
*   Who can and cannot take it

*   Side effects

source_info.title: Sodium cromoglicate capsules
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about sodium cromoglicate capsules \- Brand name: Nalcrom
==========================================================================

【1】How do sodium cromoglicate capsules work?

【2】Sodium cromoglicate capsules work by stopping the release of the natural substances in your body (including histamine) that can cause an allergic reaction. They also reduce how severe your symptoms are when you're exposed to substances which you are allergic to.

【3】How long does it take to work?

【4】Allergy symptoms usually start to get better about 2 to 3 weeks after first taking sodium cromoglicate capsules. Try to avoid eating or drinking anything which may cause an allergic reaction.

【5】Are there any long-term side effects?

【6】Sodium cromoglicate capsules are unlikely to have any lasting, harmful effects. Follow your doctor's instructions about taking them.

【7】What will happen if I stop taking it?

【8】If you stop taking sodium cromoglicate capsules, your symptoms may come back.

【9】Will it affect my contraception?

【10】Sodium cromoglicate capsules do not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【11】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【12】Yes, you can. Sodium cromoglicate capsules do not affect being able to drive or cycle.

【13】Can I drink alcohol while taking sodium cromoglicate capsules?

【14】Yes, it's OK to drink alcohol while taking these capsules.

【15】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【16】Apart from avoiding foods you are allergic to, you can eat and drink normally while taking sodium cromoglicate capsules.

【17】Can lifestyle changes help with food allergies?

【18】It will help to:

【19】*   check the list of ingredients on pre-packed food and drinks – labels should highlight whether they contain things like celery, gluten, eggs, fish and other ingredients that may cause an allergic reaction
*   try to check the ingredients of unpackaged foods that you usually get in places like bakeries, delis and takeaways
*   read the menu and check foods if you go out to eat
*   take anti-allergy medicine with you when eating out
删除7：<u>Find out more about food allergies.</u>
删除11：<u>More in Sodium cromoglicate capsules
------------------------------------
