*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 11 July 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 11 July 2025</u>

source_info.title: Testosterone and pregnancy
source_info.text:
【0】Testosterone and pregnancy
==========================

【1】Testosterone therapy uses an artificial version of the testosterone hormone.

【2】It's given to people for a number of reasons, including as a treatment for gender dysphoria in people who want to change how their body looks and works.

【3】Testosterone can reduce breast tissue, stop periods, and make hair grow on your face.

【4】Testosterone and fertility
--------------------------

【5】It is possible to get pregnant if you’re taking testosterone, but it's not recommended. This is because taking testosterone in pregnancy may affect the baby's development.

【6】If you are taking testosterone and want to get pregnant, talk to the doctor who is prescribing you testosterone.

【7】### Important: Testosterone and contraception

【8】You can get pregnant while taking testosterone.

【9】You need to use contraception if you do not want to get pregnant.

【10】Testosterone and pregnancy
--------------------------

【11】Taking testosterone in pregnancy is not recommended.

【12】Do not stop taking testosterone before talking with the doctor who is prescribing it for you.

【13】If you stop taking testosterone you’ll probably start to have periods. You may also notice changes in your body shape around your hips, chest and thighs.

【14】You should not notice any changes to your tone of voice or facial hair.

【15】If you get pregnant, you may have mood swings, such as suddenly feeling very irritable or tearful. These are common in most pregnancies.

【16】You may find being pregnant triggers feelings of gender dysphoria.

【17】Find out about mental health in pregnancy.

【18】### Urgent advice: Contact the doctor who is prescribing your testosterone immediately if:

【19】*   you are taking testosterone and think you might be pregnant

【20】Testosterone and chestfeeding
-----------------------------

【21】If you have taken testosterone in the past then your milk supply may be affected. So you may not be able to chestfeed your baby.

【22】If you can chestfeed and you also decide to start taking testosterone again, your milk will have small amounts of testosterone in it.

【23】It is unclear what, if any, effect this could have on your baby.

【24】It is also important to consider your own wellbeing if you are finding that not taking testosterone is triggering dysphoria.

【25】Talk to your midwife or doctor about any concerns you may have.

【26】Find out about chestfeeding.
删除11：<u>More in Having a baby if you're LGBT+
-------------------------------------

【27】*   Ways to become a parent if you're LGBT+
*   Testosterone and pregnancy
*   Chestfeeding if you're trans or non-binary
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 22 December 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 22 December 2024</u>

source_info.title: Sequential combined hormone replacement therapy (HRT) tablets and patches
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about sequential combined hormone replacement therapy (HRT) \- Brand names: Evorel Sequi, Elleste Duet, Femoston, Novofem
==========================================================================================================================================

【1】How does sequential combined HRT work?

【2】As you approach the menopause, levels of the sex hormones oestrogen and progesterone fall, which causes symptoms such as hot flushes, night sweats, mood swings and vaginal dryness.

【3】Sequential combined HRT works by replacing these hormones, which helps to improve menopause symptoms.

【4】When will I feel better?

【5】It can take up to 3 months for hormone replacement therapy (HRT) to work fully to improve your symptoms.

【6】There are different types of HRT, and it can take time to find the type and dose that works for you.

【7】If you do not feel better after 3 months, speak to your doctor. They may suggest changing your dose, or switching to a different type of HRT.

【8】Are there any long-term side effects?

【9】It's best to only take HRT at the lowest dose that works for you, and only for as long as you need it to control your menopause symptoms.

【10】This is because HRT can slightly increase the risk of breast cancer and blood clots. The risk is small, but it increases the longer you take HRT.

【11】Usually, the risk is outweighed by the benefits of HRT, such as improving menopause symptoms, quality of life and preventing osteoporosis. But this depends on your age, symptoms and health. Speak to your doctor, who can help you decide.
删除7：<u>Find out more about the benefits and risks of HRT</u>

【12】How does it compare with other types of HRT?

【13】There are several different types of HRT. They all work equally well to replace the hormones that fall during and after the menopause.

【14】No one type of HRT is suitable for everyone. You may need to try different types to find what works best for you.

【15】It's better to take or use sequential combined HRT if you're still having periods (perimenopause). You'll normally have withdrawal bleeding at the end of each course of progestogen.

【16】Once your periods have stopped, you'll usually be advised to switch to continuous combined HRT, where you take both oestrogen and progestogen every day, without a monthly bleed.

【17】Sequential combined HRT contains an oestrogen and a progestogen to protect your womb. If you've had a hysterectomy to remove your womb, you'll be advised to take oestrogen-only HRT.

【18】Your doctor can help you decide on the type of HRT that's best for you.
删除7：<u>Find out more about types of HRT</u>

【19】How does it compare with alternatives to HRT?

【20】HRT such as sequential combined HRT is usually the most effective treatment for menopause symptoms.

【21】If you cannot take HRT, or prefer not to take it, your doctor may be able to recommend other medicines or lifestyle changes to help with your symptoms.

【22】Medicines such as clonidine and some antidepressants (such as fluoxetine or sertraline) are sometimes used as an alternative to HRT to help with symptoms such as hot flushes, night sweats and mood swings.
删除7：<u>Find out more about alternatives to HRT</u>

【23】What will happen if I stop taking it?

【24】If you stop taking HRT your menopause symptoms might come back.

【25】If you're taking it for osteoporosis there is a chance that your bones will get weaker and you may be more likely to have fractures in the future.

【26】Talk to your doctor if you're thinking of stopping. They'll help you decide what's best for you. They may suggest that you reduce your dose gradually, to help stop symptoms coming back.

【27】If you're having problems with side effects, your doctor might suggest changing your dose, or switching to another type of HRT.
删除7：<u>Find out more about when to take HRT and stopping taking it</u>

【28】Can I switch to a different brand?

【29】There are different brands and types of sequential combined HRT. A pharmacist or doctor can advise on which type would be suitable. It will depend on whether you prefer to take tablets or use patches, and what dose you need.

【30】If the brand or type of HRT that you've been using is not available because of supply shortages, is not helping your symptoms, or if you have problems with side effects, a doctor or pharmacist can advise about switching to a different type.

【31】Can I get HRT for free?

【32】You'll need to pay for your hormone replacement therapy (HRT) prescriptions unless you're eligible for free prescriptions. When there is more than one type of patch or tablet in the same box, you will need to pay a charge for each.

【33】However, you can reduce the cost by getting an HRT pre-payment certificate (PPC). This means you can pay a small fee that will cover all your HRT prescriptions for a year.

【34】Find out how to save money with a prescription prepayment certificate.

【35】Will I gain or lose weight?

【36】There's no good evidence that sequential combined HRT makes you put on weight.

【37】However, it's common to gain weight around the time of the menopause. Eating a balanced diet and exercising regularly will help you keep to a healthy weight.

【38】Will it affect my contraception?

【39】Sequential combined HRT is not a contraceptive.

【40】It's still possible to get pregnant while taking HRT, so you'll need to use contraception until 2 years after your last period if you're under 50 years old, or for 1 year if you're over 50 years old.

【41】You'll need to use a non-hormonal method of contraception such as condoms or a diaphragm, or other options which you can speak to your doctor about.

【42】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【43】Yes. Sequential combined HRT does not affect your ability to drive or ride a bike.

【44】Can I drink alcohol while taking sequential combined HRT?

【45】You can drink alcohol while taking HRT but it may be helpful to cut down on alcohol during the menopause to reduce symptoms of flushing, and improve your sleep.

【46】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【47】You can eat and drink normally while taking sequential combined HRT.

【48】Try to have a healthy diet, as this can help with menopause symptoms and keep you well.

【49】Cutting down on alcohol and caffeine may help reduce hot flushes and improve your sleep.

【50】Can lifestyle changes help menopause symptoms?

【51】The following lifestyle changes can sometimes help with menopause symptoms:

【52】*   Regular exercise. This helps with bone health and can reduce hot flushes and improve your sleep. It may also help improve your general mood, reduce stress and help you keep to a healthy weight.
*   Cut down on caffeine and alcohol. This may help reduce hot flushes and improve your sleep.
*   Quit smoking. This can help reduce hot flushes and reduce your risk of developing other health problems such as cancer, heart disease and stroke.
删除7：<u>Find out more about lifestyle changes for menopause symptoms</u>
删除11：<u>More in Sequential combined hormone replacement therapy (HRT) tablets and patches
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

【53】*   About sequential combined HRT

*   Side effects

</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 18 January 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 18 January 2026</u>

source_info.title: Kidney transplant
source_info.text:
【0】What happens \- Kidney transplant
=================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Waiting list
3.  What happens
4.  Living with
5.  Risks</u>

【2】**When a suitable donor kidney is found, the transplant centre will contact you. Staff at the centre will check you do not have any new medical problems and then ask you to go to the centre.**

【3】When you hear from the transplant centre:

【4】*   do not eat or drink anything
*   take all current medicines with you
*   take a bag of clothes and essential items for your hospital stay

【5】When you arrive at the transplant centre, you'll be quickly assessed. Some of the tests you had at your initial assessment may be repeated to ensure no new medical conditions have developed. Tests will also be done to ensure the donor kidney is suitable for you.

【6】The transplant procedure must be carried out as quickly as possible for the transplant to have the best chance of success. After the medical team has confirmed the kidney is in good condition and is suitable, you'll be given the general anaesthetic and taken to the operating theatre.

【7】The operation
-------------

【8】The kidney transplant procedure involves 3 main stages:

【9】*   First, an incision (cut) is made in your lower abdomen (tummy), through which the donated kidney is put into place. Your own kidneys will usually be left where they are, unless they're causing problems such as pain or infection.
*   Second, nearby blood vessels are attached to the blood vessels of the donated kidney. This is to provide the donated kidney with the blood supply it needs to function properly.
*   Finally, the ureter (the tube that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder) of the donated kidney is connected to your bladder.

【10】A small plastic tube called a stent may be inserted into the ureter to help ensure a good flow of urine initially. This will usually be removed about 6 to 12 weeks later during a minor procedure called a cystoscopy.

【11】When the kidney is properly in place, the incision in your abdomen will be closed with surgical staples, stitches or surgical glue.

【12】Although the procedure may sound relatively straightforward, it's very demanding and complex surgery that usually takes around 3 hours to complete.

【13】After the operation
-------------------

【14】Once you've recovered from the effects of the anaesthetic, it's likely you will feel some pain at the site of the incision. Painkillers will be provided, if necessary.

【15】After the operation, you'll immediately begin treatment with medicine designed to prevent your immune system from rejecting your new kidney. See living with a kidney transplant for more information on this.

【16】Most transplanted kidneys will start working within a week or two. You may need to have dialysis until your transplanted kidney is working properly.

【17】Most people can leave hospital in about a week, but you'll need to attend frequent appointments at the transplant centre, so your kidney function can be assessed and tests can be carried out to check how well your medicines are working.

【18】For the first month after surgery, you may need to have 2 to 3 appointments a week. However, over time, your appointments will become less frequent. After a year, as long as you do not have any serious problems, you should only have to attend the centre once every 3 to 6 months.

【19】After kidney surgery, you should be able to return to work and normal activities within a few months, provided you make good progress.

source_info.title: Gallstones
source_info.text:
【0】Treatment \- Gallstones
=======================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications
7.  Prevention</u>

【2】**Your treatment plan for gallstones depends on how the symptoms are affecting your daily life.**

【3】If you don't have any symptoms, active monitoring is often recommended. This means you won't receive immediate treatment, but you should let your GP know if you notice any symptoms.

【4】As a general rule, the longer you go without symptoms, the less likely it is that your condition will get worse.

【5】You may need treatment if you have a condition that increases your risk of developing complications, such as:

【6】*   scarring of the liver (cirrhosis)
*   high blood pressure inside the liver (this is known as portal hypertension and is often a complication of alcohol-related liver disease)
*   diabetes

【7】Treatment may also be recommended if a scan shows high levels of calcium inside your gallbladder, as this can lead to gallbladder cancer in later life.

【8】If you have episodes of abdominal pain (biliary colic), treatment depends on how the pain affects your daily activities.

【9】If the pain is mild and infrequent, you may be prescribed painkillers to control further episodes and be given advice about eating a healthy diet to help control the pain.

【10】If your symptoms are more severe and frequent, surgery to remove the gallbladder is usually recommended.

【11】The gallbladder isn't an essential organ and you can lead a normal life without one.

【12】Some people may experience symptoms of bloating and diarrhoea after eating fatty or spicy food. If certain foods trigger symptoms, you may wish to avoid them in the future.

【13】Keyhole surgery to remove the gallbladder
-----------------------------------------

【14】If surgery is recommended, you'll usually have keyhole surgery to remove your gallbladder. This is known as a laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

【15】During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, 3 or 4 small cuts are made in your abdomen.

【16】One larger cut (about 2 to 3cm) is made by the belly button and the others (each 1cm or less) will be on the right side of your abdomen.

【17】Your abdomen is temporarily inflated using carbon dioxide gas. This is harmless and makes it easier for the surgeon to see your organs.

【18】A laparoscope (a long, thin telescope with a tiny light and video camera at the end) is inserted through one of the cuts in your abdomen.

【19】This allows your surgeon to view the operation on a video monitor. They'll remove your gallbladder using special surgical instruments.

【20】If it's thought there may be gallstones in the bile duct, an X-ray or ultrasound scan of the bile duct is also taken during the operation.

【21】If gallstones are found, they may be removed during keyhole surgery. If the operation can't be done this way, or an unexpected complication occurs, it may have to be converted to open surgery.

【22】After the gallbladder has been removed, the gas in your abdomen escapes through the laparoscope and the cuts are closed with dissolvable stitches and covered with dressings.

【23】Laparoscopic cholecystectomies are usually carried out under a general anaesthetic, which means you'll be unconscious during the procedure and won't feel any pain while it's carried out.

【24】The operation takes 60 to 90 minutes and you can usually go home the same day.

【25】Full recovery typically takes around 10 days.

【26】### Single-incision keyhole surgery

【27】Single-incision laparoscopic cholecystectomy is a newer type of keyhole surgery used to remove the gallbladder.

【28】During this type of surgery, only 1 small cut is made, which means you'll only have a single scar.

【29】But as this type of cholecystectomy hasn't been carried out as often as conventional cholecystectomies, there are still some uncertainties about it.

【30】Access to single-incision laparoscopic cholecystectomies is also limited because it needs an experienced surgeon with specialist training.
删除7：<u>Read more about single-incision laparoscopic cholecystectomy on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) website</u>

【31】Open surgery
------------

【32】A laparoscopic cholecystectomy may not be recommended if you:

【33】*   are in the third trimester (the last 3 months) of pregnancy
*   are extremely overweight
*   have an unusual gallbladder or bile duct structure that makes a keyhole procedure difficult and potentially dangerous

【34】In these circumstances, an open cholecystectomy may be recommended.

【35】A 10 to 15cm (4 to 6in) incision is made in the abdomen, underneath the ribs, so the gallbladder can be removed.

【36】General anaesthetic is used, so you'll be unconscious and won't feel any pain.

【37】Open surgery is just as effective as laparoscopic surgery, but it does have a longer recovery time and causes more visible scarring.

【38】Most people have to stay in hospital for up to 5 days. It typically takes 6 weeks to fully recover.
删除7：<u>Read more about recovering from gallbladder surgery.</u>

【39】Endoscopic retrograde cholangio-pancreatography (ERCP)
------------------------------------------------------

【40】Endoscopic retrograde cholangio-pancreatography (ERCP) is a procedure that can be used to remove gallstones from the bile duct.

【41】The gallbladder isn't removed during this procedure, so any stones in the gallbladder will remain unless they're removed using other surgical techniques.

【42】ERCP is similar to a diagnostic cholangiography (see diagnosing gallstones for more information), where an endoscope (a long, thin flexible tube with a camera at the end) is passed through your mouth down to where the bile duct opens into the small intestine.

【43】But during ERCP, the opening of the bile duct is widened with a small cut or an electrically heated wire.

【44】The bile duct stones are then removed or left to pass into your intestine and out of your body.

【45】Sometimes a small tube called a stent is permanently placed in the bile duct to help the bile and stones pass.

【46】ERCP is usually carried out under sedation, which means you'll be conscious throughout the procedure but won't experience any pain.

【47】The procedure lasts about 30 minutes on average, but can take from 15 minutes to over an hour.

【48】Afterwards, you may need to stay in hospital overnight so you can be monitored.

【49】Medicine to dissolve gallstones
-------------------------------

【50】If your gallstones are small and don't contain calcium, it may be possible to take ursodeoxycholic acid tablets to dissolve them.

【51】But these aren't prescribed very often because:

【52】*   they're rarely very effective
*   they need to be taken for a long time (up to 2 years)
*   you can get gallstones again after treatment is stopped

【53】Side effects of ursodeoxycholic acid are uncommon and are usually mild. The most commonly reported side effects are feeling sick, being sick and itchy skin.

【54】Ursodeoxycholic acid isn't usually recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women.

【55】Sexually active women should either use a barrier method of contraception, such as a condom, or a low-dose oestrogen contraceptive pill while taking ursodeoxycholic acid, as it may affect other types of oral contraceptive pills.

【56】Ursodeoxycholic acid tablets may occasionally be used to prevent gallstones if it's thought you're at risk of developing them.

【57】For example, ursodeoxycholic acid may be prescribed if you have recently had weight loss surgery, as rapid weight loss can cause gallstones to grow.

【58】Diet and gallstones
-------------------

【59】In the past, people with gallstones who weren't suitable for surgery were sometimes advised to adopt a very low-fat diet to stop the gallstones growing.

【60】But recent evidence suggests this isn't helpful because rapid weight loss resulting from a very low-fat diet can actually cause gallstones to grow.

【61】This means that if surgery isn't recommended or you want to avoid having an operation, it's advisable to adopt a healthy, balanced diet based on The Eatwell Guide.

【62】This involves eating a variety of foods, including moderate amounts of fat, and having regular meals.

【63】A healthy diet won't cure gallstones or completely eliminate your symptoms, but it can improve your general health and help control pain caused by gallstones.
删除7：<u>Read more about healthy eating.</u>

source_info.title: Do not attempt cardiopulmonary resuscitation (DNACPR) decisions
source_info.text:
【0】Do not attempt cardiopulmonary resuscitation (DNACPR) decisions
===============================================================

【1】CPR stands for cardiopulmonary resuscitation. It's a treatment that can be given when you stop breathing (respiratory arrest) or your heart stops beating (cardiac arrest).

【2】CPR tries to get your breathing and heart going again.

【3】It can involve:

【4】*   pressing down hard on your chest repeatedly (chest compressions)
*   a machine to stimulate your heart using electrical shocks (sometimes more than once)
*   equipment that helps move oxygen around your body (artificial ventilation)
*   giving medicine by injection

【5】How successful is CPR?
----------------------

【6】CPR can sometimes get the heart and breathing going again. The actions used in CPR, such as chest compressions, can cause bruising, break ribs and puncture lungs.

【7】Overall, CPR restarts the heart and/or breathing for between 1 and 2 in 10 people whose heart or breathing have stopped.

【8】You have the best chance of CPR restarting your heart or breathing if:

【9】*   your lungs, heart or other organs are healthy and working well before your heart or breathing stops
*   you are near a person trained in CPR
*   any equipment that is needed, such as a defibrillator, is nearby

【10】The chances of CPR starting your heart and/or breathing are lower if your lungs, heart or other organs are struggling to work before CPR is needed. Your organs might be struggling because you:

【11】*   have previous organ damage (for example, your lungs have been damaged by smoking)
*   have a serious long-term condition (this is not the same as a disability)
*   have current severe illness
*   are frail
*   are approaching the end of your life

【12】Only a few people make a full recovery even if their heart or breathing can be restarted with CPR.

【13】You may still be very unwell and need more treatment and you may never get back to the health you had before.

【14】Your heart and/or brain may be permanently damaged. This is why DNACPR forms are written. They mean you do not receive a treatment that may prolong or cause suffering at the end of your life.

【15】What does DNACPR mean and how is it recorded?
---------------------------------------------

【16】DNACPR stands for do not attempt cardiopulmonary resuscitation. It's sometimes called DNAR (do not attempt resuscitation) or DNR (do not resuscitate) but they all refer to the same thing.

【17】DNACPR means if your heart or breathing stops your healthcare team will not try to restart it.

【18】A DNACPR decision is made by you and/or your doctor or healthcare team. This is explained in more detail in the following section "When is a DNACPR decision made and a form written and who is involved?".

【19】A DNACPR decision is usually recorded on a special form. Different doctors or hospitals might use different forms, but they all serve the same purpose. Some examples are a DNACPR form, a treatment escalation plan, or a recommended summary plan for emergency care and treatment (ReSPECT) process.

【20】All these forms are easily recognised by doctors, nurses and healthcare workers, so they know what to do in an emergency.

【21】This form is kept in your medical records. It may also be printed and kept with you if you are at home or in a care home.

【22】You and the people important to you should know that a DNACPR form has been put in your medical records.

【23】The form says that if your heart or breathing stop, CPR should not be tried. This means medical staff will not try to restart your heart or breathing.

【24】### Important

【25】DNACPR is about CPR only. It does not mean that you will not get care and treatment. You will continue to have all the other appropriate care, treatment and support you need.

【26】When is a DNACPR decision made and a form written and who is involved?
----------------------------------------------------------------------

【27】There are different situations when a DNACPR decision might be made.

【28】### You decide – deciding in advance to refuse CPR

【29】Everyone who has capacity to do so can refuse CPR if they wish.

【30】This is a choice you can make at any time, for example when you are healthy or when you are approaching the end of your life.

【31】You can make it clear to your doctor or medical team that you do not want CPR if your heart or breathing stops.

【32】Your doctor may complete a DNACPR form to indicate this and put it in your medical records.

【33】*   If you wish to make your refusal of CPR legally binding for when in the future you are unable to make this decision, then you should write an Advance Decision to Refuse Treatment (ADRT). An ADRT explains to a doctor or medical team when you want to refuse CPR (or other treatments).
*   You can change your mind about your DNACPR decision at any time. If you do, you need to tell your doctors and nurses so that the DNACPR form is marked as no longer valid. The fact that you once had a DNACPR form will still be recorded on your records so that doctors and nurses can see your full medical history and know about conversations that happened in the past.

【34】### A doctor decides in advance

【35】*   DNACPR is a medical treatment decision that can be made by your doctor even if you do not agree.
*   You must be told that a DNACPR form will be/has been completed for you, but a doctor does not need your consent. Doctors can only not tell you that a DNACPR form has been completed for you if they think doing so would cause you physical or psychological harm.
*   You should be given the chance to understand what a DNACPR is, how the decision is made and why they think CPR would not be suitable for you. For example, your doctor may think that CPR will not help you live longer or that giving you CPR could cause you more harm. This may be because your organs are already too damaged because of another illness or you are approaching the end of your life.
*   You should then be consulted, and doctors should ask about your wishes and preferences. Your doctor makes the final decision.
*   Doctors do not have to give you treatment if they think it will not work.
*   A DNACPR decision must be made on an individual (person by person) basis. This means it must be based on your health, needs and priorities as an individual. The judgement about whether the discussion or decision would cause you harm should also be made on an individual basis.
*   DNACPR decisions should not be made for a group of people at once. For example, DNACPR decisions should not be made for everyone living in a care home or for a group of people over a certain age. This is unlawful, irrespective of medical condition, age, disability, race or language.
*   Learning disability, autism or dementia are not reasons to put a DNACPR on someone's record.
*   If you disagree with a DNACPR decision that a doctor has made, you can ask for a second opinion and a review. You cannot demand CPR. The law does not require your consent to a DNACPR. The law does provide you with the right to be involved in, and informed of, a doctor's DNACPR decision.

【36】What happens if you are unable to make or discuss a DNACPR decision in advance of your heart stopping?
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

【37】Some people cannot make decisions about CPR for themselves. If you have been assessed as unable to make a specific decision for yourself, you will be referred to as "lacking capacity".

【38】If you lack capacity to decide about CPR, doctors should first check to see if you have an Advance Decision to Refuse Treatment (ADRT) that says that you do not want CPR. They should also check to see if you have a Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA) for health and care decisions.

【39】An LPA is a document that explains who you have chosen to help you make decisions or who can make decisions for you. Your chosen person(s) are known as "attorneys". If you would like your LPA to make decisions about CPR, then you must complete and sign the section on life-sustaining treatment in the LPA document.

【40】An LPA (with the right to make decisions on life-sustaining treatment) means if you lack the relevant capacity, your attorney can make the decision relating to CPR in your best interests. Your attorney cannot insist on CPR being given.

【41】If you do not have an ADRT (which says that you do not want CPR) or an LPA (with life-sustaining treatment decision-making powers) then a best interest's decision is made by the senior doctor.

【42】This doctor must ask the people who are important to you about your wishes and preferences. This includes anyone with the legal power to represent you, such as a personal welfare deputy, special guardian or – for children and young people under 16 – a parent.

【43】If you do not have family or friends appropriate to ask, then the doctor should ask an independent mental capacity advocate (IMCA) to represent you in the decision-making process. The doctor should also ask members of your healthcare (multidisciplinary) team for their views.
删除6：<u>Information:

【44】### Further information

【45】*   GOV.UK: Deputies - make decisions for someone who lacks capacity
*   GOV.UK: Become a special guardian

【46】</u>
How long does a DNACPR form last?
---------------------------------

【47】A DNACPR form can be written for a short period – for example, if you have been admitted to hospital. Or it can be written with no end date – for example, if you have a long-term condition that has damaged your heart, lungs or other organs – only being reviewed if your situation changes.

【48】When the DNACPR decision is made you should be told when it will be reviewed, and this is usually recorded on the form. It's recommended that a DNACPR is reviewed each time your situation changes – for example, when you leave hospital. If a DNACPR form is placed on your medical records while in hospital, this will be included in your discharge summary and shared with your GP.

【49】Is a DNACPR form legally binding?
---------------------------------

【50】A DNACPR form is not legally binding. It's a tool to tell doctors, nurses or paramedics not to attempt CPR.

【51】If you wish to make your DNACPR decision legally binding, you should write an Advance Decision to Refuse Treatment (ADRT). An ADRT explains when you want to refuse CPR (or other treatment).

【52】Talking about a DNACPR
----------------------

【53】You do not have to talk about DNACPR if you do not want to. If you would prefer not to talk about it, you can let your doctors and nurses know. You could ask your doctors and nurses to make it clear on your record. If you change your mind and want to talk about it, you can.

【54】If a decision needs to be made about CPR, your doctors can still decide to complete a form even if you ask not to talk about it. Your doctor will do this if they believe that CPR would not prolong your life or would do you more harm than good.

【55】Even if you ask not to be involved in the decision, you should be told if a DNACPR form is written and placed on your medical records. Doctors can only not tell you that a DNACPR form has been completed for you if they think doing so would cause you physical or psychological harm.

【56】What should you do if you are concerned about a DNACPR form in your medical record or on somebody else's (such as a relative)?
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

【57】If you are concerned about a DNACPR form, you should first raise those concerns with your doctor.

【58】If you are still not happy, then you can ask for another doctor's opinion.

【59】If you are not the patient and the patient has capacity to make their own decisions, they will need to agree to it being discussed with you. If you do not have capacity, your family, friends or those with the legal power to represent you (such as a Lasting Power of Attorney) can raise concerns on your behalf.

【60】It's important to understand that nobody has the right to demand CPR, so the decision may not change if there was a good clinical reason for it (for example, your heart, lungs or other organs are struggling to work). The doctor should explain their reasons and ask about your wishes and preferences.

【61】If the DNACPR form was made by a GP, and you are not happy with their response, you should follow the practice's complaints procedure. If you are still concerned, or you wish to make a complaint, contact NHS England and NHS Improvement.

【62】If the DNACPR form was made by a doctor in a hospital, and you are not happy with their response, you can ask to speak to the senior doctor on duty or the consultant responsible for your care. The hospital should have its own complaints procedure. This will tell you how to make a complaint.

【63】If your DNACPR form was made by a GP or doctor in a hospital, you can contact your local Healthwatch to find out about how to get help making a complaint. You can also have support from an advocate if you want help to make a complaint about your GP or a doctor in the hospital.

【64】If you are still not happy with the response you can contact the Parliamentary and Health Service Ombudsman.

source_info.title: Lidocaine for piles and itchy bottom
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about lidocaine for piles and itchy bottom \- Brand names: Anusol, Boots Haemorrhoid, Germaloids, Perinal, Xylopract
=====================================================================================================================================

【1】How does lidocaine work?

【2】Lidocaine is a local anaesthetic that numbs the area where you've used it.

【3】It works by stopping nerves from sending pain signals to your brain.

【4】If you use lidocaine treatment for piles or itchy bottom, it helps relieve any pain and itching.

【5】When will I feel better?

【6】Lidocaine works quickly.

【7】Most people start to feel better within an hour.

【8】Are there any long-term side effects?

【9】Talk to your doctor if your symptoms last for more than 7 days or if you keep getting piles or itching. They may want to find out what's causing this.

【10】If you use these treatments for a long time, there's also more chance of your skin becoming sensitive to lidocaine.

【11】Are there other treatments for piles?

【12】There are various types of treatments for piles. Some are available on prescription from your doctor. There are others that you can buy in a pharmacy.

【13】These treatments contain different local anaesthetics and are likely to provide similar relief for your symptoms.

【14】Some treatments also contain steroids, such as hydrocortisone.

【15】Ask your doctor or a pharmacist about the best treatment to help with your symptoms. They may recommend:

【16】*   creams to ease the pain, itching and swelling
*   treatment to help constipation and soften poo
*   cold packs to ease discomfort

【17】Will it affect my contraception?

【18】Lidocaine treatments for piles and itchy bottom do not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【19】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【20】Yes. lidocaine treatments for piles and itchy bottom will not affect your ability to drive or ride a bike.

【21】Can I drink alcohol while using lidocaine for piles and itchy bottom?

【22】Yes, you can drink alcohol with lidocaine treatments for piles and itchy bottom.

【23】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【24】Lidocaine treatments for piles and itchy bottom do not affect what you can eat or drink.

【25】However, it's a good idea to get more fibre into your diet so you do not get constipated. Constipation can make your symptoms worse.

【26】Good sources of fibre include:

【27】*   porridge oats and wholegrain breakfast cereals
*   wholemeal or granary bread
*   brown pasta and brown rice
*   pulses such as lentils, peas and beans
*   potatoes with their skins on

【28】Other tips for preventing constipation include drinking plenty of fluids and doing some gentle exercise, if you can.

【29】Can lifestyle changes help with piles?

【30】Piles often settle down without treatment but there are some things you can do to help your symptoms.

【31】Piles can be brought on by too much pushing or straining on the toilet. This is often because of constipation.

【32】Check with your doctor or a pharmacist if any other medicines you're taking could be causing constipation.

【33】You're less likely to get constipated if you:

【34】*   get more fibre into your diet, like wholemeal bread, fruit and vegetables
*   drink lots of water every day
*   exercise regularly
*   go to the toilet as soon as you feel you need to – do not hold it in
删除11：<u>More in Lidocaine for piles and itchy bottom
--------------------------------------------

【35】*   About lidocaine for piles and itchy bottom
*   Who can and cannot use it
*   How and when to use it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Using it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 30 August 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 30 August 2025</u>

source_info.title: Dexamethasone tablets and liquid
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about dexamethasone tablets and liquid \- Brand names: Neofordex, Glensoludex, Martapan
========================================================================================================

【1】How does dexamethasone work?

【2】Dexamethasone is a steroid (also called a corticosteroid) medicine.

【3】Steroids closely copy the effects of natural hormones produced in your adrenal glands. The adrenal glands are above your kidneys.

【4】When prescribed in doses higher than your body's usual levels, steroids like dexamethasone reduce inflammation (swelling). This can help the symptoms of inflammatory conditions, such as croup, arthritis and asthma.

【5】Steroids also help calm your immune system. This can help in autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, where your immune system mistakenly attacks your own tissues.

【6】When taken for nausea and vomiting dexamethasone is thought to work on chemical messengers in the brain to reduce feelings of sickness.

【7】How is dexamethasone used to treat COVID-19?

【8】Dexamethasone is being used to treat severe COVID-19 in hospitals.

【9】For patients on a ventilator or who need oxygen to help them breathe, dexamethasone can improve their chances of recovery.

【10】There's no evidence to suggest that dexamethasone will help in less serious COVID-19 when people do not need to be in hospital.

【11】It does not stop you getting COVID-19 and it may not stop mild symptoms getting worse.

【12】When will I feel better?

【13】This can vary depending on why you're taking dexamethasone.

【14】For some conditions, you will feel better after a couple of days.

【15】For other conditions, you may not feel any better even though the medicine is helping you.

【16】Ask your doctor what to expect for your condition.

【17】Are there any long-term side effects?

【18】If you take dexamethasone for several months it can make your bones weaker and more likely to break (osteoporosis).

【19】You can also get eyesight problems and it can cause slower growth in children and teenagers.

【20】If you have diabetes, dexamethasone can affect blood sugar control. Your doctor may need to adjust your diabetes treatment while you take this medicine and again after you stop.

【21】However, there are steps you can take to help you stay as healthy as possible.

【22】### For healthy bones

【23】Take regular exercise and make sure you get enough calcium in your diet to help strengthen your bones. Calcium-rich foods include milk, cheese and leafy green vegetables. To check your bones, your doctor may arrange for you to have an occasional bone scan.

【24】### For diabetes

【25】If you have diabetes you may need to check your blood glucose more often. Your doctor can give you more advice about this.

【26】### For eye health

【27】To reduce the chances of eyesight problems, visit an optometrist every 12 months. They'll check for high pressure in your eye (glaucoma) and cataracts.

【28】### For children and teenagers

【29】If your child takes dexamethasone for several months, their height and weight need to be monitored carefully. This is to make sure the steroid is not affecting their growth. Talk to their doctor if you're worried. They'll be able to explain the benefits and risks of giving your child dexamethasone.

【30】What will happen if I stop taking it?

【31】Do not stop taking dexamethasone suddenly, especially if you've been on a high dose for a long time.

【32】Your health condition may flare up again.

【33】You may also get extra side effects including:

【34】*   severe tiredness
*   weakness
*   body aches
*   joint pain

【35】Your doctor will probably want to reduce your dose gradually over several weeks to prevent these side effects.

【36】### Important

【37】Do not stop taking dexamethasone without talking to your doctor. You'll need to reduce your dose gradually.

【38】Can I still have vaccinations?

【39】If you need any vaccinations, let the doctor or nurse know that you're taking a steroid.

【40】Some types of vaccines, known as live vaccines, are not suitable while you're taking dexamethasone. This is because taking dexamethasone affects your immune system, so you're more at risk of infection caused by a live vaccine.

【41】Live vaccines include the oral typhoid vaccine and the BCG vaccine for tuberculosis.

【42】There are non-live versions of vaccines available for conditions including flu, shingles and polio. These are safe to have while you're taking dexamethasone.

【43】Do I need a steroid card?

【44】### Red steroid emergency card

【45】If you're prescribed steroid medicines such as dexamethasone, your adrenal glands may not make as much of some of the hormones your body needs such as cortisol (known as the stress hormone). This is known as adrenal insufficiency.

【46】It's more likely to happen if you either:

【47】*   take high doses for a long time, especially tablets and injections
*   regularly use different kinds of steroids at the same time, such as a steroid nasal spray and a steroid inhaler

【48】Your doctor or pharmacist will assess your risk of adrenal insufficiency based on the type and dose of steroids you're taking and may recommend that you carry a red steroid emergency card. This card is the size of a credit card and fits in your wallet or purse删除7：<u>

【49】The Addison's Disease Self-Help Group (ADSHG) website has more information about the NHS steroid emergency card.</u>

【50】#### Important

【51】If you need any medical or dental treatment, or are having surgery or an invasive procedure, show your steroid emergency card to your doctor or dentist. This is important so they know you're having steroid treatment and can give you extra steroids as needed.

【52】### Blue steroid card

【53】If you take dexamethasone for longer than 3 weeks, or you take more than 6mg a day, your doctor or pharmacist will give you a blue steroid treatment card.

【54】It tells you how you can reduce the risks of side effects. It also gives details of your doctor, how much dexamethasone you take and how long the treatment will last for. The card is the size of a credit card and fits in your wallet or purse.

【55】If you need any medical or dental treatment, show your blue steroid card to the doctor or dentist.

【56】How does dexamethasone compare with other steroid medicines?

【57】There are other steroids available, including:

【58】*   deflazacort
*   methylprednisolone
*   prednisolone
*   prednisone

【59】For most health problems, these steroids are very similar to dexamethasone in terms of how well they work and how safe they are.

【60】Do I need to be careful of infections?

【61】Taking dexamethasone makes you more likely to catch infections such as flu, COVID-19, the common cold and chest infections. Tell your doctor if you get symptoms of an infection or test positive for COVID-19.

【62】Keep away from people with an infectious illness, especially measles, chickenpox or shingles. If you get any of these illnesses they could make you very ill.

【63】Tell your doctor straight away if you come into contact with someone who has chickenpox, shingles or measles. Your doctor may be able to prescribe a medicine to protect you.

【64】Will it affect my contraception?

【65】Dexamethasone will not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【66】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【67】Dexamethasone does not make you sleepy and so it's usually safe to drive or ride a bike while taking this medicine.

【68】However, do not drive, cycle or operate machinery if your eyesight is affected.

【69】Can I drink alcohol while taking dexamethasone?

【70】Yes, you can drink alcohol while taking dexamethasone.

【71】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【72】No, you can eat and drink normally while taking dexamethasone.
删除11：<u>More in Dexamethasone tablets and liquid

source_info.title: Cyclizine
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about cyclizine
================================

【1】How does cyclizine work?

【2】Sometimes, when your body produces a substance called histamine, it can send signals to your brain that make you feel sick. Cyclizine works by blocking these signals and reducing feelings of sickness.

【3】How long does it take to work?

【4】Cyclizine starts to work after 30 minutes. You should feel better after 1 to 2 hours.

【5】It should work for about 4 to 6 hours.

【6】Are there any long-term side effects?

【7】Cyclizine tablets are unlikely to do you any harm if you take them for a long time. However, there have been a few reports of people having problems stopping cyclizine injections after long-term use. Because of this, it's best to only take cyclizine for as long as you need it to control your symptoms.

【8】How does cyclizine compare to other anti-sickness medicines?

【9】Cyclizine is a type of drowsy (sedating) antihistamine, as it can make you feel sleepy.

【10】There are other drowsy antihistamines that can help with feeling or being sick, such as promethazine and cinnarizine. Both cyclizine and cinnarizine are less likely to make you feel sleepy than promethazine.

【11】There's not enough information available to say whether one is better than another for helping with sickness.

【12】There are also other medicines that can help with sickness, such as metoclopramide, ondansetron and domperidone.

【13】You may need to try a few different medicines to find out what works best for you. Ask your pharmacist or doctor for advice if you're unsure.

【14】Is cyclizine addictive?

【15】It's unlikely that you'll get addicted to cyclizine tablets prescribed to help relieve sickness or feeling dizzy. However, to be on the safe side it's best to only take cyclizine for as long as you need to.

【16】Are there other ways to treat morning sickness?

【17】Most cases of feeling and being sick in pregnancy pass after 16 to 20 weeks.

【18】If your morning sickness is not too bad, there are some lifestyle changes you can make to help.

【19】Although cyclizine has not been officially approved for treating morning sickness, it's considered to be a useful and safe medicine to use in pregnancy.

【20】Will it affect my contraception?

【21】Cyclizine does not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【22】But if cyclizine is not working for you and you're being sick, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy.

【23】Check the pill packet to find out what to do or find out what to do if you're on the pill and you're being sick.

【24】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【25】Do not drive a car, ride a bike or use heavy machinery or tools if cyclizine makes you sleepy, gives you blurred vision, or makes you feel dizzy, or unable to concentrate or make decisions.

【26】This may be more likely when you first start taking cyclizine, but could happen at any time, for example, when starting another medicine.

【27】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【28】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking cyclizine删除7：<u> GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.</u>

【29】Can I drink alcohol while taking cyclizine?

【30】Do not drink alcohol while you're taking cyclizine.

【31】Alcohol and cyclizine together can make you sleep very deeply. It may affect your breathing and you may have difficulty waking up.

【32】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【33】Apart from alcohol, you can eat and drink normally while taking cyclizine.

【34】Can lifestyle changes help to stop me feeling or being sick?

【35】There are some lifestyle changes that can help with feeling or being sick:

【36】*   stick to simple meals and try not to eat rich or spicy foods – having smaller, more frequent meals can help
*   avoid drinking with meals – drinking any liquids with meals may make you feel more full, which makes feeling sick worse
*   eat foods or drinks containing ginger – this is a popular natural remedy commonly used to stop you feeling sick
*   avoid strong smells – these may make you feel worse
*   stay hydrated – drink plenty of fluids, such as water, and taking small sips often may help
删除11：<u>More in Cyclizine
-----------------

【37】*   About cyclizine
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it

source_info.title: Lithium
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about lithium \- Brand names: Priadel, Camcolit, Liskonum, Li-Liquid
=====================================================================================

【1】How does lithium work?

【2】Lithium is a metal. Tiny amounts of lithium are found naturally in rocks, and in our food and bodies.

【3】We do not really know how lithium works to treat mental health conditions, but it's thought that it may protect and help create more neurons (the cells that pass messages in your brain).

【4】How long does it take to work?

【5】Lithium may take several weeks or months to work.

【6】How will it make me feel?

【7】If you have the right amount of lithium in your blood, you probably will not have any problems with your medicine.

【8】However, some people find it slows down their thinking or makes them feel a bit “numb”. Sometimes it's hard to know if this is because the lithium is helping to control your mood, or if you have mania.

【9】Talk to your doctor if you're worried that lithium is slowing down your thinking or numbing your emotions. You may need to have your lithium levels checked again.

【10】What will happen if I stop taking lithium?

【11】If you or your doctor decide to stop your lithium, it must be reduced gradually over a number of weeks or months. If you stop taking it suddenly the symptoms of your condition are likely to come back.

【12】Do not stop taking lithium suddenly even if you feel better, or because you think the dose is too little or too much.

【13】Your doctor will help you to reduce your medicine and stop completely, if you need to.

【14】However, if you think you have lithium toxicity (the side effects of having taken more than your prescribed dose) it's important to stop taking lithium straight away and get medical help.

【15】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E now if:

【16】you have any of these symptoms:

【17】*   stomach ache, feeling sick (nausea) and having diarrhoea
*   problems with your eyesight (blurred vision)
*   feeling very thirsty, needing to pee more than normal, and lack of control over pee or poo
*   feeling lightheaded or drowsy
*   confusion and blackouts
*   shaking, muscle weakness, muscle twitches, jerks or spasms affecting the face, tongue, eyes or neck
*   difficulty speaking

【18】These are signs of lithium toxicity, which is an emergency. Stop taking lithium straight away.

【19】Are there any long-term side effects?

【20】Lithium is generally safe to take for a long time. Most people take it for years with no problems.

【21】If you've been taking lithium for some time, it can cause weight gain.

【22】If you find you're putting on weight after taking lithium for a while, try to have a healthy balanced diet. Regular exercise will also help you keep your weight stable. Your doctor will usually monitor your weight while you're taking this medicine.

【23】It can also cause problems with your kidneys or thyroid gland.

【24】Common signs of an underactive thyroid are tiredness, weight gain and feeling depressed. Signs of kidney problems include swollen hands or ankles, feeling tired and short of breath, changes in your pee and feeling sick.

【25】Tell your doctor if you get any these symptoms. Your doctor will arrange a blood test to check your thyroid and kidneys for any changes.

【26】Your doctor may discuss topping up levels of the hormone that the thyroid gland normally produces (thyroxine) with a tablet.

【27】Is lithium an antipsychotic?

【28】Lithium is used to stabilise your mood and is not an antipsychotic medicine. However, your doctor might prescribe an antipsychotic medicine with lithium.

【29】How well does lithium treat depression?

【30】Usually, if you have depression, you'll be prescribed an antidepressant medicine first as they're considered more effective for depression than lithium.

【31】However, if antidepressants have not worked, your doctor might prescribe lithium as well. This may be more effective and help your symptoms get better.

【32】Will it affect my contraception?

【33】Lithium does not affect contraception, including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【34】However, if you're sick (vomit) or have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your combined pill may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet to find out what to do.

【35】Find out what to do if you're on the pill and you're being sick or have diarrhoea.

【36】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【37】If you have just started taking lithium, or your dose has recently been changed, it may make you feel tired, dizzy, sleepy and make your hands shake.

【38】If this happens, stop driving a car, riding a bike or using tools or heavy machinery for the first few days, until you know how lithium affects you and until you feel more alert.

【39】If you've been diagnosed with bipolar disorder you must tell the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA).

【40】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【41】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking lithium删除7：<u> GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving</u>

【42】Can I drink alcohol while taking lithium?

【43】Lithium can make you drowsy so it's best to stop drinking alcohol during the first few days of taking lithium, or if your dose is increased.

【44】If you feel OK after this, you can drink alcohol but it's best not to drink too much as it's likely to make you dehydrated. This can increase the chance of high levels of lithium in your blood. It's important to remember this, especially in hot weather when you will sweat more, and your body loses water.

【45】Are there any foods and drink I need to avoid?

【46】You can eat and drink normally while taking lithium.

【47】However, it's best to avoid a low-sodium (low-salt) diet as this can increase the levels of lithium in your blood and increase the chance of getting side effects.

【48】The amount of fluid you drink is very important as it can affect the levels of lithium in your blood. Getting dehydrated will affect the levels, so it's good to drink plenty of fluids.

【49】Some people may put on weight when taking lithium. Try to eat well without increasing your portion sizes. Regular exercise can also help to keep your weight stable.

【50】Can I take lithium with recreational drugs?

【51】Using recreational drugs can affect the level of lithium in the body.

【52】Taking ecstasy while you're on lithium can make you dehydrated, which can lead to lithium toxicity.

【53】Tell your doctor if you think you may take recreational drugs while you're on lithium.

【54】Find out more the side effects of some recreational drugs on the Frank website.
删除11：<u>More in Lithium
---------------

【55】*   About lithium
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 9 August 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 9 August 2026</u>

source_info.title: Asthma
source_info.text:
【0】Diagnosis \- Asthma
===================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Living with
7.  Asthma attacks</u>

【2】**Asthma can usually be diagnosed from your symptoms and some simple tests.**

【3】A GP will probably be able to diagnose it, but they may refer you to a specialist if they're not sure.

【4】Seeing a GP
-----------

【5】The GP may ask:

【6】*   what symptoms you have
*   when they happen and how often
*   if anything seems to trigger them
*   if you have conditions such as eczema or allergies, or a family history of them

【7】They may suggest doing some tests to confirm if you have asthma.

【8】These cannot always be done easily in young children, so your child may be given an asthma inhaler to see if it helps relieve their symptoms until they're old enough to have the tests.

【9】Tests for asthma
----------------

【10】The main tests used to help diagnose asthma are:

【11】*   FeNO test – you breathe into a machine that measures the level of nitric oxide in your breath, which is a sign of inflammation in your lungs
*   spirometry – you blow into a machine that measures how fast you can breathe out and how much air you can hold in your lungs
*   peak flow test – you blow into a handheld device that measures how fast you can breathe out, and this may be done several times over a few weeks to see if it changes over time

【12】After you're diagnosed with asthma, you may also have a chest X-ray or allergy tests to see if your symptoms might be triggered by an allergy.

【13】Asthma + Lung UK: diagnosing asthma
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 19 April 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 19 April 2024</u>

source_info.title: Obesity
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Obesity
===================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Causes
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment</u>

【2】**The term obese describes a person who has excess body fat.**

【3】In the UK it's estimated that around 1 in every 4 adults and around 1 in every 5 children aged 10 to 11 are living with obesity.

【4】How to tell if you're living with obesity
-----------------------------------------

【5】The most widely used method to check if you're a healthy weight is body mass index (BMI).

【6】BMI is a measure of whether you're a healthy weight for your height. You can use the NHS BMI healthy weight calculator to find out your BMI.

【7】For most adults, if your BMI is:

【8】*   below 18.5 – you're in the underweight range
*   18.5 to 24.9 – you're in the healthy weight range
*   25 to 29.9 – you're in the overweight range
*   30 to 39.9 – you're in the obese range
*   40 or above – you're in the severely obese range

【9】If you have a South Asian, Chinese, other Asian, Middle Eastern, Black African or African-Caribbean family background you'll need to use a lower BMI score to measure overweight and obesity:

【10】*   23 to 27.4 – you're in the overweight range
*   27.5 or above – you're in the obese range

【11】BMI score has some limitations because it measures whether a person is carrying too much weight but not too much fat. For example, people who are very muscular, like professional sportspeople, can have a high BMI without much fat.

【12】But for most people, BMI is a useful indication of whether they're a healthy weight.

【13】Another measure of excess fat is waist to height ratio, which can be used as an additional measure in adults who have a BMI under 35.

【14】To calculate your waist to height ratio, measure around your waist just above your belly button, and divide it by your height, measured in the same units (for example, centimetres or inches).

【15】A waist to height ratio of 0.5 or higher means you may have increased health risks.

【16】Risks of living with obesity
----------------------------

【17】Obesity is a serious health concern that increases the risk of many other health conditions.

【18】These include:

【19】*   type 2 diabetes
*   coronary heart disease
*   some types of cancer, such as breast cancer and bowel cancer
*   stroke

【20】Living with overweight and obesity can also affect your quality of life and contribute to mental health problems, such as depression, and can also affect self-esteem.

【21】Causes of obesity
-----------------

【22】Obesity is a complex issue with many causes. Obesity and overweight is caused when extra calories, particularly those from foods high in fat and sugar, are stored in the body as fat.

【23】Obesity is an increasingly common problem because the environment we live in makes it difficult for many people to eat healthily and do enough physical activity.

【24】Genetics can also be a cause of obesity for some people. Your genes can affect how your body uses food and stores fat.

【25】There are also some underlying health conditions that can occasionally contribute to weight gain, such as an underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism), although these types of conditions do not usually cause weight problems if they're effectively controlled with medicines.

【26】Some medicines can also make people more likely to put on weight, including steroids and some medicines for high blood pressure, diabetes or mental health conditions.

【27】Treating obesity
----------------

【28】The best way to treat obesity is to eat a healthy reduced-calorie diet and exercise regularly.

【29】To do this, you can:

【30】*   eat a balanced calorie-controlled diet as recommended by a GP or weight loss management health professional (such as a dietitian)
*   take up activities such as fast walking, jogging, swimming or tennis for 150 to 300 minutes (2.5 to 5 hours) a week

【31】You may benefit from joining a local weight management programme with group meetings or online support. Your GP can tell you about these.

【32】You may also benefit from receiving support and counselling from a trained healthcare professional to help you better understand your relationship with food and develop different eating habits.

【33】If you're living with obesity and lifestyle and behavioural changes alone do not help you lose weight, a medicine called orlistat may be recommended.

【34】If taken correctly, this medicine works by reducing the amount of fat you absorb during digestion. Your GP will know whether orlistat is suitable for you.

【35】A specialist may prescribe other medicines called liraglutide or semaglutide. They work by making you feel fuller and less hungry.

【36】For some people living with obesity, a specialist may recommend weight loss surgery.

【37】Other obesity-related problems
------------------------------

【38】Living with obesity can cause a number of further problems, including difficulties with daily activities and serious health conditions.

【39】Day-to-day problems related to obesity include:

【40】*   breathlessness
*   increased sweating
*   snoring
*   difficulty doing physical activity
*   often feeling very tired
*   joint and back pain
*   low confidence and self-esteem
*   feeling isolated

【41】The psychological problems associated with living with obesity can also affect your relationships with family and friends, and may lead to depression.

【42】### Serious health conditions

【43】Living with obesity can also increase your risk of developing many potentially serious health conditions, including:

【44】*   type 2 diabetes 
*   high blood pressure
*   high cholesterol and atherosclerosis (where fatty deposits narrow your arteries), which can lead to coronary heart disease and stroke
*   asthma
*   metabolic syndrome, a combination of diabetes, high blood pressure and obesity
*   several types of cancer, including bowel cancer, breast cancer and womb cancer
*   gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD), where stomach acid leaks out of the stomach and into the gullet
*   gallstones 
*   reduced fertility
*   osteoarthritis, a condition involving pain and stiffness in your joints
*   sleep apnoea, a condition that causes interrupted breathing during sleep, which can lead to daytime sleepiness with an increased risk of road traffic accidents, as well as a greater risk of diabetes, high blood pressure and heart disease
*   liver disease and kidney disease
*   pregnancy complications, such as gestational diabetes or pre-eclampsia, when a woman experiences a potentially dangerous rise in blood pressure during pregnancy

【45】Obesity reduces life expectancy by an average of 3 to 10 years, depending on how severe it is.

【46】Outlook
-------

【47】Managing a complex issue like obesity can be hard. Losing weight takes time and commitment.

【48】The healthcare professionals involved with your care can provide encouragement and advice about how to mange your weight, build healthy lifestyle habits and maintain weight loss achieved.

【49】Completing a weight management programme, regularly monitoring your weight, setting realistic goals, and involving your friends and family with ways to lose weight can also help.

【50】It's important to remember that losing what seems like a small amount of weight, such as 3% or more of your original body weight, and maintaining this for life, can significantly reduce your risk of developing obesity-related complications like diabetes and heart disease.

【51】Information:

【52】### Social care and support guide

【53】If you:

【54】*   need help with day-to-day living because of illness or disability
*   care for someone regularly because they're ill, disabled or because of their age (including family members)

【55】Our guide to care and support explains your options and where you can get support.

【56】Couch to 5K
-----------

【57】If it's been a long time since you did any exercise, you should check out the Couch to 5K running plan.

【58】It consists of podcasts delivered over the course of 9 weeks and has been specifically designed for absolute beginners.

【59】To begin with, you start running for short periods of time, and as the plan progresses, gradually increase the amount.

【60】At the end of the 9 weeks, you should be able to run for 30 minutes non-stop, which for most people is around 5 kilometres (3.1 miles).

source_info.title: Sleepwalking
source_info.text:
【0】Sleepwalking
============

【1】**Sleepwalking is when someone walks or carries out complex activities while not fully awake.**

【2】It usually happens during a period of deep sleep. This peaks during the early part of the night, so sleepwalking tends to happen in the first few hours after falling asleep.

【3】Sleepwalking can start at any age but is more common in children. It's thought 1 in 5 children will sleepwalk at least once. Most grow out of it by the time they reach puberty, but it can sometimes persist into adulthood.

【4】Why some people sleepwalk
-------------------------

【5】The exact cause of sleepwalking is unknown, but it seems to run in families. You're more likely to sleepwalk if other members of your close family have or had sleepwalking behaviours or night terrors.

【6】The following things can trigger sleepwalking or make it worse:

【7】*   not getting enough sleep
*   stress and anxiety
*   infection with a high temperature, especially in children
*   drinking too much alcohol
*   taking drugs
*   certain types of medicine, such as some sedatives
*   being startled by a sudden noise or touch, causing abrupt waking from deep sleep
*   waking up suddenly from deep sleep because you need to go to the toilet

【8】Other sleep disorders that can cause you to frequently wake up suddenly during the night, such as obstructive sleep apnoea and restless legs syndrome, can also trigger a sleepwalking episode.

【9】Taking steps to prevent some of these triggers – such as making sure you get enough sleep, and working on strategies to deal with and reduce stress – will often help.

【10】What happens when a person sleepwalks
-------------------------------------

【11】In some episodes of sleepwalking, a person may just sit up in bed and look around, briefly appearing confused. Others may get out of bed and walk about, open cupboards, get dressed or eat, and they may appear agitated.

【12】In extreme cases, the person may walk out of the house and carry out complex activities, such as driving a car.

【13】The eyes are usually open while someone is sleepwalking, although the person will look straight through people and not recognise them. They can often move well around familiar objects.

【14】If you talk to a person who is sleepwalking, they may partially respond or say things that do not make sense.

【15】Most sleepwalking episodes last less than 10 minutes, but they can be longer. At the end of each episode, the person may wake up, or return to bed and go to sleep.

【16】They will not normally have any memory of it in the morning or may have patchy memory. If woken while sleepwalking, the person may feel confused and not remember what happened.

【17】What to do if you find someone sleepwalking
-------------------------------------------

【18】The best thing to do if you see someone sleepwalking is to make sure they're safe. If undisturbed, they will often go back to sleep again. Gently guide them back to bed by reassuring them.

【19】Do not shout or startle the person and do not try to physically restrain them unless they're in danger, as they may lash out.

【20】When to get medical advice
--------------------------

【21】Occasional sleepwalking episodes do not usually need medical attention. Sleepwalking is rarely a sign of anything serious and may get better with time, particularly in children.

【22】But, you should consider seeing a GP if sleepwalking happens frequently, you're concerned a person may be at risk of injuring themselves or others, or the episodes continue or start in adult life.

【23】The GP may refer you to a specialist sleep centre, where your or your child's sleep history can be discussed in more detail. If appropriate, sleep studies can be arranged to exclude other conditions that could be triggering the sleepwalking, such as obstructive sleep apnoea or restless legs syndrome.

【24】Treatments for sleepwalking
---------------------------

【25】There's no specific treatment for sleepwalking, but it generally helps to try to get enough sleep and have a regular and relaxing routine before bedtime. 

【26】You may find the following advice helpful:

【27】*   try to go to bed at a similar time each night
*   make sure your bedroom is dark and quiet when you go to sleep
*   limit drinks before bedtime, particularly ones containing caffeine, and go to the toilet before going to sleep
*   find ways to relax before going to bed, such as having a warm bath, reading or deep breathing
*   if your child sleepwalks at the same time most nights, try gently waking them for a short time 15 to 30 minutes before they would normally sleepwalk – this may stop them sleepwalking by altering their normal sleep cycle

【28】Read about sleep and young children.

【29】Medicine is not usually used to treat sleepwalking. However, medicines such as benzodiazepines or antidepressants are sometimes used if you sleepwalk often or there's a risk you could seriously injure yourself or others. These medicines can help you sleep and may reduce the frequency of sleepwalking episodes.

【30】Therapies such as cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) or hypnotherapy may sometimes be helpful.

【31】Preventing accidents
--------------------

【32】It's important to keep the areas of your home where a person may sleepwalk free of breakable or potentially harmful objects and to remove any items they could trip over. It's also a good idea to keep windows and doors locked.

【33】If your child sleepwalks, do not let them sleep on the top bed of a bunk bed. You may want to fit safety gates at the top of the stairs.

【34】It's also important to tell babysitters, relatives or friends who look after your child at night that your child may sleepwalk and what they should do if it happens.

source_info.title: Lumbar decompression surgery
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Lumbar decompression surgery
========================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  When it's used
3.  How it's performed
4.  Recovery
5.  Risks</u>

【2】**Lumbar decompression surgery is a type of surgery used to treat compressed nerves in the lower (lumbar) spine.**

【3】It's only recommended when non-surgical treatments haven't helped. 

【4】The surgery aims to improve symptoms such as persistent pain and numbness in the legs caused by pressure on the nerves in the spine.

【5】Lumbar decompression surgery is used to treat:

【6】*   **spinal stenosis** – narrowing of a section of the spinal column, which puts pressure on the nerves inside
*   **a** **slipped disc** and **sciatica** – where a damaged spinal disc presses down on an underlying nerve
*   **spinal injuries** – such as a fracture or the swelling of tissue
*   **metastatic spinal cord compression** – where cancer in one part of the body, such as the lungs, spreads into the spine and presses on the spinal cord or nerves

【7】What happens during lumbar decompression surgery
------------------------------------------------

【8】If lumbar decompression surgery is recommended, you'll usually have at least 1 of the following procedures:

【9】*   **laminectomy** – where a section of bone is removed from 1 of your vertebrae (spinal bones) to relieve pressure on the affected nerve
*   **discectomy** – where a section of a damaged disc is removed to relieve pressure on a nerve
*   **spinal fusion** – where 2 or more vertebrae are joined together with a section of bone to stabilise and strengthen the spine

【10】In many cases, a combination of these techniques may be used.

【11】Lumbar decompression is usually carried out under general anaesthetic, which means you'll be unconscious during the procedure and won't feel any pain as it's carried out. The whole operation usually takes at least an hour, but may take much longer, depending on the complexity of the procedure.

【12】Recovering from lumbar decompression surgery
--------------------------------------------

【13】You'll usually be well enough to leave hospital about 1 to 4 days after having surgery, depending on the complexity of the surgery and your level of mobility before the operation.

【14】Most people are able to walk unassisted within a day of having the operation, although more strenuous activities will need to be avoided for about 6 weeks.

【15】You may be able to return to work after about 4 to 6 weeks, although you may need more time off if your job involves driving for long periods or lifting heavy objects.

【16】Effectiveness of lumbar decompression surgery
---------------------------------------------

【17】There's good evidence that decompression surgery can be an effective treatment for people with severe pain caused by compressed nerves. 

【18】Many people who have the operation experience a significant improvement in pain. People who found walking difficult before surgery because of leg pain or weakness are often able to walk further and more easily after the operation.

【19】Risks of lumbar decompression surgery
-------------------------------------

【20】Although lumbar decompression is often successful, like all types of surgery it carries a risk of complications.

【21】Complications associated with lumbar decompression surgery include:

【22】*   infection at the site of the operation, or in rare cases an infection elsewhere
*   a blood clot developing in 1 of your leg veins, known as DVT (deep vein thrombosis); in rare cases, the clot can dislodge and travel to the lungs, causing a serious problem called a pulmonary embolism
*   damage to the spinal nerves or cord – resulting in continuing symptoms, numbness or weakness in 1 or both legs, or in rare cases some degree of paralysis

【23】Surgery tends to be safer if you do not smoke, have good general fitness and lose weight if needed.

【24】The spine and spinal cord
-------------------------

【25】The spine is made up of 33 segments, called vertebrae, which are stacked on top of each other to form the spinal column. In between each vertebra are protective, circular pads of tissue called discs, which cushion the vertebrae during activities such as walking and running.

【26】The spinal canal runs through the centre of the spinal column. It contains and protects the spinal cord and nerves.
删除3：<u>Video: lumbar surgery
---------------------

【27】In this video, an expert talks about what happens during lumbar surgery.
