source_info.title: Oxybutynin
source_info.text:
【0】Oxybutynin \- Brand names: Ditropan, Lyrinel, Kentera
=====================================================
删除10：<u>On this page
------------

【1】1.  About oxybutynin
2.  Key facts
3.  Who can and cannot take oxybutynin
4.  How and when to take oxybutynin
5.  Side effects
6.  How to cope with side effects of oxybutynin
7.  Pregnancy and breastfeeding
8.  Cautions with other medicines
9.  Common questions about oxybutynin</u>

【2】1\. About oxybutynin
--------------------

【3】Oxybutynin is a medicine used to treat symptoms of an overactive bladder. These can include:

【4】*   a sudden and urgent need to pee (urinary urgency)
*   needing to pee more often than usual (urinary frequency)
*   wetting yourself if you cannot make it to the loo in time (urinary incontinence)

【5】It's also used to treat bedwetting in children (nocturnal enuresis).

【6】Oxybutynin works by relaxing the muscles around your bladder. This means your bladder can hold more liquid and you do not need to pee as often or as urgently.

【7】Oxybutynin is only available on prescription.

【8】It comes as standard tablets for immediate release, or slow-release tablets (also called prolonged release), a liquid to swallow, or as patches.

【9】2\. Key facts
-------------

【10】*   Oxybutynin may take up to 4 weeks to reach its full effect. If the symptoms do not improve after 1 to 2 weeks, talk to your doctor.
*   Your doctor will do a review after 4 weeks to check oxybutynin is still working and is the best treatment for you.
*   Your doctor will also check that your treatment is still needed every 6 to 12 months .
*   Common side effects of oxybutynin include dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation and feeling dizzy or sleepy.
*   It's best not to drink alcohol when you first start taking oxybutynin, as it can make you very sleepy.

【11】3\. Who can and cannot take oxybutynin
--------------------------------------

【12】Oxybutynin can be taken by adults and children aged 5 years or over.

【13】Oxybutynin is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell your doctor before starting oxybutynin if you have:

【14】*   ever had an allergic reaction to oxybutynin, any of its ingredients or any other medicine
*   myasthenia gravis, a rare long-term condition that causes muscle weakness
*   an eye problem called glaucoma
*   difficulty peeing, or an enlarged prostate
*   ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease
*   heart problems, including a very fast heart rate or high blood pressure
*   thyroid, kidney or liver problems

【15】4\. How and when to take oxybutynin
-----------------------------------

【16】Always read the information that comes with your medicine.

【17】### Dosage and strength of standard tablets

【18】Standard tablets come as either 2.5mg, 3mg or 5mg.

【19】The usual starting dose of 2.5mg is 1 tablet, taken twice a day, in the morning or evening, or 1 tablet, taken 3 times a day.

【20】If you take 3 doses a day, space each dose evenly throughout the day. You could take it first thing in the morning, in the middle of the afternoon and at bedtime.

【21】### Dosage and strength of slow-release tablets

【22】Slow-release tablets come in 2 strengths, 5mg and 10mg. The usual starting dose is 5mg once a day.

【23】### Dosage and strength of liquid

【24】Oxybutynin is available as a liquid for children and people who find it difficult to swallow tablets. It comes in 2 strengths:

【25】*   2.5mg of oxybutynin in a 5ml spoonful
*   5mg in oxybutynin in a 5ml spoonful

【26】The usual starting dose for an adult is 5mg, taken twice a day (12 hours apart), or 5mg, taken 3 times a day.

【27】The dose will usually be lower for adults over 65 and children.

【28】If you take 3 doses a day, space each dose evenly throughout the day. You could take it first thing in the morning, in the middle of the afternoon and at bedtime.

【29】### How to take standard tablets

【30】Swallow the tablets whole with a drink of water. You can take tablets with or without food.

【31】### How to take slow-release tablets

【32】Slow-release tablets release oxybutynin slowly and evenly throughout the day.

【33】Swallow these tablets whole with a drink of water. Do not break, crush or chew them.

【34】Try to take your tablet at the same time each day. This will help you to remember to take them.

【35】Part of the tablet can pass through your body and you might see it in your poo. Do not worry, this is normal and does not affect the way the medicine works.

【36】### How to take liquid

【37】If you are giving this medicine to a child to help stop them wetting the bed, give the last dose just before bedtime.

【38】Oxybutynin liquid will come with a plastic syringe or spoon to help you measure out the right dose. If you do not have one, ask your pharmacist for one. Do not use a kitchen teaspoon as it will not give the right amount of medicine.

【39】### How to use patches

【40】Oxybutynin patches are applied twice a week.

【41】They work like a plaster. you stick them to your skin.

【42】1.  Follow the instructions that come with the patches.
2.  Stick a patch to clean, dry skin on your stomach, hip or bottom twice a week (every 3 or 4 days).
3.  Change the patch on the same 2 days every week, such as every Sunday and Wednesday, or Monday and Thursday.
4.  Remove the old patch before sticking on the new one.
5.  Stick the new patch to a different area of your stomach, hips or bottom. Using the same area may irritate your skin. Do not stick the patch in the same place for at least 1 week.

【43】### Will my dose go up or down?

【44】Your doctor may increase your dose depending on how the medicine works for you.

【45】### What if I forget to take it?

【46】If you forget to take a dose, take it as soon as you remember, unless it's almost time for your next dose. In this case, just skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time.

【47】Never take 2 doses at the same time. Never take an extra dose to make up for a forgotten one.

【48】If you often forget doses, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to remember to take your medicine.

【49】### What if I take too much?

【50】Taking 1 extra dose of oxybutynin is unlikely to harm you.

【51】However, you may get more side effects, such as a dry mouth or headache.

【52】The amount of oxybutynin that can lead to an overdose varies from person to person, and too much oxybutynin can be dangerous.

【53】#### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【54】You take 2 or more extra doses of oxybutynin and you:

【55】*   have hallucinations
*   feel very restless or excited
*   have dilated pupils in your eyes
*   are not able to pee

【56】Call 111 or go to 111.nhs.uk

【57】If you need to go to hospital, do not drive yourself. Get someone else to drive you, or to call you an ambulance.

【58】Take the oxybutynin packet with you, or the leaflet inside it, plus any remaining medicine.

【59】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E if:

【60】You take more than your usual dose of oxybutynin and you have:

【61】*   a fast heartbeat
*   breathing problems

【62】5\. Side effects
----------------

【63】Like all medicines, oxybutynin can cause side effects, but not everyone gets them.

【64】Keep taking oxybutynin, but talk to your doctor or pharmacist if these side effects bother you or do not go away, or if you notice any other possible side effects.

【65】### Common side effects of oxybutynin

【66】These common side effects of oxybutynin may affect more than 1 in 100 people:

【67】*   dry mouth
*   headache
*   feeling dizzy, sleepy, or a spinning sensation (vertigo)
*   diarrhoea or being sick (vomiting)
*   constipation
*   farting and burping (wind)
*   stomach pain
*   dry eyes
*   blurred vision
*   problems or pain when peeing, and not being able to empty your bladder

【68】### Serious side effects

【69】Serious side effects are rare.

【70】Tell your doctor if you have:

【71】*   stomach pain (especially after meals), feeling sick or being sick, a persistent urge to poo, not being able to poo or you have runny poos – these are all signs of faecal impaction, where large, hardened poo gets stuck and you cannot push it out
*   difficulty fully emptying your bladder, or difficulty in starting to pee – these are signs of urinary retention, where pee builds up in your bladder because you're unable to pee
*   high temperature or chills, burning sensation when peeing, pain in your back or side, or bloody or cloudy pee – these can be signs of a severe urinary tract infection (UTI)
*   swollen ankles or legs (oedema) – where fluid builds up in your legs

【72】Do not take any more oxybutynin and call a doctor straight away if you feel you're overheating and not sweating when you're in hot surroundings.

【73】#### Serious allergic reaction

【74】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to oxybutynin.

【75】##### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【76】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【77】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【78】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【79】These are not all the side effects of oxybutynin. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicines packet.
删除5：<u>Information:

【80】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.
删除12：<u>Visit Yellow Card for further information.</u></u>

【81】6\. How to cope with side effects of oxybutynin
-----------------------------------------------

【82】**What to do about:**

【83】*   **dry mouth** – try sugar-free gum or having sugar-free sweets. Having a dry mouth can cause tooth decay or a fungal infection. It also might stop medicine that you put under your tongue from dissolving properly, such as medicine for angina.
*   **headaches** – make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Avoid alcohol. Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller. Talk to your doctor if your headache is severe or lasts longer than 1 or 2 days.
*   **feeling dizzy, sleepy or a spinning sensation** – do not drive, cycle, use tools, or operate machinery. Avoid drinking alcohol, as this may make your symptoms worse. Talk to your doctor if the dizziness or sleepiness bothers you or lasts more than a few days.
*   **diarrhoea or being sick** – drink lots of fluids, such as water or squash, to avoid dehydration. Take small, frequent sips if you're being sick. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee. Do not take any other medicines without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor, if the effects last more than 1 or 2 days.
*   **constipation** – eat more high-fibre foods, such as fresh fruit and vegetables and cereals, and drink plenty of water. Try to exercise more regularly, for example, by going for a daily walk or run. If this does not help, talk to a pharmacist or doctor. Watch this short video about how to treat constipation.
*   **farting and burping** – eat less foods that cause wind, like lentils, peas, beans and onions. It might also help to eat smaller and more frequent meals, eat and drink slowly, and exercise regularly. Ask your pharmacist about remedies you can buy to help with trapped wind.
*   **stomach pain** – try to rest and relax. It can help to eat and drink slowly and have smaller and more frequent meals. Try putting a heat pad or a covered hot water bottle on your stomach to help. If you have episodes of severe, griping pain, speak to your pharmacist or doctor.
*   **dry eyes** – ask your pharmacist or optician to recommend some eye drops. If you wear contact lenses and these become uncomfortable, you might have to wear glasses instead while you're taking this medicine.
*   **blurred vision** – do not drive or cycle until you can see clearly again. Do not take your next dose of oxybutynin if your vision is still blurred. Speak to your doctor or pharmacist if your vision has not returned to normal a day after taking your last dose.
*   **problems or pain when peeing** – try to relax when you pee. Do not try to force the flow of urine. If it does not happen, try again later. Talk to a doctor urgently if you cannot pee at all.

【84】7\. Pregnancy and breastfeeding
-------------------------------

【85】### Oxybutynin and pregnancy

【86】Oxybutynin is occasionally used in pregnancy when bladder symptoms are severe and cannot be controlled any other way.

【87】If you're pregnant or trying to get pregnant, talk to your doctor about whether taking oxybutynin is right for you.

【88】### Oxybutynin and breastfeeding

【89】Oxybutynin is not usually recommended while breastfeeding. However, you may still need to take it.

【90】It's not known how much oxybutynin gets into breast milk, but it's likely to be small.

【91】If your doctor says it's OK for you to keep taking oxybutynin, monitor your baby for possible side effects, such as constipation, peeing less and colic.

【92】Talk to your doctor, midwife, or health visitor if you have any concerns about your baby, or you do not think your baby is putting on enough weight.

【93】### Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:

【94】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【95】通用删除3(英):<u>For more information about treating bladder problems (urinary incontinence) during pregnancy, read this leaflet on the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPs) website.</u>

【96】8\. Cautions with other medicines
---------------------------------

【97】Oxybutynin may affect the way other medicines work, and other medicines may affect how oxybutynin works.

【98】Tell your pharmacist or doctor if you're taking:

【99】*   amantadine, a medicine used for Parkinson's disease or for infections
*   levodopa, used to treat Parkinson's disease
*   phenothiazines, clozapine, haloperidol or benperidol, medicines for mental health problems
*   donepezil, rivastigmine, galantamine or tacrine, medicines used for dementia
*   amitriptyline, imipramine or dosulepin (tricyclic antidepressants), medicines for depression
*   medicines used to make you feel sleepy (sedatives)
*   anti-sickness medicines like prochlorperazine
*   medicines for stomach and bowel-related problems like domperidone and metoclopramide
*   digoxin, quinidine or disopyramide, medicines used to treat heart problems
*   dipyridamole, used to treat blood problems
*   chlorphenamine or diphenhydramine, medicines used to treat allergies
*   any medicines used to treat irritable bowel syndrome, asthma, incontinence, motion sickness or movement disorders related to Parkinson's disease, that work in a similar way to oxybutynin

【100】### Mixing oxybutynin with herbal remedies and supplements

【101】There's very little information about taking oxybutynin with herbal remedies and supplements. These remedies are not tested in the same way as medicines.

【102】Some herbal medicines can make you feel sleepy, cause a dry mouth, or make it difficult to pee. Their effect is similar to oxybutynin. This can increase your risk of getting side effects or make your side effects worse.

【103】### Important: Medicine safety

【104】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal medicines, vitamins or supplements.

【105】9\. Common questions about oxybutynin
-------------------------------------

【106】How does oxybutynin work?

【107】Oxybutynin is a type of medicine called an antimuscarinic (or anticholinergic) muscle relaxant.

【108】It works by relaxing the muscle that is found in the wall of the bladder. This helps to increase the volume of pee your bladder can hold and control the release of pee.

【109】How long does it take to work?

【110】Oxybutynin starts to work after about 3 to 4 hours to relax the muscle surrounding your bladder.

【111】However it may take up to 4 weeks before it works fully.

【112】If your symptoms do not start to get better after 7 days talk to your doctor.

【113】Talk to your doctor if your symptoms get worse at any time.

【114】How long will I take it for?

【115】Usually, you'll need to take oxybutynin for a long time.

【116】After 4 weeks your doctor will check that oxybutynin is helping your symptoms. They'll also do a review every 6 to 12 months after that to check it's still working for you.

【117】Take oxybutynin until your doctor tells you to stop. Do not stop taking it just because you feel better.

【118】Is it safe to take for a long time?

【119】There may be an increased risk of confusion and possibly dementia in people taking oxybutynin, but more study needs to be done. If you're worried about this, talk to your doctor.

【120】Do not take oxybutynin for longer than you need to. Your doctor will check every 6 to 12 months that your treatment is still needed.

【121】Is it safe to take with painkillers?

【122】It's safe to take oxybutynin with everyday painkillers like paracetamol and ibuprofen.

【123】What will happen if I stop taking it?

【124】If you've been taking oxybutynin for at least 6 months your doctor may suggest that you stop taking the medicine for up to 4 weeks to see how your symptoms change without it.

【125】Some people find that the improvement in their symptoms continues after the medicine has been stopped. Talk to your doctor if you're thinking about stopping your medicine.

【126】Do not stop taking oxybutynin without talking to your doctor first.

【127】Are there other medicines for urinary incontinence and overactive bladder?

【128】Oxybutynin belongs to a group of medicines called antimuscarinics. There are other antimuscarinics that can be used for overactive bladder:

【129】*   solifenacin
*   tolterodine
*   darifenacin
*   fesoterodine
*   propiverine
*   trospium

【130】They all seem to work just as well as oxybutynin. However, if you get side effects with one antimuscarinic a different one may suit you better.

【131】If antimuscarinics are unsuitable for you, they have not helped your overactive bladder, or you have had side effects, you may be offered a medicine called mirabegron, which works in a slightly different way.

【132】Can I drink alcohol with it?

【133】Try to avoid drinking alcohol when you first start taking oxybutynin, or if your dose is increased, to see how you feel. Oxybutynin combined with alcohol can make you feel very sleepy.

【134】Drinking alcohol may make you more likely to need to get up in the night to pee.

【135】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【136】You can eat normally while taking oxybutynin. If you have urinary incontinence, cut down on alcohol and drinks containing caffeine, such as tea, coffee and cola.

【137】Will I gain or lose weight?

【138】Oxybutynin can make you feel less hungry, so you may lose weight.

【139】If you start to have problems with your weight while taking oxybutynin, talk to your doctor or pharmacist.

【140】Will it affect my contraception?

【141】Oxybutynin does not stop contraceptive pills working, including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【142】However, if oxybutynin makes you sick or have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy. Look on the pill packet to find out what to do.
删除7：<u>Read more about what to do if you're on the pill and you're being sick or have diarrhoea.</u>

【143】Will it affect my fertility?

【144】There's no clear evidence to suggest that taking oxybutynin will reduce fertility in either men or women.

【145】However, speak to a pharmacist or your doctor before taking it if you're trying to get pregnant.

【146】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【147】Do not drive a car, ride a bike, use tools or operate machinery if oxybutynin makes you sleepy, gives you blurred vision, or makes you feel dizzy, clumsy or unable to concentrate or make decisions.

【148】This may be more likely when you first start taking it, but it could happen at any time, such as when you increase the dose or start another medicine.

【149】Talk to a doctor or pharmacist if you're not sure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking oxybutynin.

【150】Are there lifestyle changes that can help overactive bladder?

【151】There are a number of lifestyle changes that may help your symptoms. It's a good idea to:

【152】*   cut back on drinks that contain caffeine, such as tea, coffee and cola, as caffeine can increase how much you pee
*   not drink too much or too little fluid during the day, as this can make incontinence worse
*   lose weight if you are overweight or obese, as being overweight can increase your risk of urinary incontinence – use the BMI healthy weight calculator to find out if you're a healthy weight for your height
*   try pelvic floor muscle training (Kegel exercises)
*   try bladder training
*   discuss other options for urinary incontinence with your doctor, such as surgery and procedures
删除11：<u>Related conditions
------------------

【153】*   Urinary incontinence
</u>删除11：<u>Useful resources
----------------

【154】*   HealthUnlocked: oxybutynin forum
*   Bladder & Bowel UK: charity
*   Medicines for Children: charity

source_info.title: Heat exhaustion and heatstroke
source_info.text:
【0】Heat exhaustion and heatstroke
==============================

【1】**Heat exhaustion does not usually need emergency medical help if you can cool down within 30 minutes. If it turns into heatstroke, it needs to be treated as an emergency.**

【2】Check for signs of heat exhaustion
----------------------------------

【3】The signs of heat exhaustion include:

【4】*   tiredness
*   dizziness
*   headache
*   feeling sick or being sick
*   excessive sweating and skin becoming pale and clammy or getting a heat rash, but a change in skin colour can be harder to see on brown and black skin
*   cramps in the arms, legs and stomach
*   fast breathing or heartbeat
*   a high temperature
*   being very thirsty
*   weakness

【5】The symptoms of heat exhaustion are often the same in adults and children, although children may become irritable too.

【6】If someone is showing signs of heat exhaustion they need to be cooled down and given fluids.

【7】Things you can do to cool someone down
--------------------------------------

【8】If someone has heat exhaustion, follow these 4 steps:

【9】1.  Move them to a cool place.
2.  Remove all unnecessary clothing like a jacket or socks.
3.  Get them to drink a sports or rehydration drink, or cool water.
4.  Cool their skin – spray or sponge them with cool water and fan them. Cold packs, wrapped in a cloth and put under the armpits or on the neck are good too.

【10】Stay with them until they're better.

【11】They should start to cool down and feel better within 30 minutes.

【12】Urgent advice: Contact 111 if:
------------------------------

【13】*   you or someone else have symptoms of heat exhaustion that you're struggling to treat or you need advice about

【14】You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.

【15】Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:
-------------------------------------------

【16】You or someone else have signs of heatstroke, including:

【17】*   still unwell after 30 minutes of resting in a cool place, being cooled and drinking fluids
*   a very high temperature
*   hot skin that's not sweating and might look red (this can be harder to see on brown and black skin)
*   a fast heartbeat
*   fast breathing or shortness of breath
*   confusion and lack of coordination
*   a seizure or fit
*   loss of consciousness

【18】Put the person in the recovery position if they lose consciousness while you're waiting for help.

【19】Preventing heat exhaustion and heatstroke
-----------------------------------------

【20】There's a high risk of heat exhaustion or heatstroke during hot weather or exercise.

【21】To help prevent heat exhaustion or heatstroke:

【22】*   drink more cold drinks, especially if you're active or exercising
*   wear light-coloured, loose clothing
*   avoid the sun between 11am and 3pm
*   avoid excess alcohol
*   avoid extreme exercise
*   if you're inside on a very hot day, close curtains, close windows if it's hotter outside than in your home and turn off electrical equipment and lights that get hot

【23】This will also prevent dehydration and help your body keep itself cool.

【24】Children, older people and people with long-term health conditions (such as diabetes or heart problems) are more at risk of heat exhaustion or heatstroke.
删除7：<u>Read more about what do to and how to cope in hot weather.</u>

【25】Find out about dehydration
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 12 August 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 12 August 2025</u>

source_info.title: What should I do if I think I've got an STI?
source_info.text:
【0】What should I do if I think I've got an STI?
============================================

【1】If you think you may have a sexually transmitted infection (STI), go to your GP or local sexual health or genitourinary medicine (GUM) clinic.

【2】Most STIs can be successfully treated, but it's important to get any symptoms checked as soon as possible.

【3】Read about visiting an STI clinic.

【4】Sexually transmitted infections (STIs)
--------------------------------------

【5】STIs are infections that are passed on through unprotected sex (not using a condom) or genital contact.

【6】They include:

【7】*   chlamydia
*   genital warts
*   genital herpes
*   gonorrhoea
*   HIV
*   pubic lice
*   syphilis

【8】When should I go to a sexual health or GUM clinic?
--------------------------------------------------

【9】Go to a sexual health or GUM clinic if you have any of the symptoms listed below.

【10】In women:

【11】*   yellow or green discharge from your vagina, or discharge that smells
*   bleeding during or after sex
*   bleeding between periods
*   pain during sex
*   pain in your lower abdomen

【12】In men:

【13】*   discharge from your penis
*   pain in your testicles

【14】In women and men:

【15】*   pain when passing urine
*   itching, burning or tingling around your genitals
*   blisters, sores, spots or lumps around your genitals or anus
*   black powder or tiny white dots in your underwear (this could be droppings or eggs from pubic lice)

【16】Some GP practices, pharmacies, contraception clinics and young people's services may also provide testing for some STIs.

【17】Not everyone with an STI has symptoms. You should get checked if:

【18】*   you have had unprotected sex with a new partner
*   you or your sexual partner have had sex with someone else without using a condom
*   your sexual partner has any symptoms
*   you're planning to get pregnant and may have been at risk of infection
删除6：<u>Further information
-------------------

【19】*   How soon do STI symptoms appear?
*   What services do sexual health clinics (GUM clinics) provide?
*   What infections can I catch through oral sex?
*   Why is my penis smelly and sore?
*   Sexwise: sexually transmitted infections
</u>
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 30 April 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 30 April 2024</u>

source_info.title: Having an operation (surgery)
source_info.text:
【0】After surgery \- Having an operation (surgery)
==============================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Seeing a specialist
3.  Before surgery
4.  On the day
5.  After surgery
6.  Getting back to normal</u>

【2】**After surgery, you'll be moved back to the ward (after local anaesthetic) or a recovery room (after general anaesthetic or an epidural), where you'll be told how the operation went.**

【3】You may feel hazy or groggy as you come round from the general anaesthetic. A nurse may give you oxygen (through tubes in your nose or a mask) to help you feel better.

【4】It's common to feel sick or vomit after you've been given general anaesthesia. Your nurse may offer you medicine to help with sickness. You may also have a sore throat and dry mouth.

【5】Your blood pressure will be taken regularly. This will either be done by a nurse, or by using an automatic cuff that squeezes tightly at regular times. Your temperature will also be taken.

【6】The outcome of your operation
-----------------------------

【7】It's important to find out how your operation went.

【8】Here are some questions you may want to ask:

【9】*   Was the operation as successful as expected?
*   What effect has the operation had on my condition?
*   How will I expect to feel when I get home?
*   How long will it be before I'm back to normal?

【10】Coping with pain
----------------

【11】You'll always have some pain after having surgery. Tell your nurse as soon as you start to feel any pain so they can give you painkilling medicine as soon as possible.

【12】This will stop it getting worse (medicine can take 20 minutes to start working) and improve it.

【13】Avoiding blood clots
--------------------

【14】The sooner you start to move around, the better. Lying in bed for too long can cause some of your blood to pool in your legs. This puts you at risk of a blood clot.

【15】If possible, doing some leg exercises can help prevent a blood clot. These may be as simple as flexing your knees or ankles and rotating your feet.

【16】You may be given special support stockings to wear after surgery to help your blood circulation. Your nurse or doctor will explain how you should use these.

【17】Some people are given an injection to thin the blood slightly to help reduce the risk of clots.

【18】Enhanced recovery
-----------------

【19】Research shows the earlier you get out of bed and start walking, eating and drinking after your operation, the better.

【20】Your hospital may offer an enhanced recovery programme if you have had major surgery. This rehabilitation programme aims to get you back to full health quickly.

【21】Plan for your days after surgery
--------------------------------

【22】It's important to arrange for appropriate care after your operation. For older people, it's important to arrange for suitable equipment and care.

【23】You should not be afraid to ask for things that may help you, such as a wheelchair or walking frame.

【24】It's a good idea to have an adult available to help you for at least 24 hours after having a general anaesthetic or an epidural.

【25】Discharge from hospital
-----------------------

【26】Before you leave hospital, you may (depending on the type of operation you had) have an appointment with a physiotherapist. They'll be able to advise you about any exercises you need to carry out.

【27】You'll also be given advice about how to care for your wound, any equipment you may require, such as dressings, bandages, crutches and splints, and maybe painkillers.

【28】Each hospital will have its own policy and arrangements for sending patients home (discharge).

【29】Your discharge will be affected by:

【30】*   how quickly your health improves while you're in hospital
*   what support you'll need after you return home

【31】You may want to ask some questions before you leave hospital, such as:

【32】*   Who should I call if I have any concerns once I'm home?
*   What should I be trying to do on my own – for example, going to the bathroom and getting out of bed?
*   Is there anything I should avoid doing?
*   When can I go back to work?
*   How much pain, bruising or swelling should I expect when I get home?
*   When and where will any stitches be removed?
*   Do I need to return to hospital or my GP for follow-up? If so, when will this be?
删除7：<u>Read more about being discharged from hospital.</u>

【33】Transport home
--------------

【34】You will not usually be able to drive yourself home after surgery. Instead, you could ask someone to pick you up or take you home in a taxi.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 03 September 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 03 September 2024</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : On the day</u>删除1：<u>*   Next : Getting back to normal</u>

source_info.title: Metoprolol
source_info.text:
【0】Taking metoprolol with other medicines and herbal supplements
=============================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】There are some medicines that may affect the way metoprolol works.

【3】Tell your doctor if you're taking:

【4】*   other medicines for high blood pressure (hypertension) – the combination with metoprolol can sometimes lower your blood pressure too much, which may make you feel dizzy or faint. Tell your doctor if this keeps happening as they may change your dose
*   other medicines that can lower your blood pressure and cause hypotension – these include some antidepressants, nitrates (for chest pain), baclofen (a muscle relaxant), tamsulosin (for an enlarged prostate), and co-careldopa and levodopa (for Parkinson's disease)
*   non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen – these medicines may increase your blood pressure, so it's best to keep them to a minimum
*   cough medicines that contain pseudoephedrine or xylometazoline
*   medicines for diabetes – metoprolol may make it more difficult to recognise the warning signs of low blood sugar
*   medicines for allergies – such as ephedrine, noradrenaline or adrenaline
*   medicines for asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

【5】Mixing metoprolol with herbal remedies and supplements
------------------------------------------------------

【6】There's not enough information to say that herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with metoprolol. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【7】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【8】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.
删除11：<u>More in Metoprolol
------------------

【9】*   About metoprolol
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking metoprolol with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 9 March 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 9 March 2025</u>

source_info.title: Molnupiravir (Lagevrio)
source_info.text:
【0】Taking molnupiravir with other medicines and herbal supplements
===============================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】There is no evidence to say that molnupiravir will affect any other medicine you are taking. If you are taking medicines for other conditions, it's important to keep taking them.

【3】Talk to your doctor if you're worried about taking other medicines with molnupiravir.

【4】Molnupiravir and coronavirus (COVID-19) vaccines
------------------------------------------------

【5】There's no evidence that molnupiravir affects the COVID-19 vaccine.

【6】COVID-19 treatments do not replace vaccinations. Vaccines are given to help your immune system fight a future COVID-19 infection.

【7】The COVID-19 vaccine is not recommended within 4 weeks of having COVID-19.

【8】Mixing molnupiravir with herbal remedies and supplements
--------------------------------------------------------

【9】There's not enough information to say that herbal remedies or supplements are safe to take with molnupiravir.

【10】They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【11】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【12】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.
删除11：<u>More in Molnupiravir (Lagevrio)
-------------------------------

【13】*   About molnupiravir
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking molnupiravir with other medicines and herbal supplements

source_info.title: Guillain-Barré syndrome
source_info.text:
【0】Causes \- Guillain-Barré syndrome
=================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Recovery</u>

【2】**Guillain-Barré syndrome is thought to be caused by a problem with the immune system, the body's natural defence against illness and infection.**

【3】Normally the immune system attacks any germs that get into the body. But in people with Guillain-Barré syndrome, something goes wrong and it mistakenly attacks the nerves.

【4】This damages the nerves and stops signals from the brain travelling along them properly, which can cause problems such as numbness, weakness and pain in the limbs.

【5】It's not clear exactly why this happens. The condition is not passed from person to person and is not inherited.

【6】Possible triggers
-----------------

【7】Sometimes Guillain-Barré syndrome appears to have a particular trigger. These are some of the main triggers.

【8】### Infections

【9】In most cases, Guillain-Barré syndrome occurs a few days or weeks after an infection.

【10】Infections that have been known to trigger the condition include:

【11】*   food poisoning – especially if caused by Campylobacter bacteria
*   flu
*   cytomegalovirus – a common virus that does not usually cause any symptoms
*   glandular fever
*   HIV
*   some tropical diseases, including dengue and the Zika virus

【12】### Vaccinations

【13】In the past, vaccinations (particularly the flu vaccine used in the US during a swine flu outbreak in 1976) were linked to an increased risk of Guillain-Barré syndrome.

【14】But research has since found the chances of developing the condition after having a vaccination are extremely small.

【15】For example, a study into the vaccine used during the 2009 swine flu outbreak found that for every million people who had the vaccination, there were fewer than 2 extra cases of Guillain-Barré syndrome.

【16】And evidence suggests that you are far more likely to get Guillain-Barré syndrome from an infection, such as the flu, than the vaccine designed to prevent the infection, such as the flu jab.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 02 May 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 02 May 2026</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Symptoms</u>删除1：<u>*   Next : Diagnosis</u>

source_info.title: Anticoagulant medicines
source_info.text:
【0】Considerations \- Anticoagulant medicines
=========================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Uses
3.  Dosage
4.  Considerations
5.  Side effects</u>

【2】**If you're prescribed anticoagulants, always follow the instructions of your GP or another healthcare professional.**

【3】Some of the main issues you'll need to consider while taking your medicine are outlined below.

【4】Having surgery
--------------

【5】If you're taking anticoagulants and you need to have surgery or any kind of invasive procedure, make sure that the healthcare professionals treating you are aware of your medicine.

【6】This includes procedures used to diagnose other conditions, such as an endoscopy or cystoscopy.

【7】As anticoagulants reduce the ability of your blood to clot, there's a risk you could experience heavy bleeding if any kind of cut (incision) is made during a procedure.

【8】You may therefore be advised to stop taking your medicine before surgery.

【9】If you're having a dental procedure, such as having a tooth removed, tell your dentist that you take anticoagulants.

【10】You may not need to stop taking your medicine, but you might need to have a blood test before the procedure to make sure your blood clots at the right speed.

【11】Only stop taking your medicine on the advice of your GP or another healthcare professional.

【12】Pregnancy
---------

【13】Warfarin isn't normally given to pregnant women because it can affect the unborn baby.

【14】It can cause birth defects or excessive bleeding from the placenta or foetus.

【15】It may sometimes be used in the second trimester, but should never be taken during the first trimester and should ideally be avoided in the third trimester as well.

【16】The newer anticoagulant medicines apixaban (Eliquis), dabigatran (Pradaxa), edoxaban (Lixiana) and rivaroxaban (Xarelto) also are not recommended in pregnancy.

【17】If you're taking any of these medicines, you should make sure you use contraception when having sex to avoid becoming pregnant.

【18】If you're on anticoagulants and find out you're pregnant or plan to start trying for a baby, speak to your GP or anticoagulant clinic about stopping or changing your prescription. 

【19】Injections of an anticoagulant called heparin can be given while you're pregnant if necessary.删除7：<u>Read more about heparin on the Electronic Medicines Compendium (EMC) website.</u>

【20】Breastfeeding
-------------

【21】You can usually take warfarin while you're breastfeeding, but you should discuss this with your GP or midwife first.

【22】Heparin is also safe to take while you're breastfeeding.

【23】Apixaban, dabigatran, edoxaban and rivaroxaban aren't recommended if you're breastfeeding because it's not clear if they're safe for the baby.

【24】If you're on anticoagulants and are breastfeeding or planning to breastfeed, speak to your GP, anticoagulant clinic or midwife to find out if you need to change your prescription.

【25】Avoiding injury
---------------

【26】Taking anticoagulant medicines can make you more prone to bleeding if you're injured.

【27】Try to avoid minor injuries and cuts and grazes by:

【28】*   taking care when brushing your teeth and shaving (consider using a soft toothbrush and an electric razor)
*   using insect repellent to avoid insect bites or stings
*   using protection when gardening, sewing or playing sports

【29】Your GP or anticoagulant clinic may advise you to avoid contact sports because of the risk of excessive bleeding.

【30】Other medicines and remedies
----------------------------

【31】If you're taking anticoagulants, you should speak to your GP, anticoagulant clinic or pharmacist before taking any other medicine, remedy or supplement.

【32】This includes prescription medicines, medicines bought over the counter without a prescription (such as aspirin), and any herbal remedies (such as St John's Wort).

【33】Some treatments can stop anticoagulants working or can increase the effect they have, which can be dangerous.

【34】Some of the medicines that can affect anticoagulants include certain:

【35】*   antibiotics
*   antidepressants
*   steroids (medicines used to reduce inflammation)
*   anticonvulsants (medicines used to treat epilepsy)
*   non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen (take paracetamol instead if you need pain relief)

【36】For a full list of medicines that you should avoid, check the patient information leaflet that comes with your medicine.

【37】Food and drink
--------------

【38】It's important to have a healthy, balanced diet that includes lots of fruit and vegetables if you're taking anticoagulants.

【39】But you should avoid making frequent changes to the amount of green vegetables you eat if you're taking warfarin.

【40】Foods with a lot of vitamin K, such as leafy green vegetables, chickpeas and liver, can interfere with how warfarin works.

【41】You can still include these in your diet while taking warfarin, as the clinic will adjust your dose accordingly, but it's important to be consistent in the amount you eat.

【42】Do not drink cranberry juice, grapefruit juice or pomegranate juice while you're taking warfarin. They can increase the blood-thinning effect of warfarin.

【43】You should also seek advice before taking supplements containing vitamin K.

【44】The effect of warfarin is also affected by alcohol. If you're taking warfarin, do not drink more than 1 or 2 alcoholic drinks a day and never binge drink.

【45】These food and drink restrictions don't usually apply if you're taking apixaban, dabigatran, edoxaban or rivaroxaban, but you should check with your GP, anticoagulant clinic or pharmacist if you're not sure.

source_info.title: Barium enema
source_info.text:
【0】Barium enema
============

【1】**A barium enema is a test that helps to highlight the large bowel so it can be clearly seen on an** **X-ray****.**

【2】During the test, a white liquid called barium is passed into your bowel through your bottom.

【3】A barium enema may be requested by any doctor who thinks you might have a problem with your bowel, including your GP.

【4】The test will usually be carried out at a hospital radiology department by a radiologist or radiographer.

【5】When barium enemas are used
---------------------------

【6】Nowadays, barium enemas aren't carried out very often, as alternative tests such as a colonoscopy or CT scan are usually preferred.

【7】But a barium enema can sometimes be a useful way of finding the cause of problems like blood in your stools or a constant change in your bowel habits.

【8】Conditions that can be detected during a barium enema include:

【9】*   bowel cancer
*   growths in the bowel (bowel polyps)
*   inflammation of the bowel (ulcerative colitis) or Crohn's disease
*   pouches in the bowel (diverticular disease)

【10】Preparing for a barium enema
----------------------------

【11】To ensure the X-ray images taken during a barium enema are clear, your bowel must be empty before the test.

【12】The hospital should send you instructions on what you need to do to prepare.

【13】You'll normally be asked to:

【14】*   eat a light diet – for a few days leading up to the test, only eat low-fibre foods such as clear soup, white bread and lean meat
*   take laxatives – you'll be given medication that makes you empty your bowels frequently to take from the day before the test
*   drink plenty of fluids – this will help to replace the fluids you lose each time you empty your bowels

【15】It's usually a good idea to stay at home the day before the test, as the laxative medication will make you go to the toilet frequently.

【16】Contact the hospital as soon as you receive your appointment letter if you have diabetes or are pregnant (or think you could be pregnant).

【17】Barium enemas aren't done during pregnancy because the X-rays may harm the baby.

【18】If you have diabetes, you'll need to follow special instructions to ensure your blood sugar level is kept under control.

【19】Having a barium enema
---------------------

【20】When you arrive at hospital, you'll be asked to change into a hospital gown.

【21】You can take someone with you to the hospital, but they're not usually allowed into the X-ray room.

【22】During the test:

【23】*   you'll be asked to lie on your side on an X-ray table, and an injection of a medication called Buscopan may be given into your arm or hand to prevent involuntary bowel movements
*   a small, soft tube will be gently inserted a few centimetres into your bottom, where it will remain throughout the test
*   the barium is passed through the tube and into your bowel – try to keep the muscles in your bottom tight to prevent it coming back out, but don't worry if some leaks out
*   you may be asked to move around a bit to help the barium spread along your bowel, and air may be pumped into your bowel to expand it and help push the barium around
*   several X-rays will be taken with you in different positions

【24】The whole process usually takes around 30 to 45 minutes.

【25】What happens after a barium enema
---------------------------------

【26】When the test is finished, the tube will be removed from your bottom and you can go to the toilet to empty your bowels.

【27】You should be able to go home shortly afterwards, although it's a good idea to take things easy for a few hours before returning to your normal activities.

【28】If you had a Buscopan injection, your vision may be blurry for a short while afterwards, so you won't be able to drive. It's best to arrange for someone to drive you home.

【29】When you get home:

【30】*   stay close to a toilet for the next few hours, as you may find you need to empty your bowels quite often at first
*   your poo may be a whitish colour for a few days – this is normal and is just the remaining barium passing out of your body
*   you can eat and drink as normal – drink plenty of fluids and eat high-fibre foods for the first few days to help stop the barium causing constipation

【31】The X-ray images taken during the test will be analysed by a specialist. A report will be sent to the doctor who referred you for the test and you can discuss the results at your next appointment.

【32】Does a barium enema hurt?
-------------------------

【33】Having a barium enema may be a bit embarrassing and unpleasant, but it shouldn't be painful.

【34】You'll probably feel uncomfortable when the air is pumped into your bowel during the test, similar to the feeling of having trapped wind.

【35】You may have some bloating, wind or stomach cramps for a short while afterwards.

【36】Are there any risks or side effects?
------------------------------------

【37】A barium enema is generally a very safe procedure, although there a few risks and side effects that you should be aware of.

【38】These include:

【39】*   laxative side effects – side effects such as feeling sick, a mild headache and bloating are common, but shouldn't last long
*   barium side effects – barium is usually harmless, but it can cause an upset stomach or constipation, and can cause an allergic reaction in very rare cases
*   radiation exposure – you'll be exposed to a small amount of radiation during the test; this is about the equivalent to what you would receive naturally from the environment over 3 years (for more information, see GOV.UK: patient dose information)
*   bowel perforation – there's a risk of a small hole developing in your bowel as a result of the procedure, but this is very rare

【40】Your doctor can help you weigh up the risks of the procedure against the benefits of identifying any problem in your bowel.

source_info.title: Lidocaine for piles and itchy bottom
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while using lidocaine for piles and itchy bottom \- Brand names: Anusol, Boots Haemorrhoid, Germaloids, Perinal, Xylopract
=================================================================================================================================================================

【1】Lidocaine for piles and itchy bottom and pregnancy
--------------------------------------------------

【2】It's safe to use lidocaine treatments for piles and itchy bottom while you're pregnant.

【3】Lidocaine for piles and itchy bottom and breastfeeding
------------------------------------------------------

【4】Lidocaine is OK to use while breastfeeding. It is only likely to pass into breast milk in tiny amounts, which are very unlikely to cause side effects in your baby.

【5】Always wash your hands after using a lidocaine treatment and before picking up your baby.

【6】Some lidocaine treatments for piles and itchy bottom also contain other ingredients such as steroids. Steroids are also OK to use while breastfeeding for a short time. Always check the ingredients.

【7】Ask a pharmacist for advice if you have piles or an itchy bottom. They will be able to recommend the best treatment for you.

【8】Lidocaine for piles and itchy bottom and fertility
--------------------------------------------------

【9】There's no evidence to suggest that lidocaine treatments for piles and itchy bottom affect fertility in either men or women.

【10】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【11】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【12】通用删除3(英):<u>For more information about how treatment for piles such as lidocaine can affect you and your baby during pregnancy, visit the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website.</u>
删除7：<u>Find out more about piles in pregnancy.</u>
删除11：<u>More in Lidocaine for piles and itchy bottom
--------------------------------------------

source_info.title: Acute pancreatitis
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Acute pancreatitis
==============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications
7.  Prevention</u>

【2】**Acute pancreatitis is a condition where the pancreas becomes inflamed (swollen) over a short period of time.**

【3】The pancreas is a small organ, located behind the stomach, that helps with digestion.

【4】Most people with acute pancreatitis start to feel better within about a week and have no further problems. But some people with severe acute pancreatitis can go on to develop serious complications.

【5】Acute pancreatitis is different to chronic pancreatitis, where the pancreas has become permanently damaged from inflammation over many years.

【6】Symptoms of acute pancreatitis
------------------------------

【7】The most common symptoms of acute pancreatitis include:

【8】*   suddenly getting severe pain in the centre of your tummy (abdomen)
*   feeling or being sick
*   a high temperature of 38C or more (fever)
删除7：<u>Read more about the symptoms of acute pancreatitis and diagnosing acute pancreatitis.</u>

【9】When to get medical help
------------------------

【10】See a GP immediately if you suddenly develop severe abdominal pain. If this isn't possible, contact NHS 111 for advice.

【11】Causes of acute pancreatitis
----------------------------

【12】Acute pancreatitis is most often linked to:

【13】*   gallstones 
*   drinking too much alcohol

【14】But sometimes the cause is not known.

【15】By reducing how much alcohol you drink and altering your diet to make gallstones less likely, you can reduce your chances of developing acute pancreatitis.
删除7：<u>Read more about the causes of acute pancreatitis and preventing acute pancreatitis.</u>

【16】How it's treated
----------------

【17】Treatment for acute pancreatitis aims to help control the condition and manage any symptoms.

【18】This usually involves admission to hospital. You may be given fluids directly into a vein (intravenous fluids), pain relief, liquid food through a tube in your tummy and oxygen through tubes in your nose.

【19】Most people with acute pancreatitis get better within a week and are well enough to leave hospital after a few days.

【20】Recovery can take longer in severe cases, as some people can develop complications.
删除7：<u>Read more about treating acute pancreatitis and the possible complications of acute pancreatitis.</u>

source_info.title: Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP)
source_info.text:
【0】Recovery \- Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP)
==========================================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  How it's performed
3.  Recovery
4.  Risks
5.  Alternatives</u>

【2】**Following a transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), you may need to recover in hospital for1 to 3 days before you can go home.**

【3】While in hospital, you may be given fluids directly into a vein (intravenously) until you've recovered from the anaesthetic and are able to eat and drink.

【4】You shouldn't experience any severe pain, but there may be some discomfort and bladder spasms (contractions) from the catheter, which is left in place because your urethra (the tube that carries urine out of the body) will be swollen and sore.

【5】Before you're discharged, you'll be given advice about your recovery. A follow-up appointment to check your progress should be made for a few weeks later.

【6】Peeing after TURP
-----------------

【7】You won't be able to pee normally at first because your urethra will be swollen.

【8】The catheter used to flush out your bladder during the operation will be left in place for a while to allow you to pee until the swelling goes down.

【9】During the day after the operation, water may be pumped through the catheter to clean your bladder and get rid of any blood clots and other debris.

【10】This usually is not painful, but may make your bladder feel uncomfortably full.

【11】The catheter may be removed to check if you can pee before going home.

【12】It's normal to find peeing uncomfortable and difficult to control for at least a few days after the catheter is removed.

【13】If you still cannot pee, a catheter may need to be put back in.

【14】You'll be able to go home with the catheter still in place, and an appointment will be made to remove it a few days or weeks later. 

【15】See living with a urinary catheter for information about looking after your catheter.

【16】Recovering at home
------------------

【17】It's common to feel tired and under the weather for a week or two after having a TURP. Most men are up and about after 3 to 4 weeks recovery.

【18】For the first 3 to 4 weeks, you shouldn't lift or move any heavy objects (including shopping) or do any strenuous exercise. If possible, ask friends or family members if they can help around the house.

【19】Once you feel able, gentle exercise such as walking will help keep your blood circulating and lower your risk of getting a blood clot in your legs.

【20】Drinking plenty of water while you're recovering may help reduce the risk of getting a urinary tract infection (UTI) and can help clear any blood from your pee.

【21】You may also be advised to do some pelvic floor exercises to help improve your bladder control.

【22】Any pain can usually be treated by taking over-the-counter painkillers, such as paracetamol or ibuprofen.

【23】Returning to your normal activities
-----------------------------------

【24】It usually takes between 3 and 4 weeks to fully recover from a TURP. Your surgeon or GP will advise you about when it's safe to return to your normal activities.

【25】### Work

【26】When you can return to work will largely depend on your job. For example, someone who works in an office may be able to return to work sooner than someone who does heavy manual work.

【27】In most cases, you'll be advised to take around 3 or 4 weeks off work.

【28】### Driving

【29】Ask your surgeon or GP for advice on when it's safe for you to drive again.

【30】You should also speak to your insurer before driving again after having surgery.

【31】### Having sex

【32】It will probably be around 3 or 4 weeks after your operation before you feel comfortable enough to have sex.

【33】Blood in your pee
-----------------

【34】After having a TURP, it's normal to occasionally notice some blood in your urine. Around a week or two after the operation, the amount of blood may increase as the scab on your prostate falls off.

【35】Drinking plenty of fluids will help flush any blood or small blood clots out of your bladder.

【36】When to seek medical advice
---------------------------

【37】While you're recovering, you should contact a GP immediately or call 111 if:

【38】*   you have a high temperature
*   you have severe pain when peeing
*   you cannot pee
*   there's a lot of blood in your pee or this gets worse
*   there are blood clots in your pee

【39】These symptoms can be a sign of a problem, such as internal bleeding or a urinary infection, that needs to be treated.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 14 September 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 14 September 2024</u>

source_info.title: Ferrous fumarate
source_info.text:
【0】Taking ferrous fumarate with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand names: Fersamal, Galfer
====================================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】There are some medicines that may affect how ferrous fumarate works.

【3】Ferrous fumarate can also affect the way other medicines work. It's a good idea to leave a gap between taking ferrous fumarate and any other medicine. Ask a doctor or pharmacist for advice on how long the gap should be.

【4】Before you start taking ferrous fumarate, tell a pharmacist or doctor if you're taking any of these medicines:

【5】*   iron injections
*   antacids and other indigestion remedies
*   antibiotics such as oxytetracycline, doxycycline or ciprofloxacin
*   antivirals used for HIV infection such as bictegravir or dolutegravir
*   laxatives containing magnesium such as magnesium hydroxide or milk of magnesia
*   medicines used to treat or prevent osteoporosis (bisphosphonates), such as alendronic acid or risedronate
*   cholestyramine, a medicine used to reduce cholesterol
*   eltrombopag, a medicine used to increase platelets in the blood
*   levothyroxine, a medicine used to treat an underactive thyroid
*   levodopa, carbidopa or entacapone, medicines used to treat Parkinson's disease
*   mycophenolate, a medicine used after an organ transplant
*   methyldopa, a medicine used to treat high blood pressure
*   penicillamine, a medicine used to treat arthritis
*   trientine, a medicine used to treat Wilson's disease

【6】Mixing ferrous fumarate with herbal remedies or supplements
-----------------------------------------------------------

【7】Talk to a pharmacist or doctor before taking any herbal remedies or supplements together with ferrous fumarate. Some vitamin and mineral supplements may already contain ferrous fumarate.

【8】Tell a pharmacist or doctor if you take any supplements or remedies that contain iron, calcium, magnesium or zinc. Ferrous fumarate can stop zinc working as well as it should. Calcium can reduce the effect of ferrous fumarate.

【9】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【10】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.
删除11：<u>More in Ferrous fumarate
------------------------

source_info.title: How to cut down on sugar in your diet
source_info.text:
【0】How to cut down on sugar in your diet
=====================================

【1】**Added sugars, such as table sugar, honey and syrups, should not make up more than 5% of the energy you get from food and drink each day. That's about 30g a day for anyone aged 11 and older.**

【2】Sugar's many guises
-------------------

【3】There are lots of different ways added sugar can be listed on ingredients labels:

【4】*   sucrose
*   glucose
*   fructose
*   maltose
*   fruit juice
*   molasses
*   hydrolysed starch
*   invert sugar
*   corn syrup
*   honey

【5】Food labels tell you how much sugar a food contains:

【6】*   high in sugar – 22.5g or more of total sugar per 100g
*   low in sugar – 5g or less of total sugar per 100g

【7】Some packaging uses a colour-coded system that makes it easy to choose foods that are lower in sugar, salt and fat. Look for more "greens" and "ambers", and fewer "reds", in your shopping basket.

【8】Breakfast
---------

【9】Many breakfast cereals are high in sugar. Try switching to lower-sugar cereals or those with no added sugar, such as:

【10】*   plain wheat biscuit cereal
*   plain shredded wholegrain cereal
*   no-added-sugar muesli
*   plain porridge
*   wholemeal toast
*   plain natural yoghurt topped with chopped fruit

【11】Porridge oats are cheap and contain vitamins, minerals and fibre. Make porridge with semi-skimmed, 1% or skimmed milk, or water.

【12】If you usually add sugar to your porridge, try adding a few chopped dried apricots or a sliced or mashed banana instead.

【13】For a more gradual approach, you could eat sugary cereals and plain cereals on alternate days, or mix both in the same bowl.

【14】If you add sugar to your cereal, you could try adding less. Or you could eat a smaller portion and add some chopped fruit, such as a pear or banana, which is an easy way of getting some of your 5 A Day.

【15】If toast is your breakfast staple, try wholemeal or granary bread, which is higher in fibre than white bread, and see if you can get by with a little less of your usual spreads like jam, marmalade, honey or chocolate. Or you could try sugar-free or lower-sugar options.

【16】You can find breakfast recipes on the Better Health website.

【17】Main meals
----------

【18】Many foods that we do not consider to be sweet contain a surprisingly large amount of sugar. Some ready-made soups, stir-in sauces and ready meals can also be higher in sugar than you think.

【19】When eating out or buying takeaways, watch out for dishes that are typically high in sugar, such as sweet and sour dishes, sweet chilli dishes and some curry sauces, as well as salads with dressings like salad cream, which can also be high in sugar.

【20】Condiments and sauces such as ketchup can have as much as 23g of sugar in 100g – roughly half a teaspoon per serving. These foods are usually served in small quantities, but the sugar count can add up if eaten every day.

【21】Snacks
------

【22】Healthier snack options are those without added sugar, such as fresh or tinned fruit (in juice, not syrup), unsalted mixed nuts, plain popcorn, rice cakes, crackers topped with lower-fat cheese or lower-sugar yoghurts.

【23】If you are not ready to give up your favourite flavours, you could start by having less. Instead of 2 biscuits in 1 sitting, try having 1. If your snack has 2 bars, have 1 and share the other, or save it for another day.

【24】If you're an "all-or-nothing" type person, you could find something to do to take your mind off food on some days of the week.

【25】When shopping, look out for lower-sugar (and lower-fat) versions of your favourite snacks. Buy smaller packs, or skip the family bags and just go for the normal-sized one instead.

【26】Here are some lower-calorie substitutes for popular snacks:

【27】*   **cereal bars** – despite their healthy image, many cereal bars can be high in sugar and fat. Look out for bars that are lower in sugar, fat and salt.
*   **chocolate** – swap for a lower-calorie hot instant chocolate drink. You can also get chocolate with coffee and chocolate with malt varieties.
*   **biscuits** – swap for oatcakes, oat biscuits, or unsalted rice cakes, which also provide fibre.
*   **cakes** – swap for a plain currant bun, fruit scone, or malt loaf. If you add toppings or spreads, use them sparingly or choose lower-fat and lower-sugar varieties.

【28】Dried fruit, such as raisins, dates and apricots, is high in sugar and can be bad for your dental health because it sticks to your teeth.

【29】To prevent tooth decay, dried fruit is best enjoyed at mealtimes – as part of a dessert, for example – rather than as a snack.

【30】Drinks
------

【31】Nearly a quarter of the added sugar in our diets comes from sugary drinks, such as fizzy drinks, sweetened juices, milkshakes and cordials.

【32】A can of regular cola contains 7 teaspoons of sugar (35g). Try swapping to water, sugar-free or no-added-sugar drinks or lower-fat milks.

【33】If you take sugar in tea or coffee, gradually reduce the amount until you can cut it out altogether, or try swapping to sweeteners instead. Try some new flavours with herbal teas, or make your own with hot water and a slice of lemon or ginger.

【34】Like some fizzy drinks, fruit juice can be high in sugar. When juice is extracted from the whole fruit to make fruit juice, sugar is released, and this can damage your teeth.

【35】Your combined total of drinks from fruit juice, vegetable juice and smoothies should not be more than 150ml a day – which is a small glass. For example, if you have 150ml of orange juice and 150ml smoothie in one day, you'll have exceeded the recommendation by 150ml.

【36】Fruit juices and smoothies do contain vitamins and minerals and can count towards your 5 A Day. However they can only ever count as a maximum of 1 portion of your 5 A Day. For example, if you have 2 glasses of fruit juice and a smoothie in 1 day, that still only counts as 1 portion.

【37】You could try flavouring water with a slice of lemon, lime, or a splash of fruit juice. But watch out for the sugar content in squash or cordials with added sugar. Some can contain up to 3 teaspoons of sugar in each glass.

【38】Dessert
-------

【39】Work out some ground rules. Do you need to have dessert every day? How about only having dessert after your evening meal, or only eating dessert on odd days of the month, or only on weekends, or only at restaurants?

【40】Do you have to have chocolate, biscuits, and cake every day? If you had this type of sugary snack less often, would you actually enjoy it more?

【41】Less sugary desserts include fruit – fresh, frozen, dried, or tinned, but choose those canned in juice rather than syrup – as well as lower-fat and lower-sugar rice pudding, and plain lower-fat yoghurt.

【42】However, lower fat does not necessarily mean low sugar. Some lower-fat yoghurts can be sweetened with refined sugar, fruit juice concentrate, glucose, and fructose syrup.

【43】If you're stuck between choosing 2 desserts at the supermarket, why not compare the labels on both packages and go for the one with the lower amount of sugar.
删除11：<u>More in How to eat a balanced diet
----------------------------------

【44】*   Eating a balanced diet
*   The vegan diet
*   The vegetarian diet
*   Eating processed foods
*   How to eat less saturated fat
*   How to cut down on sugar in your diet
*   8 tips for healthy eating
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 3 October 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 3 October 2025</u>

source_info.title: Cholera
source_info.text:
【0】Cholera
=======

【1】**Cholera is an infection that can cause severe diarrhoea. It's not found in the UK, but there's a very small risk of getting it while travelling in some parts of the world.**

【2】Check if you could be at risk of cholera
----------------------------------------

【3】You can catch cholera from:

【4】*   drinking unclean water
*   eating food (particularly shellfish) that's been in unclean water
*   eating food that's been handled by an infected person

【5】The risk of getting it while travelling is very small.

【6】It's mainly found in places without a clean water supply or modern sewage system, such as parts of Africa and Asia.

【7】Information:

【8】You can check the country information on the TravelHealthPro website

【9】How to avoid cholera while travelling
-------------------------------------

【10】Good hygiene can help stop you getting ill while travelling in areas where cholera is found.

【11】### Do

【12】*   wash your hands with soap and water regularly, especially after using the toilet and before preparing food or eating

【13】*   only drink tap water that's been boiled or bottled water

【14】*   brush your teeth using bottled or boiled water

【15】### Don’t

【16】*   do not eat uncooked fruit and vegetables (including salads) that you have not washed with bottled or boiled water and prepared yourself

【17】*   do not eat shellfish and seafood

【18】*   do not eat ice cream or have ice in your drinks

【19】You can get vaccinated against cholera if you're at risk
--------------------------------------------------------

【20】There's a vaccine for cholera, but most people do not need it.

【21】It's usually only recommended if either:

【22】*   you're travelling to an area where cholera is common and you'll be visiting remote places without access to medical care
*   you're an aid or disaster relief worker going to an area where a cholera outbreak is likely

【23】The vaccine is given as a drink. For adults, 2 doses (given 1 to 6 weeks apart) can provide protection for up to 2 years.

【24】You need to have had both doses at least a week before travelling.

【25】Information:

【26】If you need the cholera vaccine, you may be able to get it for free on the NHS. Ask at your GP surgery.

【27】### Urgent advice: See a doctor if:

【28】you have been in an area where there is cholera and you have:

【29】*   severe watery diarrhoea and vomiting
*   symptoms of dehydration, such as feeling thirsty or dark yellow and strong-smelling pee

【30】Tell the doctor if you have been in an area where cholera is found in the last few weeks.

【31】You may need treatment to stop you becoming dangerously dehydrated.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 05 May 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 05 May 2024</u>

source_info.title: Oestrogen tablets, patches, gel and spray
source_info.text:
【0】Taking or using oestrogen tablets, patches, gel and spray with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand names: Oestrogel, Evorel, Sandrena, Lenzetto, Estradot, Progynova
================================================================================================================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】There are some medicines that may affect how oestrogen works.

【3】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking:

【4】*   medicines for epilepsy, such as phenytoin, carbamazepine or phenobarbital
*   certain medicines for infections, such as rifampicin, rifabutin, nevirapine, efavirenz, ritonavir or nelfinavir

【5】Mixing oestrogen tablets, patches, gel and spray with herbal remedies and supplements
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

【6】There are several different herbal products sold to help relieve menopause symptoms. These include evening primrose oil, soya, red clover, black cohosh, ginseng and St John's wort.

【7】All of these products might affect other medicines you're taking, so it's important to check with your doctor or pharmacist before starting to take them.

【8】It's not possible to say that other herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with oestrogen. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy or prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they can have on other medicines.

【9】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【10】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

source_info.title: Chloramphenicol
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot use chloramphenicol
======================================

【1】Who can use chloramphenicol
---------------------------

【2】Chloramphenicol can be used by most adults and children including babies.

【3】The eyedrops and eye ointment are available to buy in pharmacies for use in adults and children aged 2 years and over.

【4】For children under 2 years, you'll need a prescription for chloramphenicol from your doctor.

【5】Who may not be able to use chloramphenicol
------------------------------------------

【6】Chloramphenicol is not suitable for everyone. To make sure it's safe for you, tell your doctor if:

【7】*   you have ever had an allergic reaction to chloramphenicol or any other medicine
*   you or anyone in your family has ever had a rare condition called aplastic anaemia (when your bone marrow does not produce blood cells)

【8】Who may not be able to use eyedrops or ointment
-----------------------------------------------

【9】Before using chloramphenicol, tell you doctor if you're using other eyedrops or ointment, or if you normally wear contact lenses.

【10】It's also important to speak to your doctor if you have:

【11】*   any problems with your eyesight, or severe eye pain
*   swollen eyes, and a rash on your face or head
*   a cloudy eye
*   unusual looking pupils – irregular size, dilated (bigger than normal), or not reacting to light
*   had a recent eye injury, or something in your eye
*   recently had conjunctivitis
*   dry eye syndrome (when your eyes do not produce enough tears)
*   glaucoma
*   had eye surgery or laser treatment in the last 6 months

【12】Who may not be able to use eardrops
-----------------------------------

【13】Before using chloramphenicol eardrops, tell your doctor if you:

【14】*   currently have a perforated (burst) eardrum
*   are allergic to polyethylene glycol (an ingredient used in some medicines and cosmetics, and found in some foods)
删除11：<u>More in Chloramphenicol
