source_info.title: Meat in your diet
source_info.text:
【0】Meat in your diet
=================

【1】**Meat is a good source of protein, vitamins and minerals in your diet. However, if you currently eat more than 90g (cooked weight) of red or processed meat a day, the Department of Health and Social Care advises that you cut down to 70g.**

【2】Some meats are high in saturated fat, which can raise blood cholesterol levels if you eat too much of it. Making healthier choices can help you eat meat as part of a balanced diet.

【3】If you eat a lot of red or processed meat, it's recommended that you cut down as there is likely to be a link between red and processed meat and bowel cancer.

【4】A healthy balanced diet can include protein from meat, as well as from fish and eggs or non-animal sources such as beans and pulses. Meats such as chicken, pork, lamb and beef are all rich in protein.

【5】Red meat provides us with iron, zinc and B vitamins. Meat is one of the main sources of vitamin B12 in the diet.

【6】Food hygiene is important when storing, preparing and cooking meat.

【7】Meat and saturated fat
----------------------

【8】Some meats are high in fat, especially saturated fat. Eating a lot of saturated fat can raise cholesterol levels in the blood, and having high cholesterol raises your risk of coronary heart disease.

【9】The type of meat product you choose and how you cook it can make a big difference to the saturated fat content.

【10】Make healthier choices when buying meat
---------------------------------------

【11】When buying meat, go for the leanest option. As a rule, the more white you can see on meat, the more fat it contains. For example, back bacon contains less fat than streaky bacon.

【12】These tips can help you buy healthier options:

【13】*   ask your butcher for a lean cut
*   if you're buying pre-packed meat, check the nutrition label to see how much fat it contains and compare products
*   go for turkey and chicken without the skin as these are lower in fat (or remove the skin before cooking)
*   try to limit processed meat products such as sausages, salami, pâté and beefburgers, because these are generally high in fat – they are often high in salt, too
*   try to limit meat products in pastry, such as pies and sausage rolls, because they are often high in fat and salt

【14】Cut down on fat when cooking meat
---------------------------------

【15】Cut off any visible fat and skin before cooking – crackling and poultry skin are much higher in fat than the meat itself.

【16】Here are some other ways to reduce fat when cooking meat:

【17】*   grill meat, rather than frying
*   avoid adding extra fat or oil when cooking meat
*   roast meat on a metal rack above a roasting tin so the fat can run off
*   try using smaller quantities of meat and replacing some of the meat with vegetables, pulses and starchy foods in dishes such as stews, curries and casseroles

【18】How much red and processed meat should we eat?
----------------------------------------------

【19】Red meat (such as beef, lamb and pork) can form part of a healthy diet. But eating a lot of red and processed meat probably increases your risk of bowel (colorectal) cancer.

【20】Processed meat refers to meat that has been preserved by smoking, curing, salting or adding preservatives. This includes sausages, bacon, ham, salami and pâtés.

【21】If you currently eat more than 90g (cooked weight) of red or processed meat a day, the Department of Health and Social Care advises that you cut down to 70g.

【22】90g is equivalent to around 3 thinly cut slices of beef, lamb or pork, where each slice is about the size of half a piece of sliced bread. A cooked breakfast containing 2 typical British sausages and 2 rashers of bacon is equivalent to 130g.

【23】通用删除3(英):<u>For more information read red meat and the risk of bowel cancer.</u>

【24】Storing meat safely
-------------------

【25】It's important to store and prepare meat safely to stop bacteria from spreading and to avoid food poisoning:

【26】*   store raw meat or raw poultry in clean sealed containers on the bottom shelf of the fridge, so the meat cannot touch or drip onto other food
*   follow any storage instructions on the label and do not eat meat after its "use by" date
*   store red meat or raw poultry in a freezer before its "use by" date
*   if you cook meat that you're not going to eat straight away, cool it as quickly as possible and then put it in the fridge or freezer – remember to keep cooked meat separate from raw meat and only reheat cooked meat once
*   always thoroughly clean plates, utensils, surfaces and hands straight away after they have touched raw or thawing meat using warm soapy water or disinfectant cleaning products

【27】### Freezing meat safely

【28】It's safe to freeze raw meat providing that you:

【29】*   freeze it before the "use by" date
*   date and label meat in the freezer, following any freezing or thawing instructions on the packaging
*   defrost meat in the microwave, using the defrost setting, if you are going to cook it straight away
*   thaw meat fully in a fridge, if you want to defrost it and cook it later – keep it in the fridge and use it within 2 days of defrosting
*   cook food until it's steaming hot all the way through

【30】When meat thaws, liquid can come out of it. This liquid will spread bacteria to any food, plates or surfaces that it touches. Keep the meat in a sealed container at the bottom of the fridge so that it cannot touch or drip onto other foods.

【31】If you defrost raw meat and then cook it thoroughly, you can freeze it again. But never reheat meat or any other food more than once as this could lead to food poisoning.

【32】### Cooking meat safely

【33】Follow the cooking instructions on the packaging.

【34】Some people wash meat before they cook it, but this actually increases your risk of food poisoning, because the water droplets splash onto surfaces and can contaminate them with bacteria.

【35】It's important to prepare and cook food safely. Cooking meat properly ensures that harmful bacteria on the meat are killed. If meat is not cooked all the way through, these bacteria may cause food poisoning.

【36】Bacteria and viruses can be found all the way through poultry and certain meat products (such as burgers). This means you need to cook poultry and these sorts of meat products all the way through. When meat is cooked all the way through, its juices run clear and there is no pink or red meat left inside.

【37】Meats and meat products that you should cook all the way through are:

【38】*   poultry and game, such as chicken, turkey, duck and goose, including liver
*   pork
*   offal, including liver
*   burgers and sausages
*   kebabs
*   rolled joints of meat

【39】You can eat whole cuts of beef or lamb when they are pink inside – or "rare" – as long as they are cooked on the outside.

【40】These meats include:

【41】*   steaks
*   cutlets
*   joints

【42】Liver and liver products
------------------------

【43】Liver and liver products, such as liver pâté and liver sausage, are a good source of iron, as well as being a rich source of vitamin A.

【44】You should be able to get all the vitamin A you need from your daily diet. Adults need:

【45】*   700 micrograms of vitamin A per day for men
*   600 micrograms of vitamin A per day for women

【46】However, because they are such a rich source of vitamin A, we should be careful not to eat too much liver and liver product foods.

【47】Having too much vitamin A – more than 1.5mg (1,500 micrograms) of vitamin A per day from food and supplements – over many years may make your bones more likely to fracture when you are older.

【48】People who eat liver or liver pâté once a week may be having more than an average of 1.5mg of vitamin A per day. If you eat liver or liver products every week, you may want to consider cutting back or not eating them as often. Also, avoid taking any supplements that contain vitamin A and fish liver oils, which are also high in vitamin A.

【49】Women who have been through the menopause, and older men, should avoid having more than 1.5mg of vitamin A per week from food and supplements. This is because older people are at a higher risk of bone fracture. This means not eating liver and liver products more than once a week, or having smaller portions. It also means not taking any supplements containing vitamin A, including fish liver oil, if they do eat liver once a week.

【50】Pregnant women should avoid liver and liver products and vitamin A supplements.

【51】Eating meat when you're pregnant
--------------------------------

【52】Meat can generally be part of a pregnant woman's diet. However, pregnant women should avoid:

【53】*   raw and undercooked meat because of the risk of toxoplasmosis – make sure any meat you eat is well cooked before eating
*   pâté of all types, including vegetable pâté – they can contain listeria, a type of bacteria that could harm your unborn baby
*   liver and liver products – these foods are very high in vitamin A, and too much vitamin A can harm the unborn child
*   game meats such as goose, partridge or pheasant – these may contain lead shot
删除7：<u>Read more about foods to avoid in pregnancy.</u>
删除11：<u>More in Food types

source_info.title: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD)
source_info.text:
【0】Living with AMD \- Age-related macular degeneration (AMD)
=========================================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  What is AMD?
2.  Symptoms
3.  Getting diagnosed
4.  Treatments
5.  Living with AMD</u>

【2】Help with low vision
--------------------

【3】Speak to your eye specialist about a referral to a low-vision clinic if you're having difficulty with daily activities.

【4】Staff at the clinic can give useful advice and practical support.

【5】For example, they can talk to you about:

【6】*   useful devices – such as magnifying lenses
*   changes you can make to your home – such as brighter lighting
*   software and mobile apps that can make computers and phones easier to use

【7】If you have poor vision in both eyes, your specialist may refer you for a type of training called eccentric viewing training.

【8】This involves learning techniques that help make the most of your remaining vision.
删除7：<u>Read more about help and support if you have low vision</u>

【9】Staying healthy
---------------

【10】AMD is often linked to an unhealthy lifestyle.

【11】If you have it, try to:

【12】*   eat a balanced diet
*   exercise regularly
*   lose weight if you're overweight
*   stop smoking if you smoke

【13】There's some evidence to suggest that certain health supplements might help stop AMD getting worse, but this is not definitive.

【14】### Important

【15】Speak to a GP or your specialist if you're considering taking supplements for AMD. They're not suitable for everyone.

【16】Information:

【17】Macular Society: diet and nutrition for AMD

【18】Driving
-------

【19】AMD can make it unsafe for you to drive. Ask your specialist if they think you should stop driving.

【20】You're required by law to tell DVLA about your condition if:

【21】*   it affects both eyes
*   it only affects 1 eye but your remaining vision is below the minimum standards of vision for driving

【22】Information:

【23】GOV.UK: driving eyesight rules

【24】GOV.UK: how to tell DVLA about a medical condition

【25】Monitoring and check-ups
------------------------

【26】You'll have regular check-ups with a specialist to monitor your condition.

【27】Contact your specialist as soon as possible if your vision gets worse or you notice any new symptoms.

【28】Information:

【29】Keep having routine eye tests (usually every 2 years). They can pick up other eye problems that your check-ups do not look for.

【30】Registering as sight impaired
-----------------------------

【31】If your vision continues to get worse, you may want to consider registering your sight loss.

【32】This can make it easier to claim financial benefits, such as help with health costs.

【33】Your specialist can check your vision and complete an official certificate if you meet the requirements to be registered.

【34】Information:

【35】RNIB: registering as sight impaired

【36】Getting more help and support
-----------------------------

【37】Living with AMD can be very difficult.

【38】In addition to support from your specialist, you may find it useful to use support groups such as:

【39】*   Macular Society: support services – contact their helpline on 0300 3030 111
*   RNIB: sight loss advice service – contact their helpline on 0303 123 9999

【40】### Important

【41】See a GP if you've been feeling low for more than 2 weeks. They can offer support and treatment if you need it.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 20 April 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 20 April 2024</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Treatments</u>

source_info.title: Allopurinol
source_info.text:
【0】Side effects of allopurinol \- Brand names: Zyloric, Uricto
===========================================================

【1】Like all medicines, allopurinol can cause side effects, but many people have no side effects or only minor ones.

【2】Common side effects
-------------------

【3】There are things you can do to cope with these common side effects of allopurinol:

【4】Feeling or being sick (nausea or vomiting)

【5】If you're feeling sick, eat little and often and drink lots of fluids such as water or squash. Also try taking your medicine with, or just after, a meal or snack. Stick to simple meals and do not eat rich or spicy food.

【6】If you're being sick, take small, frequent sips of water to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee.

【7】If you take contraceptive pills and you're being sick, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet for advice.

【8】Serious side effects
--------------------

【9】It's unusual to have serious side effects after taking allopurinol. Tell a doctor or call 111 now if:

【10】*   the whites of your eyes or your skin turn yellow, although this is less obvious on black or brown skin – these can be signs of a liver problem
*   you get a high temperature, sore throat and swollen glands or feel generally unwell – this could mean there are problems with your white blood cells
*   you have bruising for no obvious reason or bleeding gums (which takes a long time to stop) when brushing your teeth
*   you are unusually thirsty, going to the toilet to pee a lot, unusually tired, losing weight without trying, or have blurred vision – these could be signs of diabetes

【11】### Skin rashes

【12】Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a rare side effect of allopurinol. It causes flu-like symptoms, followed by a red or purple rash that spreads and forms blisters. The affected skin eventually dies and peels off.

【13】It's more likely to happen in the first 8 weeks of taking allopurinol, or when the dose is increased too quickly. It can also happen if allopurinol is stopped suddenly for a few days and then restarted at the same dose as before. It's better to reduce the dose and then increase it slowly.

【14】Stevens-Johnson syndrome is more common in:

【15】*   children
*   people who developed a rash with an epilepsy medicine in the past
*   people who are allergic to an antibiotic called trimethoprim
*   people also taking a medicine called sodium valproate

【16】To help prevent the chance of you getting a rash that could be confused with Stevens-Johnson syndrome, it's best not to try new medicines or food during the first 3 months of treatment with allopurinol.

【17】It's also best to not start taking allopurinol within 2 weeks of a viral infection, vaccination, or rash caused by something else.

【18】#### Immediate action required: Go to A&E now if:

【19】*   you get a skin rash with flushing, blisters or ulcers – these can be signs of Stevens-Johnson syndrome

【20】Find your nearest A&E

【21】### Serious allergic reaction

【22】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to allopurinol.

【23】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【24】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【25】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【26】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【27】Other side effects
------------------

【28】These are not all the side effects of allopurinol. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicines packet.
删除5：<u>Information:

【29】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.
删除12：<u>Visit Yellow Card for further information.</u></u>

source_info.title: Nystatin
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take or use nystatin \- Brand name: Nystan
=============================================================

【1】Who can take or use nystatin
----------------------------

【2】Most adults and children, including babies, can take nystatin liquid or use nystatin cream and ointments.

【3】Who may not be able to take or use nystatin
-------------------------------------------

【4】Nystatin is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell a pharmacist or doctor if you:

【5】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to nystatin or any other medicine, including any ingredients in the cream or ointment
*   cannot digest some sugars – the liquid has a small amount of sucrose in it
*   have tuberculosis (TB) of the skin – you may not be able to use the cream or ointment

source_info.title: Contraceptive injections (medroxyprogesterone)
source_info.text:
【0】How and when to have medroxyprogesterone contraceptive injections \- Brand names: Depo-Provera, Sayana Press
============================================================================================================

【1】Dosage
------

【2】Medroxyprogesterone contraceptive injections come in syringes that already contain the right dose.

【3】For Depo-Provera the dose is 150mg and for Sayana Press, the dose is 104mg.

【4】How to have the injection
-------------------------

【5】You'll usually need to see a doctor or nurse to get the injection. This could be at your GP surgery or at a sexual health or contraception clinic.

【6】Depo-Provera is injected either into a muscle in your bottom or into the top of your arm.

【7】Sayana Press is injected under the skin in your tummy or thigh. You can be taught how to inject it yourself. However, the Sayana Press injection is not available everywhere.

【8】When to have it
---------------

【9】You have the injection during the first 5 days from when your period starts.

【10】You'll usually need to have an injection once every 12 to 13 weeks. Your clinic will advise you on how often to have it.

【11】How long to have medroxyprogesterone contraceptive injections for
-----------------------------------------------------------------

【12】This will depend on how long you need contraception and your reasons for choosing the injection.

【13】Medroxyprogesterone injections are sometimes stopped after 2 years, but you can keep having them for longer.

【14】If you stay on medroxyprogesterone injections for more than 2 years a doctor may suggest a bone scan to check the strength of your bones.

【15】If you forget to have it
------------------------

【16】If you do not have the injection 14 weeks after your last injection, you could get pregnant.

【17】If you forget to have it, talk to the doctor or nurse as soon as you remember. You'll need to use another type of contraception. You will not be able to have the dose late if there's a chance you might be pregnant.

【18】If you have the injection too soon
----------------------------------

【19】If you have the injection less than 12 weeks after your last injection, it's unlikely to harm you but you could get more of the common side effects.

【20】Talk to the nurse, doctor or your pharmacist.
删除11：<u>More in Contraceptive injections (medroxyprogesterone)

【5】    healthunlocked.com

source_info.title: Cefalexin
source_info.text:
【0】About cefalexin \- Brand name: Keflex
=====================================

【1】Cefalexin is an antibiotic. It belongs to a group of antibiotics called cephalosporins.

【2】It's used to treat bacterial infections, such as pneumonia and other chest infections, skin infections and urinary tract infections (UTIs).

【3】Cefalexin is only available on prescription. It comes as capsules, tablets or as a liquid that you swallow.

【4】Key facts
---------

【5】*   You'll usually start to feel better in a few days, depending on the type of infection you have.
*   The most common side effects of cefalexin are feeling sick (nausea) and diarrhoea.
*   Do not take zinc supplements while you're taking cefalexin. Zinc can affect how cefalexin works in your body.
*   You can drink alcohol while taking cefalexin.
*   It's important to keep taking cefalexin until you've completed the course, even if you feel better.
删除11：<u>More in Cefalexin
-----------------

【6】*   About cefalexin
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking cefalexin with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 5 April 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 5 April 2026</u>

source_info.title: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease
source_info.text:
【0】Causes \- Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease
=====================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment</u>

【2】**Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT) is caused by mutations (faults) in genes that cause the peripheral nerves to become damaged.**

【3】The peripheral nerves are a network of nerves that run from the brain and spinal cord (the central nervous system).

【4】They carry impulses to and from the rest of the body, such as the limbs and organs, and are responsible for the body's senses and movements.

【5】A peripheral nerve is similar to an electrical cable, and is made up of 2 parts:

【6】*   the axon – which transmits electrical information between your brain and limbs, similar to the wiring in an electrical cable
*   the myelin sheath – which is wrapped around the axon to protect it and ensure the electrical signal is not broken, similar to the insulation around electrical cable

【7】In some types of CMT, faulty genes cause the myelin sheath to break down.

【8】Without protection, the axons become damaged, which affects the transmission of messages between the brain and the muscles and senses. This leads to muscle weakness and numbness.

【9】In other types of CMT, the axons are directly affected and do not transmit electrical signals at the normal strength.

【10】This means the muscles and senses do not get used enough, leading to symptoms of muscle weakness and numbness.

【11】How CMT is inherited
--------------------

【12】A child with CMT may have inherited the genetic fault responsible for the condition from 1 or both parents.

【13】No single faulty gene causes CMT. The many types of CMT are caused by different genetic mutations and the faulty genes can be inherited in several different ways.

【14】### Autosomal dominant

【15】Autosomal dominant inheritance of CMT occurs when 1 copy of a mutated gene is enough to cause the condition.

【16】If either parent carries a faulty gene, there's a 1 in 2 chance the condition will be passed on to each child they have.

【17】### Autosomal recessive

【18】Autosomal recessive inheritance of CMT occurs when 2 copies of the defective gene are needed to cause the condition.

【19】You inherit 1 copy from each parent. As your parents only have 1 copy of the gene, they don't develop CMT themselves.

【20】If both you and your partner are carriers of the autosomal recessive CMT gene, there's a:

【21】*   1 in 4 chance each child you have will develop CMT
*   1 in 2 chance each child you have will inherit 1 of the defective genes and be able to pass the condition to any children they have (known as being a carrier) – although they will not have any of the symptoms of CMT themselves
*   1 in 4 chance each child you have will receive a pair of healthy genes and will not develop CMT

【22】If only 1 parent has the autosomal recessive gene, your children will not develop CMT. But there's a 1 in 2 chance each child will be a carrier.

【23】### X-linked inheritance

【24】In X-linked inheritance, the mutated gene is located on the X chromosome and passed from mother to son. Chromosomes are the parts of cells that carry your genes.

【25】Men have XY sex chromosomes. They receive the X chromosome from their mother and the Y chromosome from their father.

【26】Women have XX chromosomes. They receive 1 X chromosome from their mother and the other X chromosome from their father.

【27】A woman with the defective X chromosome will usually have no or very mild symptoms because the other healthy X chromosome counters the effect of the defective one.

【28】But there's a 1 in 2 chance she'll pass on the defective gene to her son and he'll develop CMT.

【29】If a woman with the defective X chromosome only has daughters, CMT can skip a generation until one of her grandsons inherits it.

【30】Types of CMT
------------

【31】There are many different types of CMT that are all caused by different mutations (changes) in your genes.

【32】The main types of CMT are:

【33】*   CMT 1 – the most common type, caused by defective genes that cause the myelin sheath to slowly break down
*   CMT 2 – a less common and usually less severe type than CMT 1, caused by defects in the axon
*   CMT 3 (Dejerine-Sottas syndrome) – a rare and severe type of CMT that affects the myelin sheath, causing severe muscle weakness and sensory problems to begin developing in early childhood
*   CMT 4 – another rare and severe type of CMT that affects the myelin sheath, which begins developing in early childhood and causes many people to eventually lose the ability to walk
*   CMT X – caused by a mutation in the X chromosome, and more common in men than women

【34】You can read more about the classification of CMT on Charcot-Marie-Tooth UK.

source_info.title: Gum disease
source_info.text:
【0】Gum disease
===========

【1】**Gum disease is where the gums become red, swollen and sore, and bleed. It's very common, but it's important to get it checked by a dentist.**

【2】Check if you have gum disease
-----------------------------

【3】Symptoms of gum disease include:

【4】*   your gums bleeding when you brush your teeth, floss or eat hard foods such as apples
*   your gums becoming swollen, red and sore

【5】Gum disease can lead to:

【6】*   bad breath and a bad taste in the mouth
*   your gums shrinking
*   your teeth becoming loose or falling out

【7】Non-urgent advice: See a dentist if:
------------------------------------

【8】*   your gums bleed when you brush your teeth or eat hard foods
*   your gums are painful and swollen
*   you have bad breath
*   your child has sore, bleeding gums

【9】Urgent advice: Ask for an urgent dentist appointment if:
--------------------------------------------------------

【10】You or your child have gum disease and other symptoms such as:

【11】*   very sore and swollen gums
*   teeth becoming loose or falling out
*   ulcers or red patches in your mouth
*   a lump in your mouth or on your lip

【12】Information:

【13】### To see a dentist in an emergency or out of hours:

【14】*   call your dentist – if they're closed, their answerphone may tell you what to do

【15】### If you do not have a dentist or cannot get an emergency appointment:

【16】*   call 111 – they can advise you what to do
*   find a dentist near you – ask if you can have an emergency appointment

【17】You may have to pay for your appointment.
删除7：<u>Read more about NHS dental charges.</u>

【18】### Important: Get regular dental check-ups

【19】You should have regular dental check-ups even if you do not have any problems. See a dentist if you have not had a check-up for 2 years (or 1 year if you're under 18).

【20】Treatments for gum disease
--------------------------

【21】Your dentist will check your teeth and gums, and may take some X-rays to check your teeth and jaw bone.

【22】They may also refer you to a specialist for further tests and treatment.

【23】How gum disease is treated depends on how severe it is.

【24】In the early stages, your dentist will:

【25】*   give you advice about keeping your teeth clean, such as using interdental brushes
*   advise you to stop smoking, if you smoke
*   advise you to get your teeth cleaned by a hygienist

【26】If your gum disease is serious, you may need:

【27】*   to have deep cleaning under the gums
*   antibiotics
*   to have some teeth removed
*   gum surgery

【28】Cost of dental treatment

【29】NHS dental treatment is free for some people, including:

【30】*   children aged under 18, or under 19 and in full-time education
*   if you're pregnant or have had a baby in the past 12 months
*   if you're on some benefits, including Income Support or Universal Credit

【31】If you do not qualify for free dental care, you will usually have to pay for treatment.
删除7：<u>Find out more about dental costs</u>

【32】Preventing gum disease
----------------------

【33】Gum disease is caused by a build-up of plaque on the teeth.

【34】If you do not remove plaque from your teeth by brushing and cleaning in between them regularly, it builds up and irritates your gums.

【35】There are things you can do yourself to prevent gum disease.

【36】### Do

【37】*   brush your teeth with fluoride toothpaste at least twice a day – spit after brushing, do not rinse

【38】*   clean in between your teeth every day using floss or interdental brushes

【39】*   replace your toothbrush every 1 to 3 months

【40】*   see a dentist and dental hygienist for regular check-ups, especially if you're pregnant or have type 2 diabetes

【41】### Don’t

【42】*   do not use mouthwash straight after brushing your teeth

【43】*   do not smoke

【44】删除6：<u>Information:

【45】### Find out more

【46】*   Taking care of your teeth and gums
*   Looking after your children's teeth
*   Looking after your baby's teeth
</u>

source_info.title: Piles in pregnancy
source_info.text: 【0】Piles in pregnancy ================== 【1】Symptoms of piles ----------------- 【2】Piles, also known as haemorrhoids, are swellings containing enlarged blood vessels inside or around your bottom (the rectum and anus). 【3】Anyone can get piles – they don't just happen in pregnancy. When you're pregnant, piles can occur because hormones make your veins relax. 【4】Symptoms of piles can include: 【5】* itching, aching, soreness or swelling around your anus * pain when passing a stool (faeces, poo) and a mucus discharge afterwards * a lump hanging outside the anus, which may need to be pushed back in after passing a stool * bleeding after passing a stool – the blood is usually bright red 【6】How to ease piles ----------------- 【7】Constipation can cause piles. If this is the cause, try to keep your stools soft and regular by eating plenty of food that's high in fibre. 【8】This includes: 【9】* wholemeal bread * fruit * vegetables 【10】Drinking plenty of water can help, too. 删除7：Find out more about a healthy diet in pregnancy. 【11】Other things you can try include: 【12】* avoid standing for long periods * take regular exercise to improve your circulation * use a cloth wrung out in iced water to ease the pain – hold it gently against the piles * if the piles stick out, push them gently back inside using a lubricating jelly * avoid straining to pass a stool, as this may make your piles worse * after passing a stool, clean your anus with moist toilet paper instead of dry toilet paper * pat, rather than rub, the area 【13】There are medicines that can help soothe the inflammation around your anus. These treat the symptoms, but not the cause, of piles. 【14】Ask your doctor, midwife or pharmacist if they can suggest a suitable ointment to help ease the pain. Don't use a cream or medicine without checking with them first. 删除3：### Video: What can I do about haemorrhoids? 【15】In this video, a midwife explains ways you can treat or prevent haemorrhoids during pregnancy. 删除1：Media last reviewed: 2 February 2023 删除1：Media review due: 2 February 2026 删除14：Community content from HealthUnlocked 【16】删除11：More in Common symptoms in pregnancy ------------------------------------ 【17】* Common health problems in pregnancy * Back pain in pregnancy * Bleeding gums in pregnancy * Headaches in pregnancy * Indigestion and heartburn in pregnancy * Leaking from your nipples * Nosebleeds in pregnancy * Pelvic pain in pregnancy * Piles in pregnancy * Stomach pain in pregnancy * Stretch marks in pregnancy * Swollen ankles, feet and fingers in pregnancy * Tiredness and sleep problems * Thrush * Vaginal bleeding * Vaginal discharge in pregnancy * Vomiting and morning sickness * Weight gain in pregnancy 删除1：Page last reviewed: 17 February 2021 删除1：Next review due: 17 February 2024

source_info.title: Loratadine (Clarityn)
source_info.text:
【0】Loratadine (Clarityn)
=====================
删除10：<u>On this page
------------

【1】1.  About loratadine
2.  Key facts
3.  Who can and cannot take loratadine
4.  How and when to take loratadine
5.  Side effects
6.  How to cope with side effects of loratadine
7.  Pregnancy and breastfeeding
8.  Cautions with other medicines
9.  Common questions about loratadine</u>

【2】1\. About loratadine
--------------------

【3】Loratadine is an antihistamine medicine that helps with the symptoms of allergies. It's used to treat:

【4】*   hay fever
*   conjunctivitis (red, itchy eyes)
*   eczema
*   hives (urticaria)
*   reactions to insect bites and stings
*   some food allergies

【5】Loratadine is known as a non-drowsy antihistamine. It's much less likely to make you feel sleepy than some other antihistamines.

【6】Loratadine is available on prescription. You can also buy it from pharmacies and supermarkets.

【7】It comes as tablets or as a liquid that you swallow.

【8】2\. Key facts
-------------

【9】*   You'll usually take loratadine once a day.
*   Loratadine is classed as a non-drowsy antihistamine, but some people still find it makes them feel slightly sleepy.
*   Children may have a headache and feel tired or nervous after taking loratadine.
*   It's best not to drink alcohol while you're taking loratadine as it can make you feel sleepy.

【10】3\. Who can and cannot take loratadine
--------------------------------------

【11】Adults and children aged 2 years and older can take loratadine.

【12】Loratadine is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell your doctor or pharmacist before taking loratadine if you:

【13】*   have ever had an allergy to loratadine or any other medicines
*   have severe liver failure
*   have an allergy to food additives
*   have epilepsy or another illness that puts you at risk of seizures or fits
*   are due to have an allergy test – taking loratadine may affect the results, so you might need to stop taking it a few days before the test

【14】4\. How and when to take loratadine
-----------------------------------

【15】If you or your child have been prescribed loratadine, follow your doctor's instructions about how and when to take it.

【16】If you've bought loratadine from a pharmacy or shop, follow the instructions that come with the packet.

【17】### Dosage

【18】Loratadine comes as 10mg tablets and as a liquid medicine (labelled either 5mg/5ml or 1mg/1ml).

【19】The usual dose in adults is 10mg once a day.

【20】Doses are usually lower for people with liver problems.

【21】For children, your doctor will use your child's weight or age to work out the right dose. Children aged between 6 and 12 years can only take loratadine tablets if they weigh more than 30kg. Give children loratadine liquid instead of tablets if they are under 6 or weigh 30kg or less.

【22】### How to take it

【23】Loratadine comes as 2 different types of tablet: ordinary and melt-in-the-mouth tablets.

【24】Swallow ordinary loratadine tablets with a drink of water, milk or juice. If the tablet has a score line across the middle, you can break it in half if you find it hard to swallow it whole. Do not chew it.

【25】Melt-in-the-mouth tablets dissolve instantly on your tongue without needing a drink. Be careful not to crush them when you take them out of the packet.

【26】You can take loratadine with or without food.

【27】Loratadine liquid may be easier for children to take than tablets. The medicine will come with a plastic syringe or spoon to help you measure out the right dose. If you do not have a syringe or spoon, ask your pharmacist for one. Do not use a kitchen teaspoon as it will not measure the right amount.

【28】### When to take it

【29】You may only need to take loratadine on a day when you have symptoms, for instance if you've been exposed to a trigger such as animal hair. Or you may need to take it regularly to prevent symptoms, such as hay fever during spring and summer.

【30】Try to take loratadine at about the same time every day. Choose a time that is easy to remember.

【31】### What if I forget to take it?

【32】If you forget to take a dose, take it as soon as you remember, unless it's nearly time for your next dose. In this case, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time.

【33】Do not take 2 doses to make up for a forgotten dose.

【34】If you often forget doses, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to take your medicine.

【35】### What if I take too much?

【36】Loratadine is generally very safe. If you or your child take too much, it is unlikely to harm you.

【37】#### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice if:

【38】You've taken more than your usual dose of loratadine and:

【39】*   you get a headache, have a fast heartbeat or feel sleepy
*   you're concerned

【40】Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111

【41】Call 111 if you're asking about a child under the age of 5 years.

【42】5\. Side effects
----------------

【43】Like all medicines, loratadine can cause side effects, although not everyone gets them.

【44】### Common side effects

【45】The most common side effect of loratadine is feeling sleepy. This happens in more than 1 in 100 people.

【46】Side effects in children may include:

【47】*   headaches
*   feeling tired or nervous

【48】### Serious allergic reaction

【49】In rare cases, loratadine may cause a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis).

【50】##### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【51】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【52】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【53】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【54】These are not all the side effects of loratadine. For a full list see the leaflet inside your medicines packet.
删除5：<u>Information:

【55】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.
删除12：<u>Visit Yellow Card for further information.</u></u>

【56】6\. How to cope with side effects of loratadine
-----------------------------------------------

【57】**What to do about:**

【58】*   **feeling sleepy** – try a different non-drowsy antihistamine. If this does not help, talk to your doctor.
*   **headaches** – make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller. Headaches should normally go away after the first week of taking loratadine. Talk to your doctor if they last longer than a week or are severe.
*   **feeling tired or nervous** – talk to your doctor or pharmacist if these side effects do not go away. They may be able to offer you a different antihistamine.

【59】7\. Pregnancy and breastfeeding
-------------------------------

【60】### Loratadine and pregnancy

【61】Loratadine can be taken in pregnancy. There is no good evidence that it can harm your baby.

【62】### Loratadine and breastfeeding

【63】If your doctor or health visitor says your baby is healthy, you can take loratadine while breastfeeding.

【64】There is some information available which shows that only tiny amounts get into breast milk. It has been used for many years in breastfeeding women without side effects in their babies.

【65】If your baby is not feeding as well as usual, or seems unusually sleepy, or if you have any other concerns about your baby, talk to your doctor, pharmacist, health visitor or midwife.
删除7：<u>Find out more about how loratadine can affect you and your baby during pregnancy on the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website.</u>

【66】8\. Cautions with other medicines
---------------------------------

【67】Some medicines affect how loratadine works or can increase the chances of you having side effects.

【68】Tell your doctor if you're taking:

【69】*   amiodarone, a medicine used to treat an irregular heartbeat
*   cimetidine, an indigestion medicine
*   erythromycin, an antibiotic
*   ketoconazole, a medicine to treat fungal infections
*   any medicine that makes you feel sleepy, gives you a dry mouth or makes it difficult for you to pee – taking loratadine might make these side effects worse

【70】### Mixing loratadine with herbal remedies and supplements

【71】There's very little information about taking herbal remedies and supplements with loratadine. But there might be a problem with some of them, especially ones that cause sleepiness or a dry mouth, or make it difficult to pee.

【72】Ask your pharmacist for advice.

【73】### Important: Medicine safety

【74】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal medicines, vitamins or supplements.

【75】9\. Common questions about loratadine
-------------------------------------

【76】How does loratadine work?

【77】Loratadine is a type of medicine called an antihistamine.

【78】When you come into contact with something you have an allergy to, such as pollen, animal hair or fur, house dust or insect bites, your body produces a chemical called histamine.

【79】Usually, histamine is a useful substance but in an allergic reaction it causes unpleasant symptoms including itchy, watery eyes, running or blocked nose, sneezing and skin rashes.

【80】Loratadine blocks the effects of histamine and so reduces these symptoms.

【81】Loratadine is a non-drowsy antihistamine, so it does not make you feel as sleepy as other medicines like it.

【82】When will I feel better?

【83】You should start to feel better within an hour.

【84】How long should I take loratadine for?

【85】It depends on why you're taking it.

【86】You may only need to take loratadine for a short time or as a one-off dose. If you have a reaction to an insect bite, you may only need to take loratadine for a day or two.

【87】You may need to take it for longer if you're taking it to prevent hay fever symptoms when the pollen count is high.

【88】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're not sure how long you need to take loratadine for.

【89】Is it safe to take loratadine for a long time?

【90】Loratadine is unlikely to do you any harm if you take it for a long time. However, it's best to take it only for as long as you need to.

【91】Can I drink alcohol with it?

【92】It's best not to drink alcohol while you're taking loratadine, as it can make you feel sleepy.

【93】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【94】You can eat and drink normally while taking loratadine.

【95】Can I drive or ride a bike with it?

【96】Loratadine is classed as a non-drowsy antihistamine but it's still possible to feel sleepy after taking it.

【97】If this happens to you, do not drive a car or ride a bike until you feel better.

【98】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【99】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking loratadine删除7：<u> GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.</u>

【100】What's the difference between loratadine and other antihistamines?

【101】Loratadine is known as a non-drowsy antihistamine. It's less likely to make you feel sleepy than other, so-called, sedating antihistamines such as Piriton (chlorphenamine).

【102】Most people prefer to take a non-drowsy antihistamine instead of a sedating one. An exception is when you want the medicine to make you sleepy – for example, if you have itchy skin that's keeping you awake.

【103】What's the difference between loratadine and other non-drowsy antihistamines?

【104】Other non-drowsy antihistamines like cetirizine, desloratadine, fexofenadine and levocetirizine seem to work as well as loratadine.

【105】However, loratadine, desloratadine and fexofenadine seem to be less likely to make you feel sleepy than cetirizine.

【106】Can I take it with painkillers?

【107】Yes, you can take loratadine together with paracetamol or ibuprofen.

【108】Can I take 2 different antihistamines together?

【109】Sometimes, doctors recommend that people with a severe, itchy skin rash take 2 different antihistamines together for a few days.

【110】As well as taking a non-drowsy antihistamine like loratadine during the day, your doctor may tell you to take a sedating antihistamine at night if the itching is making it difficult to sleep.

【111】Do not take 2 antihistamines together unless recommended by your doctor.

【112】Can I take loratadine with other hay fever treatments?

【113】Yes, it's fine to take loratadine together with some other types of hay fever treatment, including steroid nasal sprays (such as Beconase, Rhinacort Aqua and Flixonase Nasules), or eyedrops.

【114】Can I take loratadine at higher doses than on the packet?

【115】Your doctor might suggest you or your child take a higher dose of loratadine (up to 4 times the usual dose) for severe itchy skin rash or swelling underneath the skin (angioedema).

【116】Taking high doses of loratadine is not suitable for everyone though.

【117】Speak to your doctor if you think loratadine is not working for you.

【118】Will it affect my fertility?

【119】There's no evidence to suggest that taking loratadine will reduce fertility in either men or women.

【120】However, speak to a pharmacist or your doctor before taking it if you're trying to get pregnant.

【121】Will it affect my contraception?

【122】Loratadine will not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【123】Can lifestyle changes relieve hay fever?

【124】It will help if you do not spend too much time outside if the pollen count is high.

【125】#### Tips for when you're outside

【126】*   Do not cut grass or walk on grass.
*   Wear wraparound sunglasses to stop pollen getting into your eyes.
*   Put Vaseline around your nostrils to help trap pollen.
*   Shower and change your clothes after you've been outside to wash off pollen.

【127】#### Tips for when you're inside

【128】*   Keep windows and doors shut as much as possible.
*   Vacuum regularly and dust with a damp cloth.
*   Do not keep fresh flowers in the house.
*   Do not smoke or be around smoke as it makes hay fever symptoms worse.
删除11：<u>Related conditions
------------------

【129】*   Atopic eczema
*   Conjunctivitis
*   Food allergy
*   Hay fever
*   Hives
*   Insect bites and stings
</u>删除11：<u>Useful resources
----------------

【130】*   HealthUnlocked: loratadine forum
*   Allergy UK: charity
*   Itchy Sneezy Wheezy: website for parents
*   Medicines for Children: loratadine for allergy symptoms
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 14 October 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 14 October 2024</u>

source_info.title: Diabetes insipidus
source_info.text:
【0】Diagnosis \- Diabetes insipidus
===============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications</u>

【2】**See your GP if you have the symptoms of diabetes insipidus. They'll ask about your symptoms and carry out a number of tests.**

【3】You may be referred to an endocrinologist (a specialist in hormone conditions) for these tests.

【4】As the symptoms of diabetes insipidus are similar to those of other conditions, including type 1 diabetes and type 2 diabetes, tests will be needed to confirm which condition you have.

【5】If diabetes insipidus is diagnosed, the tests will also be able to identify the type you have (cranial or nephrogenic).

【6】Water deprivation test
----------------------

【7】A water deprivation test involves not drinking any liquid for several hours to see how your body responds.

【8】If you have diabetes insipidus, you'll continue to pee large amounts of dilute urine when normally you'd only pee a small amount of concentrated urine.

【9】During the test, the amount of urine you produce will be measured.

【10】You may also need a blood test to assess the levels of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) in your blood.

【11】Your blood and urine may also be tested for substances such as glucose (blood sugar), calcium and potassium.

【12】If you have diabetes insipidus, your urine will be very dilute, with low levels of other substances.

【13】A large amount of sugar in your urine may be a sign of type 1 or type 2 diabetes rather than diabetes insipidus.

【14】Vasopressin test
----------------

【15】After the water deprivation test, you may be given a small dose of vasopressin (AVP), usually as an injection.

【16】This will show how your body reacts to the hormone, which helps to identify the type of diabetes insipidus you have.

【17】If the dose of AVP stops you peeing urine, it's likely your condition is the result of a shortage of AVP.

【18】If this is the case, you may be diagnosed with cranial diabetes insipidus.

【19】If you continue to pee despite the dose of AVP, this suggests there's already enough AVP in your body, but your kidneys are not responding to it.

【20】In this case, you may be diagnosed with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

【21】MRI scan
--------

【22】An MRI is a type of scan that uses a strong magnetic field and radio waves to produce images of the inside of the body, including your brain.

【23】You may need an MRI scan if your endocrinologist thinks you have cranial diabetes insipidus as a result of damage to your hypothalamus or pituitary gland.

【24】If your condition is caused by an abnormality in your hypothalamus or pituitary gland, it may need to be treated too, along with treatment for diabetes insipidus.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 13 October 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 13 October 2025</u>

source_info.title: Coeliac disease
source_info.text:
【0】Causes \- Coeliac disease
=========================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications</u>

【2】**Coeliac disease is caused by an abnormal immune system reaction to the protein gluten, which is found in foods such as bread, pasta, cereals and biscuits.**

【3】It's an autoimmune condition, where the immune system mistakes healthy cells and substances for harmful ones and produces antibodies against them (antibodies usually fight off bacteria and viruses).

【4】In the case of coeliac disease, your immune system mistakes one of the substances that makes up gluten, called gliadin, as a threat to the body. The antibodies that are produced cause the surface of your intestine to become inflamed (red and swollen).

【5】The surface of the intestine is usually covered with millions of tiny tube-shaped growths called villi. Villi increase the surface area of your gut and help it to digest food more effectively.

【6】However, in coeliac disease, the damage and inflammation to the lining of the gut flattens the villi, reducing their ability to help with digestion.

【7】As a result, your intestine is not able to digest the nutrients from your food, which causes the symptoms of coeliac disease.

【8】Oats
----

【9】Some people with coeliac disease may find that eating oats can trigger symptoms. This is because some oats may be contaminated by other grains during production.

【10】Oats also contain a protein called avenin, which is similar to gluten. Most people with coeliac disease can safely eat avenin. However, there's some evidence to suggest a very small number of people may still be sensitive to products that are gluten-free and do not contain contaminated oats.

【11】Increased risk
--------------

【12】It's not known why people develop coeliac disease. It's also not clear why some people have mild symptoms while others have severe symptoms.

【13】However, several factors are known to increase your risk of developing coeliac disease.

【14】### Family history

【15】Coeliac disease often runs in families. If you have a close relative with the condition, such as a parent, brother or sister, your chance of also getting it is increased.

【16】This risk is approximately 10% for those with a family history. If you have an identical twin with coeliac disease, there's around a 75% chance you'll also develop the condition.

【17】Research shows that coeliac disease is strongly associated with abnormal changes to the instructions that control cell activity (genetic mutations). These mutations affect the HLA-DQ genes, which are a group of genes responsible for the development of the immune system and may be passed down through a family.

【18】However, mutations in HLA-DQ genes are very common. This suggests that something else, such as environmental factors, must trigger coeliac disease in certain people.

【19】### Environmental factors

【20】You're more likely to develop coeliac disease if you had a digestive system infection (such as a rotavirus infection) during early childhood.

【21】Most experts recommend waiting until your child is at least 6 months old before giving them food containing gluten.

【22】There might also be an increased chance of babies developing coeliac disease if they're not being breastfed when gluten is introduced into their diet.
删除7：<u>Find out more about your baby's first solid foods.</u>

【23】### Other health conditions

【24】Other health conditions can increase your risk of developing coeliac disease, including:

【25】*   type 1 diabetes
*   thyroid conditions
*   Down's syndrome 
*   Turner syndrome

【26】It's unclear whether these health conditions directly increase the risk of developing coeliac disease, or whether they and coeliac disease both have another, single underlying cause.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 31 March 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 31 March 2026</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Symptoms</u>删除1：<u>*   Next : Diagnosis</u>

source_info.title: Chestfeeding if you're trans or non-binary
source_info.text:
【0】Chestfeeding if you're trans or non-binary
==========================================

【1】Chestfeeding is feeding your baby with milk from your chest.

【2】If you’re able to chestfeed, it’s your decision whether you do and you can change your mind at any time. You will be fully supported in any decisions you make.

【3】Chestfeeding if you’ve had top surgery
--------------------------------------

【4】If you’ve had top surgery to remove soft tissue, you may still be able to chestfeed or express your milk.

【5】It is not possible to know how much milk you will produce and if it will be enough for your baby. You may need to offer your baby supplementary feeds.

【6】Your baby may find it difficult to latch on to your nipple if there is less soft tissue available. In this case, talk to your midwife.

【7】### Non-urgent advice: Speak to your midwife or a GP if:

【8】*   you want to take testosterone while chestfeeding

【9】Testosterone can decrease your milk supply. Your midwife or a GP can advise you.

【10】**Binding while chestfeeding**
------------------------------

【11】If you bind (reduce the appearance of soft tissue by flattening your chest) and are chestfeeding, there may be a higher chance of you getting an infection called mastitis.

【12】Mastitis is when your chest becomes swollen, hot and painful. You may want to try wearing a larger size binder than before.

【13】Speak to your midwife or a GP if you think you may have mastitis.

【14】Skin-to-skin contact
--------------------

【15】Skin-to-skin contact with your newborn is a great way to bond with your baby.

【16】Skin-to-skin means holding your baby naked or dressed only in a nappy against your skin.

【17】It’s good to do at any time and will help to comfort you and your baby over the first few weeks as you get to know each other.

【18】Further support
---------------

【19】*   Brighton and Sussex University Hospitals Gender Inclusion has a support leaflet and resources, which might be helpful for you to take to appointments
*   La Leche League GB: Support for Transgender & Non-binary Parents
删除11：<u>More in Having a baby if you're LGBT+
-------------------------------------

【20】*   Ways to become a parent if you're LGBT+
*   Testosterone and pregnancy
*   Chestfeeding if you're trans or non-binary
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 9 December 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 9 December 2024</u>

source_info.title: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD)
source_info.text:
【0】Treatments \- Age-related macular degeneration (AMD)
====================================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  What is AMD?
2.  Symptoms
3.  Getting diagnosed
4.  Treatments
5.  Living with AMD</u>

【2】Treatment depends on the type of AMD you have.

【3】*   **Dry AMD** – there's no treatment, but vision aids can help reduce the effect on your life. Read about living with AMD.
*   **Wet AMD** – you may need regular eye injections and, very occasionally, a light treatment called photodynamic therapy, to stop your vision getting worse.

【4】What the different types mean

【5】Types of AMD

| Dry AMD | Wet AMD |
| --- | --- |
| Caused by a build-up of a fatty substance called drusen at the back of the eyes | Caused by the growth of abnormal blood vessels at the back of the eyes |
| Common | Less common |
| Gets worse gradually – usually over several years | Can get worse quickly – sometimes in days or weeks |
| No treatment – unless it develops into wet AMD | Treatment can help stop vision getting worse |

【7】### Eye injections

【8】#### Anti-VEGF medicines – ranibizumab (Lucentis), aflibercept (Eylea) and brolucizumab (Beovu)

【9】Injections given directly into the eyes:

【10】*   stops vision getting worse in 9 out of 10 people and improves vision in 3 out of 10 people
*   usually given every 1, 2 or 3 months for as long as necessary
*   drops numb the eyes before treatment – most people have minimal discomfort
*   side effects include bleeding in the eye, feeling like there's something in the eye, and redness and irritation of the eye

【11】Macular Society: injections for wet AMD

【12】### Light treatment

【13】#### Photodynamic therapy (PDT)

【14】A light is shined at the back of the eyes to destroy the abnormal blood vessels that cause wet AMD:

【15】*   may be recommended alongside eye injections if injections alone do not help
*   usually needs to be repeated every few months
*   side effects include temporary vision problems, and the eyes and skin being sensitive to light for a few days or weeks
删除7：<u>Find out more about photodynamic therapy</u>

【16】Research into new treatments
----------------------------

【17】Research into new treatments for AMD is ongoing. Your specialist can let you know if there are any studies you could take part in.

【18】You can also search the UK Clinical Trials Gateway (UKCTG) to find studies.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 20 April 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 20 April 2024</u>

source_info.title: Dexamethasone tablets and liquid
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take dexamethasone tablets and liquid \- Brand names: Neofordex, Glensoludex, Martapan
=========================================================================================================

【1】Who can take dexamethasone tablets and liquid
---------------------------------------------

【2】Most adults and children (including babies) can take dexamethasone.

【3】Who may not be able to take dexamethasone tablets and liquid
------------------------------------------------------------

【4】Dexamethasone is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell your doctor if you have:

【5】*   ever had an allergic reaction to dexamethasone or any other medicine
*   recently been in contact with someone with shingles, chickenpox or measles
*   an infection or any unhealed wounds
*   liver or kidney problems
*   ever had mental health problems (or a close family member has)
*   ever had tuberculosis (TB)
*   high blood pressure, heart failure or have recently had a heart attack
*   diabetes
*   epilepsy
*   glaucoma
*   an underactive thyroid
*   osteoporosis (thinning bones)
*   a stomach ulcer
*   myasthenia gravis, a rare condition that causes muscle weakness
*   recently had vaccinations, or are due to have vaccinations
*   been trying to get pregnant, or are pregnant or breastfeeding
删除11：<u>More in Dexamethasone tablets and liquid
----------------------------------------

【6】*   About dexamethasone tablets and liquid
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 7 September 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 7 September 2026</u>

source_info.title: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
source_info.text:
【0】Diagnosis \- Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
============================================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Living with</u>

【2】**If you think you or your child may have attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), speak to a GP. You can also speak to your child’s teacher or their school’s special educational needs co-ordinator (SENCO).**

【3】The GP cannot formally diagnose ADHD, but they can discuss your concerns with you and refer you for a specialist assessment, if necessary. Your school may also be able to arrange a specialist referral for your child.

【4】When you see a GP, they may ask you:

【5】*   about your symptoms or those of your child
*   when these symptoms started
*   where the symptoms occur – for example, at home, in school, college or university, or at work
*   whether the symptoms affect your or your child's day-to-day life – for example, if they make socialising difficult
*   if there have been any recent significant events in your or your child's life, such as a death or divorce in the family
*   if there's a family history of ADHD
*   about any other problems or symptoms of different health conditions you or your child may have

【6】Next steps
----------

【7】### Children and teenagers

【8】If the GP thinks your child may have ADHD, they may first suggest a period of "watchful waiting" – lasting around 10 weeks – to see if your child's symptoms improve, stay the same or get worse.

【9】They may also suggest starting a group-based, ADHD-focused parent training or education programme. Being offered a parent training and education programme does not mean you have been a bad parent – it aims to teach you ways of helping yourself and your child.
删除8：<u>See treating ADHD for more information.</u>

【10】If your child's behaviour does not improve, and both you and the GP believe it's affecting their day-to-day life, the GP should refer you and your child to a specialist for a formal assessment.

【11】### Adults

【12】For adults with possible ADHD, the GP will assess your symptoms and may refer you for an assessment if:

【13】*   you were not diagnosed with ADHD as a child, but your symptoms began during childhood and have been ongoing since
*   your symptoms cannot be explained by a mental health condition
*   your symptoms significantly affect your day-to-day life – for example, if you're underachieving at work or find intimate relationships difficult

【14】You may also be referred to a specialist if you had ADHD as a child or young person and your symptoms are now causing moderate or severe functional impairment.

【15】Assessment
----------

【16】You or your child may be referred to 1 of the following types of specialist for a formal assessment:

【17】*   a specialist child or adult psychiatrist
*   a paediatrician – a specialist in children's health
*   an appropriately qualified healthcare professional with training and expertise in the diagnosis of ADHD

【18】Who you're referred to depends on your age and what's available in your local area.

【19】There's no simple test to determine whether you or your child has ADHD, but your specialist can make an accurate diagnosis after a detailed assessment. The assessment may include:

【20】*   a physical examination, which can help rule out other possible causes for the symptoms
*   a series of interviews with you or your child
*   interviews or reports from other significant people, such as partners, parents and teachers

【21】Diagnosis in children and teenagers
-----------------------------------

【22】Diagnosing ADHD in children depends on a set of strict criteria. To be diagnosed with ADHD, your child must have 6 or more symptoms of inattentiveness, or 6 or more symptoms of hyperactivity and impulsiveness.
删除7：<u>Read more about the symptoms of ADHD</u>

【23】To be diagnosed with ADHD, your child must also have:

【24】*   been displaying symptoms continuously for at least 6 months
*   started to show symptoms before the age of 12
*   been showing symptoms in at least 2 different settings – for example, at home and at school, to rule out the possibility that the behaviour is just a reaction to certain teachers or to parental control
*   symptoms that make their lives considerably more difficult on a social, academic or occupational level
*   symptoms that are not just part of a developmental disorder or difficult phase, and are not better accounted for by another condition

【25】Diagnosis in adults
-------------------

【26】Diagnosing ADHD in adults is more difficult because there's some disagreement about whether the list of symptoms used to diagnose children and teenagers also applies to adults.

【27】In some cases, an adult may be diagnosed with ADHD if they have 5 or more of the symptoms of inattentiveness, or 5 or more of hyperactivity and impulsiveness, listed in diagnostic criteria for children with ADHD.

【28】As part of your assessment, the specialist will ask about your present symptoms. However, under current diagnostic guidelines, a diagnosis of ADHD in adults cannot be confirmed unless your symptoms have been present from childhood.

【29】If you find it difficult to remember whether you had problems as a child, your specialist may wish to see your old school records, or talk to your parents, teachers or anyone else who knew you well when you were a child.

【30】For an adult to be diagnosed with ADHD, their symptoms should also have a moderate effect on different areas of their life, such as:

【31】*   underachieving at work or in education
*   driving dangerously
*   difficulty making or keeping friends
*   difficulty in relationships with partners

【32】If your problems are recent and did not occur regularly in the past, you're not considered to have ADHD. This is because it's currently thought that ADHD cannot develop for the first time in adults.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 24 December 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 24 December 2024</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Causes</u>删除1：<u>*   Next : Treatment</u>

source_info.title: What is a knee replacement?
source_info.text:
【0】What is a knee replacement?
===========================

【1】*   Knee replacement surgery involves replacing damaged parts of your knee joint with metal or plastic parts.
*   It's most commonly used to treat pain and stiffness in the knee joint caused by osteoarthritis.
*   It may be recommended if other treatments or lifestyle changes have not worked and knee pain is affecting your daily life.
*   Depending on the damage to your knee, it can be used to replace all of your knee joint (total knee replacement) or some of it (partial knee replacement).
*   You'll have the operation in hospital. It can take several months or more to fully recover afterwards.
*   Knee replacements can last for 20 years or more and can significantly improve daily life for people with knee pain.
删除3：<u>Video: Knee replacement
-----------------------

【2】This animation shows how knee replacement surgery is done and explains why it may be needed.
删除1：<u>Media last reviewed: 1 April 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Media review due: 1 April 2024</u>

------------------------
