source_info.title: Returning to work after mental health issues
source_info.text:
【0】Returning to work after mental health issues
============================================

【1】**If you've had a mental health problem and been off or out of work, you may worry about going back.**

【2】You may be concerned about how your colleagues will react, for example, or that you will not be able to cope.

【3】But most people find that going back to work is a positive step, and support is available to help ease your way back in.

【4】Going back to work after taking sick leave
------------------------------------------

【5】If your job is still open for you, consider talking to a GP before going back to work. Then you can arrange a meeting with your employer or occupational health adviser.

【6】You can discuss anything that concerns you about returning to work, including any recommendations from the GP.

【7】You may wish to ask about:

【8】*   flexible hours – you might like to return part-time, for example, or start later in the day if you're sleepy from medicine in the mornings
*   support from a colleague in the short or long term
*   a place you can go for a break when needed

【9】Support for people with mental health problems
----------------------------------------------

【10】### Reasonable adjustments

【11】By law, employers must make "reasonable adjustments" for workers with disabilities or long-term physical or mental conditions.

【12】This could mean giving someone with social anxiety their own desk rather than expecting them to hot desk, for example.

【13】See more about reasonable adjustments

【14】### Access to Work

【15】If you need extra help beyond reasonable adjustments, you can apply for an Access to Work grant. These pay for practical support so you can carry on doing your job or start a new one.

【16】Find out about Access to Work

【17】### Fit for Work  

【18】Fit for Work offers free advice to people with a health problem who want to stay in or get back to work.

【19】Visit the Fit for Work Advice Hub

【20】Looking for a new job
---------------------

【21】If you're unemployed and want to get back into work, staff at your local Jobcentre Plus can help. If you have ongoing mental health issues, ask to speak to their disability employment adviser.

【22】If you have a mental health worker, they can also tell you about the support available to help people with mental health problems get back to work.

【23】Before you speak to anyone, think about:

【24】*   where you would like to work
*   what kind of work you would like to do
*   what type of support you may need
*   your financial situation, including any benefits you're getting

【25】A full-time paid job is not the only option open to you. There are other possibilities that may suit you, including part-time work or volunteering.

【26】### Volunteering

【27】Volunteering is a popular way of getting back into work. Helping other people in need is great for your self-esteem and can take your mind off your own worries.

【28】Plus, volunteer work can improve your chances of getting a paid job when you're ready and, until then, you can carry on claiming your benefits.
删除7：<u>Find out more about how to volunteer</u>

【29】Your rights and the law
-----------------------

【30】Some people worry that when they apply for a job, they will be discriminated against if they admit that they have, or have had, mental or emotional health problems.

【31】But it's illegal for employers to ask health or health-related questions before making a job offer.

【32】It's also illegal to discriminate against people with any kind of health condition or disability, including mental health issues.

【33】How work benefits your mental health
------------------------------------

【34】People usually find going back to work after a period of mental illness a positive experience.

【35】Among other things, work can give you:

【36】*   a sense of identity and purpose
*   the chance to build new friendships
*   better financial security
*   the feeling that you're playing an active part in society
删除4：<u>More information
----------------

【37】*   GOV.UK has advice on when mental health becomes a disability
*   See tips on preparing for your return to work on the Mind website

【38】</u>删除11：<u>More in Advice for life situations and events
---------------------------------------------

【39】*   Returning to work after mental health issues
*   Bullying at work
*   Coping with financial worries
*   Mental health support if you're lesbian, gay, bisexual or trans (LGBTQ+)
*   How to help someone with depression
*   Loneliness in older people: how to help
*   How to help someone with an eating disorder
*   Bereavement
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 26 March 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 26 March 2024</u>

source_info.title: Peripheral arterial disease (PAD)
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Peripheral arterial disease (PAD)
=============================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Diagnosis
3.  Treatment</u>

【2】**Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is a common condition where a build-up of fatty deposits in the arteries restricts blood supply to leg muscles. It's also known as peripheral vascular disease (PVD).**

【3】Symptoms of peripheral arterial disease
---------------------------------------

【4】Many people with PAD have no symptoms. However, some develop a painful ache in their legs when they walk, which usually disappears after a few minutes' rest. The medical term for this is "intermittent claudication".

【5】The pain can range from mild to severe, and usually goes away after a few minutes when you rest your legs.

【6】Both legs are often affected at the same time, although the pain may be worse in 1 leg.

【7】Other symptoms of PAD can include:

【8】*   hair loss on your legs and feet
*   numbness or weakness in the legs
*   brittle, slow-growing toenails
*   ulcers (open sores) on your feet and legs, which do not heal
*   changing skin colour on your legs, such as turning paler than usual or blue – this may be harder to see on brown and black skin
*   shiny skin
*   in men, erectile dysfunction
*   the muscles in your legs shrinking (wasting)

【9】The symptoms of PAD often develop slowly, over time. If your symptoms develop quickly, or get suddenly worse, it could be a sign of a serious problem requiring immediate treatment.

【10】When to see a GP
----------------

【11】You should see a GP if you experience recurring leg pain when exercising.

【12】Many people mistakenly think this is just part of growing older, but there's no reason why an otherwise healthy person should experience leg pain.

【13】PAD is usually diagnosed through a physical examination by a GP, and by comparing the blood pressure in your arm and your ankle.

【14】A difference between the 2 may indicate PAD and is called the ankle brachial pressure index (ABPI).

【15】Read about diagnosing PAD.

【16】Causes of peripheral arterial disease
-------------------------------------

【17】PAD is a form of cardiovascular disease (CVD) because it affects the blood vessels.

【18】It's usually caused by a build-up of fatty deposits in the walls of the leg arteries. The fatty deposits (atheroma) are made up of cholesterol and other waste substances.

【19】The build-up of fatty deposits on the walls of the arteries makes the arteries narrower and restricts blood flow to the legs. This process is called atherosclerosis.

【20】There are certain things that can increase your chances of developing PAD and other forms of CVD, including:

【21】*   smoking – the most significant risk factor
*   type 1 diabetes and type 2 diabetes
*   high blood pressure (hypertension)
*   high cholesterol
*   growing older

【22】Treating peripheral arterial disease
------------------------------------

【23】PAD is largely treated through lifestyle changes and medication.

【24】Exercising regularly and not smoking are the main lifestyle changes that can ease the symptoms of PAD and reduce the chances of it getting worse. It's also important to:

【25】*   eat a healthy diet
*   lose weight, if you're overweight or obese
*   moderate your consumption of alcohol

【26】Read about:

【27】Stopping smoking

【28】Exercise

【29】The underlying causes should also be treated, including high blood pressure, high cholesterol and diabetes. Medicine and, in some cases, surgery can be used to improve the blood flow in your legs.

【30】With treatment, most people's symptoms remain stable and some people may experience an improvement in their pain.

【31】If treatment is unsuccessful, there's a risk of potentially serious complications.

【32】Read about treating PAD.

【33】Complications of peripheral arterial disease
--------------------------------------------

【34】PAD is not immediately life-threatening, but the process of atherosclerosis that causes it can lead to serious and potentially fatal problems.

【35】### Coronary heart disease (CHD)

【36】The blockages in the arteries in the legs can also affect other areas of your body, such as the arteries supplying the heart and brain. 

【37】This means that having PAD makes you more likely to develop another form of cardiovascular disease (CVD), such as:

【38】*   coronary heart disease
*   stroke
*   heart attack
*   angina

【39】### Critical limb ischaemia (CLI)

【40】If the blood flow to the legs becomes severely restricted, critical limb ischaemia (CLI) can develop. CLI is an extremely serious complication that can be challenging to treat.

【41】Symptoms of CLI include:

【42】*   a severe burning pain in your legs and feet that continues even when you're resting
*   your skin turning pale, shiny, smooth and dry
*   wounds and ulcers (open sores) on your feet and legs that do not heal
*   loss of muscle mass in your legs
*   the skin on your toes or lower limbs becoming cold and numb, turning red and then black, and/or beginning to swell and produce smelly pus, causing severe pain (gangrene) – changes in skin colour may be harder to see on brown and black skin

【43】If you think you're developing symptoms of CLI, contact a GP immediately. If this is not possible call 111 or use 111 online.

【44】An angioplasty or bypass graft is usually recommended if you have CLI, although these may not always be successful or possible. In a few cases, an amputation below the knee may be required.

source_info.title: Terbinafine
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take or use terbinafine \- Brand names: Lamisil, Lamisil Once
================================================================================

【1】Who can take or use terbinafine
-------------------------------

【2】Terbinafine tablets, cream and gel can be prescribed for adults and children aged 1 year old and over.

【3】The cream, gel and spray that you can buy in a pharmacy or shop are suitable for people aged 16 years old and over.

【4】The solution is only suitable for adults aged 18 years old and over.

【5】Who may not be able to take or use terbinafine
----------------------------------------------

【6】Terbinafine is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you have ever had an allergic reaction to terbinafine or any other medicine.

【7】To make sure the tablets are safe for you, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you:

【8】*   have ever had liver or kidney problems
*   are pregnant, trying to get pregnant or are breastfeeding
删除11：<u>More in Terbinafine
-------------------

【9】*   About terbinafine
*   Who can and cannot take or use it
*   How and when to take or use it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking or using it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 24 March 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 24 March 2026</u>

source_info.title: Remdesivir (Veklury)
source_info.text:
【0】About remdesivir
================

【1】Remdesivir is an antiviral medicine that works by stopping the virus that causes COVID-19 from growing and spreading in the body.

【2】It's used to treat early COVID-19 infection and help to prevent more severe symptoms.

【3】You will be given remdesivir through a drip, usually in your arm (infusion).

【4】You'll need to have the treatment as soon as possible after you have tested positive for COVID-19 and within 7 days of your symptoms starting.

【5】You'll be given remdesivir in a hospital or at a local centre.

【6】You will only be eligible to have the medicine if you are in the highest risk group.

【7】If you test positive for COVID-19, and are eligible, call your GP surgery, NHS 111 or your hospital specialist as soon as possible. This is so they can consider referring you for an assessment for COVID-19 treatment.

【8】Find about more about how to get treatment for COVID-19

【9】Key facts
---------

【10】*   You will have remdesivir treatment once a day for 3 days in a hospital or at a local centre. Even if you start to feel better, it's important that you complete the course.
*   It's important that you start treatment within 7 days of getting COVID-19 symptoms.
*   Your treatment will be given through a drip in your arm (infusion) – it can take between 30 minutes and 2 hours.
*   Remdesivir starts working very soon after having it.
*   Common side effects of remdesivir include headaches and feeling sick.
删除11：<u>More in Remdesivir (Veklury)
----------------------------

【11】*   About remdesivir
*   Who can and cannot have it
*   How and when to have it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Having remdesivir with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 18 May 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 18 May 2025</u>

source_info.title: Kyphosis
source_info.text:
【0】Diagnosis \- Kyphosis
=====================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Causes
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment</u>

【2】**Kyphosis can usually be diagnosed by examining your spine and taking an X-ray.**

【3】Examination
-----------

【4】During the examination, your GP may ask you to do a number of exercises to assess whether your balance and range of movement are affected.

【5】Your GP may also ask you to lie down so they can see whether the curvature of your spine is caused by bad posture or a structural problem.

【6】Although it's not always the case, if your spine straightens when you lie down, it's likely that your kyphosis is caused by poor posture (postural kyphosis).

【7】However, if your spine stills curves while you're lying down, it's likely that kyphosis is caused by a problem with the structure of your spine, as found in the Scheuermann's or congenital types of kyphosis.

【8】X-ray and scans
---------------

【9】An X-ray can usually confirm the diagnosis and determine the cause of the kyphosis.

【10】Further scans are usually only required if complex treatment, such as surgery, is being planned, or if you have additional symptoms that suggest your nervous system has been affected, such as numbness in your arms or legs.

【11】If you need additional scans you'll probably have a:

【12】*   CT scan – where a series of X-rays are taken to build-up a detailed 3-dimensional image of your spine
*   MRI scan – where strong, fluctuating magnetic fields are used to produce a detailed image of the inside of your spine

【13】Adults
------

【14】If you develop kyphosis in adulthood, you'll usually need some additional tests to determine the underlying cause.

【15】The tests you'll be referred for depend on any additional symptoms you have. They may include:

【16】*   blood tests – which can check for infections such as tuberculosis (TB)
*   a bone density scan – a type of X-ray to assess how strong your bones are; this can be useful for diagnosing conditions that cause weakening of the bones, such as osteoporosis or Paget's disease of bone
*   CT and MRI scans
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 12 May 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 12 May 2025</u>

source_info.title: Hydronephrosis
source_info.text:
【0】Treatment \- Hydronephrosis
===========================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Causes
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment</u>

【2】**Treatment for hydronephrosis depends on what's causing the condition and how severe it is.**

【3】In adults, the aims of treatment are to:

【4】*   remove the build-up of urine and relieve the pressure on your kidneys
*   prevent permanent kidney damage
*   treat the underlying cause

【5】Most people with hydronephrosis will have a procedure called urinary catheterisation to drain the urine from their kidneys.

【6】Depending on the underlying cause, medication or surgery may be needed afterwards to correct the problem.

【7】If the condition is severe or causing problems such as a urinary tract infection (UTI), you may to be treated soon after you're diagnosed.

【8】In less severe cases, it may be safe to delay treatment for a short period.

【9】Draining the urine
------------------

【10】The first stage in treating hydronephrosis is to drain the urine out of your kidneys.

【11】This will help ease your pain and prevent any further damage to your kidneys.

【12】A thin tube called a catheter may be inserted into your bladder through your urethra (the tube that carries urine out of the body). Or a catheter may be inserted directly into your bladder through a small cut in your tummy (abdomen). This is called a suprapubic catheter

【13】Find out about urinary catheterisation.

【14】In a few cases where one of the kidneys has already been severely damaged, it may be better to remove the affected kidney. 

【15】Most people can function normally with just one working kidney, which will not usually have a significant effect on your health or lifestyle.

【16】Treating the underlying cause
-----------------------------

【17】Once the pressure on your kidneys has been relieved, the cause of the build-up of urine may need to be treated.

【18】Some possible causes and their treatments are described below:

【19】*   **kidney stones** can be removed during an operation or broken up using sound waves – read more about treating kidney stones
*   **an** **enlarged prostate** can be treated with medication or surgery to remove some of the prostate – read more about treating prostate enlargement
*   **narrowing of the ureter** (the tube that runs from the kidney to the bladder) can be treated by inserting a hollow plastic or metal tube called a stent, which allows urine to flow through the narrowed section – this can often be done without making cuts in your skin
*   **cancer** that's causing hydronephrosis may be treated using chemotherapy, radiotherapy or surgery to remove the cancerous tissue

【20】If hydronephrosis happens because you're pregnant, you will not usually need any treatment because the condition will pass within a few weeks of giving birth.

【21】In the meantime, catheters can be regularly used to drain urine from the kidneys.

【22】Painkillers and antibiotics can also be given if you're in pain or develop a UTI.

【23】Treating antenatal hydronephrosis in babies
-------------------------------------------

【24】Most babies diagnosed with antenatal hydronephrosis (ANH) before they're born will not need any treatment because the condition will improve before they're born or within a few months of their birth.

【25】There's usually no risk to you or your child, so labour should not need to be started early.

【26】After the birth, your baby may be examined to check for any obvious problems, such as swollen kidneys, but normally you'll be able to take them home with you.

【27】Your baby may need to return to hospital for some scans during the next few weeks to check there aren't any continuing problems.

【28】These scans may include:

【29】*   **an** **ultrasound scan** – where sound waves are used to create a picture of your baby's kidneys
*   **a micturating cystourethrogram (MCUG)** – where a thin tube is used to pass a special type of liquid that shows up clearly on X-rays into your baby's bladder while a series of X-rays are taken
*   **a dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan or MAG-3 scan** – where your baby is injected with a substance that shows up on a special device called a gamma camera; the camera is then used to take pictures of your child's kidneys

【30】In most babies, antenatal hydronephrosis will get better as they get older. But until scans show there's no longer a problem, your child may need to take antibiotics to reduce their chances of developing a UTI. This is because the urine inside their kidneys can make them more vulnerable to infection.

【31】If ANH does not get better by itself, your child may need to keep taking antibiotics. Surgery is not usually needed.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 11 December 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 11 December 2024</u>

source_info.title: Breast cancer in women
source_info.text:
【0】Treatment \- Breast cancer in women
===================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Living with
7.  Prevention</u>

【2】**If you have breast cancer, you should be assigned a multidisciplinary team (MDT), which is a group of specialists who work together to provide the best treatment and care.**

【3】The main treatments for breast cancer are:

【4】*   surgery
*   radiotherapy
*   chemotherapy
*   hormone therapy
*   targeted therapy

【5】You may have one of these treatments, or a combination. The type or combination of treatments you have will depend on how the cancer was diagnosed and the stage it's at.

【6】Breast cancer diagnosed at routine screening may be at an early stage, but breast cancer diagnosed when you have symptoms may be at a later stage and require a different treatment.

【7】Your MDT should discuss with you which treatments are most suitable.

【8】Choosing the right treatment for you
------------------------------------

【9】When deciding what treatment is best for you, your doctors will consider:

【10】*   the stage and grade of the cancer (how big it is and how far it has spread)
*   your general health
*   whether you have experienced the menopause

【11】You should be able to discuss your treatment with your care team at any time and ask questions.

【12】### Want to know more?

【13】The online tool Predict helps you see how different treatments for early invasive breast cancer might affect you.

【14】Treatment overview
------------------

【15】Surgery is usually the first type of treatment for breast cancer. The type of surgery you have will depend on the type of breast cancer you have.

【16】Surgery is usually followed by chemotherapy or radiotherapy or, in some cases, hormone or targeted therapies.

【17】Again, the treatment you'll have will depend on the type of breast cancer.

【18】Your doctor will discuss the most suitable treatment plan with you. Chemotherapy or hormone therapy will sometimes be the first treatment.

【19】Treatment aims to achieve remission, where cancer shrinks or disappears, and you feel able to enjoy a good quality of life.

【20】### Secondary breast cancer

【21】Most breast cancers are discovered at an early stage.

【22】A small proportion of women discover they have breast cancer after it has already spread to other parts of the body (metastasis), and for some women breast cancer may come back after initial treatment.

【23】In these cases, the type of treatment you have may be different. Secondary cancer, also called "advanced" or "metastatic" cancer, is not curable.
删除6：<u>### Want to know more?

【24】*   Macmillan Cancer Support: treatments for breast cancer
*   Breast Cancer Now: secondary (metastatic) breast cancer

【25】</u>
Surgery
-------

【26】There are 2 main types of breast cancer surgery:

【27】*   breast-conserving surgery, where the cancerous lump (tumour) is removed
*   mastectomy, where the whole breast is removed

【28】In many cases, a mastectomy can be followed by reconstructive surgery to try to recreate a breast.

【29】Studies have shown that breast-conserving surgery followed by radiotherapy is as successful as total mastectomy at treating early-stage breast cancer.

【30】### Breast-conserving surgery

【31】Breast-conserving surgery ranges from a lumpectomy or wide local excision, where the tumour and a little surrounding breast tissue is removed, to a partial mastectomy or quadrantectomy, where up to a quarter of the breast is removed.

【32】If you have breast-conserving surgery, the amount of breast tissue that is removed will depend on:

【33】*   the type of cancer you have
*   the size of the tumour and where it is in your breast
*   the amount of surrounding tissue that needs to be removed
*   the size of your breasts

【34】Your surgeon will always remove an area of healthy breast tissue around the tumour, which will be tested for traces of cancer.

【35】If there's no cancer present in the healthy tissue, there's less chance that the cancer will return.

【36】If cancer cells are found in the surrounding tissue, more tissue may need to be removed from your breast.

【37】After having breast-conserving surgery, you'll usually be offered radiotherapy to destroy any remaining cancer cells.

【38】### Mastectomy

【39】A mastectomy is the removal of all the breast tissue, including the nipple.

【40】If there are no obvious signs that the cancer has spread to your lymph nodes, you may have a mastectomy, where your breast is removed, along with a sentinel lymph node biopsy.

【41】If the cancer has spread to your lymph nodes, you'll probably need more extensive removal (clearance) of lymph nodes from the area under your arm (axilla).

【42】### Reconstruction

【43】Breast reconstruction is surgery to make a new breast shape that looks as much as possible like your other breast.

【44】Reconstruction can be done at the same time as a mastectomy (immediate reconstruction), or it can be done later (delayed reconstruction).

【45】It can be done either by inserting a breast implant or by using tissue from another part of your body to create a new breast.

【46】### Lymph node surgery

【47】To find out if the cancer has spread, a procedure called a sentinel lymph node biopsy may be done.

【48】The sentinel lymph nodes are the first lymph nodes that the cancer cells reach if they spread. They're part of the lymph nodes under your arms (axillary lymph nodes).

【49】The position of the sentinel lymph nodes varies. They're identified using either a combination of a radioisotope and a blue dye, or a magnetic liquid (Magtrace).

【50】The sentinel lymph nodes are examined in the laboratory to see if there are any cancer cells present. This provides a good indicator of whether the cancer has spread.

【51】If there are cancer cells in the sentinel nodes, you may need further surgery to remove more lymph nodes from under your arm.
删除6：<u>### Want to know more?

【52】*   Cancer Research UK: types of breast cancer surgery
*   Breast Cancer Now: breast reconstruction and prostheses

【53】</u>
Radiotherapy
------------

【54】Radiotherapy uses controlled doses of radiation to kill cancer cells. It's usually given after surgery and chemotherapy to kill any remaining cancer cells.

【55】If you need radiotherapy, your treatment will begin about a month after your surgery or chemotherapy to give your body a chance to recover.

【56】You'll probably have radiotherapy sessions 3 to 5 days a week, for 3 to 5 weeks. Each session will last a few minutes.

【57】### The types of radiotherapy

【58】The type of radiotherapy you have will depend on the type of breast cancer and the type of surgery you have. Some women may not need to have radiotherapy at all.

【59】Types of radiotherapy include:

【60】*   breast radiotherapy – after breast-conserving surgery, radiation is applied to the whole of the remaining breast tissue
*   chest-wall radiotherapy – after a mastectomy, radiotherapy is applied to the chest wall
*   breast boost – some women may be offered a boost of high-dose radiotherapy in the area where the cancer was removed; however, this may affect the appearance of your breast, particularly if you have large breasts, and can sometimes have other side effects, including hardening of breast tissue (fibrosis)
*   radiotherapy to the lymph nodes – where radiotherapy is aimed at the armpit (axilla) and the surrounding area to kill any cancer that may be in the lymph nodes

【61】### The side effects of radiotherapy

【62】Side effects of radiotherapy include:

【63】*   irritation and darkening of the skin on your breast, which may lead to sore, red, weepy skin
*   extreme tiredness (fatigue)
*   excess fluid build-up in your arm caused by blockage of the lymph nodes under your arm (lymphoedema)
删除6：<u>### Want to know more?

【64】*   Macmillan Cancer Support: radiotherapy explained
*   Breast Cancer Now: radiotherapy for primary breast cancer
*   Cancer Research UK: radiotherapy for breast cancer

【65】</u>
Chemotherapy
------------

【66】Chemotherapy involves using anti-cancer (cytotoxic) medicine to kill cancer cells.

【67】It's usually used after surgery to destroy any cancer cells that have not been removed. This is called adjuvant chemotherapy.

【68】In some cases, you may have chemotherapy before surgery, which is often used to shrink a large tumour. This is called neo-adjuvant chemotherapy.

【69】Several different medicines are used in chemotherapy, and 2 to 3 are often given at once.

【70】The choice of medicine and the combination will depend on the type of breast cancer you have and how far it has spread.

【71】Chemotherapy is usually given as an outpatient treatment, which means you will not have to stay in hospital overnight.

【72】The medicines are usually given through a drip straight into a vein.

【73】In some cases, you may be given tablets that you can take at home. You may have chemotherapy sessions once every 2 to 4 weeks and then have a break. Each treatment session is known as a cycle. You may have up to 8 cycles of chemotherapy.

【74】The main side effects of chemotherapy are caused by its influence on normal, healthy cells, such as immune cells.

【75】Side effects of chemotherapy include:

【76】*   infections
*   loss of appetite
*   feeling sick
*   being sick
*   tiredness
*   hair loss
*   sore mouth

【77】Many side effects can be prevented or controlled with medicines that your doctor can prescribe.

【78】Chemotherapy medicine can also stop the production of oestrogen in your body, which is known to encourage the growth of some breast cancers.

【79】If you have not experienced the menopause, your periods may stop while you're having chemotherapy treatment.

【80】After you have finished the course of chemotherapy, your ovaries should start producing oestrogen again.

【81】But this does not always happen and you may enter an early menopause. This is more likely in women over 40, as they're closer to menopausal age.

【82】Your doctor will discuss with you the impact that treatment will have on your fertility.

【83】### Chemotherapy for secondary breast cancer

【84】If your breast cancer has spread beyond the breast and lymph nodes to other parts of your body, chemotherapy will not cure the cancer, but it may shrink the tumour, relieve your symptoms and help lengthen your life.
删除6：<u>### Want to know more?

【85】*   Breast Cancer Now: chemotherapy
*   Cancer Research UK: chemotherapy for breast cancer
*   Macmillan Cancer Support: chemotherapy explained

【86】</u>
Hormone treatment
-----------------

【87】Some breast cancers are stimulated to grow by the hormones oestrogen or progesterone, which are found naturally in your body. These are known as hormone receptor-positive cancers.

【88】Hormone therapy lowers the levels of oestrogen or progesterone hormones in your body or stops their effects.

【89】The type of hormone therapy you have will depend on the stage and grade of the cancer, which hormone it's sensitive to, your age, whether you have experienced the menopause, and what other type of treatment you're having.

【90】You'll probably have hormone therapy after surgery and chemotherapy, but it's sometimes given before surgery to shrink a tumour and make it easier to remove.

【91】Hormone therapy may be used as the only treatment for breast cancer if your general health prevents you having surgery, chemotherapy or radiotherapy.

【92】In most cases, you'll need to take hormone therapy for 5 years or more after having surgery.

【93】If the type of breast cancer you have is not sensitive to hormones, hormone therapy will have no effect.

【94】### Tamoxifen

【95】Tamoxifen stops oestrogen from binding to oestrogen-receptor-positive cancer cells. It's taken every day as a tablet or liquid.

【96】### Aromatase inhibitors

【97】If you have experienced the menopause, you may be offered an aromatase inhibitor.

【98】This type of medicine blocks aromatase, a substance that helps the body to produce oestrogen after the menopause. Before the menopause, oestrogen is made by the ovaries.

【99】3 aromatase inhibitors may be offered. These are anastrozole, exemestane and letrozole. These are taken as a tablet once a day.

【100】### Ovarian ablation or suppression

【101】In women who have not yet experienced the menopause, oestrogen is produced by the ovaries.

【102】Ovarian ablation or suppression stops the ovaries working and producing oestrogen.

【103】Ablation can be done using surgery or radiotherapy. It permanently stops the ovaries from working and means you'll experience the menopause early.

【104】Ovarian suppression involves using a medicine called goserelin, which is a luteinising hormone-releasing hormone agonist (LHRHa).

【105】Your periods will stop while you're taking it, although they should start again once your treatment is complete.

【106】If you're approaching the menopause (around the age of 50), your periods may not start again after you stop taking goserelin.

【107】Goserelin comes as an injection you have once a month.
删除6：<u>### Want to know more?

【108】*   Breast Cancer Now: hormone therapy

【109】</u>
Targeted therapies
------------------

【110】Targeted therapies are medicines that change the way cells work and help to stop cancer from growing and spreading. Not all types of breast cancer can be treated with targeted therapies

【111】The targeted therapy most commonly used to treat breast cancer is trastuzumab (also known by the brand name herceptin).

【112】Other targeted therapies include abemaciclib (brand name Verzenios), and palbociclib (brand name, Ibrance). These are used alongside hormone therapy treatments such as fulvestrant to treat certain types of breast cancer. You may be offered them if the cancer has spread to other parts of your body.

【113】Abemaciclib is also used for primary breast cancer if it's likely to come back after treatment such as surgery.

【114】Targeted therapies come as tablets or injections or are given through a drip into a vein.

【115】Side effects of targeted therapies include:

【116】*   shivering and feeling unwell
*   diarrhoea
*   feeling and being sick
*   headache
*   cough
*   skin rash
删除6：<u>### Want to know more?

【117】*   Breast Cancer Now: targeted therapies for breast cancer
*   Cancer Research UK: targeted cancer drugs

【118】</u>
Risk of infection
-----------------

【119】Some of the medicines used to treat breast cancer can make you more vulnerable to infections. You should contact your care team immediately if you develop possible symptoms of infection, such as:

【120】*   a high temperature
*   feeling shivery
*   you suddenly feel very unwell even though your temperature may be normal

【121】Bisphosphonates
---------------

【122】If you have been through the menopause, you may be offered bisphosphonates (zoledronic acid or sodium clodronate).

【123】Recent research has shown they may help to reduce the risk of breast cancer spreading to your bones and elsewhere in your body.

【124】Bisphosphonates will probably be given to you at the same time as chemotherapy, either directly into a vein or as tablets.

【125】Rarely, they can cause kidney problems and osteonecrosis of the jaw (when bone in the jaw dies).

【126】Your doctor will explain the benefits and possible side effects before starting this treatment.

【127】Psychological support
---------------------

【128】Dealing with cancer can be a huge challenge for you and your family and friends. It can cause emotional and practical difficulties.

【129】Many women with breast cancer will have to cope with the removal of part or all of a breast, which can be very upsetting.

【130】It often helps to talk about your feelings or other difficulties with a trained counsellor or therapist. You can ask for this kind of help at any stage of your illness.

【131】Your hospital doctor, specialist nurse or GP can refer you to a counsellor.

【132】If you're feeling depressed, talk to a GP. A course of antidepressants may help, or a GP can refer you to see a counsellor or psychotherapist.

【133】It can also help to talk to someone who's been through the same thing as you. Many breast cancer charities have helplines and online forums and staff can also put you in touch with other women who have had cancer treatment.
删除6：<u>### Want to know more?

【134】*   Breast Cancer Now: someone to talk to
*   Macmillan Cancer Support: online community

【135】</u>
Clinical trials
---------------

【136】A great deal of progress has been made in breast cancer treatment, and more women now live longer and have fewer side effects from treatment.

【137】These advances were discovered in clinical trials, where new treatments and treatment combinations are compared with standard ones.

【138】All cancer trials in the UK are carefully overseen to ensure they're worthwhile and conducted safely.

【139】If you're invited to take part in a trial, you'll be given information about it and, if you want to take part, you'll be asked to sign a consent form.

【140】You can refuse or withdraw from a clinical trial without it affecting your care.
删除6：<u>### Want to know more?

【141】*   Against Breast Cancer: our research
*   Breast Cancer Now: clinical trials
*   Cancer Research UK: breast cancer research and clinical trials

【142】</u>
Complementary therapies
-----------------------

【143】Complementary therapies are therapies that may help improve physical and emotional wellbeing.

【144】They're given alongside conventional treatments and include:

【145】*   breathing exercises for stress
*   massage
*   aromatherapy
*   acupuncture

【146】Complementary therapies can help some women cope with their diagnosis and treatment, and provide a break from their regular treatment plan.

【147】Your hospital or breast unit may be able to provide access to complementary therapies or suggest where you can get them.

【148】It's important to speak to your breast cancer specialist nurse about any complementary therapy you wish to try to make sure it does not interfere with your conventional treatment.
删除6：<u>### Want to know more?

【149】*   Breast Cancer Now: complementary therapies

【150】</u>
Will the NHS fund an unlicensed medicine?
-----------------------------------------

【151】It's possible for your doctor to prescribe a medicine outside the uses it's licensed for if they're willing to take personal responsibility for this 'off-licence' use of treatment.

【152】Your local integrated care board (ICB) may need to be involved, as it would have to decide whether to support your doctor's decision and pay for the medicine from NHS budgets.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 28 October 2019  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 28 October 2022</u>

source_info.title: Lung cancer
source_info.text:
【0】Symptoms \- Lung cancer
=======================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Living with
7.  Prevention</u>

【2】**There are usually no signs or symptoms of lung cancer in the early stages. Symptoms develop as the condition progresses.**

【3】The main symptoms of lung cancer include:

【4】*   a cough that does not go away after 3 weeks
*   a long-standing cough that gets worse
*   chest infections that keep coming back
*   coughing up blood
*   an ache or pain when breathing or coughing
*   persistent breathlessness
*   persistent tiredness or lack of energy
*   loss of appetite or unexplained weight loss

【5】Less common symptoms of lung cancer include:

【6】*   changes in the appearance of your fingers, such as becoming more curved or their ends becoming larger (this is known as finger clubbing)
*   difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) or pain when swallowing
*   wheezing
*   a hoarse voice
*   swelling of your face or neck
*   persistent chest or shoulder pain

【7】See a GP if you have any of the main symptoms of lung cancer or any of the less common symptoms.
删除6：<u>**Want to know more?**

【8】*   Cancer Research UK: lung cancer symptoms
*   Macmillan: signs and symptoms of lung cancer

source_info.title: Budesonide tablets, capsules and granules
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking budesonide tablets, capsules and granules \- Brand names: Budenofalk, Entocort CR, Cortiment, Jorveza
=========================================================================================================================================================

【1】Budesonide and pregnancy
------------------------

【2】Steroid tablets like budesonide are commonly used in pregnancy. Most doctors will recommend continuing to take them if they are needed.

【3】Taking budesonide for a long time in pregnancy might affect your baby's growth and you may need extra scans later on in your pregnancy.

【4】If it's not well treated, inflammatory bowel disease can affect your baby, causing premature birth and growth problems. It's recommended that you continue to take budesonide to keep you and your baby well.

【5】Budesonide and breastfeeding
----------------------------

【6】If your doctor or health visitor says that your baby is healthy, it's OK to take budesonide while you're breastfeeding.

【7】It is not known how much budesonide gets into breast milk, but it's likely to be a small amount, and it is unlikely to cause side effects in your baby. However, your baby may need extra monitoring if you take higher doses or if you're taking it for a long time.

【8】If you notice that your baby is not feeding as well as usual, or if you have any other concerns about your baby, talk to your health visitor, midwife or doctor as soon as possible.

【9】Budesonide and fertility
------------------------

【10】There's no evidence to suggest that taking budesonide reduces fertility in either men or women.

【11】Speak to a pharmacist or your doctor if you're trying to get pregnant.

【12】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【13】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【14】通用删除3(英):<u>For more information about how budesonide can affect you and your baby during pregnancy, visit the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website.</u>
删除11：<u>More in Budesonide tablets, capsules and granules
-------------------------------------------------

source_info.title: You and your baby at 36 weeks pregnant
source_info.text:
【0】You and your baby at 36 weeks pregnant
======================================

【1】Your baby at 36 weeks
---------------------

【2】By 36 weeks, your baby's lungs are fully formed and ready to take their first breath after the birth.

【3】The digestive system is fully developed and your baby will be able to feed if they're born now.

【4】You at 36 weeks
---------------

【5】From around now, you may be aware of a tightening feeling in your lower tummy from time to time. These are a normal part of pregnancy, known as Braxton Hicks contractions – your uterus is "practising" for the tightenings, or contractions, of labour.

【6】Find out about signs that labour has begun and what happens.

【7】When contractions become longer, stronger and more frequent, it can be a sign that labour is starting.

【8】Information:

【9】Call your midwife or hospital when your contractions are in a regular pattern, coming every 5 minutes or more often.

【10】It can help to keep a record of how long your contractions are and when they come, so you can tell your midwife when you call.

【11】You can also call your midwife or maternity unit if you're unsure or worried about anything.

【12】Things to think about
---------------------

【13】*   pack your bag for labour if you're planning to give birth in hospital or a midwifery unit
*   have all your important phone numbers handy (your midwife, hospital, any family and friends) in case labour starts
*   if you have children already, make childcare arrangements for when you go into labour
*   pain relief in labour, including things you can do yourself
*   epidurals: are there any side effects?
*   breastfeeding: positioning and attachment
*   washing and bathing your baby

【14】During childbirth, your midwife or doctor may offer to help avoid a tear or help the baby out by making a cut (episiotomy) between the vagina and anus (perineum).

【15】Find out about episiotomy and perineal tears and tips to help healing删除7：<u>

【16】The Start4Life site has more about you and your baby at 36 weeks.</u>

【17】You can sign up for Start4Life's weekly emails for expert advice, videos and tips on pregnancy, birth and beyond.

source_info.title: Paracetamol for adults
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take paracetamol for adults \- Brand names: Disprol, Hedex, Medinol, Panadol
===============================================================================================

【1】Who can take paracetamol
------------------------

【2】Most people aged 16 and over can take paracetamol. You can also take it if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.

【3】Who may not be able to take paracetamol
---------------------------------------

【4】Paracetamol is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you:

【5】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to paracetamol or any other medicine
*   have liver or kidney problems
*   regularly drink more than the maximum amount of alcohol recommended (14 units a week)

【6】If you weigh less than 50kg (8 stone), check with your doctor or pharmacist. You may need to take a lower dose.
删除11：<u>More in Paracetamol for adults
------------------------------

source_info.title: Pacemaker implantation
source_info.text:
【0】Why it's performed \- Pacemaker implantation
============================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Why it's performed
3.  How it's performed
4.  FAQs
5.  Risks</u>

【2】**Pacemakers are sometimes recommended for people with conditions that cause the heart to beat abnormally.**

【3】Each time the heart beats, the heart muscle contracts (pulls inwards) in preparation for pumping blood around the body.

【4】The contractions are triggered by electrical pulses. These are generated by a group of specialised cells known as the sinoatrial node (SA node).

【5】The SA node is often referred to as a natural pacemaker because it generates a series of electrical pulses at regular intervals.

【6】The pulse is then sent to a group of cells known as the atrioventricular node (AV node). The AV node relays the pulse to the 2 lower chambers of the heart (the ventricles).

【7】A pacemaker or implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) is needed when something disrupts this process and causes an abnormal heartbeat.

【8】An abnormal heartbeat is called an arrhythmia. Here are some of the most common causes of arrhythmias:

【9】Sick sinus syndrome
-------------------

【10】In sick sinus syndrome, the SA node doesn't work as it should. This can lead to an abnormally slow heartbeat (bradycardia), an abnormally fast heartbeat (tachycardia), or a combination of both.

【11】Symptoms of sick sinus syndrome can include:

【12】*   a slower pulse than normal (bradycardia)
*   extreme tiredness (fatigue)
*   fainting (or nearly fainting)
*   dizziness or lightheadedness
*   shortness of breath
*   chest pain
*   irregular or fluttering heartbeats (palpitations)

【13】Most cases of sick sinus syndrome are thought to be related to age.

【14】Over time, the SA node tissue can become hardened and scarred. This can disrupt the normal pattern of electrical pulses released by the SA node.

【15】Some types of medication can also trigger sick sinus syndrome as a side effect. These include calcium channel blockers and beta blockers.

【16】Atrial fibrillation
-------------------

【17】Atrial fibrillation is a condition that causes the heart to beat abnormally fast.

【18】This is usually considerably higher than 100 beats a minute (often 140 beats a minute or more).

【19】Atrial fibrillation can usually be treated with medication, but some people don't respond to treatment, so a pacemaker may be recommended.

【20】Sometimes people with atrial fibrillation can have a much slower pulse rate than normal, which can also be intermittent (not continuous).

【21】In these cases, a pacemaker will usually be recommended.

【22】Heart block
-----------

【23】In people with heart block, the pulse that needs to be sent from the SA node to the AV node is either delayed or absent.

【24】Heart block can be caused when the heart is damaged (acquired heart block), or it can occur if a baby is born with 1 or more defects that affect their heart (congenital heart block).

【25】If you have heart block and it's causing troublesome symptoms, a pacemaker will usually be recommended.

【26】Cardiac arrest
--------------

【27】An implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD), which is a device similar to a pacemaker, is mainly used to prevent cardiac arrest.

【28】A cardiac arrest is a potentially fatal condition where the electrical activity that controls the heart becomes so disrupted that the heart stops beating.

【29】Unless it's treated quickly, a cardiac arrest will be fatal.

【30】An ICD can detect abnormal electrical signals that could indicate that a cardiac arrest is about to happen.

【31】If the ICD detects these type of signals, it sends a powerful electrical shock to the heart. 

【32】This basically "reboots" the heart. After the shock, the heart should start beating normally again.

【33】An ICD implantation may be recommended if you have had a cardiac arrest in the past or it's thought you have a significant risk of having one in the future.

【34】Factors that increase the risk of a cardiac arrest occurring include:

【35】*   coronary heart disease (where the main vessels that supply the heart become narrowed and hardened, reducing the blood supply)
*   having a heart attack
*   congenital heart disease (where a person is born with one or more defects affecting their heart)
*   cardiomyopathy (abnormalities of the heart muscle, which leads to poor heart function)

【36】Types of pacemaker
------------------

【37】There are several different types of pacemaker.

【38】The main types are:

【39】*   single-chamber pacemaker – this has 1 wire, which is connected to either the right atrium (upper heart chamber) or right ventricle (lower heart chamber)
*   dual-chamber pacemaker – this has 2 wires, which are connected to the right atrium and right ventricle
*   biventricular pacemaker – this has 3 wires, which are connected to the right atrium, right ventricle and left ventricle

【40】The type of pacemaker you need will depend on your specific heart problem.
删除9：<u>Credit:

【41】Alila Medical Images / Alamy Stock Photo https://www.alamy.com/stock-photo-pacemaker-insertion-surgery-49381420.html?pv=1&stamp=2&imageid=2E7D9799-97E0-47F6-A282-E690C0934D4A&p=178046&n=0&orientation=0&pn=1&searchtype=0&IsFromSearch=1&srch=foo%3dbar%26st%3d0%26pn%3d1%26ps%3d100%26sortby%3d2%26resultview%3dsortbyPopular%26npgs%3d0%26qt%3dCT9EE4%26qt\_raw%3dCT9EE4%26lic%3d3%26mr%3d0%26pr%3d0%26ot%3d0%26creative%3d%26ag%3d0%26hc%3d0%26pc%3d%26blackwhite%3d%26cutout%3d%26tbar%3d1%26et%3d0x000000000000000000000%26vp%3d0%26loc%3d0%26imgt%3d0%26dtfr%3d%26dtto%3d%26size%3d0xFF%26archive%3d1%26groupid%3d%26pseudoid%3d%26a%3d%26cdid%3d%26cdsrt%3d%26name%3d%26qn%3d%26apalib%3d%26apalic%3d%26lightbox%3d%26gname%3d%26gtype%3d%26xstx%3d0%26simid%3d%26saveQry%3d%26editorial%3d1%26nu%3d%26t%3d%26edoptin%3d%26customgeoip%3d%26cap%3d1%26cbstore%3d1%26vd%3d0%26lb%3d%26fi%3d2%26edrf%3d0%26ispremium%3d1%26flip%3d0%26pl%3d</u>

source_info.title: Furosemide
source_info.text:
【0】Side effects of furosemide
==========================

【1】Common side effects
-------------------

【2】These common side effects of furosemide happen in more than 1 in 100 people. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【3】Peeing more than normal

【4】This will last for about 6 hours after taking furosemide. It's nothing to worry about, but if it's inconvenient for you, change the time you take furosemide to one that suits you better (provided it's no later than 4pm).

【5】If peeing a lot is still a problem for you, talk to your doctor or pharmacist.

【6】Feeling thirsty

【7】It's important not to get dehydrated, but how much you drink will depend on why you're taking furosemide.

【8】Check with your doctor how much liquid you can drink while you're taking this medicine.

【9】Dry mouth

【10】Chew sugar-free gum or suck sugar-free sweets.

【11】Headaches

【12】Make sure you rest and drink fluids – ask your doctor how much you can drink while taking this medicine. Do not drink too much alcohol.

【13】Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller. Talk to your doctor if the headaches last longer than a week or are severe.

【14】Feeling confused or dizzy

【15】If furosemide makes you feel dizzy when you stand up, try getting up very slowly or stay sitting down until you feel better. If you begin to feel dizzy, lie down so that you do not faint, then sit until you feel better.

【16】Do not drive, ride a bike or use tools or machinery while you're feeling dizzy.

【17】Feeling or being sick (nausea or vomiting)

【18】Take furosemide with or just after a meal or snack. Take small, regular sips of water or squash so you do not get dehydrated (ask your doctor how much fluid you can drink). Speak to a pharmacist if you have signs of dehydration, such as peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee.

【19】If you take contraceptive pills and you're being sick, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet for advice.

【20】Speak to a doctor or pharmacist if any of these side effects bother you or last more than a few days.

【21】Serious side effects
--------------------

【22】Some people have serious side effects after taking furosemide.

【23】Tell your doctor or call 111 now if you get:

【24】*   unexplained bruising or bleeding, a high temperature, sore throat and mouth ulcers – these could be signs of a blood disorder
*   severe stomach pain which could reach through to your back – this could be a sign of an inflamed pancreas (pancreatitis)
*   severe pain in your side or blood in your urine – these could be signs of inflamed kidneys
*   ringing in your ears (tinnitus) or loss of hearing

【25】### Serious allergic reaction

【26】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to furosemide.

【27】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【28】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【29】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【30】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【31】Other side effects
------------------

【32】These are not all the side effects of furosemide. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.
删除5：<u>Information:

【33】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.
删除12：<u>Visit Yellow Card for further information.</u></u>
删除11：<u>More in Furosemide
------------------

*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects

source_info.title: Lercanidipine
source_info.text:
【0】About lercanidipine
===================

【1】Lercanidipine is a calcium channel blocker medicine used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension).

【2】If you have high blood pressure, taking lercanidipine helps prevent heart disease, heart attacks and strokes.

【3】Lercanidipine is only available on prescription. It comes as tablets.

【4】Key facts
---------

【5】*   Lercanidipine lowers your blood pressure and makes it easier for your heart to pump blood around your body.
*   Lercanidipine starts to work on the day you start taking it, but it may take a couple of weeks to take full effect.
*   You'll usually take lercanidipine once a day. You can take it at any time of day, but try to make sure it's around the same time each day.
*   You do not need to take it on an empty stomach, but fatty food can increase the amount of lercanidipine your body takes in and make you more likely to have side effects. It's best to take it at least 15 minutes before a meal.
*   Do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while you're taking lercanidipine. It can increase the amount of lercanidipine in your body and cause side effects.
删除11：<u>More in Lercanidipine
---------------------

【6】*   About lercanidipine
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking lercanidipine with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 4 February 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 4 February 2025</u>

source_info.title: You and your baby at 4 weeks pregnant
source_info.text:
【0】You and your baby at 4 weeks pregnant
=====================================

【1】Your baby at 4 weeks
--------------------

【2】In weeks 4 to 5 of early pregnancy, the embryo grows and develops within the lining of your womb.

【3】The outer cells reach out to form links with your blood supply. The inner cells form into 2, and then later into 3 layers.

【4】Each of these layers will grow to be different parts of your baby's body:

【5】*   the inner layer becomes the breathing and digestive systems, including the lungs, stomach, gut and bladder
*   the middle layer becomes the heart, blood vessels, muscles and bones
*   the outer layer becomes the brain and nervous system, the eye lenses, tooth enamel, skin and nails

【6】In these early weeks of pregnancy, the embryo is attached to a tiny yolk sac that provides nourishment.

【7】A few weeks later, the placenta will be fully formed and take over the transfer of nutrients to the embryo.

【8】The embryo is surrounded by fluid inside the amniotic sac. It's the outer layer of this sac that develops into the placenta.

【9】Cells from the placenta grow deep into the wall of the womb, establishing a rich blood supply. This ensures the baby receives all the oxygen and nutrients it needs.

【10】You at 4 weeks
--------------

【11】Conception usually takes place about 2 weeks after your last period, around the time you release an egg (ovulate).

【12】In the first 4 weeks of pregnancy, you probably will not notice any symptoms.

【13】The first thing you may notice is that your period does not arrive, or you may have other signs and symptoms of pregnancy, such as breast tenderness.

【14】You can confirm the pregnancy with a pregnancy test.

【15】You can work out the date when your baby is due. This date may be changed when you have an ultrasound scan删除7：<u>

【16】Things to think about
---------------------

【17】*   what to expect on your NHS pregnancy journey
*   there's help and support if you're a teenager
*   avoid drinking alcohol when you're pregnant or trying to get pregnant
*   how emotional changes in pregnancy can affect your relationships

【18】Start4Life has more about you and your baby at 4 weeks of pregnancy</u>

【19】You can sign up for Start4Life's weekly emails for expert advice, videos and tips on pregnancy, birth and beyond.
删除3：<u>Video: Should I take supplements during my pregnancy?
-----------------------------------------------------

【20】In this video, a midwife explains which supplements you can take during pregnancy.

text.content:
【0】You and your baby at 4 weeks pregnant
=====================================

【1】Your baby at 4 weeks
--------------------

【2】In weeks 4 to 5 of early pregnancy, the embryo grows and develops within the lining of your womb.

【3】The outer cells reach out to form links with your blood supply. The inner cells form into 2, and then later into 3 layers.

【4】Each of these layers will grow to be different parts of your baby's body:

【5】*   the inner layer becomes the breathing and digestive systems, including the lungs, stomach, gut and bladder
*   the middle layer becomes the heart, blood vessels, muscles and bones
*   the outer layer becomes the brain and nervous system, the eye lenses, tooth enamel, skin and nails

【6】In these early weeks of pregnancy, the embryo is attached to a tiny yolk sac that provides nourishment.

【7】A few weeks later, the placenta will be fully formed and take over the transfer of nutrients to the embryo.

【8】The embryo is surrounded by fluid inside the amniotic sac. It's the outer layer of this sac that develops into the placenta.

【9】Cells from the placenta grow deep into the wall of the womb, establishing a rich blood supply. This ensures the baby receives all the oxygen and nutrients it needs.

【10】You at 4 weeks
--------------

【11】Conception usually takes place about 2 weeks after your last period, around the time you release an egg (ovulate).

【12】In the first 4 weeks of pregnancy, you probably will not notice any symptoms.

【13】The first thing you may notice is that your period does not arrive, or you may have other signs and symptoms of pregnancy, such as breast tenderness.

【14】You can confirm the pregnancy with a pregnancy test.

【15】You can work out the date when your baby is due. This date may be changed when you have an ultrasound scan删除7：<u>

【16】Things to think about
---------------------

【17】*   what to expect on your NHS pregnancy journey
*   there's help and support if you're a teenager
*   avoid drinking alcohol when you're pregnant or trying to get pregnant
*   how emotional changes in pregnancy can affect your relationships

【18】Start4Life has more about you and your baby at 4 weeks of pregnancy</u>

【19】You can sign up for Start4Life's weekly emails for expert advice, videos and tips on pregnancy, birth and beyond.
删除3：<u>Video: Should I take supplements during my pregnancy?
-----------------------------------------------------

【20】In this video, a midwife explains which supplements you can take during pregnancy.
删除1：<u>Media last reviewed: 2 February 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Media review due: 2 February 2026</u>

【21】</u>删除11：<u>More in 1 to 12 weeks pregnant
------------------------------

【22】*   You and your pregnancy at 1 to 3 weeks
*   You and your baby at 4 weeks pregnant
*   You and your baby at 5 weeks pregnant
*   You and your baby at 6 weeks pregnant
*   You and your baby at 7 weeks pregnant
*   You and your baby at 8 weeks pregnant
*   You and your baby at 9 weeks pregnant
*   You and your baby at 10 weeks pregnant

*   You and your baby at 12 weeks pregnant

source_info.title: Acute myeloid leukaemia
source_info.text:
【0】Treatment \- Acute myeloid leukaemia
====================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications</u>

【2】**Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) is an aggressive cancer that grows quickly, so treatment will usually begin a few days after a diagnosis has been confirmed.**

【3】As AML is a complex condition, it's usually treated by a group of different specialists working together called a multidisciplinary team (MDT).

【4】Your treatment plan
-------------------

【5】Treatment for AML is often carried out in 2 stages:

【6】*   induction – this first stage of treatment aims to kill as many leukaemia cells in your blood and bone marrow as possible and treat any symptoms you may have
*   consolidation – this stage aims to prevent the cancer coming back (relapsing) by killing any remaining leukaemia cells in your body

【7】The induction stage of treatment is not always successful and sometimes needs to be repeated before consolidation can begin.

【8】If you're thought to have a high risk of experiencing complications of AML treatment (for example, if you're over 75 or have another underlying health condition), less intensive chemotherapy treatment may be carried out.

【9】Your doctors will watch you carefully and suggest other treatments if needed.

【10】Induction
---------

【11】The initial treatment you have for AML will largely depend on whether you're fit enough to have intensive chemotherapy, or whether treatment at a lower dosage is recommended.

【12】### Intensive chemotherapy

【13】If you can have intensive induction chemotherapy, you'll be given chemotherapy medicine at a high dose to kill the cancerous cells in your blood and bone marrow.

【14】You'll usually be given a combination of 2 or more chemotherapy medicines.

【15】The treatment will be carried out in hospital or in a specialist centre, as you'll need very close medical and nursing supervision.

【16】You may be able to go home between treatment rounds.

【17】You'll have regular blood transfusions because your blood will not contain enough healthy blood cells.

【18】You'll also be vulnerable to infection, so it's important that you're in a clean and stable environment where your health can be carefully monitored and any infection you have can be treated quickly.

【19】You may also be prescribed antibiotics to help prevent infections.

【20】For intensive treatment, the chemotherapy medicines will be injected into a thin tube that's inserted either into a blood vessel near your heart or into your arm.

【21】Side effects of intensive chemotherapy for AML are common.

【22】They can include: 

【23】*   feeling or being sick
*   bruising or bleeding easily
*   diarrhoea
*   loss of appetite
*   sore mouth and mouth ulcers (mucositis)
*   tiredness
*   skin rashes
*   hair loss
*   infertility – this may be temporary or permanent (see complications of AML for more information)

【24】Most side effects should resolve once treatment has finished. Tell a member of your care team if side effects become particularly troublesome, as there are medicines that can help you cope better with certain side effects.
删除7：<u>Find out more about the side effects of chemotherapy</u>

【25】### Non-intensive chemotherapy

【26】If your doctors do not think you're fit enough to withstand the effects of intensive chemotherapy, they may recommend non-intensive treatment.

【27】This involves using an alternative type of chemotherapy to the standard intensive therapy.

【28】The medicines used during non-intensive chemotherapy may be given through a drip into a vein, by mouth or by injection under the skin, and can often be given on an outpatient basis.

【29】### Other medicines

【30】If you have the type of AML known as acute promyelocytic leukaemia, you'll usually be given other medicines as well as having chemotherapy.

【31】The 2 medicines most commonly used are:

【32】*   all tans retinoic acid (ATRA) – usually given during and after induction chemotherapy, it changes immature white blood cells into healthy mature cells, and can reduce symptoms quickly
*   arsenic trioxide – usually given if the AML has come back, it speeds up the death of leukaemia cells and changes the immature blood cells into healthy mature cells

【33】Side effects of ATRA can include headaches, nausea, bone pain, and dry mouth (excessive thirst), skin and eyes.

【34】Consolidation
-------------

【35】If there's no AML left after induction chemotherapy, the next stage of treatment is consolidation.

【36】This often involves regularly having chemotherapy medicine, which may be given as injections or tablets.

【37】The consolidation phase of treatment lasts several months.

【38】Other treatments
----------------

【39】### Radiotherapy

【40】Radiotherapy involves using high doses of controlled radiation to kill cancerous cells.

【41】It's used to:

【42】*   prepare the body for a bone marrow or stem cell transplant
*   treat advanced cases that have spread to the nervous system or brain, although this is uncommon

【43】Side effects of radiotherapy can include hair loss, nausea and fatigue.

【44】Most of the side effects should pass once your course of radiotherapy has been completed.

【45】### Bone marrow and stem cell transplants

【46】If the treatment is not working or there's a high chance of your leukaemia coming back, you may be offered a bone marrow or stem cell transplant.

【47】Before transplantation can take place, the person receiving the transplant will need intensive high-dose chemotherapy, and possibly radiotherapy, to destroy the cells in their bone marrow.

【48】You may be given donated stem cells or you may have a transplant of your own stem cells. The stem cells are given through a tube into a blood vessel (a drip) in a similar way to chemotherapy medicine.

【49】You'll need to stay in hospital for a few weeks after the transplant, usually in a room on your own, because you'll have a high chance of getting infections.

【50】Your friends and family should be able to visit you, but they'll need to wear protective clothing.

【51】Transplantations have better outcomes if the donor has the same tissue type as the person receiving the donation.

【52】The best candidate to provide a donation is usually a brother or sister with the same tissue type.

【53】### Targeted medicines

【54】You may be offered targeted medicines if you have certain types of AML. Targeted medicines affect the way cancer cells grow.

【55】Some targeted medicines come as tablets and others are given through a drip into your vein.

【56】Adults recently diagnosed with AML may be offered a combination of venetoclax and low-dose cytarabine, if intensive chemotherapy is not suitable.

【57】Your specialist can discuss with you whether targeted treatment is suitable for you.

【58】Clinical trials and newer unlicensed treatments
-----------------------------------------------

【59】In the UK, a number of clinical trials are currently underway that aim to find the best way of treating AML.

【60】Clinical trials are studies that use new and experimental techniques to see how well they work in treating, and possibly curing, AML.

【61】As part of your treatment, your care team may suggest taking part in a clinical trial to help researchers learn more about the best way to treat your AML, and AML in general.

【62】Find a clinical trial for acute myeloid leukaemia on Cancer Research UK

【63】If you take part in a clinical trial, you may be offered medicine that's not licensed for use in the UK and is not normally available.

【64】But there's no guarantee that the techniques being studied in the clinical trial will work better than current treatments.

【65】Your care team can tell you whether there are any clinical trials available in your area, and can explain the benefits and risks involved.

【66】Find more research into AML on Cancer Research UK

【67】Your care team
--------------

【68】A treatment team for AML may include a:

【69】*   haematologist (blood cancer specialist)
*   haemato-pathologist (specialist in the study of cancerous blood cells)
*   paediatrician (specialist in treating children)
*   cancer nurse specialist (sometimes called a CNS), who will be the first point of contact between you and the members of your care team
*   radiologist (specialist in X-rays and scans)
*   pharmacist
*   social worker
*   psychologist
*   counsellor
