source_info.title: Antisocial personality disorder
source_info.text:
【0】Antisocial personality disorder
===============================

【1】**Personality disorders are mental health conditions that affect how someone thinks, perceives, feels or relates to others.**

【2】Antisocial personality disorder is a particularly challenging type of personality disorder characterised by impulsive, irresponsible and often criminal behaviour.

【3】Someone with antisocial personality disorder will typically be manipulative, deceitful and reckless, and will not care for other people's feelings.

【4】Like other types of personality disorder, antisocial personality disorder is on a spectrum, which means it can range in severity from occasional bad behaviour to repeatedly breaking the law and committing serious crimes.

【5】Psychopaths are considered to have a severe form of antisocial personality disorder删除7：<u>

【6】The Mind website has more information about signs of antisocial personality disorder</u>
删除7：<u>Find out more about personality disorders</u>

【7】Signs of antisocial personality disorder
----------------------------------------

【8】A person with antisocial personality disorder may:

【9】*   exploit, manipulate or violate the rights of others
*   lack concern, regret or remorse about other people's distress
*   behave irresponsibly and show disregard for normal social behaviour
*   have difficulty sustaining long-term relationships
*   be unable to control their anger
*   lack guilt, or not learn from their mistakes
*   blame others for problems in their lives
*   repeatedly break the law

【10】A person with antisocial personality disorder will have a history of conduct disorder during childhood, such as truancy (not going to school), delinquency (for example, committing crimes or substance misuse), and other disruptive and aggressive behaviours.

【11】Who develops antisocial personality disorder?
---------------------------------------------

【12】Antisocial personality disorder affects more men than women.

【13】It's not known why some people develop antisocial personality disorder, but both genetics and traumatic childhood experiences, such as child abuse or neglect, are thought to play a role.

【14】A person with antisocial personality disorder will have often grown up in difficult family circumstances. 

【15】One or both parents may misuse alcohol, and parental conflict and harsh, inconsistent parenting are common.

【16】As a result of these problems, social services may become involved with the child's care.

【17】These types of difficulties in childhood will often lead to behavioural problems during adolescence and adulthood.

【18】Effects of antisocial personality disorder
------------------------------------------

【19】Criminal behaviour is a key feature of antisocial personality disorder, and there's a high risk that someone with the disorder will commit crimes and be imprisoned at some point in their life.

【20】Men with antisocial personality disorder have been found to be 3 to 5 times more likely than women to misuse alcohol and drugs than those without the disorder. They also have an increased risk of dying prematurely as a result of reckless behaviour or attempting suicide.

【21】People with antisocial personality disorder are also more likely to have relationship problems during adulthood and be unemployed and homeless.

【22】Diagnosing antisocial personality disorder
------------------------------------------

【23】To be diagnosed with antisocial personality disorder, a person will usually have a history of conduct personality disorder before the age of 15.

【24】Antisocial personality disorder is diagnosed after rigorous detailed psychological assessment.

【25】A diagnosis can only be made if the person is aged 18 years or older and at least 3 of the following criteria behaviours apply:

【26】*   repeatedly breaking the law
*   repeatedly being deceitful
*   being impulsive or incapable of planning ahead
*   being irritable and aggressive
*   having a reckless disregard for their safety or the safety of others
*   being consistently irresponsible
*   lack of remorse

【27】These signs are not part of a schizophrenic or manic episode – they're part of a person's everyday personality and behaviour.

【28】This behaviour usually becomes most extreme and challenging during the late teens and early 20s. It may improve by the time the person reaches their 40s.

【29】Treating antisocial personality disorder
----------------------------------------

【30】In the past, antisocial personality disorder was thought to be a lifelong disorder, but that's not always the case and it can sometimes be managed and treated.

【31】Evidence suggests behaviour can improve over time with therapy, even if core characteristics such as lack of empathy remain. 

【32】But antisocial personality disorder is one of the most difficult types of personality disorders to treat.

【33】A person with antisocial personality disorder may also be reluctant to seek treatment and may only start therapy when ordered to do so by a court.

【34】The recommended treatment for someone with antisocial personality disorder will depend on their circumstances, taking into account factors such as age, offending history and whether there are any associated problems, such as alcohol or drug misuse.

【35】The person's family and friends will often play an active role in making decisions about their treatment and care.

【36】Sometimes, substance misuse services and social care may also need to be involved.

【37】National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE): management and prevention of antisocial personality disorder

【38】### Talking therapies

【39】Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) is sometimes used to treat antisocial personality disorder.

【40】It's a talking therapy that aims to help a person manage their problems by changing the way they think and behave.

【41】Mentalisation-based therapy (MBT) is another type of talking therapy that's becoming more popular in the treatment of antisocial personality disorder.

【42】The therapist will encourage the person to consider the way they think and how their mental state affects their behaviour.

【43】### Democratic therapeutic communities (DTC)

【44】Evidence suggests community-based programmes can be an effective long-term treatment method for people with antisocial personality disorder, and is becoming increasingly popular in prisons.

【45】DTC is a type of social therapy that aims to address the person's risk of offending, as well as their emotional and psychological needs.

【46】It's based around large and small therapy groups and focuses on community issues, creating an environment where both staff and prisoners contribute to the decisions of the community.

【47】There may also be opportunities for educational and vocational work.

【48】The recommended length of treatment is 18 months, as there needs to be enough time for a person to make changes and put new skills into practice.

【49】Self-motivation is another important factor for acceptance on to this type of scheme. For example, the person must be willing to work as part of a community, participate in groups, and be subject to the democratic process.
删除7：<u>Read more about DTC and working with offenders with personality disorder on GOV.UK</u>

【50】### Medicine

【51】There's little evidence to support the use of medicine for treating antisocial personality disorder, but certain antipsychotic and antidepressant medicines may be helpful in some instances.

【52】Carbamazepine and lithium may help control symptoms such as aggression and impulsive behaviour, and a class of antidepressant called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) may improve anger and general personality disorder symptoms.
删除6：<u>### Further information

【53】*   Personality disorders
</u>
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 23 December 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 23 December 2024</u>

source_info.title: Bronchodilators
source_info.text:
【0】Side effects \- Bronchodilators
===============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Side effects</u>

【2】**Bronchodilators can sometimes cause side effects, although these are usually mild or short-lived.**

【3】This page lists some of the main side effects of bronchodilators. But this is not an exhaustive list and some side effects may not apply to the specific medicine you're taking.

【4】For information on the side effects of a particular bronchodilator, check the patient information leaflet that comes with your medicine.

【5】You may be able to find a specific leaflet in the medicines A to Z on the MHRA website.

【6】Beta-2 agonists
---------------

【7】The main side effects of beta-2 agonists like salbutamol include:

【8】*   trembling, particularly in the hands
*   nervous tension
*   headaches
*   suddenly noticeable heartbeats (palpitations)
*   muscle cramps

【9】These side effects often improve and disappear completely after you have been using beta-2 agonists for a few days or weeks.

【10】See a GP if your side effects persist, as your dose may need to be adjusted.

【11】More serious side effects are rare, but can include sudden tightening of the airways (paradoxical bronchospasm) with some inhalers.

【12】Excessive doses can occasionally cause heart attacks and a severely low level of potassium in the blood (hypokalemia).

【13】Anticholinergics
----------------

【14】The main side effects of anticholinergics like ipratropium include:

【15】*   a dry mouth
*   constipation
*   a cough
*   headaches
*   feeling sick (nausea)

【16】Less common side effects include:

【17】*   difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)
*   palpitations
*   throat irritation
*   difficulty urinating

【18】If you have glaucoma, it may get worse if the medication gets in your eyes when using an inhaler or a nebuliser.

【19】Theophylline
------------

【20】Theophylline can cause serious side effects if too much of it builds up in your body.

【21】You'll usually need to have regular blood tests during treatment to make sure the levels of theophylline in your body are safe.

【22】Older people are more at risk of developing side effects from theophylline, as their livers may not be able to remove it from their body.

【23】The main side effects of theophylline include:

【24】*   nausea and vomiting
*   diarrhoea
*   palpitations
*   a rapid heartbeat (tachycardia)
*   an irregular heartbeat (arrhythmia)
*   headaches
*   problems sleeping (insomnia)

【25】See a GP if you have any of these side effects, as your dose may need to be reviewed.

【26】Reporting side effects
----------------------

【27】The Yellow Card Scheme allows you to report side effects of any medicine you're taking.

【28】It's run by a medicines safety watchdog called the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA).
删除7：<u>Find out more about the Yellow Card Scheme from the MHRA</u>

source_info.title: Alzheimer's disease
source_info.text:
【0】Diagnosis \- Alzheimer's disease
================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Prevention</u>

【2】**It's best to see a GP if you're worried about your memory or are having problems with planning and organising.**

【3】If you're worried about someone else, encourage them to make an appointment and perhaps suggest going with them. It's often very helpful having a friend or family member there.

【4】An accurate, timely diagnosis gives you the best chance to adjust, prepare and plan for the future, as well as access to treatments and support that may help.

【5】Seeing a GP
-----------

【6】Memory problems are not just caused by dementia – they can also be caused by:

【7】*   depression or anxiety
*   stress
*   medicines
*   alcohol or drugs
*   other health problems – such as hormonal disturbances or nutritional deficiencies

【8】Read about common causes of memory loss.

【9】A GP can carry out some simple checks to try to find out what the cause may be. They can then refer you to a specialist for assessment, if necessary.

【10】A GP will ask about your concerns and what you or your family have noticed.

【11】They'll also check other aspects of your health and carry out a physical examination.

【12】They may also organise some blood tests and ask about any medicines you're taking to rule out other possible causes of your symptoms.

【13】You'll usually be asked some questions and to carry out some memory, thinking, and pen and paper tasks to check how different areas of your brain are functioning.

【14】This can help a GP decide if you need to be referred to a specialist for more assessments.

【15】Referral to a specialist
------------------------

【16】If a GP is unsure about whether you have Alzheimer's disease, they may refer you to a specialist, such as:

【17】*   a psychiatrist (usually called an old age psychiatrist)
*   an elderly care physician (sometimes called a geriatrician)
*   a neurologist (an expert in treating conditions that affect the brain and nervous system)

【18】The specialist may be based in a memory clinic alongside other professionals who are experts in diagnosing, caring for and advising people with dementia and their families.

【19】There's no simple and reliable test for diagnosing Alzheimer's disease, but the staff at the memory clinic will listen to the concerns of both you and your family about your memory or thinking.

【20】They'll assess your memory and other areas of mental ability and, if necessary, arrange more tests to rule out other conditions.

【21】### Mental ability tests 

【22】A specialist will usually assess your mental abilities, such as memory or thinking, using tests known as cognitive assessments.

【23】Most cognitive assessments involve a series of pen and paper tests and questions, each of which carries a score.

【24】These tests assess a number of different mental abilities, including:

【25】*   short- and long-term memory
*   concentration and attention span
*   language and communication skills
*   awareness of time and place (orientation)
*   abilities related to vision (visuospatial abilities)

【26】It's important to remember that test scores may be influenced by a person's level of education.

【27】For example, someone who cannot read or write very well may have a lower score, but they may not have Alzheimer's disease.

【28】Similarly, someone with a higher level of education may achieve a higher score, but still have dementia.

【29】These tests can therefore help doctors work out what's happening, but they should never be used by themselves to diagnose dementia.

【30】### Other tests

【31】To rule out other possible causes of your symptoms and look for possible signs of damage caused by Alzheimer's disease, your specialist may recommend having a brain scan.

【32】This could be a:

【33】*   CT scan – several X-rays of your brain are taken at slightly different angles and a computer puts the images together
*   MRI scan – a strong magnetic field and radio waves are used to produce detailed images of your brain
删除7：<u>Read more about tests for diagnosing dementia.</u>

【34】After diagnosis
---------------

【35】It may take several appointments and tests over many months before a diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease can be confirmed, although often it may be diagnosed more quickly than this.

【36】It takes time to adapt to a diagnosis of dementia, for both you and your family.

【37】Some people find it helpful to seek information and plan for the future, but others may need a longer period to process the news.

【38】It might help to talk things through with family and friends, and to seek support from the Alzheimer's Society.

【39】As Alzheimer's disease is a progressive illness, the weeks to months after a diagnosis are often a good time to think about legal, financial and healthcare matters for the future.
删除7：<u>Read more about what to do if you have just been diagnosed with dementia.</u>

source_info.title: Fluoxetine (Prozac)
source_info.text:
【0】Side effects of fluoxetine
==========================

【1】Like all medicines, fluoxetine can cause side effects in some people, but many people have no side effects or only minor ones.

【2】Some of the common side effects will gradually improve as your body gets used to it.

【3】Common side effects
-------------------

【4】These common side effects of fluoxetine happen in more than 1 in 100 people. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【5】Feeling sick (nausea)

【6】Try taking fluoxetine with or after food. It may also help to stick to simple meals and avoid rich or spicy food.

【7】Headaches

【8】Make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Try not to drink too much alcohol. Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller.

【9】Headaches usually go away after the first week of taking fluoxetine. Talk to your doctor if they last longer than a week or are severe.

【10】Being unable to sleep

【11】Take fluoxetine first thing in the morning.

【12】Diarrhoea

【13】Drink plenty of water or other fluids to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee.

【14】Do not take any other medicines to treat diarrhoea without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.

【15】If you take contraceptive pills and you have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet to find out what to do.

【16】Feeling tired or weak

【17】If fluoxetine makes you feel tired or weak, stop what you’re doing and sit or lie down until you feel better.

【18】Do not drive, ride a bike or use tools or machinery if you’re feeling tired. It’s best not to drink alcohol as it will make you feel worse.

【19】If these symptoms do not go away after a week or two, ask your doctor for advice.

【20】Speak to a doctor or pharmacist if the advice on how to cope does not help and a side effect is still bothering you or does not go away.

【21】Serious side effects
--------------------

【22】It happens rarely (in less than 1 in 100 people), but some people may have serious side effects when taking fluoxetine.

【23】Book an appointment with your doctor if you:

【24】*   gain weight or lose weight without trying
*   get changes in your periods such as heavy bleeding, spotting, or bleeding between periods

【25】Call a doctor or call 111 straight away if you:

【26】*   get feelings of overwhelming happiness (euphoria), excessive enthusiasm or excitement, or a feeling of restlessness that means you cannot sit or stand still
*   are bleeding from the gums or get bruises that appear without a reason or that get bigger
*   are coughing up blood, or have blood in your pee
*   have black or red poo, or blood in your vomit – these can be signs of bleeding in your stomach

【27】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E now if:

【28】*   you get chest pain or pressure, or shortness of breath
*   you get severe dizziness or pass out
*   you get painful erections that last longer than 2 hours – this may happen even when you are not having sex
*   you have a fit or seizure
*   you get headaches, have trouble focusing, have memory problems, cannot think clearly, have a seizure or fit, or lose your balance – these can be signs of low sodium levels
*   you have thoughts about harming yourself or ending your life
*   you get any severe bleeding, or bleeding that you cannot stop, such as cuts or nosebleeds that do not stop within 10 minutes

【29】### Serious allergic reaction

【30】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to fluoxetine.

【31】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【32】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【33】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【34】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【35】Long-term side effects
----------------------

【36】Sexual side effects, such as problems getting an erection or a lower sex drive, have been reported after taking fluoxetine. In some cases, these can continue even after stopping the medicine.

【37】Other side effects
------------------

【38】These are not all the side effects of fluoxetine. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.
删除5：<u>Information:

【39】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.
删除12：<u>Visit Yellow Card for further information.</u></u>
删除11：<u>More in Fluoxetine (Prozac)
---------------------------

【40】*   About fluoxetine
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking fluoxetine with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 10 February 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 10 February 2025</u>

source_info.title: Haemochromatosis
source_info.text:
【0】Symptoms \- Haemochromatosis
============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications</u>

【2】**Symptoms of haemochromatosis usually begin between the ages of 30 and 60, although they can occur earlier.**

【3】The symptoms tend to develop earlier in men than in women. Women often do not experience problems until after the menopause.

【4】Sometimes there are no symptoms and the condition is only found during a blood test.

【5】Early symptoms
--------------

【6】Initial symptoms of haemochromatosis can include:

【7】*   feeling very tired all the time (fatigue)
*   brain fog, mood swings, depression and anxiety
*   weight loss
*   weakness
*   joint pain, especially in the fingers
*   an inability to get or maintain an erection (erectile dysfunction)
*   irregular periods or stopped or missed periods

【8】These symptoms can have many different causes and may sometimes just be because of getting older.

【9】Later problems
--------------

【10】As the condition progresses, it can also cause problems such as:

【11】*   loss of sex drive (libido)
*   darkening of the skin, if you are white – you may look permanently tanned
*   tummy (abdominal) pain and swelling
*   yellowing of the skin (which may be less noticeable on brown or black skin) and the white parts of the eyes (jaundice)
*   feeling thirsty all the time and needing to pee frequently
*   severe pain and stiffness in your joints, particularly in the fingers
*   chest pain
*   shortness of breath
*   swelling of your hands and feet
*   an irregular heartbeat (arrhythmia)
*   the testicles getting smaller

【12】These problems are often caused by complications of haemochromatosis that can happen if the condition is not treated early on.

【13】When to see a GP
----------------

【14】See a GP if you have:

【15】*   persistent or worrying symptoms that could be caused by haemochromatosis – particularly if you have a northern European family background, as the condition is most common in this group
*   a parent or sibling with haemochromatosis, even if you do not have symptoms yourself – tests can be done to check if you're at risk of developing problems

【16】Talk to the GP about whether you should have blood tests to check for haemochromatosis.
删除7：<u>Read more about how haemochromatosis is diagnosed</u>
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 29 March 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 29 March 2026</u>

source_info.title: Phenytoin
source_info.text:
【0】About phenytoin
===============

【1】Phenytoin is a medicine used to treat epilepsy.

【2】Seizures are bursts of electrical activity in the brain that temporarily affect how it works. Phenytoin slows down these electrical signals to stop seizures.

【3】It can also be used to treat trigeminal neuralgia, a type of nerve pain that affects your face.

【4】Phenytoin can help to relieve nerve pain by slowing down electrical impulses in the nerves and reducing their ability to transmit pain.

【5】Phenytoin is available on prescription. It comes as standard tablets, tablets that can be chewed (Infatabs), capsules and a liquid that you swallow.

【6】Key facts
---------

【7】*   You'll usually take phenytoin once or twice a day. You can take it with or without food.
*   The most common side effects are headaches and feeling dizzy.
*   It takes around 4 weeks for phenytoin to work.
*   If you have epilepsy, it's best to stay on the same brand of phenytoin, as other brands may not work as well for you. If you take it for trigeminal neuralgia, most people do not have to stay on the same brand.
*   You may feel sleepy or dizzy when you first start taking phenytoin or the dose is increased. If this happens to you, do not drive, ride a bike or operate machinery until you feel better.
*   If you have epilepsy, you're entitled to free prescriptions for all of your medicines, not just your epilepsy ones. You'll need a medical exemption certificate from your doctor's surgery.
删除11：<u>More in Phenytoin
-----------------

【8】*   About phenytoin
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking phenytoin with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 9 March 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 9 March 2025</u>

source_info.title: Femoral hernia repair
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Femoral hernia repair
=================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  How it's performed
3.  Recovery</u>

【2】**A hernia occurs when an internal part of the body pushes through a weakness in the muscle or surrounding tissue wall.**

【3】Your muscles are usually strong and tight enough to keep your intestines and organs in place, but a hernia can develop if there are any weak spots.

【4】Femoral hernia
--------------

【5】A femoral hernia is a rare type of hernia.

【6】Femoral hernias sometimes appear as a painful lump in the inner upper part of the thigh or groin. The lump can often be pushed back in or disappears when you lie down. Coughing or straining may make the lump appear.

【7】For information on other types of hernia, see: 

【8】*   inguinal hernia
*   hiatus hernia
*   umbilical hernia

【9】Causes of a femoral hernia
--------------------------

【10】A femoral hernia usually occurs when fatty tissue or a part of your bowel pokes through into your groin at the top of your inner thigh.

【11】It pushes through a weak spot in the surrounding muscle wall (abdominal wall) into an area called the femoral canal.

【12】Unlike inguinal hernias, femoral hernias are far more common in women, particularly older women. This is because of the wider shape of the female pelvis. Femoral hernias are rare in children.

【13】Femoral hernias can sometimes appear suddenly because of strain on the tummy, such as:

【14】*   straining on the toilet if you have constipation
*   carrying and pushing heavy loads

【15】They've also been linked to obesity and having a persistent, heavy cough.

【16】When surgery is needed
----------------------

【17】Femoral hernias can be repaired using surgery to push the bulge back into place and strengthen the weakness in the wall of the tummy.

【18】Unlike some other types of hernia, treatment of femoral hernias is almost always recommended straight away because there's a higher risk of complications developing in these cases.

【19】Complications that can develop as a result of a femoral hernia include:

【20】*   **obstruction** – where a section of the bowel becomes stuck in the femoral canal, causing nausea, vomiting and stomach pain, as well as a painful lump in the groin
*   **strangulation** – where a section of bowel becomes trapped and its blood supply is cut off; this requires emergency surgery within hours to release the trapped tissue and restore its blood supply, so it does not die

【21】Surgery gets rid of the hernia and prevents any serious complications, although there's a chance of it returning after the operation.

【22】What happens during surgery
---------------------------

【23】There are 2 ways a femoral hernia repair can be performed:

【24】*   **open surgery** – where a cut is made to allow the surgeon to push the lump back into your tummy
*   **laparoscopy (keyhole) surgery** – a less invasive, but more difficult, technique where several smaller cuts are made, allowing the surgeon to use various instruments to repair the hernia

【25】There are advantages and disadvantages to both methods. The type of surgery you have depends on which method suits you and your surgeon's experience.

【26】You should be able to go home the same day or the day after surgery. It's important to follow the hospital's instructions on how to look after yourself. This includes eating a good diet to avoid constipation, caring for the wound and not straining yourself too soon.

【27】Most people make a full recovery from femoral hernia repair within 6 weeks, although many people can return to driving, work and light activities within 2 weeks.
删除7：<u>Read more about:</u>

【28】*   how femoral hernia repair is performed
*   recovering from femoral hernia repair

【29】Risks of femoral hernia repair
------------------------------

【30】Femoral hernia repair is a routine operation with very few risks, although in a small number of cases, the hernia returns after the operation.

【31】Other uncommon complications of femoral hernia repair include:

【32】*   developing a lump under the wound
*   difficulty passing urine
*   injury or narrowing of the femoral vein (which passes through the femoral canal)
*   injury to the bowel
*   temporary weakness of the leg
*   injury to the nerves, causing pain or numbness in the groin area

【33】Complications are more likely in older people or those with existing conditions.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 11 January 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 11 January 2025</u>
删除1：<u>*   Next : How it's performed</u>

source_info.title: Fluticasone skin creams
source_info.text:
【0】About fluticasone skin creams \- Brand name: Cutivate
=====================================================

【1】Fluticasone is a type of medicine known as a steroid (also called a corticosteroid). This is not the same as an anabolic steroid.

【2】Fluticasone skin creams are stronger than other steroid skin creams such as hydrocortisone.

【3】Fluticasone cream has more fluticasone in it than the ointment. Although they are different strengths, both work well for treating skin conditions such as contact dermatitis, eczema and psoriasis.

【4】Fluticasone skin creams are available on prescription only.

【5】Fluticasone also comes as an inhaler and nebuliser to treat asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and a nasal (nose) spray or drops to treat hay fever and allergies.

【6】Key facts
---------

【7】*   You're unlikely to have side effects from fluticasone skin cream or ointment, if you follow the instructions.
*   Creams are better for skin that is moist or weepy. Ointments are thicker and greasier and better for dry or flaky skin.
*   Only use fluticasone on your face if your doctor says it's OK.
*   Do not give fluticasone to children under the age of 3 months.
*   Fluticasone will not help with skin conditions such as acne and rosacea.
删除11：<u>More in Fluticasone skin creams
-------------------------------

【8】*   About fluticasone skin creams
*   Who can and cannot use it
*   How and when to use it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Using it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 20 February 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 20 February 2026</u>

source_info.title: Terbinafine
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking or using terbinafine \- Brand names: Lamisil, Lamisil Once
==============================================================================================================

【1】Terbinafine and pregnancy
-------------------------

【2】Terbinafine tablets are not generally recommended in pregnancy.

【3】There's no evidence that using terbinafine cream, gel or spray in pregnancy will harm your baby.

【4】If you're pregnant or trying to get pregnant speak to your doctor about whether terbinafine is the right medicine for you.

【5】Terbinafine and breastfeeding
-----------------------------

【6】If your doctor or health visitor says your baby is healthy, you can take or use terbinafine when you're breastfeeding.

【7】### Cream, gel, spray or solution

【8】Terbinafine from the cream, gel, spray or solution is very unlikely to get into breast milk and will not cause any side effects in your baby.

【9】Be careful that your baby does not come into contact with the areas of your body you have put it on. Wash your hands after you have used it and before picking up your baby. Do not put it on your breasts.

【10】### Tablets

【11】There is not much information about how much terbinafine from the tablets passes into breast milk, but information shows that it's a very small amount. However, your doctor or pharmacist may recommend other antifungal medicines which might be better while breastfeeding.

【12】If you do take terbinafine tablets while breastfeeding, talk to your health visitor, midwife, doctor or pharmacist as soon as possible if you have any concerns, including if your baby:

【13】*   is not feeding as well as usual
*   has an upset stomach, such as being sick or diarrhoea
*   has signs of jaundice – these include yellowing of the whites of the eyes or the skin (this may be less obvious on brown or black skin), dark pee and pale poo
*   has a rash

【14】Terbinafine and fertility
-------------------------

【15】There is no evidence that terbinafine reduces fertility in either men or women.

【16】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【17】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding
删除11：<u>More in Terbinafine
-------------------

【18】*   About terbinafine
*   Who can and cannot take or use it
*   How and when to take or use it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking or using it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 24 March 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 24 March 2026</u>

source_info.title: Ebola virus disease
source_info.text:
【0】Ebola virus disease
===================

【1】**Ebola virus disease is a serious, rare infection usually found in certain parts of Africa. It's caught by coming into contact with the body fluids of an infected person or wild animal.**

【2】Check if you're at risk of Ebola
--------------------------------

【3】Ebola is caused by a virus caught from wild animals. It spreads from person to person when you touch infected body fluids, such as semen, saliva, blood, poo, pee and vomit.

【4】There have been outbreaks of the virus in Central and West Africa in the past.

【5】The most recent outbreaks have been in:

【6】*   Uganda
*   Guinea
*   Democratic Republic of Congo

【7】It's never been spread from person to person in the UK.

【8】Information:

【9】### Check before you travel

【10】It's important to check the Ebola risk for the country you're travelling to before you go.

【11】Check the risks for a country you're travelling to on the Travel Health Pro website

【12】How to avoid Ebola
------------------

【13】If you're travelling to an area where Ebola is found, get advice from a travel clinic before you go.

【14】It's best to do this at least 4 to 6 weeks before you travel, but you can still get advice at the last minute if you need to.

【15】### Do

【16】*   wash your hands regularly

【17】*   wash and peel fruit and vegetables before eating them

【18】*   try to avoid anyone who has symptoms of Ebola

【19】*   use a condom if you have sex with someone who's recovered from Ebola in the last few months

【20】### Don’t

【21】*   do not touch or eat raw or undercooked meat from wild animals in countries where Ebola is found

【22】*   do not touch a person, their body fluids (such as vomit) or anything they may have come into contact with (such as clothes and bedding) if they've died from Ebola or have Ebola symptoms

【23】*   do not touch the body fluids of someone who has Ebola, or anything they may have come into contact with (such as clothes and bedding)

【24】*   do not handle wild animals, especially bats, monkeys, baboons and chimpanzees

【25】Symptoms of Ebola
-----------------

【26】Ebola symptoms can start between 2 and 21 days after being infected.

【27】They can appear suddenly and include flu-like symptoms, such as a high temperature, extreme tiredness and a headache.

【28】Other symptoms include:

【29】*   being sick
*   diarrhoea and tummy pain
*   a skin rash
*   yellowing of the skin and eyes
*   blood in your poo
*   lots of bruises all over your body
*   bleeding from your ears, eyes, nose or mouth

【30】Urgent advice: Call NHS 111 if:
-------------------------------

【31】*   you have travelled to a country where Ebola is found and have Ebola symptoms
*   you have come into contact with someone who's travelled to a country where Ebola is found and have Ebola symptoms

【32】Stay at home and avoid close contact with other people, including sharing towels or bedding, until you've been told what to do.

【33】Get medical advice quickly if you have Ebola symptoms while you're travelling.

【34】Treatment for Ebola
-------------------

【35】Ebola is an emergency and needs to be treated quickly.

【36】You'll usually be treated in isolation in hospital and will need specialist care in an intensive care unit.

【37】Treatment involves managing your symptoms, such as:

【38】*   help with breathing
*   fluids given directly into a vein to stop you becoming dehydrated
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 11 January 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 11 January 2026</u>

source_info.title: Overview     -       Polycystic ovary syndrome
source_info.text: 【0】Overview - Polycystic ovary syndrome Overview \- Polycystic ovary syndrome ===================================== 删除10：Contents -------- 【1】1. Overview 2. Symptoms 3. Causes 4. Diagnosis 5. Treatment 【2】**Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is a common condition that affects how a woman's ovaries work.** 【3】The 3 main features of PCOS are: 【4】* irregular periods – which means your ovaries do not regularly release eggs (ovulation) * excess androgen – high levels of "male" hormones in your body, which may cause physical signs such as excess facial or body hair * polycystic ovaries – your ovaries become enlarged and contain many fluid-filled sacs (follicles) that surround the eggs (but despite the name, you do not actually have cysts if you have PCOS) 【5】If you have at least 2 of these features, you may be diagnosed with PCOS. 【6】Polycystic ovaries ------------------ 【7】Polycystic ovaries contain a large number of harmless follicles that are up to 8mm (approximately 0.3in) in size. 【8】The follicles are underdeveloped sacs in which eggs develop. In PCOS, these sacs are often unable to release an egg, which means ovulation does not take place. 【9】It's difficult to know exactly how many women have PCOS, but it's thought to be very common, affecting about 1 in every 10 women in the UK. 【10】More than half of these women do not have any symptoms. 【11】Symptoms of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) -------------------------------------------- 【12】If you have signs and symptoms of PCOS, they'll usually become apparent during your late teens or early 20s. 【13】They can include: 【14】* irregular periods or no periods at all * difficulty getting pregnant as a result of irregular ovulation or no ovulation * excessive hair growth (hirsutism) – usually on the face, chest, back or buttocks * weight gain * thinning hair and hair loss from the head * oily skin or acne 【15】PCOS is also associated with an increased risk of developing health problems in later life, such as type 2 diabetes and high cholesterol levels. 【16】What causes polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)? --------------------------------------------- 【17】The exact cause of PCOS is unknown, but it often runs in families. 【18】It's related to abnormal hormone levels in the body, including high levels of insulin. 【19】Insulin is a hormone that controls sugar levels in the body. 【20】Many women with PCOS are resistant to the action of insulin in their body and produce higher levels of insulin to overcome this. 【21】This contributes to the increased production and activity of hormones like testosterone. 【22】Being overweight or obese also increases the amount of insulin your body produces. 【23】Treating polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) ----------------------------------------- 【24】There's no cure for PCOS, but the symptoms can be treated. Speak to a GP if you think you may have the condition. 【25】If you have PCOS and you're overweight, losing weight and eating a healthy, balanced diet can make some symptoms better. 【26】Medicines are also available to treat symptoms such as excessive hair growth, irregular periods and fertility problems. 【27】If fertility medicines are not effective, a simple surgical procedure called laparoscopic ovarian drilling (LOD) may be recommended. 【28】This involves using heat or a laser to destroy the tissue in the ovaries that's producing androgens, such as testosterone. 【29】With treatment, most women with PCOS are able to get pregnant. 删除14：Community content from HealthUnlocked 删除1：Page last reviewed: 11 October 2022 删除1：Next review due: 11 October 2025 删除1：* Next : Symptoms

source_info.title: Warfarin
source_info.text:
【0】Taking warfarin with other medicines and herbal supplements
===========================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Many medicines and supplements can affect warfarin. This can make you more likely to bleed.

【3】You might need a blood test to check the other medicine is not affecting how your blood clots.

【4】Tell your doctor if you're taking any of these medicines before you start taking warfarin:

【5】*   medicines for heart problems, such as amiodarone, quinidine or propafenone
*   non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen or aspirin
*   cholesterol-lowering medicines, such as bezafibrate, gemfibrozil, clofibrate or cholestyramine
*   antibiotics, such as erythromycin, co-trimoxazole or norfloxacin
*   miconazole gel for fungal infections like thrush

【6】Taking warfarin with everyday painkillers
-----------------------------------------

【7】It's safe to take paracetamol while you're on warfarin. But take the lowest dose that controls your pain. Taking more than four, 500mg tablets over 24 hours for longer than a few days may make your blood clot more slowly. This puts you at risk of bleeding.

【8】If you're still in pain after taking paracetamol for 3 or 4 days, speak to your pharmacist or doctor.

【9】Do not take aspirin or ibuprofen while you're taking warfarin unless a doctor has said it's OK. They increase the chance of bleeding.

【10】Mixing warfarin with herbal remedies and supplements
----------------------------------------------------

【11】Do not take St John's wort, the herbal remedy for depression, while you're taking warfarin. It can increase your risk of side effects.

【12】Tell your doctor if you're taking vitamin K supplements before you start taking warfarin. Do not start taking vitamin K supplements while you are taking warfarin without checking with your doctor first.

【13】There's not enough information to say that other herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with warfarin. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines.

【14】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【15】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.
删除11：<u>More in Warfarin
----------------

【16】*   About warfarin
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Advice about food and drink
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking warfarin with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

source_info.title: Vitamins and minerals
source_info.text:
【0】Others \- Vitamins and minerals
===============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Vitamin A
3.  B vitamins and folic acid
4.  Vitamin C
5.  Vitamin D
6.  Vitamin E
7.  Vitamin K
8.  Calcium
9.  Iodine
10.  Iron
11.  Others</u>

【2】**As well as vitamins and more common minerals, a healthy diet includes many other nutrients.**

【3】This section has information on:

【4】*   beta-carotene
*   chromium
*   copper
*   magnesium
*   manganese
*   molybdenum
*   phosphorus
*   potassium
*   selenium
*   sodium chloride (salt)
*   zinc

【5】Beta-carotene
-------------

【6】Beta-carotene gives yellow and orange fruit and vegetables their colour. It's turned into vitamin A in the body, so it can perform the same jobs in the body as vitamin A.

【7】### Good sources of beta-carotene

【8】The main sources of beta-carotene are:

【9】*   yellow and green (leafy) vegetables – such as spinach, carrots and red peppers
*   yellow fruit – such as mango, papaya and apricots

【10】### How much beta-carotene do I need?

【11】You should be able to get the amount of beta-carotene you need from your daily diet.

【12】### What happens if I take too much beta-carotene?

【13】There's no evidence the beta-carotene we get from food is harmful.

【14】But beta-carotene supplements have been found to increase the risk of lung cancer in people who smoke or have been heavily exposed to asbestos at work.

【15】### What does the Department of Health and Social Care advise?

【16】You should be able to get the amount of beta-carotene you need by eating a varied and balanced diet.

【17】If you decide to take beta-carotene supplements, it's important not to take too much as this could be harmful.

【18】Do not take more than 7mg of beta-carotene supplements a day unless advised to by a doctor.

【19】People who smoke or who have been exposed to asbestos are advised not to take any beta-carotene supplements.

【20】Chromium
--------

【21】Good sources of chromium include:

【22】*   meat
*   nuts
*   cereal grains

【23】### How much chromium do I need?

【24】Around 25 micrograms of chromium a day should be enough for adults. A microgram is 1,000 times smaller than a milligram (mg).

【25】The word microgram is sometimes written with the Greek symbol μ followed by the letter g (μg).

【26】You should be able to get all the chromium you need by eating a varied and balanced diet.

【27】### What happens if I take too much chromium?

【28】There's not enough evidence to know what the effects might be of taking high doses of chromium each day.

【29】### What does the Department of Health and Social Care advise?

【30】You should be able to get all the chromium you need by eating a varied and balanced diet.

【31】If you take chromium supplements, do not take too much as this might be harmful.

【32】Having 10mg or less a day of chromium from food and supplements is unlikely to cause any harm.

【33】Copper
------

【34】Copper helps:

【35】*   produce red and white blood cells
*   trigger the release of iron to form haemoglobin, the substance that carries oxygen around the body

【36】It's also thought to be important for infant growth, brain development, the immune system and strong bones.

【37】### Good sources of copper

【38】Good sources of copper include:

【39】*   nuts
*   shellfish
*   offal

【40】### How much copper do I need?

【41】Adults aged 19 to 64 need 1.2mg of copper a day.

【42】You should be able to get all the copper you need from your daily diet.

【43】### What happens if I take too much copper?

【44】Taking high doses of copper could cause:

【45】*   stomach pain
*   sickness
*   diarrhoea
*   damage to the liver and kidneys (if taken for a long time)

【46】### What does the Department of Health and Social Care advise?

【47】You should be able to get all the copper you need by eating a varied and balanced diet. If you take copper supplements, do not take too much as this could be harmful.

【48】Having 10mg or less a day of copper is unlikely to cause any harm. This includes copper from food, water and supplements.

【49】Magnesium
---------

【50】Magnesium is a mineral that helps:

【51】*   turn the food we eat into energy
*   make sure the parathyroid glands, which produce hormones important for bone health, work normally

【52】### Good sources of magnesium

【53】Magnesium is found in a wide variety of foods, including:

【54】*   spinach
*   nuts
*   wholemeal bread

【55】### How much magnesium do I need?

【56】The amount of magnesium you need is:

【57】*   300mg a day for men (19 to 64 years)
*   270mg a day for women (19 to 64 years)

【58】### What happens if I take too much magnesium?

【59】Taking high doses of magnesium (more than 400mg) for a short time can cause diarrhoea.

【60】There's not enough evidence to say what the effects might be of taking high doses of magnesium for a long time.

【61】### What does the Department of Health and Social Care advise?

【62】You should be able to get all the magnesium you need by eating a varied and balanced diet.

【63】If you take magnesium supplements, do not take too much as this could be harmful.

【64】Having 400mg or less a day of magnesium from supplements is unlikely to cause any harm.

【65】Manganese
---------

【66】Manganese helps make and activate some of the enzymes in the body. Enzymes are proteins that help the body carry out chemical reactions, such as breaking down food.

【67】### Good sources of manganese

【68】Manganese is found in a variety of foods, including:

【69】*   bread
*   nuts
*   breakfast cereals (especially wholegrain)
*   green vegetables – such as peas

【70】### How much manganese do I need?

【71】You should be able to get all the manganese you need from your daily diet.

【72】### What happens if I take too much manganese?

【73】Taking high doses of manganese for long periods of time might cause muscle pain, nerve damage and other symptoms, such as fatigue and depression.

【74】### What does the Department of Health and Social Care advise?

【75】You should be able to get all the manganese you need by eating a varied and balanced diet.

【76】If you take manganese supplements, do not take too much as this could be harmful.

【77】For most people, taking 4mg or less of manganese supplements a day is unlikely to cause any harm.

【78】For older people, who may be more sensitive to manganese, taking 0.5mg or less of manganese supplements a day is unlikely to cause any harm.

【79】Molybdenum
----------

【80】Molybdenum helps make and activate some of the proteins involved in chemical reactions (enzymes) that help with repairing and making genetic material.

【81】### Good sources of molybdenum

【82】Molybdenum is found in a wide variety of foods. Foods that grow above ground tend to be higher in molybdenum than foods that grow below the ground, such as potatoes or carrots.

【83】### How much molybdenum do I need?

【84】You should be able to get all the molybdenum you need from your daily diet.

【85】### What happens if I take too much molybdenum?

【86】There's some evidence to suggest taking molybdenum supplements might cause joint pain.

【87】### What does the Department of Health and Social Care advise?

【88】You should be able to get all the molybdenum you need by eating a varied and balanced diet. The molybdenum we get from food is not likely to be harmful.

【89】Phosphorus
----------

【90】Phosphorus is a mineral that helps build strong bones and teeth, and helps release energy from food.

【91】### Good sources of phosphorus

【92】Phosphorus is found in many foods.

【93】Good sources include:

【94】*   red meat
*   dairy foods
*   fish
*   poultry
*   bread
*   brown rice
*   oats

【95】### How much phosphorus do I need?

【96】Adults need 550mg of phosphorus a day.

【97】You should be able to get all the phosphorus you need from your daily diet.

【98】### What happens if I take too much phosphorus?

【99】Taking high doses of phosphorus supplements for a short time can cause diarrhoea or stomach pain.

【100】Taking high doses for a long time can reduce the amount of calcium in the body, which means bones are more likely to fracture.

【101】### What does the Department of Health and Social Care advise?

【102】You should be able to get all the phosphorus you need by eating a varied and balanced diet.

【103】If you take phosphorus supplements, it's important not to take too much as this could be harmful.

【104】Taking 250mg or less a day of phosphorus supplements on top of the phosphorous you get from your diet is unlikely to cause any harm.

【105】Potassium
---------

【106】Potassium is a mineral that helps control the balance of fluids in the body, and also helps the heart muscle work properly.

【107】### Good sources of potassium

【108】Potassium is found in most types of food.

【109】Good sources of potassium include:

【110】*   bananas
*   some vegetables – such as broccoli, parsnips and brussels sprouts
*   beans and pulses
*   nuts and seeds
*   fish
*   beef
*   chicken
*   turkey

【111】### How much potassium do I need?

【112】Adults (19 to 64 years) need 3,500mg of potassium a day. You should be able to get all the potassium you need from your daily diet.

【113】### What happens if I take too much potassium?

【114】Taking too much potassium can cause stomach pain, feeling sick and diarrhoea.

【115】### What does the Department of Health and Social Care advise?

【116】You should be able to get all the potassium you need by eating a varied and balanced diet.

【117】If you take potassium supplements, do not take too much as this could be harmful.

【118】Taking 3,700mg or less of potassium supplements a day is unlikely to have obvious harmful effects.

【119】But older people may be more at risk of harm from potassium because their kidneys may be less able to remove potassium from the blood.

【120】Older people should not take potassium supplements unless advised to by a doctor.

【121】Selenium
--------

【122】Selenium helps the immune system work properly, as well as in reproduction. It also helps prevent damage to cells and tissues.

【123】Good sources of selenium include:

【124】*   brazil nuts
*   fish
*   meat
*   eggs

【125】### How much selenium do I need?

【126】The amount of selenium you need is:

【127】*   75μg a day for men (19 to 64 years)
*   60μg a day for women (19 to 64 years)

【128】If you eat meat, fish or nuts, you should be able to get all the selenium you need from your daily diet.

【129】### What happens if I take too much selenium?

【130】Too much selenium causes selenosis, a condition that, in its mildest form, can lead to loss of hair and nails.

【131】### What does the Department of Health and Social Care advise?

【132】You should be able to get all the selenium you need by eating a varied and balanced diet that includes meat, fish or nuts.

【133】If you take selenium supplements, it's important not to take too much as this could be harmful.

【134】Taking 350μg or less a day of selenium supplements is unlikely to cause any harm.

【135】Sodium chloride (salt)
----------------------

【136】Sodium chloride is commonly known as salt.

【137】Sodium and chloride are minerals needed by the body in small amounts to help keep the level of fluids in the body balanced. Chloride also helps the body digest food.

【138】### Sources of salt

【139】Salt is found naturally at low levels in all foods, but some salt is added to many processed foods, such as:

【140】*   ready meals
*   meat products – such as bacon
*   some breakfast cereals
*   cheese
*   tinned vegetables with added salt
*   some bread
*   savoury snacks

【141】### How much salt do I need?

【142】You should have no more than 6g of salt (2.4g of sodium) a day.

【143】But, on average, people in the UK eat approximately 8g of salt (about 3.2g of sodium) a day, which is much more than the body needs.

【144】A few practical tips for cutting down on salt include:

【145】*   check food labels and choose foods with less salt – where colour-coded labels are used, try to pick products with more greens and ambers, and fewer reds, for a healthier choice
*   choose tinned vegetables and pulses with no added salt
*   choose tinned fish in spring water rather than brine
*   only use sauces like soy sauce, brown sauce, ketchup and mayonnaise sparingly, as these are often high in salt
*   eat fewer salty snacks, such as crisps, salted nuts, and salty foods such as bacon, cheese, pickles and smoked fish
*   add less or no salt when cooking – use herbs and spices for flavour instead
*   choose low-salt stock cubes, or make your own stock without added salt
*   taste your food first, and do not automatically add extra salt

【146】Read more facts about salt, cutting down on salt and how much salt is good for me?

【147】You can also download the Change4Life Be Food Smart app, which allows you to scan food barcodes to check the salt content.

【148】### What happens if I have too much salt?

【149】Having too much salt is linked to high blood pressure, which raises your risk of serious problems like strokes and heart attacks.

【150】### What does the Department of Health and Social Care advise?

【151】Adults should eat no more than 6g of salt a day – that's around 1 teaspoon. On average, we eat 2.1g more salt than we should each day.

【152】The Department of Health and Social Care advises that people cut down on salt and says sodium chloride should not be used in supplements.

【153】Zinc
----

【154】Zinc helps with:

【155】*   making new cells and enzymes
*   processing carbohydrate, fat and protein in food
*   wound healing

【156】### Good sources of zinc

【157】Good sources of zinc include:

【158】*   meat
*   shellfish
*   dairy foods – such as cheese
*   bread
*   cereal products – such as wheatgerm

【159】### How much zinc do I need?

【160】The amount of zinc you need is about:

【161】*   9.5mg a day for men (aged 19 to 64 years)
*   7mg a day for women

【162】You should be able to get all the zinc you need from your daily diet.

【163】### What happens if I take too much zinc?

【164】Taking high doses of zinc reduces the amount of copper the body can absorb. This can lead to anaemia and weakening of the bones.

【165】### What does the Department of Health and Social Care advise?

【166】You should be able to get all the zinc you need by eating a varied and balanced diet.

【167】If you take zinc supplements, do not take too much as this could be harmful.

【168】Do not take more than 25mg of zinc supplements a day unless advised to by a doctor.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 03 August 2020  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 03 August 2023</u>

source_info.title: Domperidone
source_info.text:
【0】Taking domperidone with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand name: Motilium
======================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Some medicines and domperidone can affect each other. This may increase your chance of having side effects.

【3】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking:

【4】*   antidepressants or antipsychotic medicines
*   antibiotics or medicines for fungal infections
*   medicines for malaria
*   medicines for HIV infection
*   medicines for a heart condition or high blood pressure
*   medicines for cancer, or if you're having treatment for cancer

【5】Taking domperidone with other anti-sickness medicines
-----------------------------------------------------

【6】It's usually best to only take 1 type of medicine for feeling or being sick.

【7】If domperidone does not work for you, speak to a doctor. They may want to recommend a different medicine.

【8】Mixing domperidone with herbal remedies and supplements
-------------------------------------------------------

【9】Some herbal remedies can make your side effects worse.

【10】There's not enough information to say that other complementary medicines and herbal remedies are safe to take with domperidone. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【11】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【12】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.
删除11：<u>More in Domperidone
-------------------

【13】*   About domperidone

*   Side effects

source_info.title: You and your baby at 7 weeks pregnant
source_info.text:
【0】You and your baby at 7 weeks pregnant
=====================================

【1】Your baby at 7 weeks
--------------------

【2】By 7 weeks, the embryo has grown to about 10mm long from head to bottom. This measurement is called the crown-rump length.

【3】The brain is growing rapidly and this results in the head growing faster than the rest of the body. The embryo has a large forehead, and the eyes and ears continue to develop.

【4】The inner ears start to develop, but the outer ears on the sides of the head will not appear for a couple more weeks.

【5】The limb buds start to form cartilage, which will develop into the bones of the legs and arms. The arm buds get longer and the ends flatten out – these will become the hands.

【6】Nerve cells continue to multiply and develop as the brain and spinal cord (the nervous system) starts to take shape.

【7】You at 7 weeks
--------------

【8】Your womb has grown to the size of a lemon by the time you're around 7 or 8 weeks pregnant.

【9】You're probably feeling tired. Your breasts might feel sore and enlarged, and you may need to pee more often than usual.

【10】You may start to feel sick or tired, or have other minor pregnancy problems for a few weeks around this time.

【11】In most cases, feelings of nausea and vomiting (morning sickness) start to improve after around 14 weeks of pregnancy.

【12】Some infections can harm a pregnancy. It's important to let your doctor or midwife know if you think you may have an infection so they can give you the right care as early as possible.

【13】Find out about infections that may cause problems in pregnancy

【14】You may have bleeding or sore gums when you're pregnant. Good mouth hygiene and regular dental care, to keep your teeth and gums as healthy as possible, is the best way to avoid or care for gum problems.

【15】Dental care is free during pregnancy and until 1 year after your due date. Ask your midwife or doctor about how to apply for free dental care删除7：<u>

【16】Things to think about
---------------------

【17】*   find out about midwives, obstetricians and other healthcare professionals who may provide your pregnancy (antenatal) care
*   what to expect from your NHS pregnancy journey
*   your first midwife appointment

【18】Start4Life has more about you and your baby at 7 weeks of pregnancy</u>

【19】You can sign up for Start4Life weekly emails for expert advice, videos and tips on pregnancy, birth and beyond.
删除3：<u>Video: What will happen to my body during pregnancy?
----------------------------------------------------

【20】In this video, mothers talk about how they dealt with some of the physical changes during pregnancy.

source_info.title: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome
source_info.text:
【0】Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome
=================================

【1】**Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is a rare condition that affects the signals sent from the nerves to the muscles.**

【2】It means the muscles are unable to tighten (contract) properly, resulting in muscle weakness and a range of other symptoms.

【3】More than half of LEMS cases occur in middle-aged or older people with lung cancer. The remaining cases are not associated with cancer and can start at any age.

【4】LEMS is also known as myasthenic syndrome or Eaton-Lambert syndrome.

【5】Symptoms of LEMS
----------------

【6】The symptoms of LEMS develop gradually over weeks or months.

【7】The main symptoms are weakness in the legs, arms, neck and face, as well as problems with automatic body functions, such as controlling blood pressure.

【8】Common symptoms include:

【9】*   aching muscles
*   feeling very tired all the time (fatigue)
*   difficulty walking and climbing stairs
*   difficulty lifting objects or raising the arms
*   drooping eyelids, dry eyes and blurred vision
*   swallowing problems
*   dizziness upon standing
*   a dry mouth
*   constipation
*   erectile dysfunction
*   muscle weakness that gets worse with time

【10】See a GP if you have a combination of these symptoms.

【11】Causes of LEMS
--------------

【12】LEMS is caused by the body's natural defences (the immune system) mistakenly attacking and damaging the nerves.

【13】Normally, nerve signals travel down the nerves and stimulate the nerve endings to release a chemical called acetylcholine. This chemical then helps activate the muscles.

【14】If the nerve endings are damaged, the amount of acetylcholine they produce decreases, which means nerve signals do not reach the muscles properly.

【15】It's not known what triggers the immune system to attack the nerves. It's often associated with lung cancer, but can occur in people without cancer.

【16】Tests for LEMS
--------------

【17】The GP will first check your medical history, ask about your symptoms, carry out a physical examination, and test your reflexes.

【18】If they think you have a problem with your nerves, they may refer you to a specialist called a neurologist for further tests to determine the cause.

【19】Tests you may have include:

【20】*   **blood tests** – a blood test can detect substances in the blood (antibodies) resulting from the immune system attacking the nerves
*   **nerve studies** – a needle may be inserted into your skin to check how well signals are reaching the muscles from the nerves
*   **scans** – you may have a CT scan or PET scan to check for lung cancer

【21】If initial scans do not find cancer, you may be advised to have regular scans every few months for a few years to check that it does not develop later on.

【22】Treatments for LEMS
-------------------

【23】There's currently no cure for LEMS, but a number of treatments can help reduce the symptoms.

【24】These include:

【25】*   **treatment for lung cancer** – if you have lung cancer, treating it can significantly improve the symptoms of LEMS
*   **medicine to help nerve signals reach the muscles** – commonly used medicines include 3,4-diaminopyridine and pyridostigmine
*   **medicine to reduce the activity of the immune system (immunosuppressants)** – commonly used medicines include steroid tablets (such as prednisolone), azathioprine and methotrexate
*   **plasmapheresis** – a procedure to redirect your blood through a machine that filters out the antibodies attacking your nerves
*   **immunoglobulin therapy** – injections of antibodies from donated blood that temporarily stop your immune system attacking your nerves

【26】Medicine is the main treatment, although plasmapheresis and immunoglobulin therapy may be recommended in the short term, or if muscle weakness is severe and other treatments have not helped.

【27】Outlook for LEMS
----------------

【28】Some people respond well to treatment and find that treatment helps keep their symptoms under control.

【29】Others respond less well and find the condition affects their everyday activities and quality of life.

【30】LEMS does not affect life expectancy if it's not associated with cancer. But people with lung cancer and LEMS tend to have a shorter life expectancy because by this point it's very difficult to treat.

【31】Information about you
---------------------

【32】If you have LEMS, your clinical team may pass information about you on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

【33】This helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat this condition. You can opt out of the register at any time删除7：<u>

【34】GOV.UK has more information about NCARDRS</u>

source_info.title: Lidocaine skin cream
source_info.text:
【0】How and when to use lidocaine skin cream \- Brand names: Denela, EMLA, LMX4, Nulbia
===================================================================================

【1】A doctor or nurse will usually give you a prescription for lidocaine cream or give you the cream itself, before your appointment for your procedure.

【2】Always follow the instructions that come with your cream.

【3】If you're having a cosmetic procedure and have bought lidocaine from a pharmacy to numb the area, tell the person doing the procedure before it starts. It will help them to know that the area has been numbed and you will not feel as much pain.

【4】Dosage
------

【5】The amount of lidocaine skin cream you use depends on the procedure you're having and the type of lidocaine cream you're using.

【6】Check the instructions that come with the cream or follow the advice of your doctor or nurse.

【7】They may tell you to use a whole tube of cream on each area of your skin, more than 1 tube, or only part of a tube.

【8】How to use it
-------------

【9】If you're having a drip or having blood taken, put the lidocaine cream on 1 hour beforehand.

【10】For minor surgery, your doctor may tell you to use the cream more than 1 hour before the procedure.

【11】If the procedure is delayed and the numbing effects of the cream have worn off, ask your doctor or nurse for advice before using any more cream.

【12】1.  Gently squeeze the tube so the cream goes straight onto the area of skin to be treated.
2.  Do not rub it in.
3.  Place a waterproof dressing over the cream to keep it in place. (The dressings come with the cream.)
4.  Make a note of the time that you put the cream on.
5.  As soon as you've finished putting the cream on, wash your hands carefully with soap and water.
6.  When you're about to have your procedure, take off the dressing and wipe off any excess cream with a tissue. You may not need to do this if the cream has soaked into your skin.

【13】### Important

【14】Do not use the cream on your eyes, ears, nose or the inside of your mouth, or on your genitals or bottom (anus), unless your doctor tells you to.

【15】How long to use it for
----------------------

【16】You'll use lidocaine skin cream as a one-off, before a minor procedure like having a blood sample taken.

【17】If you forget to use it
-----------------------

【18】If you forget to use the cream, or you put it on less than 1 hour before your procedure, tell the person who is going to do the procedure. They may want to delay it.

【19】Do not put on extra cream, as this will not make the lidocaine work any faster.

【20】If you use too much
-------------------

【21】Using more than the recommended amount can cause side effects. This can also happen if you put the cream on a large area of skin, or use it for longer than recommended.

【22】If you've been prescribed lidocaine, you're unlikely to use too much cream, as a doctor or nurse will usually give you the amount you need for a one-off procedure.

【23】Ask a doctor or nurse for advice if you're worried that you may have used too much lidocaine skin cream.
删除11：<u>More in Lidocaine skin cream
----------------------------

【24】*   About lidocaine skin cream

source_info.title: Edoxaban
source_info.text:
【0】How and when to take edoxaban
=============================

【1】It's important to take edoxaban as your doctor has told you.

【2】Dosage and strength
-------------------

【3】Edoxaban comes as 15mg, 30mg and 60mg tablets.

【4】The usual dose of edoxaban is 60mg, taken once a day. Your doctor may prescribe a lower dose of 30mg a day if you:

【5】*   have kidney disease
*   have a low body weight
*   are taking ciclosporin
*   are taking dronedarone (to treat atrial fibrillation)
*   are taking erythromycin or ketoconazole

【6】If you're unsure what dose you need to take, check with your pharmacist or doctor.

【7】How to take it
--------------

【8】Swallow the tablet with a drink of water.

【9】You can take edoxaban with or without food but try to take it at the same time every day.

【10】How long to take it for
-----------------------

【11】How long you need to take edoxaban will depend on why you're taking it.

【12】If you've had a blood clot (deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism) you'll normally take edoxaban for at least 3 months. Depending on what caused the blood clot, you might need to take it for longer.

【13】If you have atrial fibrillation you might need to take edoxaban long term or even for the rest of your life.

【14】Do not stop taking edoxaban without talking to your doctor. If you stop taking it you may be at increased risk of serious health problems caused by blood clots.

【15】If you forget to take it
------------------------

【16】If you forget a dose of edoxaban, take your tablet as soon as you remember. If you only remember the following day, leave out the forgotten dose and take your next dose at the usual time.

【17】Never take 2 doses at the same time. Never take an extra dose to make up for a forgotten one.

【18】If you often forget doses, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to remember to take your medicines.

【19】If you take too much
--------------------

【20】Taking too much edoxaban puts you at risk of bleeding.

【21】### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【22】*   you take more than your prescribed dose of edoxaban

【23】Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111

【24】Anticoagulant alert card
------------------------

【25】Your doctor or pharmacist will give you an anticoagulant alert card. Carry this with you all the time. It tells healthcare professionals that you're taking an anticoagulant. This can be useful for them to know in case of a medical emergency.

【26】If you need any medical or dental treatment, show your anticoagulant alert card to the nurse, doctor or dentist. This includes before you have vaccinations and routine sessions with the dental hygienist.

【27】Your doctor may advise you to stop taking edoxaban or reduce your dose for a short time.

【28】Switching from warfarin to edoxaban
-----------------------------------

【29】If you need to switch from warfarin to edoxaban, your doctor will advise you when to stop taking warfarin. This will probably be a few days before you start edoxaban.

【30】Your doctor or anticoagulant clinic will do a blood test called the international normalised ratio (INR) to check how quickly your blood's clotting. This is to help decide exactly when you should start taking edoxaban.

【31】Switching from edoxaban to warfarin
-----------------------------------

【32】If you need to switch from edoxaban to warfarin, you may need to take both medicines together for a few days.

【33】Your doctor or anticoagulant clinic will do a blood test called the international normalised ratio (INR) to check how quickly your blood's clotting. This is to help decide exactly when you should stop taking edoxaban.
删除11：<u>More in Edoxaban
----------------

【34】*   About edoxaban
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking edoxaban with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
