source_info.title: Feeling sick (nausea)
source_info.text:
【0】Feeling sick (nausea)
=====================

【1】**Feeling sick (nausea) is common and usually goes away on its own. There are some things you can try that might help.**

【2】Things that may help you stop feeling sick
------------------------------------------

【3】### Do

【4】*   get plenty of fresh air

【5】*   distract yourself – for example, listen to music or watch a film

【6】*   take regular sips of a cold drink

【7】*   drink ginger or peppermint tea

【8】*   eat foods containing ginger – such as ginger biscuits

【9】*   eat smaller, more frequent meals

【10】### Don’t

【11】*   do not eat or cook strong-smelling food

【12】*   do not eat hot, fried or greasy food

【13】*   do not eat too quickly

【14】*   do not have a large drink with meals

【15】*   do not lie down soon after eating

【16】*   do not wear clothes that are tight around your waist or tummy

【17】### Important: If you're being sick

【18】If you're also being sick (vomiting), you could become dehydrated.

【19】Find out what to do if you're vomiting

【20】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if you:
-----------------------------------

【21】*   are feeling sick and do not feel better in a few days
*   often feel sick (it keeps coming back)

【22】The GP can look for the cause and suggest treatments.

【23】They may prescribe anti-sickness medicine if needed.

【24】Call 111 for advice if you cannot see a GP.

【25】Immediate action required: Call 999 if:
---------------------------------------

【26】You suddenly feel sick and have:

【27】*   chest pain that feels tight or heavy
*   pain that spreads to your arms, back, neck or jaw
*   shortness of breath

【28】This could be a heart attack.

【29】Common causes of feeling sick
-----------------------------

【30】Lots of things can make you feel sick.

【31】Any other symptoms you have may give you an idea of the cause. But do not self-diagnose – see a GP if you're worried.

【32】Possible causes of feeling sick.

| Other symptoms | Possible cause |
| --- | --- |
| Diarrhoea or vomiting | Norovirus or food poisoning |
| Headache and a high temperature | An infection, such as flu |
| Heartburn or bloating after eating | Acid reflux |
| Headache and sensitivity to light or sound | Migraine |
| Dizziness | Labyrinthitis or vertigo |

【34】Other reasons for feeling sick include:

【35】*   pregnancy (morning sickness)
*   motion sickness
*   anxiety
*   alcohol
*   medicines
*   recent surgery

【36】Information:

【37】Do not worry if you're not sure what's causing you to feel sick. Try the things that may stop you feeling sick and see a GP if you do not feel better in a few days.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 17 November 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 17 November 2026</u>

source_info.title: Angioedema
source_info.text:
【0】Angioedema
==========

【1】**Angioedema is sudden swelling that is often caused by an allergic reaction. It can be very serious if your throat becomes swollen and your breathing is affected. Treatment can help keep the swelling under control.**

【2】Check if you have angioedema
----------------------------

【3】Angioedema is where a part of the body suddenly becomes swollen.

【4】You'll usually have a raised, itchy rash (hives) if an allergic reaction has caused the swelling.

【5】Areas of the body commonly affected include:

【6】*   the face – particularly the lips, tongue and eyelids
*   the hands or feet
*   the genitals

【7】Sometimes the bowel may also become swollen, which can cause stomach pain.

【8】Less commonly, the throat can swell up, leading to breathing difficulties. This is a medical emergency and immediate treatment is needed.

【9】Immediate action required: Call 999 if:
---------------------------------------

【10】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【11】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised or itchy.

【12】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【13】Urgent advice: Ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

【14】*   part of your body suddenly becomes swollen (such as your hands, feet or genitals)

【15】You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.

【16】Treatments for angioedema
-------------------------

【17】You may not need treatment for angioedema if the swelling is mild or it only affects a small area of your body.

【18】If the swelling is severe or widespread, or if it affects your lips, tongue, or throat, you'll usually need emergency treatment in hospital.

【19】Treatments for angioedema include:

【20】*   identifying and avoiding the underlying cause – if a medicine is thought to be the cause, you may be given a different one to take instead
*   antihistamine medicine, such as cetirizine, fexofenadine or loratadine
*   steroid tablets, such as prednisolone

【21】If you have a type of angioedema that keeps coming back (hereditary angioedema), you may also need medicine to stop this happening.

【22】You may have regular reviews to check if your treatment is working.

【23】If your symptoms do not improve or get worse, you may need to go back to hospital for further tests and treatment.

【24】Types of angioedema
-------------------

【25】Types of angioedema

| Cause | Type |
| --- | --- |
| Angioedema caused by an allergic reaction to certain foods, medicines or substances | Acute allergic angioedema |
| A non-allergic reaction to a medicine, most commonly angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors | Non-allergic angioedema |
| Long-term angioedema where the cause is unknown | Idiopathic angioedema |
| A rare and potentially life-threatening type of angioedema that's often inherited from your parents | Hereditary angioedema |
| A very rare type of angioedema that you can get if you have lymphoma (cancer), or a condition that affects the connective tissue, such as lupus | Acquired angioedema |

source_info.title: Clarithromycin
source_info.text:
【0】Side effects of clarithromycin
==============================

【1】Common side effects
-------------------

【2】These common side effects of clarithromycin happen in more than 1 in 100 people. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【3】Feeling sick (nausea)

【4】Stick to simple meals and do not eat rich or spicy food while you're taking this medicine. It might help to take your clarithromycin after you have a meal or snack.

【5】Being sick (vomiting)

【6】Try taking small, frequent sips of water to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee. Do not take any other medicines to treat vomiting without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.

【7】If you take contraceptive pills and you're being sick, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet for advice.

【8】Diarrhoea

【9】Drink lots of fluids, such as water or squash, to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee. Do not take any other medicines to treat diarrhoea without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.

【10】If you take contraceptive pills and you have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet for advice.

【11】Bloating and indigestion

【12】Try not to eat foods that cause farting (flatulence) like lentils, beans and onions. Eat smaller meals, eat and drink slowly, and exercise. There are pharmacy medicines that can also help, such as antacids or simeticone. Ask a pharmacist for advice.

【13】Headaches

【14】Rest and drink plenty of fluids. It's best not to drink too much alcohol. Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller if you need one. Talk to your doctor if the headaches last longer than a week or are severe.

【15】Difficulty sleeping (insomnia)

【16】Avoid having a big meal, smoking, and drinking alcohol, tea or coffee in the evening. Try not to watch television or use your mobile phone before going to bed. Instead, try to relax for an hour before bedtime.

【17】If this advice does not help and any of these side effects continue to bother you, keep taking the medicine, but tell your doctor or pharmacist.

【18】Serious side effects
--------------------

【19】Serious side effects are rare and happen in less than 1 in 1,000 people.

【20】Call a doctor or call 111 now if you get:

【21】*   a faster or irregular heartbeat
*   pale poo, dark pee and a yellow colour to the whites of your eyes or skin (although this may be less obvious on brown or black skin) – these can be signs of liver problems
*   severe pain in your stomach and/or back – this can be a sign of inflammation of the pancreas (pancreatitis)
*   diarrhoea (perhaps with muscle cramps) that contains blood or mucus – if you have severe diarrhoea without blood or mucus for more than 4 days, also speak to a doctor
*   hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not there)

【22】### Serious allergic reaction

【23】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to clarithromycin.

【24】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【25】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【26】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【27】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【28】Other side effects
------------------

【29】These are not all the side effects of clarithromycin. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.
删除5：<u>Information:

【30】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.
删除12：<u>Visit Yellow Card for further information.</u></u>
删除11：<u>More in Clarithromycin
----------------------

【31】*   About clarithromycin

*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking clarithromycin with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

source_info.title: Diabetes insipidus
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Diabetes insipidus
==============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications</u>

【2】**Diabetes insipidus is a rare condition where you pee a lot and often feel thirsty.**

【3】Diabetes insipidus is not related to type 1 diabetes or type 2 diabetes (also known as diabetes mellitus), but it does share some of the same signs and symptoms.

【4】The 2 main symptoms of diabetes insipidus are:

【5】*   extreme thirst (polydipsia)
*   peeing a lot, even at night (polyuria)

【6】In very severe cases of diabetes insipidus, a person can pee up to 20 litres of urine in a day.
删除7：<u>Find out more about the symptoms of diabetes insipidus</u>

【7】When to seek medical advice
---------------------------

【8】You should always see your GP if you're feeling thirsty all the time.

【9】Although it may not be diabetes insipidus, it should be investigated.

【10】Also see your GP if you're:

【11】*   peeing more than normal – most healthy adults pass urine 4 to 7 times in a 24-hour period
*   needing to pee small amounts at frequent intervals – sometimes this can occur along with the feeling that you need to pee immediately

【12】Children tend to pee more frequently because they have smaller bladders.

【13】But seek medical advice if your child pees more than 10 times a day.

【14】Your GP will be able to carry out a number of tests to help determine what's causing the problem.
删除7：<u>Find out more about diagnosing diabetes insipidus</u>

【15】What causes diabetes insipidus
------------------------------

【16】Diabetes insipidus is caused by problems with a hormone called vasopressin (AVP), also called antidiuretic hormone (ADH).

【17】AVP plays a key role in regulating the amount of fluid in the body.

【18】It's produced by specialist nerve cells in a part of the brain known as the hypothalamus.

【19】AVP passes from the hypothalamus to the pituitary gland, where it's stored until needed.

【20】The pituitary gland releases AVP when the amount of water in the body becomes too low. 

【21】It helps retain water in the body by reducing the amount of water lost through the kidneys, making the kidneys produce more concentrated urine.

【22】In diabetes insipidus, the lack of production of AVP means the kidneys cannot make enough concentrated urine and too much water is passed from the body.

【23】In rare cases, the kidneys do not respond to AVP. This causes a specific form of diabetes insipidus called nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

【24】People feel thirsty as the body tries to compensate for the increased loss of water by increasing the amount of water taken in.
删除7：<u>Find out more about the causes of diabetes insipidus</u>

【25】Who's affected by diabetes insipidus
------------------------------------

【26】Diabetes insipidus affects about 1 in 25,000 people in the general population.

【27】Adults are more likely to develop the condition, but it can occur at any age.

【28】In rarer cases, diabetes insipidus can develop during pregnancy, known as gestational diabetes insipidus.

【29】Types of diabetes insipidus
---------------------------

【30】There are 2 main types of diabetes insipidus:

【31】*   cranial diabetes insipidus
*   nephrogenic diabetes insipidus

【32】### Cranial diabetes insipidus

【33】Cranial diabetes insipidus occurs when there's not enough AVP in the body to regulate urine production.

【34】Cranial diabetes insipidus is the most common type of diabetes insipidus.

【35】It can be caused by damage to the hypothalamus or pituitary gland – for example, after an infection, operation, brain tumour or head injury.

【36】In about 1 in 3 cases of cranial diabetes insipidus there's no obvious reason why the hypothalamus stops making enough AVP.

【37】### Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus

【38】Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus occurs when there's enough AVP in the body but the kidneys fail to respond to it.

【39】It can be caused by kidney damage or, in some cases, inherited as a problem on its own.

【40】Some medications, particularly lithium (used to help stabilise mood in some people with specific mental health conditions, such as bipolar disorder), can cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

【41】Treating diabetes insipidus
---------------------------

【42】Treatment is not always needed for mild cases of cranial diabetes insipidus.

【43】You just need to increase the amount of water you drink to compensate for the fluid lost through urination.

【44】If necessary, a medication called desmopressin can be used to replicate the functions of AVP.

【45】Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is often treated with medications called thiazide diuretics, which reduce the amount of urine the kidneys produce.
删除7：<u>Find out more about treating diabetes insipidus</u>

【46】Complications
-------------

【47】As diabetes insipidus increases water loss in the urine, the amount of water in the body can become low. This is known as dehydration.

【48】Rehydration with water can be used to treat mild dehydration. Severe dehydration will need to be treated in hospital.
删除7：<u>Find out more about the complications of diabetes insipidus</u>

source_info.title: Chorionic villus sampling
source_info.text:
【0】What happens \- Chorionic villus sampling
=========================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Why it's offered
3.  What happens
4.  Results
5.  Complications</u>

【2】**Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) involves taking a sample of cells from the tissue of the placenta (the chorionic villi).**

【3】Preparing for CVS
-----------------

【4】You will not usually need to do anything special to prepare for CVS. You can eat and drink as normal beforehand.

【5】In some cases, you may be asked to avoid going to the toilet for a few hours before having CVS because it's sometimes easier to do the test when your bladder is full.

【6】Your doctor or midwife will tell you about this before you attend your appointment.

【7】You can bring a partner, friend or family member for support when you have the test.

【8】How CVS is performed
--------------------

【9】CVS is carried out under the continuous guidance of an ultrasound scan.

【10】This is to make sure nothing enters the amniotic sac (the protective sac that cushions the baby) or touches the baby.

【11】The test can be carried out using 2 different methods: transabdominal CVS and transcervical CVS.

【12】### Transabdominal CVS

【13】Your tummy is cleaned with antiseptic before a local anaesthetic injection is used to numb it.

【14】A needle is inserted through your skin into the womb and guided to the placenta using the image on the ultrasound scan.

【15】A syringe is attached to the needle, which is used to take a small sample of cells from the chorionic villi.

【16】After the sample is removed, the needle is removed.

【17】### Transcervical CVS

【18】A sample of cells from the chorionic villi is collected through the neck of your womb (the cervix).

【19】A thin tube attached to a syringe, or small forceps, are inserted through your vagina and cervix and guided towards the placenta using the ultrasound scan.

【20】Which method will be used?
--------------------------

【21】The transabdominal method is preferred in most cases because it's often easier to carry out.

【22】Transcervical CVS is also more likely to cause vaginal bleeding immediately after the procedure, which occurs in about 1 in 10 women who have this procedure.

【23】But there's no difference in the rate of miscarriages between the 2 methods.

【24】Transcervical CVS may be preferred to transabdominal CVS if it's easier to reach your placenta this way.

【25】Is CVS painful?
---------------

【26】CVS is usually described as being uncomfortable, rather than painful.

【27】In most cases, an injection of local anaesthetic will be given before transabdominal CVS to numb the area where the needle is inserted, but you may have a sore tummy afterwards.

【28】Transcervical CVS feels similar to a cervical screening test.

【29】How long does it take?
----------------------

【30】CVS usually takes around 10 minutes, although the whole consultation may take about 30 minutes.

【31】Afterwards, you'll be monitored for up to an hour in case you have any side effects, such as heavy bleeding.

【32】You can then go home to rest.

【33】It's a good idea to arrange for someone to drive you home as you might not feel up to it yourself.

【34】Recovering after CVS
--------------------

【35】After having CVS, it's normal to have cramps similar to period pain and light vaginal bleeding called spotting for a few hours.

【36】You can take painkillers you can buy in a pharmacy or shop, such as paracetamol (but not ibuprofen or aspirin) if you experience any discomfort.

【37】You may wish to avoid any strenuous activity for the rest of the day.

【38】Contact your midwife or the hospital where the procedure was carried out for advice as soon as possible if you develop any of the following symptoms afterwards:

【39】*   persistent or severe pain
*   a high temperature or feeling hot or shivery
*   heavy vaginal bleeding
*   discharge of clear fluid from your vagina
*   contractions

source_info.text:
【0】Treatment \- Pelvic organ prolapse
==================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Treatment</u>

【2】**There are several treatment options available for pelvic organ prolapse.**

【3】The most suitable for you will depend on:

【4】*   the severity of your symptoms
*   the severity of the prolapse
*   your age and health
*   whether you're planning to have children in the future

【5】You may not need any treatment if the prolapse is mild to moderate and not causing any pain or discomfort.

【6】Treatment options include:

【7】*   lifestyle changes
*   pelvic floor exercises
*   hormone treatment
*   vaginal pessaries
*   surgery

【8】Your doctor should offer you the full range of treatments and explain the possible benefits and risks of each option. This will help you choose the right one for you.

【9】Lifestyle changes
-----------------

【10】If you do not have any symptoms or the prolapse is mild, making some lifestyle changes may help and could stop the prolapse getting worse.

【11】They can also help reduce your risk of getting a prolapse in the first place.

【12】They include:

【13】*   losing weight if you're overweight
*   eating a high-fibre diet to avoid constipation
*   avoiding lifting heavy objects

【14】Pelvic floor exercises
----------------------

【15】Doing pelvic floor exercises will strengthen your pelvic floor muscles and may well relieve your symptoms.

【16】A GP or specialist may recommend a programme of supervised pelvic floor muscle training for at least 16 weeks before you move on to other treatments or surgery.

【17】You'll be shown how to do the exercises. If they help, you may be asked to continue with them.
删除7：<u>Find out more about pelvic floor exercises</u>

【18】Hormone (oestrogen) treatment
-----------------------------

【19】If you have a mild prolapse and have been through the menopause, your doctor may recommend treatment with oestrogen to ease some of your symptoms, such as vaginal dryness or discomfort during sex.

【20】Oestrogen is available as:

【21】*   a cream you apply to your vagina
*   a tablet you insert into your vagina
*   an oestrogen-releasing vaginal ring

【22】Vaginal pessaries
-----------------

【23】A device made of rubber (latex) or silicone is inserted into the vagina and left in place to support the vaginal walls and pelvic organs.

【24】Vaginal pessaries allow you to get pregnant in the future. They can be used to ease the symptoms of moderate or severe prolapses and are a good option if you cannot or would prefer not to have surgery.

【25】Vaginal pessaries come in different shapes and sizes depending on your need. The most common is called a ring pessary.

【26】You may need to try a few different types and sizes to find the one that works best for you.

【27】A gynaecologist or a specialist nurse usually fits a pessary. It needs to be removed, cleaned and replaced regularly.

【28】### Side effects of vaginal pessaries

【29】Vaginal pessaries can occasionally cause:

【30】*   unpleasant smelling vaginal discharge, which could be a sign of a bacterial infection in the vagina (bacterial vaginosis)
*   some irritation and sores inside your vagina, and possibly bleeding
*   stress incontinence, where you pass a small amount of urine when you cough, sneeze or exercise
*   a urinary tract infection
*   interference with sex (but most women can have sex without any problems)

【31】These side effects can usually be treated.

【32】Surgery
-------

【33】If non-surgical options have not worked or the prolapse is more severe, surgery may be an option.

【34】There are several different surgical treatments for pelvic organ prolapse.

【35】They include:

【36】*   surgical repair
*   vaginal mesh surgery
*   hysterectomy
*   closing the vagina

【37】Your doctor will discuss the benefits and risks of different treatments, and you'll decide together which is best for you.

【38】### Surgical repair

【39】There are several different types of surgery that involve lifting and supporting the pelvic organs.

【40】This could be by stitching them into place or supporting the existing tissues to make them stronger.

【41】Surgical repairs are usually done by making cuts in the wall of the vagina under general anaesthetic.

【42】This means you'll be asleep during the operation and will not feel any pain.

【43】You may need 6 to 12 weeks off work to recover, depending on the type of surgery you have.

【44】If you'd like to have children in the future, your doctors may suggest delaying surgery because pregnancy can cause the prolapse to happen again.

【45】### Vaginal mesh surgery

【46】Information:

【47】At the moment, it's not possible to have vaginal mesh surgery for pelvic organ prolapse on the NHS unless there's no alternative and the procedure cannot be delayed, and after detailed discussion between you and a doctor.

【48】Vaginal mesh surgery is where a piece of synthetic mesh, a plastic product that looks like a net, is inserted to hold the pelvic organs in place.

【49】The mesh stays in your body permanently.

【50】You'll be asleep during the operation and you will usually need to stay in hospital for 1 to 3 days afterwards.

【51】A few women have had serious complications after mesh surgery. Some, but not all, of these complications can also happen after other types of surgery.

【52】The complications include:

【53】*   long-lasting pain
*   permanent nerve damage
*   incontinence
*   constipation
*   sexual problems
*   mesh exposure through vaginal tissues and occasionally injury to nearby organs, such as the bladder or bowel

【54】#### If you're concerned about vaginal mesh

【55】If you have previously had vaginal mesh inserted and think you're having complications, speak to a GP or your surgeon.

【56】If you're not having any complications, there's no need to do anything.

【57】Many women have had these types of surgery without developing any problems afterwards.

【58】You can report a problem with a medicine or medical device on GOV.UK
删除7：<u>Find out more about the rules for the use of vaginal mesh on GOV.UK</u>

【59】You can also read about the Mesh Working Group set up by NHS England to address safety concerns about the use of vaginal mesh

【60】### Hysterectomy

【61】For women with a prolapsed womb who have been through the menopause or do not wish to have any more children, a doctor may recommend surgery to remove the womb (hysterectomy).

【62】It can help to relieve pressure on the walls of the vagina and reduce the chance of a prolapse returning.

【63】You cannot get pregnant after having a hysterectomy, and sometimes it may cause you to go through the menopause early.

【64】You may need 6 to 12 weeks off work to recover.

【65】通用结尾删除-1:<u>### Closing the vagina</u>

【66】通用结尾删除-1:<u>Occasionally, an operation that closes part or all of the vagina may be an option.</u>

【67】通用结尾删除-1:<u>This treatment is only offered to women who have advanced prolapse, when other treatments have not worked and they're sure they do not want to have sex again in the future.</u>

【68】通用结尾删除-1:<u>This operation can be a good option for frail women who would not be able to have more complex surgery.</u>

【69】通用结尾删除-1:<u>### Side effects of surgery</u>

【70】通用结尾删除-1:<u>Your doctor should have an in-depth discussion with you about the risks and benefits of the 4 different types of surgery, including mesh surgery, before you decide together whether one of them could be an option.</u>

【71】通用结尾删除-1:<u>Doctors must also keep detailed records about the type of surgery they do, including any complications you get after you have had your surgery.</u>

【72】通用结尾删除-1:<u>You should be given a copy of this record.</u>

【73】通用结尾删除-1:<u>Possible side effects of all 4 types of surgery, including mesh surgery, include:</u>

【74】通用结尾删除-1:<u>*   risks associated with anaesthesia
*   bleeding, which may require a blood transfusion
*   damage to the surrounding organs, such as your bladder or bowel
*   an infection – you may be given antibiotics to take during and after surgery to reduce the risk
*   changes to your sex life, such as discomfort during intercourse – but this should improve over time
*   vaginal discharge and bleeding
*   experiencing more prolapse symptoms, which may require further surgery
*   a blood clot (DVT) forming in 1 of your veins, such as in your leg – you may be given medicine to help reduce this risk after surgery</u>

【75】通用结尾删除-1:<u>If you have any of the following symptoms after your surgery, let your surgeon or a GP know as soon as possible:</u>

【76】通用结尾删除-1:<u>*   a high temperature
*   severe pain low in your tummy
*   heavy vaginal bleeding
*   a stinging or burning sensation when you pee
*   abnormal vaginal discharge – this may be an infection</u>

【77】通用结尾删除-1:<u>You should be offered a check-up 6 months after surgery that includes a vaginal examination.</u>

【78】通用结尾删除-1:<u>### More information to help you choose which type of prolapse surgery</u>

【79】通用结尾删除-1:<u>There are several useful guides that you can read to help you decide, together with your doctor, which type of surgery would be right for you:</u>

【80】通用结尾删除-1:<u>*   NICE guidance: management of urinary incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse in women – patient decision aids and user guides
*   NHS guide to surgical treatments for pelvic organ prolapse</u>

【81】通用结尾删除-1:<u>### Recovering from surgery</u>

【82】通用结尾删除-1:<u>You'll probably need to stay in hospital overnight or for a few days following prolapse surgery.</u>

【83】通用结尾删除-1:<u>You may have a drip in your arm to provide fluids, and a thin plastic tube (urinary catheter) to drain pee from your bladder.</u>

【84】通用结尾删除-1:<u>Some gauze may be placed inside your vagina to act as a bandage for the first 24 hours, which may be slightly uncomfortable.</u>

【85】通用结尾删除-1:<u>For the first few days or weeks after your operation, you may have some vaginal bleeding similar to a period, as well as some vaginal discharge.</u>

【86】通用结尾删除-1:<u>This may last 3 or 4 weeks. During this time, use sanitary towels rather than tampons.</u>

【87】通用结尾删除-1:<u>Your stitches will usually dissolve on their own after a few weeks.</u>

【88】通用结尾删除-1:<u>Try to move around as soon as possible, but with good rests every few hours.</u>

【89】通用结尾删除-1:<u>You should be able to have a shower and bathe as normal once you have left hospital, but you may need to avoid swimming for a few weeks.</u>

【90】通用结尾删除-1:<u>It's best to avoid having sex for around 4 to 6 weeks, until you have healed completely.</u>

【91】通用结尾删除-1:<u>Your healthcare team will advise about when you can return to work.
删除7：<u>Find out more about having and recovering from an operation</u>
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 24 March 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 24 March 2024</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Pelvic organ prolapse</u></u>

【0】Treatment \- Pelvic organ prolapse
==================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Treatment</u>

【2】**There are several treatment options available for pelvic organ prolapse.**

【3】The most suitable for you will depend on:

【4】*   the severity of your symptoms
*   the severity of the prolapse
*   your age and health
*   whether you're planning to have children in the future

【5】You may not need any treatment if the prolapse is mild to moderate and not causing any pain or discomfort.

【6】Treatment options include:

【7】*   lifestyle changes
*   pelvic floor exercises
*   hormone treatment
*   vaginal pessaries
*   surgery

【8】Your doctor should offer you the full range of treatments and explain the possible benefits and risks of each option. This will help you choose the right one for you.

【9】Lifestyle changes
-----------------

【10】If you do not have any symptoms or the prolapse is mild, making some lifestyle changes may help and could stop the prolapse getting worse.

【11】They can also help reduce your risk of getting a prolapse in the first place.

【12】They include:

【13】*   losing weight if you're overweight
*   eating a high-fibre diet to avoid constipation
*   avoiding lifting heavy objects

【14】Pelvic floor exercises
----------------------

【15】Doing pelvic floor exercises will strengthen your pelvic floor muscles and may well relieve your symptoms.

【16】A GP or specialist may recommend a programme of supervised pelvic floor muscle training for at least 16 weeks before you move on to other treatments or surgery.

【17】You'll be shown how to do the exercises. If they help, you may be asked to continue with them.
删除7：<u>Find out more about pelvic floor exercises</u>

【18】Hormone (oestrogen) treatment
-----------------------------

【19】If you have a mild prolapse and have been through the menopause, your doctor may recommend treatment with oestrogen to ease some of your symptoms, such as vaginal dryness or discomfort during sex.

【20】Oestrogen is available as:

【21】*   a cream you apply to your vagina
*   a tablet you insert into your vagina
*   an oestrogen-releasing vaginal ring

【22】Vaginal pessaries
-----------------

【23】A device made of rubber (latex) or silicone is inserted into the vagina and left in place to support the vaginal walls and pelvic organs.

【24】Vaginal pessaries allow you to get pregnant in the future. They can be used to ease the symptoms of moderate or severe prolapses and are a good option if you cannot or would prefer not to have surgery.

【25】Vaginal pessaries come in different shapes and sizes depending on your need. The most common is called a ring pessary.

【26】You may need to try a few different types and sizes to find the one that works best for you.

【27】A gynaecologist or a specialist nurse usually fits a pessary. It needs to be removed, cleaned and replaced regularly.

【28】### Side effects of vaginal pessaries

【29】Vaginal pessaries can occasionally cause:

【30】*   unpleasant smelling vaginal discharge, which could be a sign of a bacterial infection in the vagina (bacterial vaginosis)
*   some irritation and sores inside your vagina, and possibly bleeding
*   stress incontinence, where you pass a small amount of urine when you cough, sneeze or exercise
*   a urinary tract infection
*   interference with sex (but most women can have sex without any problems)

【31】These side effects can usually be treated.

【32】Surgery
-------

【33】If non-surgical options have not worked or the prolapse is more severe, surgery may be an option.

【34】There are several different surgical treatments for pelvic organ prolapse.

【35】They include:

【36】*   surgical repair
*   vaginal mesh surgery
*   hysterectomy
*   closing the vagina

【37】Your doctor will discuss the benefits and risks of different treatments, and you'll decide together which is best for you.

【38】### Surgical repair

【39】There are several different types of surgery that involve lifting and supporting the pelvic organs.

【40】This could be by stitching them into place or supporting the existing tissues to make them stronger.

【41】Surgical repairs are usually done by making cuts in the wall of the vagina under general anaesthetic.

【42】This means you'll be asleep during the operation and will not feel any pain.

【43】You may need 6 to 12 weeks off work to recover, depending on the type of surgery you have.

【44】If you'd like to have children in the future, your doctors may suggest delaying surgery because pregnancy can cause the prolapse to happen again.

【45】### Vaginal mesh surgery

【46】Information:

【47】At the moment, it's not possible to have vaginal mesh surgery for pelvic organ prolapse on the NHS unless there's no alternative and the procedure cannot be delayed, and after detailed discussion between you and a doctor.

【48】Vaginal mesh surgery is where a piece of synthetic mesh, a plastic product that looks like a net, is inserted to hold the pelvic organs in place.

【49】The mesh stays in your body permanently.

【50】You'll be asleep during the operation and you will usually need to stay in hospital for 1 to 3 days afterwards.

【51】A few women have had serious complications after mesh surgery. Some, but not all, of these complications can also happen after other types of surgery.

【52】The complications include:

【53】*   long-lasting pain
*   permanent nerve damage
*   incontinence
*   constipation
*   sexual problems
*   mesh exposure through vaginal tissues and occasionally injury to nearby organs, such as the bladder or bowel

【54】#### If you're concerned about vaginal mesh

【55】If you have previously had vaginal mesh inserted and think you're having complications, speak to a GP or your surgeon.

【56】If you're not having any complications, there's no need to do anything.

【57】Many women have had these types of surgery without developing any problems afterwards.

【58】You can report a problem with a medicine or medical device on GOV.UK
删除7：<u>Find out more about the rules for the use of vaginal mesh on GOV.UK</u>

【59】You can also read about the Mesh Working Group set up by NHS England to address safety concerns about the use of vaginal mesh

【60】### Hysterectomy

【61】For women with a prolapsed womb who have been through the menopause or do not wish to have any more children, a doctor may recommend surgery to remove the womb (hysterectomy).

【62】It can help to relieve pressure on the walls of the vagina and reduce the chance of a prolapse returning.

【63】You cannot get pregnant after having a hysterectomy, and sometimes it may cause you to go through the menopause early.

【64】You may need 6 to 12 weeks off work to recover.

<mark>【65】通用结尾删除-1:### Closing the vagina

【66】通用结尾删除-1:Occasionally, an operation that closes part or all of the vagina may be an option.

【67】通用结尾删除-1:This treatment is only offered to women who have advanced prolapse, when other treatments have not worked and they’re sure they do not want to have sex again in the future.

【68】通用结尾删除-1:This operation can be a good option for frail women who would not be able to have more complex surgery.

【69】通用结尾删除-1:### Side effects of surgery

【70】通用结尾删除-1:Your doctor should have an in-depth discussion with you about the risks and benefits of the 4 different types of surgery, including mesh surgery, before you decide together whether one of them could be an option.

【71】通用结尾删除-1:Doctors must also keep detailed records about the type of surgery they do, including any complications you get after you have had your surgery.

【72】通用结尾删除-1:You should be given a copy of this record.

【73】通用结尾删除-1:Possible side effects of all 4 types of surgery, including mesh surgery, include:

【74】通用结尾删除-1:*   risks associated with anaesthesia

bleeding, which may require a blood transfusion
damage to the surrounding organs, such as your bladder or bowel
an infection – you may be given antibiotics to take during and after surgery to reduce the risk
changes to your sex life, such as discomfort during intercourse – but this should improve over time
vaginal discharge and bleeding
experiencing more prolapse symptoms, which may require further surgery
a blood clot (DVT) forming in 1 of your veins, such as in your leg – you may be given medicine to help reduce this risk after surgery
【75】通用结尾删除-1:If you have any of the following symptoms after your surgery, let your surgeon or a GP know as soon as possible:

【76】通用结尾删除-1:*   a high temperature

severe pain low in your tummy
heavy vaginal bleeding
a stinging or burning sensation when you pee
abnormal vaginal discharge – this may be an infection
【77】通用结尾删除-1:You should be offered a check-up 6 months after surgery that includes a vaginal examination.</mark>y be an infection</u>

【77】通用结尾删除-1:<u>You should be offered a check-up 6 months after surgery that includes a vaginal examination.</u>

【78】通用结尾删除-1:<u>### More information to help you choose which type of prolapse surgery</u>

【79】通用结尾删除-1:<u>There are several useful guides that you can read to help you decide, together with your doctor, which type of surgery would be right for you:</u>

【80】通用结尾删除-1:<u>*   NICE guidance: management of urinary incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse in women – patient decision aids and user guides
*   NHS guide to surgical treatments for pelvic organ prolapse</u>

【81】通用结尾删除-1:<u>### Recovering from surgery</u>

【82】通用结尾删除-1:<u>You'll probably need to stay in hospital overnight or for a few days following prolapse surgery.</u>

【83】通用结尾删除-1:<u>You may have a drip in your arm to provide fluids, and a thin plastic tube (urinary catheter) to drain pee from your bladder.</u>

【84】通用结尾删除-1:<u>Some gauze may be placed inside your vagina to act as a bandage for the first 24 hours, which may be slightly uncomfortable.</u>

【85】通用结尾删除-1:<u>For the first few days or weeks after your operation, you may have some vaginal bleeding similar to a period, as well as some vaginal discharge.</u>

【86】通用结尾删除-1:<u>This may last 3 or 4 weeks. During this time, use sanitary towels rather than tampons.</u>

【87】通用结尾删除-1:<u>Your stitches will usually dissolve on their own after a few weeks.</u>

【88】通用结尾删除-1:<u>Try to move around as soon as possible, but with good rests every few hours.</u>

【89】通用结尾删除-1:<u>You should be able to have a shower and bathe as normal once you have left hospital, but you may need to avoid swimming for a few weeks.</u>

【90】通用结尾删除-1:<u>It's best to avoid having sex for around 4 to 6 weeks, until you have healed completely.</u>

【91】通用结尾删除-1:<u>Your healthcare team will advise about when you can return to work.
删除7：<u>Find out more about having and recovering from an operation</u>

删除1：<u>*   Previous : Pelvic organ prolapse</u></u>

source_info.title: Rabeprazole
source_info.text:
【0】Taking rabeprazole with other medicines and herbal supplements
==============================================================

【1】You can take rabeprazole with antacids like calcium carbonate (Tums), sodium bicarbonate, Maalox and Milk of Magnesia. They help to relieve indigestion and heartburn by reducing the damage that acid can do to your stomach. They give quick relief that lasts for a few hours. They're ideal for occasional bouts of stomach acid symptoms.

【2】Some antacids, such as Gaviscon, have an extra ingredient called alginic acid. They work by lining your stomach so that juices from it do not splash up into your food pipe. They're especially good for relieving acid reflux.

【3】Taking rabeprazole with painkillers
-----------------------------------

【4】It’s safe to take painkillers, such as paracetamol or ibuprofen, at the same time as rabeprazole.

【5】It’s best to take ibuprofen with, or just after, a meal so it does not upset your stomach.

【6】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【7】If you are taking rabeprazole, it can affect the way other medicines work. Other medicines may also affect the way rabeprazole works. It can make side effects more likely, or stop one of the medicines working as well. Tell your doctor if you're taking any of these medicines before you start taking rabeprazole:

【8】*   antifungal medicines such as itraconazole, ketoconazole, posaconazole and voriconazole
*   clopidogrel and warfarin, medicines to prevent or treat blood clots
*   methotrexate, a medicine that treats psoriasis and rheumatoid arthritis
*   HIV medicines
*   rifampicin, an antibiotic

【9】These are not all the medicines that may not mix well with rabeprazole. For a full list see the leaflet inside your medicines packet.

【10】**Mixing rabeprazole with herbal remedies and supplements**
-----------------------------------------------------------

【11】Do not take St John's wort, the herbal remedy for depression, while you're taking rabeprazole. It may stop rabeprazole working as well as it should.

【12】There's not enough information to say that other complementary medicines and herbal remedies are safe to take with rabeprazole. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【13】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【14】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.
删除11：<u>More in Rabeprazole
-------------------

【15】*   About rabeprazole
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking rabeprazole with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 19 January 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 19 January 2025</u>

source_info.title: Hydrocephalus
source_info.text:
【0】Complications \- Hydrocephalus
==============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications</u>

【2】**The surgery used to treat hydrocephalus (excess fluid in the brain) can cause complications.**

【3】Shunt problems
--------------

【4】A shunt is a delicate piece of equipment that can malfunction, usually by becoming blocked or infected.

【5】Sometimes, a scan after the operation shows the shunt is not in the best position and further surgery is needed to reposition it.

【6】If a baby or child has a shunt fitted, the shunt may become too small as the child grows, and it will need to be replaced. As most people need a shunt for the rest of their life, more than one replacement may be needed.

【7】There can occasionally be bleeding when a shunt is positioned. This can cause nerve problems, such as weakness down one side. There's also a small risk of fits after any type of brain surgery.

【8】In younger children, particularly babies, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) can run alongside the shunt rather than down it, and the fluid can leak through the skin wound. Additional stitches will be needed to stop the leak.

【9】### Shunt blockage

【10】A shunt blockage can be very serious as it can lead to a build-up of excess fluid in the brain, which can cause brain damage. This will cause the symptoms of hydrocephalus.

【11】Emergency surgery will be needed to replace the malfunctioning shunt.

【12】### Shunt infection

【13】Shunt infection is also a relatively common complication after shunt surgery. Infections are more likely to develop during the first few months after surgery.

【14】The symptoms of a shunt infection may include:

【15】*   redness and tenderness along the line of the shunt
*   a high temperature
*   headache
*   vomiting
*   neck stiffness
*   tummy pain if the shunt drains into your tummy
*   irritability or sleepiness in babies

【16】Contact your care team immediately if you or your child has these symptoms. 

【17】Antibiotics may be needed to treat the infection and, in some cases, surgery may be required to replace the shunt.

【18】### Shunt alert cards

【19】The hydrocephalus and spina bifida charity Shine has produced a series of shunt alert cards for adults and children. You carry the card with you if you've had a shunt fitted.

【20】The card is useful in a medical emergency if you have symptoms of a blockage or infection.

【21】The healthcare professionals treating you will be aware that you have a shunt fitted and will check whether this is causing your symptoms.

【22】To apply for a shunt alert card, you can fill out a form on the Shine website or call 01733 555 988.

【23】Complications of endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV)
-------------------------------------------------------

【24】An endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV) is surgery to create a small hole in the floor of the brain to drain the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

【25】Possible complications after ETV surgery include:

【26】*   the hole can close
*   your brain may not be able to absorb the CSF that's now draining through it
*   you may develop an infection – although this is less likely than after shunt surgery
*   you may have bleeding inside your brain – this is usually minor

【27】If there's a problem with the hole, it may be possible to repeat the procedure, or you may need to have a shunt fitted.

【28】Other risks of ETV include nerve problems, such as weakness down 1 side of the body, double vision or hormone imbalances. Most nerve problems will get better, but there's a small risk of permanent problems.

【29】There's also a small risk of epilepsy, and a very small risk of an injury to a blood vessel in the brain, which may be fatal.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 06 February 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 06 February 2026</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Treatment</u>

text.text: 【22】To apply for a shunt alert card, you can fill out a form on the Shine website or call 01733 555 988.

6.  Complications</u>

source_info.title: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
source_info.text:
【0】Treatment \- Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
=========================================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Living with</u>

【2】**There's currently no cure for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), but treatment can help slow the progression of the condition and control the symptoms.**

【3】Treatments include:

【4】*   stopping smoking – if you have COPD and you smoke, this is the most important thing you can do
*   inhalers and tablets – to help make breathing easier
*   pulmonary rehabilitation – a specialised programme of exercise and education
*   surgery or a lung transplant – although this is only an option for a very small number of people

【5】A doctor will discuss the various treatment options with you.

【6】Stop smoking
------------

【7】If you smoke, stopping is the most effective way to prevent COPD getting worse.

【8】Although any damage done to your lungs and airways cannot be reversed, giving up smoking can help prevent further damage.

【9】This may be all the treatment that's needed in the early stages of COPD, but it's never too late to stop – even people with more advanced COPD will benefit from quitting.

【10】If you think you need help to stop smoking, visit Quit smoking for free advice and support.

【11】You may also want to talk to a GP about the stop smoking treatments available to you.
删除7：<u>Find out more about stop smoking support or find a stop smoking service near you.</u>

【12】Inhalers
--------

【13】If COPD is affecting your breathing, you'll usually be given an inhaler. This is a device that delivers medicine directly into your lungs as you breathe in.

【14】A doctor or nurse will advise you on how to use an inhaler correctly and how often to use it.

【15】There are several different types of inhaler for COPD. The main types include:

【16】### Short-acting bronchodilator inhalers

【17】For most people with COPD, short-acting bronchodilator inhalers are the first treatment used.

【18】Bronchodilators are medicines that make breathing easier by relaxing and widening your airways.

【19】There are 2 types of short-acting bronchodilator inhaler:

【20】*   beta-2 agonist inhalers – such as salbutamol and terbutaline
*   antimuscarinic inhalers – such as ipratropium

【21】Short-acting inhalers should be used when you feel breathless, up to a maximum of 4 times a day.

【22】### Long-acting bronchodilator inhalers

【23】If you experience symptoms regularly or have flare-ups (exacerbations) despite using short-acting bronchodilators, a long-acting bronchodilator inhaler may be recommended.

【24】These work in a similar way to short-acting bronchodilators, but each dose lasts for at least 12 hours, so they only need to be used once or twice a day.

【25】There are 2 types of long-acting bronchodilator inhaler:

【26】*   beta-2 agonist inhalers – such as salmeterol, formoterol and indacaterol
*   antimuscarinic inhalers – such as tiotropium, glycopyronium and aclidinium

【27】Some new inhalers contain a combination of a long-acting beta-2 agonist and antimuscarinic.

【28】### Steroid inhalers

【29】If you're still becoming breathless when using a long-acting inhaler, or you have frequent flare-ups (exacerbations), a GP may suggest including a steroid inhaler as part of your treatment.

【30】Steroid inhalers contain corticosteroid medicines, which can help to reduce the inflammation in your airways.

【31】Steroid inhalers are normally prescribed as part of a combination inhaler that also includes a long-acting medicine.

【32】Tablets
-------

【33】If your symptoms are not controlled with inhalers, a doctor may recommend taking tablets or capsules as well.

【34】### Theophylline tablets

【35】Theophylline is a type of bronchodilator. It's unclear exactly how theophylline works, but it seems to reduce swelling (inflammation) in the airways and relax the muscles lining them.

【36】Theophylline comes as tablets or capsules and is usually taken twice a day.

【37】You may need to have regular blood tests during treatment to check the level of medicine in your blood.

【38】This will help a doctor work out the best dose to control your symptoms while reducing the risk of side effects.

【39】Possible side effects include:

【40】*   feeling and being sick
*   headaches
*   difficulty sleeping (insomnia)
*   noticeable pounding, fluttering or irregular heartbeats (palpitations)

【41】Sometimes a similar medicine called aminophylline is also used.

【42】### Mucolytics

【43】If you have a persistent chesty cough with lots of thick phlegm, the doctor may recommend taking a mucolytic medicine called carbocisteine.

【44】Mucolytic medicines make the phlegm in your throat thinner and easier to cough up.

【45】Carbocisteine comes as tablets or capsules and is usually taken 3 or 4 times a day.

【46】If carbocisteine does not help your symptoms, or you cannot take it for medical reasons, another mucolytic medicine called acetylcysteine is available.

【47】This comes as a powder that you mix with water. Acetylcysteine powder has an unpleasant smell, like rotten eggs, but this smell should go away once you mix it with the water.

【48】### Steroid tablets

【49】If you have a particularly bad flare-up, you may be prescribed a short course of steroid tablets to reduce the inflammation in your airways.

【50】A 5-day course of treatment is usually recommended, as long-term use of steroid tablets can cause troublesome side effects such as:

【51】*   weight gain
*   mood swings
*   weakened bones (osteoporosis)

【52】Your doctor may give you a supply of steroid tablets to keep at home to take as soon as you experience a bad flare-up.

【53】Longer courses of steroid tablets must be prescribed by a COPD specialist. You'll be given the lowest effective dose and monitored closely for side effects.

【54】### Antibiotics

【55】Your doctor may prescribe a short course of antibiotics if you have signs of a chest infection, such as:

【56】*   becoming more breathless
*   coughing more
*   noticing a change in the colour (such as becoming brown, green or yellow) and/or consistency of your phlegm (such as becoming thicker)

【57】Sometimes you may be given a course of antibiotics to keep at home and take as soon as you experience symptoms of an infection.

【58】Pulmonary rehabilitation
------------------------

【59】Pulmonary rehabilitation is a specialised programme of exercise and education designed to help people with lung problems such as COPD.

【60】It can help improve how much exercise you're able to do before you feel out of breath, as well as your symptoms, self-confidence and emotional wellbeing.

【61】Pulmonary rehabilitation programmes usually involve 2 or more group sessions a week for at least 6 weeks.

【62】A typical programme includes:

【63】*   physical exercise training tailored to your needs and ability – such as walking, cycling and strength exercises
*   education about your condition for you and your family
*   dietary advice
*   psychological and emotional support

【64】The programmes are provided by a number of different healthcare professionals, including physiotherapists, nurse specialists and dietitians删除7：<u>

【65】The British Lung Foundation has more information about pulmonary rehabilitation.</u>

【66】Improving muscle strength
-------------------------

【67】If you are having a bad flare-up and are unable to exercise, you may be offered electrical stimulation to make your muscles stronger.

【68】This is where electrodes are placed on your skin and small electrical impulses are sent to weak muscles, usually in your arms or legs.
删除3：<u>### Video: Pulmonary rehabilitation

【69】This video explores pulmonary rehabilitation and how exercise can improve the symptoms of COPD.
删除1：<u>Media last reviewed: 1 February 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Media review due: 1 February 2024</u>

【70】</u>
Other treatments
----------------

【71】If you have severe symptoms or experience a particularly bad flare-up, you may sometimes need additional treatment.

【72】### Nebulised medicine

【73】Nebulised medicine may be used in severe cases of COPD if inhalers have not worked.

【74】This is where a machine is used to turn liquid medicine into a fine mist that you breathe in through a mouthpiece or a face mask. It enables a large dose of medicine to be taken in one go.

【75】You'll usually be given a nebuliser device to use at home after being shown how to use it.

【76】### Roflumilast

【77】Roflumilast is a new medicine that can be used to treat flare-ups.

【78】It is recommended for people whose symptoms have suddenly become worse at least 2 times over the past 12 months, and who are already using inhalers.

【79】Roflumilast comes as tablets and the medicine helps reduce inflammation inside the lungs and airways.

【80】Side effects of roflumilast include:

【81】*   feeling and being sick
*   diarrhoea
*   reduced appetite
*   weight loss
*   headache

【82】### Long-term oxygen therapy

【83】If COPD causes a low level of oxygen in your blood, you may be advised to have oxygen at home through nasal tubes or a mask.

【84】This can help stop the level of oxygen in your blood becoming dangerously low, although it's not a treatment for the main symptoms of COPD, such as breathlessness.

【85】Long-term oxygen treatment should be used for at least 15 hours a day.

【86】The tubes from the machine are long, so you will be able to move around your home while you're connected. Portable oxygen tanks are available if you need to use oxygen away from home.

【87】Do not smoke when using oxygen. The increased level of oxygen is highly flammable and a lit cigarette could cause a fire or explosion.
删除7：<u>Find out more about home oxygen therapy.</u>

【88】### Ambulatory oxygen therapy

【89】Some people with COPD will benefit from ambulatory oxygen, which is oxygen you use when you walk or are active in other ways.

【90】If your blood oxygen levels are normal while you're resting but fall when you exercise, you may be able to have ambulatory oxygen therapy rather than long-term oxygen therapy.

【91】### Non-invasive ventilation (NIV)

【92】If you're taken to hospital because of a bad flare-up, you may have a treatment called non-invasive ventilation (NIV).

【93】This is where a portable machine connected to a mask that covers your nose or face is used to support your lungs and make breathing easier.

【94】Surgery
-------

【95】Surgery is usually only suitable for a small number of people with severe COPD whose symptoms are not controlled with medicine.

【96】There are 3 main operations that can be done:

【97】*   bullectomy – an operation to remove a pocket of air from one of the lungs, allowing the lungs to work better and make breathing more comfortable
*   lung volume reduction surgery – an operation to remove a badly damaged section of lung to allow the healthier parts to work better and make breathing more comfortable
*   lung transplant – an operation to remove and replace a damaged lung with a healthy lung from a donor

【98】These are major operations done under general anaesthetic, where you're asleep, and involve significant risks.

【99】If your doctors feel surgery is an option for you, speak to them about what the procedure involves and what the benefits and risks are.

source_info.title: Blood poisoning, see Sepsis
source_info.text:
【0】Blood poisoning, see Sepsis
Treatment and recovery \- Sepsis
================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Symptoms
2.  Who can get it
3.  Treatment and recovery</u>

【2】Treatment for sepsis
--------------------

【3】Sepsis needs treatment in hospital straight away because it can get worse quickly.

【4】You should get antibiotics within 1 hour of arriving at hospital.

【5】If sepsis is not treated early, it can turn into septic shock and cause your organs to fail. This is life threatening.

【6】You may need other tests or treatments depending on your symptoms, including:

【7】*   treatment in an intensive care unit
*   a machine to help you breathe (ventilator)
*   surgery to remove areas of infection

【8】You may need to stay in hospital for several weeks.

【9】Recovering from sepsis
----------------------

【10】Most people make a full recovery from sepsis. But it can take time.

【11】You might continue to have physical and emotional symptoms. These can last for months, or even years, after you had sepsis.

【12】These long-term effects are sometimes called post-sepsis syndrome, and can include:

【13】*   feeling very tired and weak, and difficulty sleeping
*   lack of appetite
*   getting ill more often
*   changes in your mood, or anxiety or depression
*   nightmares or flashbacks
*   post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)

【14】### Treatment for post-sepsis syndrome

【15】Most symptoms of post-sepsis syndrome should get better on their own. But it can take time.

【16】There are things you can do to help with some long-term effects.

【17】#### Do

【18】*   ask your work about changes to your working hours or conditions while you're recovering

【19】*   do some gentle, easy exercises to build your strength

【20】*   get regular sleep

【21】*   try to prevent infections – for example, by washing your hands regularly

【22】*   try to eat little and often if you have a small appetite

【23】#### Don’t

【24】*   do not try to rush your recovery – give yourself time

【25】### Non-urgent advice: See a GP about:

【26】*   treatment for physical side effects
*   treatment and support for emotional symptoms
删除6：<u>Information:

【27】### Find out more:

【28】*   UK Sepsis Trust: support for sepsis survivors
*   UK Sepsis Trust: post-sepsis syndrome
*   UK Sepsis Trust: going back to work after sepsis
*   UK Sepsis Trust: support for relatives and friends

source_info.title: Air or gas embolism
source_info.text:
【0】Air or gas embolism
===================

【1】**An air or gas embolism is a bubble that becomes trapped in a blood vessel and blocks it.**

【2】Air or gas embolism in scuba divers
-----------------------------------

【3】It can happen if a scuba diver:

【4】*   spends too long underwater
*   surfaces too quickly
*   holds their breath as they come up

【5】Air can escape from the lungs into the blood vessels (arterial gas embolism) or nitrogen bubbles can form in the blood vessels (decompression sickness or "the bends").

【6】Air or gas embolisms can cause serious and potentially fatal conditions, such as a stroke or heart attack.

【7】**Call 999 and ask for an ambulance if you or someone you're with feels unwell after scuba diving and you suspect an air or gas embolism.**

【8】### Symptoms of an air or gas embolism after diving

【9】Symptoms of an air or gas embolism after diving include:

【10】*   joint or muscle pain
*   low blood pressure, which may cause dizziness
*   an irregular heartbeat
*   breathlessness and fast breathing
*   blurred vision
*   chest pain
*   strong feelings of anxiety
*   itchy skin
*   a blue tinge to the skin, lips or tongue (cyanosis)
*   bloody froth from the mouth
*   paralysis or weakness, possibly of one or more limbs
*   seizures or fits
*   loss of consciousness

【11】You may not have these symptoms immediately. They can develop within 10 to 20 minutes or sometimes even longer after surfacing. Do not ignore these symptoms – get medical help immediately.

【12】### Getting medical help

【13】**Call 999 and ask for an ambulance if you or someone you're with feels unwell after scuba diving.**

【14】A diver with a suspected air or gas embolism should be transferred to an A&E department as soon as possible.

【15】They should be laid down flat and given 100% oxygen until they reach hospital. Once stabilised, they'll be taken to a pressurised room called a hyperbaric chamber, either at the hospital or at another location.

【16】### Why diving can lead to an air or gas embolism

【17】If a diver surfaces too quickly, nitrogen bubbles can form in their tissues and bloodstream. This is often referred to as decompression sickness or "the bends".

【18】Surfacing too quickly or holding your breath while you swim to the surface can cause the air in your lungs to expand. This may rupture lung tissue (pulmonary barotrauma), which can lead to gas bubbles being released into the arterial circulation (arterial gas embolism).

【19】In some divers, underlying conditions can increase the chance of decompression sickness. These should be discussed with a doctor who specialises in diving medicine.

【20】If the gas bubble blocks an artery, it can cut off the blood supply to a particular area of the body.

【21】The seriousness of the blockage depends on which part of the body is affected, the size of the gas bubble and the amount of inert gases (unreactive gases) within the diver's tissues.

【22】An air or gas embolism can cause different problems depending on where the blockage is:

【23】*   arteries leading to the brain – immediate loss of consciousness and may lead to seizures or fits, or a stroke
*   arteries leading to the heart – a heart attack or an abnormal heartbeat (arrhythmia)
*   a blood vessel to the lungs – a pulmonary embolism

【24】These conditions are very serious and can be fatal, particularly if the air embolism is not treated quickly.

【25】### Treating an air or gas embolism caused by diving

【26】After a diver with an air or gas embolism has received emergency medical attention and their condition has stabilised, they'll be transferred to a hyperbaric chamber.

【27】A person being treated in a hyperbaric chamber
删除9：<u>Credit:

【28】GABRIELLE VOINOT/LOOK AT SCIENCES/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/415472/view</u>

【29】They'll need to lie in the hyperbaric chamber for several hours, breathing a mixture of gases and oxygen in a pressurised environment. The high pressure restores normal blood flow and oxygen to the body's tissues, and reduces the size of the air bubbles in the body.

【30】In cases of decompression sickness, the pressure forces the bubbles of nitrogen to dissolve into the bloodstream.

【31】The pressure in the chamber is then gradually reduced to allow the gases to leave the body, mimicking slowly surfacing from a dive.

【32】Depending on the severity of symptoms, treatment may need to be continued for several days删除7：<u>

【33】### Preventing an air or gas embolism while diving

【34】To reduce your risk of getting an air or gas embolism when diving you should:

【35】*   limit the depth and duration of your dives
*   always surface slowly and perform safety stops to allow any air in your tissues and blood vessels to escape safely; use a dive computer or dive tables to maintain a safe rate of ascent, and do not dive again until you've spent a suitable amount of time at the surface
*   relax and breathe normally as you ascend
*   do not dive with a cold, cough or chest infection
*   avoid vigorous exercise before, during and after a dive
*   make sure you're well hydrated before diving
*   leave adequate surface intervals between dives (if planning several dives) to allow the nitrogen to leave your body
*   wait 24 hours after diving before flying or going to a higher altitude

【36】The British Sub-Aqua Club (BSAC) has more information about diving safety</u>

【37】Other causes of air or gas embolisms
------------------------------------

【38】Although uncommon, it's possible to get an air or gas embolism during surgery, some medical procedures, and when ascending to a high altitude.

【39】In hospitals and health centres, care should be taken to prevent air embolisms by:

【40】*   removing air from syringes before injections and from intravenous lines before connecting them
*   using techniques when inserting and removing catheters and other tubes that minimise the risk of air getting into blood vessels
*   closely monitoring patients during surgery to help ensure air bubbles do not form in their blood vessels

【41】Air embolisms caused by surgery, anaesthesia or other medical procedures can be difficult to treat. Treatment is usually needed to support the heart, blood vessels and lungs.

【42】For example, fluids may be used to treat a fall in blood pressure, and oxygen may be given to correct reduced oxygen levels. Treatment in a hyperbaric chamber is occasionally needed in these cases.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 16 December 2020  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 16 December 2023</u>

【35】*   limit the depth and duration of your dives
