source_info.title: Paget's disease of the nipple
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Paget's disease of the nipple
=========================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Diagnosis
3.  Treatment
4.  Reducing the risk</u>

【2】**Paget's disease of the nipple, also known as Paget's disease of the breast, is a rare condition associated with breast cancer**.

【3】It causes eczema-like changes to the skin of the nipple and the area of darker skin surrounding the nipple (areola). It's usually a sign of breast cancer in the tissue behind the nipple.

【4】About 1 to 4% of women with breast cancer have Paget's disease of the nipple. It can also affect men, but this is extremely rare.

【5】The term Paget's disease of the nipple is used to distinguish the condition from Paget's disease of the bone (where bones become weak and deformed).

【6】Symptoms of Paget's disease of the nipple
-----------------------------------------

【7】Paget's disease of the nipple always starts in the nipple and may extend to the areola. It appears as a red, scaly rash on the skin of the nipple and areola.

【8】The affected skin is often sore and inflamed, and it can be itchy or cause a burning sensation. The nipple can sometimes be ulcerated.
删除9：<u>Credit:

【9】CID, ISM /SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/459439/view</u>

【10】The rash is often similar in appearance to other skin conditions, such as eczema or psoriasis. If you scratch it, or if it's left untreated, it can bleed, become ulcerated or scab over.

【11】If you're experiencing itchiness, burning or bleeding but the nipple looks normal and is not red or scaly, it's unlikely to be Paget's disease of the nipple. However, you should still have it checked by a doctor.

【12】Around half of all women diagnosed with Paget's disease of the nipple have a lump behind the nipple. In 9 out of 10 cases this is an invasive breast cancer.

【13】Invasive cancer is where cancerous cells invade the surrounding breast tissue. Some women with Paget's disease have invasive breast cancer but do not have a lump.

【14】However, most women with Paget's disease who do not have a lump have non-invasive cancer.

【15】This is where the cancerous cells are contained in 1 or more areas of the breast and have not spread.

【16】Causes of Paget's disease of the nipple
---------------------------------------

【17】The cause of Paget's disease of the nipple is unknown. Some women appear to be more at risk of developing breast cancer, but not specifically Paget's disease. There are no known causes that lead to a specific type of breast cancer.

【18】In terms of risk factors, you're more likely to develop breast cancer if you:

【19】*   are older – the risk of developing breast cancer increases with age
*   have close relatives with breast cancer
*   have had breast cancer before
*   have had a type of benign (non-cancerous) breast disease before – certain types of benign breast disease may be associated with an increased risk of breast cancer, but this is only seen in a very small number of women
*   are overweight or living with obesity, particularly if you've been through the menopause (you can use the BMI calculator to check if you're a healthy weight)
*   drink a lot of alcohol – your risk can increase with the amount of alcohol you drink
删除7：<u>Read more about the risk factors for breast cancer.</u>

【20】Diagnosing Paget's disease of the nipple
----------------------------------------

【21】You should see your GP if you notice any changes in the skin of your nipple or areola.

【22】As Paget's disease of the nipple is associated with breast cancer, the sooner it's diagnosed, the better the outcome is likely to be.

【23】Also see your GP if you develop a lump in your breast. Although most breast lumps are not cancerous, it's important to have them checked out.

【24】A biopsy is used to confirm a suspected diagnosis of Paget's disease of the nipple. A small tissue sample (punch biopsy of the skin) will be taken from your nipple and examined under a microscope to see if it's cancerous.

【25】If the results of the biopsy indicate Paget's disease, you'll have a mammogram (a low-dose breast X-ray) to investigate further.
删除7：<u>Read more about diagnosing Paget's disease of the nipple.</u>

【26】Treating Paget's disease of the nipple
--------------------------------------

【27】Surgery is the main treatment for Paget's disease of the nipple. Depending on whether the cancer has spread, surgery will either involve removing the whole breast (a mastectomy), or the nipple and areola with the breast tissue underneath them (a central excision).

【28】If the whole of your breast is removed, breast reconstruction surgery can be used to create a breast shape to match your remaining breast.

【29】You may also need further treatment if you have invasive breast cancer. This may be a combination of:

【30】*   chemotherapy – where powerful medicine is used to destroy cancerous cells
*   radiotherapy – where controlled doses of high-energy radiation are used to destroy cancerous cells
*   targeted or hormone therapy – which lowers the risk of cancer returning in the same breast (and affecting the other breast), and it lowers the risk of cancerous cells spreading elsewhere in the body

【31】If Paget's disease is detected and treated in its early stages, there's a good chance of a full recovery.
删除7：<u>Read more about treating Paget's disease of the nipple.</u>

【32】Reducing the risk of breast cancer, including Paget's disease of the nipple
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

【33】Modifying certain lifestyle factors, such as reducing the amount of alcohol you drink and making sure you exercise regularly, may reduce your risk of developing certain types of cancer, including breast cancer.

【34】Breast cancer screening is also used to help detect breast cancer early. In the UK, the NHS Breast Screening Programme provides free breast screening every 3 years for all women aged 50 to 70.

【35】In some areas, women aged 47 to 49 and 71 to 73 are also invited for screening as part of a study looking at whether the age range for breast screening should be extended.
删除7：<u>Read more about reducing the risks of breast cancer.</u>
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 06 April 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 06 April 2026</u>
删除1：<u>*   Next : Diagnosis</u>

source_info.title: Pravastatin
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take pravastatin
===================================

【1】Who can take pravastatin
------------------------

【2】Most adults and children over the age of 8 years can take pravastatin.

【3】Who may not be able to take pravastatin
---------------------------------------

【4】Pravastatin is not suitable for some people. Tell your doctor if you:

【5】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to pravastatin or any other medicines
*   have liver or kidney problems
*   are trying to get pregnant, are pregnant, or you're breastfeeding
*   have lung disease
*   regularly drink large amounts of alcohol
*   have an underactive thyroid
*   have had a muscle disorder (including fibromyalgia)
*   you have a history of myasthenia gravis or ocular myasthenia
删除11：<u>More in Pravastatin
-------------------

【6】*   About pravastatin
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking pravastatin with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 4 February 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 4 February 2025</u>

source_info.title: Neuromyelitis optica
source_info.text:
【0】Neuromyelitis optica
====================

【1】Neuromyelitis optica (NMO), also known as Devic's disease, is a rare condition where the immune system damages the spinal cord and the nerves of the eyes (optic nerves).

【2】NMO can affect anyone at any age, but it's more common in women than men.

【3】Symptoms of NMO
---------------

【4】Each person will experience different symptoms, which can range from mild to severe.

【5】These symptoms may include:

【6】*   eye pain
*   loss of vision
*   colours appearing faded or less vivid
*   weakness in the arms and legs
*   pain in the arms or legs – described as sharp, burning, shooting or numbing
*   increased sensitivity to cold and heat
*   tight and painful muscle spasms in the arms and legs
*   vomiting
*   bladder, bowel and sexual problems  

【7】In many people with NMO, the spinal cord becomes swollen and irritated (inflamed). This is called transverse myelitis.

【8】The optic nerve from the eye to the brain can also become inflamed – a condition called optic neuritis.

【9】Some people may only experience transverse myelitis or optic neuritis but, if they have a specific antibody associated with NMO (AQP4) in their blood, they will be said to have NMO spectrum disorder (NMOSD).

【10】NMO-UK ha more information about the symptoms of NMO

【11】### **NMO relapses**

【12】NMO can be one-off or relapsing. Some people may only have one attack of optic neuritis or transverse myelitis, with good recovery and no further relapses for a long time.

【13】But if NMO is very severe, more attacks can follow. A relapse can take from several hours up to days to develop. The attacks can be unpredictable and it's not fully understood what triggers them删除7：<u>

【14】NMO-UK has more information about NMO relapses</u>

【15】When to get medical help
------------------------

【16】See a GP if you have any of the symptoms of NMO.

【17】The GP will refer you to a neurologist (a specialist in conditions that affect the nerves) for further testing to confirm the diagnosis and rule out any other conditions with similar symptoms, such as multiple sclerosis.

【18】You'll have an MRI scan of your brain and spinal cord, and blood tests. You may also have a lumbar puncture, where a sample of the fluid surrounding your spine is removed using a thin needle and tested.

【19】NMO-UK ha more information about how NMO is diagnosed

【20】Treatments for NMO
------------------

【21】There's no cure for NMO, but treatments can help to ease symptoms, prevent future relapses and slows down the condition's progression.

【22】You may be prescribed:

【23】*   steroids to reduce the inflammation
*   medicine to suppress your immune system and ease your symptoms, such as azathioprine, mycophenolate or methotrexate
*   rituximab, a newer type of medicine to reduce inflammation

【24】Rehabilitation techniques, such as physiotherapy, can also help if you have problems with your mobility.

【25】Therapies and support groups are available删除7：<u>

【26】### Find out more

【27】Find out more about social care and support

【28】NMO-UK also has more information about treatments for NMO</u>

【29】Causes
------

【30】NMO is an autoimmune condition. This means the body's immune system reacts abnormally and attacks healthy tissues, causing the symptoms of NMO.

【31】NMO is usually not inherited, but some people with NMO may have a history of autoimmune disorders in the family and may have another autoimmune condition themselves.

【32】Driving
-------

【33】Optic neuritis may affect your ability to drive. You have a legal obligation to tell the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) about any medical condition that could affect your driving.
删除8：<u>See GOV.UK for more information about driving with a disability or health condition</u>

【34】Support
-------

【35】NMO can have a significant impact, but support is available to help you have the best possible quality of life.

【36】It might help to speak to others who have the same condition or to connect with a charity.

【37】You may find the following links useful:

【38】*   The Brain & Spine Foundation
*   The Brain Charity
*   Transverse Myelitis Society
*   The Walton Centre and John Radcliffe Hospital – national centres carrying out research into NMO in the UK

【39】National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service
-----------------------------------------------------------------

【40】If you have NMO, your clinical team can pass information about you on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

【41】The NCARDRS helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat NMO. You can opt out of the register at any time.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 16 December 2020  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 16 December 2023</u>

source_info.title: Paracetamol for children (Calpol)
source_info.text:
【0】Taking paracetamol for children with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand names: Calpol, Disprol, Hedex, Medinol, Panadol
====================================================================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】In general, paracetamol does not affect prescription medicines, including antibiotics.

【3】But check with your child's doctor or a pharmacist before giving your child paracetamol if they're taking:

【4】*   medicine to treat epilepsy
*   medicine to treat tuberculosis (TB)
*   warfarin (a medicine to prevent blood clots)

【5】Giving paracetamol with other painkillers
-----------------------------------------

【6】Ibuprofen is the only safe painkiller to give children alongside paracetamol. However, do not give paracetamol and ibuprofen at the same time.

【7】You need to give these medicines 1 at a time (unless your child's doctor or nurse gives you different instructions).

【8】#### Important

【9】Do not give your child more than the maximum daily dose of paracetamol or ibuprofen.

【10】### For high temperature

【11】If you've given your child paracetamol and they still have a high temperature after 1 hour, you could try giving them ibuprofen.

【12】If this helps bring down their temperature, carry on giving them ibuprofen instead of paracetamol. Follow the instructions that come with the medicine.

【13】Do not alternate between paracetamol and ibuprofen to treat a high temperature without advice from a doctor or nurse.

【14】See your doctor if you've tried both paracetamol and ibuprofen and they have not helped.

【15】### For pain (including teething)

【16】If you've given your child paracetamol and they're still in pain after 1 hour, you could try giving ibuprofen.

【17】If they are still in some pain after giving ibuprofen you can alternate between doses of paracetamol and ibuprofen. Only give 1 medicine at a time.

【18】It may help to keep a diary of the time and dose of each medicine you give. Follow the instructions on the leaflet that comes with each medicine.

【19】If you've tried alternating between paracetamol and ibuprofen and it has not helped, or your child becomes distressed, speak to your doctor about what may be causing their pain.

【20】Information:

【21】Do not give ibuprofen to your child if:

【22】*   they have chickenpox – it can increase the risk of getting a serious skin infection
*   they have asthma (unless your doctor has said it's OK) – if your child has an allergic reaction, it could make their asthma worse

【23】#### Important

【24】Never give aspirin to a child under the age of 16, unless their doctor prescribes it.

【25】Other medicines containing paracetamol
--------------------------------------

【26】Do not give your child more than 1 paracetamol medicine at a time. If they take 2 different medicines that contain paracetamol, there's a risk of overdose.

【27】Lots of medicines you can buy from pharmacies or supermarkets contain paracetamol. These include some cough and cold medicines, so check the ingredients carefully.

【28】Mixing paracetamol for children with herbal remedies and supplements
--------------------------------------------------------------------

【29】There's not enough information to say whether complementary medicines, herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with paracetamol for children. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【30】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【31】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.
删除11：<u>More in Paracetamol for children (Calpol)
-----------------------------------------

【32】*   About paracetamol for children
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to give it
*   Side effects
*   Taking paracetamol for children with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 15 June 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 15 June 2025</u>

source_info.title: Glyceryl trinitrate (GTN)
source_info.text:
【0】Taking glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand names: Rectogesic, Minitran, Glytrin
==========================================================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】There are some medicines that may affect how glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) works.

【3】If you take other medicines that lower blood pressure with GTN, it can sometimes lower your blood pressure too much. This might make you feel dizzy or faint.

【4】Tell your doctor if this happens to you. They may need to change your dose.

【5】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking:

【6】*   medicines for erection problems such as alprostadil, avanafil, sildenafil (Viagra), tadalafil (Cialis) or vardenafil
*   anticoagulant medicine to prevent blood clots such as heparin
*   medicines for depression or other mental health conditions
*   medicines for high blood pressure or heart problems
*   medicines for migraine that contain ergot alkaloids or ergotamine
*   medicines for Parkinson's disease such as apomorphine

【7】If you take GTN tablets, tell a doctor or pharmacist if you take any medicines that make your mouth dry (including some antidepressants, cold medicines or medicines for urinary incontinence). This is because a dry mouth can reduce how well GTN tablets work, so GTN spray may be better for you.

【8】Taking GTN with painkillers
---------------------------

【9】Paracetamol is safe to take with GTN.

【10】Do not take non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) regularly, such as ibuprofen, aspirin or naproxen. These may make your angina worse.

【11】Talk to your pharmacist if you need a painkiller stronger than paracetamol.

【12】Mixing glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) with herbal remedies and supplements
---------------------------------------------------------------------

【13】There's not enough information to say that complementary medicines and herbal remedies are safe to take with GTN. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【14】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【15】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.
删除11：<u>More in Glyceryl trinitrate (GTN)
---------------------------------

【16】*   About GTN
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 12 April 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 12 April 2026</u>

source_info.title: Flat feet
source_info.text:
【0】Flat feet
=========

【1】**Flat feet, or "fallen arches", are where your feet press flat on the ground. They're common and usually nothing to worry about.**

【2】Check if you have flat feet
---------------------------

【3】To see if you have flat feet, check the inner sides of your feet while you're standing up.

【4】If you have flat feet, your feet will be flat on the ground.
删除9：<u>Credit:

【5】Darrell Perry/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/618022/view</u>

【6】You do not have flat feet if the inside part of your foot is raised off the ground (this is called the arch).
删除9：<u>Credit:

【7】itanistock / Alamy Stock Photo https://www.alamy.com/stock-photo-side-view-of-a-womans-foot-23018109.html?pv=1&stamp=2&imageid=B45B8A4E-9820-43CE-A91D-18C9A53782A1&p=87561&n=0&orientation=0&pn=1&searchtype=0&IsFromSearch=1&srch=foo%3Dbar%26st%3D0%26sortby%3D2%26qt%3DB9CFR9%26qt\_raw%3DB9CFR9%26qn%3D%26lic%3D3%26edrf%3D1%26mr%3D0%26pr%3D0%26aoa%3D1%26creative%3D%26videos%3D%26nu%3D%26ccc%3D%26bespoke%3D%26apalib%3D%26ag%3D0%26hc%3D0%26et%3D0x000000000000000000000%26vp%3D0%26loc%3D0%26ot%3D0%26imgt%3D0%26dtfr%3D%26dtto%3D%26size%3D0xFF%26blackwhite%3D%26cutout%3D%26archive%3D1%26name%3D%26groupid%3D%26pseudoid%3D178995%26userid%3D%26id%3D%26a%3D%26xstx%3D0%26cbstore%3D1%26resultview%3DsortbyPopular%26lightbox%3D%26gname%3D%26gtype%3D%26apalic%3D%26tbar%3D1%26pc%3D%26simid%3D%26cap%3D1%26customgeoip%3D%26vd%3D0%26cid%3D%26pe%3D%26so%3D%26lb%3D%26pl%3D0%26plno%3D%26fi%3D0%26langcode%3Den%26upl%3D0%26cufr%3D%26cuto%3D%26howler%3D%26cvrem%3D0%26cvtype%3D0%26cvloc%3D0%26cl%3D0%26upfr%3D%26upto%3D%26primcat%3D%26seccat%3D%26cvcategory%3D\*%26restriction%3D%26random%3D%26ispremium%3D1%26flip%3D0%26contributorqt%3D%26plgalleryno%3D%26plpublic%3D0%26viewaspublic%3D0%26isplcurate%3D0%26imageurl%3D%26saveQry%3D%26editorial%3D1%26t%3D0%26edoptin%3D</u>

【8】Flat feet do not usually need to be treated
-------------------------------------------

【9】You do not need to do anything if you or your child have flat feet and they're not causing any problems.

【10】Most children have flat feet until they're about 6 years of age. After this time, they usually develop an arch.

【11】Flat feet:

【12】*   do not usually cause any problems
*   should not stop you doing any activities, including sports
*   are rarely a sign of anything serious

【13】But sometimes, you may have pain around your ankle or the arch of your foot may ache. Your shoes may also wear out quickly.

【14】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if you have flat feet and:
------------------------------------------------------

【15】*   your feet are painful, stiff, weak or numb
*   you often get feet or ankle injuries
*   you have problems with walking or balance
*   you did not have flat feet before
*   it only affects 1 foot

【16】These problems mean you might need treatment.

【17】Treatments for flat feet
------------------------

【18】If flat feet are causing problems and you need treatment, a GP may refer you to a specialist like a podiatrist or physiotherapist.

【19】Referral to a specialist is not available everywhere and waiting times can be long.

【20】Your GP might be able to give you advice about paying to see a specialist privately.

【21】A foot specialist can offer advice about:

【22】*   what shoes to wear (wide, comfortable shoes with a low heel are usually best)
*   shoe insoles to support your feet
*   foot stretches and exercises
*   painkillers

【23】These will not change the shape of your feet, but can help with things like pain or stiffness.

【24】### Surgery for flat feet

【25】Surgery is rarely needed for flat feet.

【26】It might help if there's a problem with the bones, tissues or muscles in your feet and other treatments have not worked.

【27】Your GP may refer you to a surgeon if they think surgery might help.

【28】Information:

【29】### Self-refer to a podiatrist

【30】If you have flat feet, you might be able to refer yourself directly to a podiatrist without seeing a GP.

【31】To find out if there are any services in your area:

【32】*   ask the reception staff at your GP surgery
*   check your GP surgery's website
*   contact your integrated care board (ICB) – find your local ICB
*   search online for NHS podiatrists near you

【33】Causes of flat feet
-------------------

【34】There's often no obvious cause for flat feet. It might just be the way your feet are.

【35】Sometimes flat feet run in families.

【36】Rarely, flat feet may be caused by:

【37】*   the bones in the feet not growing properly in the womb
*   stretching of the tissues in your feet (possibly as a result of things like an injury, getting older or being overweight)
*   conditions affecting the muscles, nerves or joints in the whole body like cerebral palsy and spina bifida
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 24 January 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 24 January 2025</u>

source_info.title: Hyperthyroidism, see Overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism)
source_info.text:
【0】Hyperthyroidism, see Overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism)
Diagnosis \- Overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism)
=================================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications</u>

【2】**See a GP if you think you may have an overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism).**

【3】A diagnosis will be based on your symptoms and the results of a blood test that assesses how well your thyroid is working.

【4】Thyroid function blood test
---------------------------

【5】A GP may arrange for you to have a blood test to check your thyroid hormone levels. This is known as a thyroid function test.

【6】The test checks the levels of:

【7】*   thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) – a hormone produced by the pituitary gland (a gland at the base of the brain) which controls the production of thyroid hormones
*   triiodothyronine (T3) – one of the main thyroid hormones
*   thyroxine (T4) – another of the main thyroid hormones

【8】Your thyroid hormone levels will be compared to what's normal for a healthy person of your age. A low level of TSH and high levels of T3 and/or T4 usually means you have an overactive thyroid.

【9】Doctors may refer to these measurements as "free" T3 and T4 (FT3 and FT4).

【10】What's considered normal varies depending on things such as your age and the exact testing technique used by the laboratory.
删除7：<u>Find out more about thyroid function tests on the Lab Tests Online UK website</u>

【11】Further tests
-------------

【12】If your thyroid hormone levels are high, you may be referred to a specialist for further tests to find out what's causing it.

【13】### Further blood tests

【14】You may have another blood test to look for anti-thyroid antibodies.

【15】These are usually found if you have Graves' disease, a common cause of an overactive thyroid.

【16】A blood test called erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) may also be done to check for inflammation in your body.

【17】If there are signs of inflammation, the increase in thyroid hormones is caused by thyroiditis (inflammation of the thyroid).
删除7：<u>Find out more about ESR tests on the Lab Tests Online UK website</u>

【18】### Thyroid scan

【19】A thyroid scan may be used to look for problems such as lumps (nodules) on your thyroid.

【20】You'll be asked to swallow a small amount of a slightly radioactive substance that will be absorbed by your thyroid. It can also be given by injection.

【21】A scan is then done to see how much of the substance has been absorbed and to examine the size and shape of your thyroid.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 11 April 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 11 April 2026</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Causes</u>删除1：<u>*   Next : Treatment</u>

source_info.title: Stomach ulcer
source_info.text:
【0】Complications \- Stomach ulcer
==============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications</u>

【2】**Complications of stomach ulcers are relatively uncommon, but they can be very serious if they happen.**

【3】Internal bleeding
-----------------

【4】Internal bleeding is the most common complication of stomach ulcers. It can happen when an ulcer develops at the site of a blood vessel.

【5】The bleeding can either be:

【6】*   slow, long-term bleeding, leading to anaemia – causing fatigue, shortness of breath, pale skin and heart palpitations (noticeable heartbeats)
*   rapid and severe bleeding – causing you to vomit blood or pass stools that are black, sticky and tar-like

【7】You should visit your GP if you have persistent symptoms of anaemia. If they think you may have a stomach ulcer, they may refer you to a gastroenterologist for an examination and treatment.

【8】Contact your GP or NHS 111 immediately, or go to your nearest accident and emergency (A&E) department, if you have symptoms of more severe bleeding.

【9】### Treating internal bleeding

【10】A gastroscopy will be used to identify the cause of the bleeding and treatment can often be given during this to stop the bleeding.

【11】Sometimes specialised procedures carried out under X-ray guidance are used to stop bleeding ulcers, although surgery may occasionally be required to repair the affected blood vessel.

【12】Blood transfusions may also be needed to replace the blood you have lost.

【13】Perforation
-----------

【14】A rarer complication of stomach ulcers is the lining of the stomach splitting open, known as perforation.

【15】This can be very serious because it enables the bacteria that live in your stomach to escape and infect the lining of your abdomen (peritoneum). This is known as peritonitis.

【16】In peritonitis, an infection can rapidly spread into the blood (sepsis) before spreading to other organs. This carries the risk of multiple organ failure and can be fatal if left untreated.

【17】The most common symptom of peritonitis is sudden abdominal pain that gets steadily worse. 

【18】If you have this type of pain, contact your GP immediately. If this isn't possible, call NHS 111 or your local NHS out-of-hours service.

【19】Peritonitis is a medical emergency that requires hospital admission. In some cases, surgery may be needed.
删除7：<u>Read more about treating peritonitis.</u>

【20】Gastric outlet obstruction
--------------------------

【21】In some cases, an inflamed (swollen) or scarred stomach ulcer can stop food from going through your digestive system. This is known as gastric outlet obstruction.

【22】Symptoms can include:

【23】*   repeated episodes of vomiting, with large amounts of vomit that contain undigested food
*   a persistent feeling of bloating or fullness
*   feeling very full after eating less food than usual
*   unintentional weight loss

【24】A gastroscopy can be used to confirm the obstruction. If the obstruction is caused by inflammation, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) or H2-receptor antagonists can be used to reduce stomach acid levels until the swelling goes down.

【25】If the obstruction is caused by scar tissue, surgery may be needed to treat it, although it can sometimes be treated by passing a small balloon through an endoscope and inflating it to widen the site of the obstruction.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 14 January 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 14 January 2025</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Treatment</u>

source_info.title: Kawasaki disease
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Kawasaki disease
============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications</u>

【2】**Kawasaki disease is a condition that mainly affects children under the age of 5. It's also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.**

【3】A child with Kawasaki disease has a high temperature that lasts for 5 days or longer, and possibly 1 or more of the following symptoms:

【4】*   a rash
*   swollen glands in the neck
*   dry, red cracked lips
*   a swollen, bumpy, red tongue (“strawberry tongue”)
*   red inside the mouth and at the back of the throat
*   swollen and red hands and feet
*   red eyes

【5】After a few weeks, and with the correct treatment, the symptoms become less severe, but it can take longer than this in some children.
删除7：<u>Read more about the symptoms of Kawasaki disease.</u>

【6】When to see a GP
----------------

【7】See a GP urgently, or call 111 if you can't speak to a GP, if your child has a persistent high temperature and 1 or more symptoms of Kawasaki disease.

【8】If your baby is less than 1 year old, it's even more important to see a GP or call 111 straight away.

【9】The symptoms of Kawasaki disease can be similar to those of other conditions that cause a fever in children.

【10】Kawasaki disease can't be prevented. Children can make a full recovery within 6 to 8 weeks if it's diagnosed and treated promptly, but complications can develop.

【11】It's important to see a GP and start treatment as soon as possible.
删除7：<u>Read more about diagnosing Kawasaki disease.</u>

【12】It's not clear exactly what causes Kawasaki disease. It may be due to a combination of factors.
删除7：<u>Read more about the possible causes of Kawasaki disease.</u>

【13】Treating Kawasaki disease
-------------------------

【14】Kawasaki disease is always treated in hospital.

【15】It's best if treatment begins as soon as possible. The sooner treatment starts, the quicker the recovery time and there's less risk of complications developing.

【16】Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), a solution of antibodies, and aspirin are the 2 main medicines used to treat Kawasaki disease.
删除7：<u>Read more about treating Kawasaki disease.</u>

【17】Complications of Kawasaki disease
---------------------------------

【18】Kawasaki disease causes the blood vessels to become inflamed and swollen, which can lead to complications in the blood vessels that supply blood to the heart (coronary arteries).

【19】Without treatment, around 1 in 4 children with Kawasaki disease get heart complications. This can be fatal in about 2 to 3% of cases.

【20】Because of this, Kawasaki disease is one of the main causes of acquired heart disease in children under 5 in the UK. Acquired heart disease develops after birth.
删除7：<u>Read more about the complications of Kawasaki disease.</u>

【21】Who's affected
--------------

【22】Around 8 in every 100,000 children develop Kawasaki disease in the UK each year.

【23】Research carried out in England from 1998 to 2003 found 72% of children with Kawasaki disease were under the age of 5.

【24】The condition was also shown to be 1.5 times more common in boys than girls.

【25】Support
-------

【26】The Kawasaki Support Group and Societi, The UK Foundation for Kawasaki Disease can provide you with additional information and advice about your child's condition.

source_info.title: Carvedilol
source_info.text:
【0】Carvedilol
==========
删除10：<u>On this page
------------

【1】1.  About carvedilol
2.  Key facts
3.  Who can and cannot take carvedilol
4.  How and when to take carvedilol
5.  Side effects
6.  How to cope with side effects of carvedilol
7.  Pregnancy and breastfeeding
8.  Cautions with other medicines
9.  Common questions about carvedilol</u>

【2】1\. About carvedilol
--------------------

【3】Carvedilol is a beta blocker.

【4】It’s used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension) and helps prevent:

【5】*   heart disease
*   heart attacks
*   strokes

【6】It can also be given with other medicines to treat heart failure and to prevent chest pain caused by angina.

【7】Carvedilol is only available on prescription. It comes as tablets.

【8】2\. Key facts
-------------

【9】*   Carvedilol slows down your heart rate and makes it easier for your heart to pump blood around your body.
*   You’ll usually take carvedilol once or twice a day.
*   It usually starts to work after about 1 hour. But it will take days or weeks for it to reach its full effect.
*   Common side effects of carvedilol include headaches and feeling tired or dizzy.
*   Do not stop taking carvedilol suddenly. This can make your condition worse, especially if you have heart disease.

【10】3\. Who can and cannot take carvedilol
--------------------------------------

【11】Carvedilol can be taken by most adults. It can sometimes be prescribed by a specialist for children aged 2 years and over.

【12】Carvedilol is not suitable for some people. Tell your doctor before starting the medicine if you have:

【13】*   ever had an allergic reaction to carvedilol or any other medicines
*   lung disease or asthma
*   heart failure that is getting worse
*   have low blood pressure (hypotension) or a slow heart rate
*   a liver problem
*   serious circulation problems in your arms and legs, such as Raynaud’s

【14】4\. How and when to take carvedilol
-----------------------------------

【15】When you start taking carvedilol, your doctor may advise you to take your first dose just before you go to bed. This is because it can make you feel dizzy.

【16】After the first dose, if you do not feel dizzy, you can take your medicine in the morning. If you do feel dizzy, it’s best to keep taking your medicine at bedtime.

【17】It’s best to take carvedilol at the same time each day.

【18】If you take it twice a day, you’ll usually have 1 dose in the morning and 1 dose in the evening. Leave 10 to 12 hours between doses if you can.

【19】Swallow the tablets whole with a drink of water. Do not chew or crush them.

【20】Carvedilol does not usually upset your stomach, so you can take it with or without food. However, if you are taking carvedilol for heart failure, it’s best to take the tablets with food. This will help reduce the risk of you feeling dizzy or faint when you stand up.

【21】If you find tablets difficult to swallow, some strengths have a score line to help you break the tablet in half. Check the information leaflet that comes with your medicine to see if you can do this.

【22】### Dosage

【23】Carvedilol tablets come in 4 different strengths – 3.125mg, 6.25mg, 12.5mg and 25mg.

【24】How much you take depends on why you need carvedilol.

【25】The usual starting dose to treat:

【26】*   **high blood pressure** is 12.5mg once a day for 2 days – this is increased to 25mg, taken once a day. If your blood pressure does not go down enough your doctor may increase your dose to up to 50mg a day. This can be taken as a single dose or split into 2 doses.
*   **heart failure** is 3.125mg, taken twice a day for 2 weeks. Your doctor will then slowly increase the dose every 2 weeks up to a maximum of 25mg to 50mg (depending on your weight).
*   **angina** is 12.5mg, taken twice a day for 2 days – this is increased to 25mg, taken twice a day.

【27】If your child is prescribed carvedilol, the doctor will use their weight to work out the right dose.

【28】### What if I forget to take it?

【29】If you miss a dose of carvedilol, take it as soon as you remember, unless it’s nearly time for your next dose. In this case, just leave out the missed dose and take your next dose as normal.

【30】Never take 2 doses at the same time. Never take an extra dose to make up for a forgotten one.

【31】If you often forget doses, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to take your medicine.

【32】### What if I take too much?

【33】The amount of carvedilol that can lead to an overdose varies from person to person.

【34】Taking too much carvedilol can lower your blood pressure, slow your heart rate, and make it difficult to breathe.

【35】#### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【36】*   you take too much carvedilol

【37】Call 111 or go to 111.nhs.uk

【38】If you need advice for a child under the age of 5 years, call 111.

【39】5\. Side effects
----------------

【40】Like all medicines, carvedilol can cause side effects in some people, but many people have no side effects or only minor ones.

【41】Side effects usually improve as your body gets used to the medicine.

【42】### Common side effects

【43】These common side effects may happen in more than 1 in 100 people. They’re usually mild and last a few days after starting the medicine or increasing your dose.

【44】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if these side effects bother you or do not go away:

【45】*   feeling dizzy
*   headaches
*   feeling tired
*   feeling or being sick (nausea or vomiting)
*   cold fingers or toes

【46】### Serious side effects

【47】It happens rarely, but some people have serious side effects when taking carvedilol.

【48】Tell a doctor straight away if you have:

【49】*   nose bleeds that last for more than 10 minutes, unexplained bruising, or you bruise more easily than usual – these can be signs of low numbers of platelets in your blood (thrombocytopenia)
*   high temperature, sore throat, mouth sores, toothache, flu-like symptoms – these can be signs of a low number of white blood cells (leukopenia)
*   shortness of breath with a cough that gets worse when you exercise (like walking up the stairs), swollen ankles or legs, chest pain, or an irregular heartbeat – these may be signs of other heart problems
*   shortness of breath, wheezing and tightening of your chest – these can be signs of lung problems
*   yellow skin or the whites of your eyes turn yellow – these can be signs of liver problems

【50】#### Serious allergic reaction

【51】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to carvedilol.

【52】##### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【53】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【54】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【55】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【56】These are not all the side effects of carvedilol. For a full list see the leaflet inside your medicines packet.
删除5：<u>Information:

【57】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.
删除12：<u>Visit Yellow Card for further information.</u></u>

【58】6\. How to cope with side effects of carvedilol
-----------------------------------------------

【59】**What to do about:**

【60】*   **feeling dizzy** – as your body gets used to carvedilol this side effect should wear off. If carvedilol makes you feel dizzy, stop what you’re doing and sit or lie down until you feel better. Do not drive or operate machinery until you feel OK again. Try to avoid alcohol as it'll make you feel worse.
*   **headaches** – make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller. Do not drink too much alcohol. Headaches usually go away after the first week of taking carvedilol. Talk to your doctor if the headaches last more than a week or are severe.
*   **feeling tired** – do not drive, ride a bike, or use tools or machinery if you’re feeling tired. Do not drink any alcohol as this will make you feel more tired.
*   **feeling sick or being sick** – stick to simple meals and do not eat rich or spicy food. It might help to take your carvedilol after a meal or snack. If you're being sick, try drinking small, frequent sips of water to avoid dehydration.
*   **cold fingers or toes** – put your hands or feet under warm running water, massage them, and wiggle your fingers and toes. Do not smoke or have drinks with caffeine, as this can make your blood vessels narrower and restrict your blood flow. It’s best not to wear tight watches or bracelets as well. Try wearing mittens (they're warmer than gloves) and warm socks. Speak to your doctor if this side effect bothers you.

【61】7\. Pregnancy and breastfeeding
-------------------------------

【62】### Carvedilol and pregnancy

【63】Carvedilol is not usually recommended if you’re pregnant.

【64】If you're trying to get pregnant or you're already pregnant, talk to your doctor about taking carvedilol. It may be possible to change to other medicines that are more suitable when you’re pregnant, such as labetalol or nifedipine.

【65】### Carvedilol and breastfeeding

【66】If your doctor or health visitor says that your baby is healthy, it's OK to take carvedilol while breastfeeding.

【67】There is no information about whether carvedilol passes into breast milk, but it would only be expected to pass through in small amounts. It’s unlikely to cause any side effects in your baby.

【68】If you notice that your baby isn't feeding as well as usual, or seems unusually sleepy, or if you have any other concerns about your baby, then talk to your health visitor, midwife or doctor as soon as possible.

【69】### Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:

【70】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding
删除7：<u>Find out more about high blood pressure and pregnancy.</u>

【71】8\. Cautions with other medicines
---------------------------------

【72】There are some medicines that can affect the way carvedilol works.

【73】Tell your doctor if you’re taking:

【74】*   other medicines for high blood pressure – when taken together with carvedilol, they can sometimes lower your blood pressure too much
*   other medicines that can lower your blood pressure – these include some antidepressants, nitrates (for chest pain), baclofen (a muscle relaxant), medicines for an enlarged prostate gland like tamsulosin, or levodopa (for Parkinson’s disease)
*   medicines for an irregular heartbeat such as amiodarone or flecainide
*   medicines for asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
*   medicines for diabetes, particularly insulin – carvedilol may make it more difficult to recognise the warning signs of low blood sugar. Speak to your doctor if you have low blood sugar levels without getting any warning signs. You should check your blood sugar after exercise, and follow usual advice about checking it before driving, or operating machinery.
*   medicines that treat nose or sinus congestion, or other cold remedies (including those you can buy in the pharmacy)
*   medicines for allergies, such as ephedrine, noradrenaline or adrenaline
*   non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medicines (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen, diclofenac and naproxen – these medicines may increase your blood pressure

【75】### Mixing carvedilol with herbal remedies and supplements

【76】There's very little information about taking herbal remedies and supplements with carvedilol. However, some herbal products, such as cod liver oil, hawthorn and garlic tablets may cause low blood pressure (hypotension).

【77】### Important: Medicine safety

【78】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal medicines, vitamins or supplements.

【79】9\. Common questions about carvedilol
-------------------------------------

【80】How does carvedilol work?

【81】Carvedilol is a type of medicine called a beta blocker.

【82】Like other beta blockers, carvedilol works by slowing down your heart rate and making it easier for your heart to pump blood around your body.

【83】It also works like an alpha blocker to widen some of your blood vessels. This helps lower your blood pressure.

【84】For angina, carvedilol works by improving the blood supply to your heart. Angina is chest pain that comes on when not enough blood gets to the muscles of the heart. It usually happens because the arteries to the heart become hardened and narrowed.

【85】Carvedilol widens the arteries so more oxygen gets to the heart and chest pain is prevented. It also slows your heart down and makes it beat more effectively. This reduces the amount of oxygen needed by your heart muscle and prevents angina.

【86】How long does it take to work?

【87】Carvedilol usually starts to work after about 1 hour. But it will take days or weeks to reach its full effect.

【88】You may not feel any different when you take carvedilol for high blood pressure, but this does not mean it’s not working. It’s important to keep taking your medicine.

【89】How long will I take it for?

【90】Usually, treatment with carvedilol is long term. It may be for the rest of your life.

【91】Can I take carvedilol for a long time?

【92】Most people take carvedilol for a long time with no problems. In fact, it works best when you take it long term.

【93】What will happen if I stop taking it?

【94】Talk to your doctor if you want to stop taking carvedilol. If you’re bothered by side effects, your doctor may be able to prescribe a different medicine instead.

【95】How does it compare with other medicines for high blood pressure?

【96】Carvedilol works as well as other beta blockers to reduce blood pressure, but it’s mainly used to prevent angina or heart failure because it also widens the blood vessels.

【97】The main difference with carvedilol is that it can affect other parts of your body too, such as your lungs.

【98】Other medicines used to lower blood pressure work in different ways to beta blockers. These include:

【99】*   ACE inhibitors such as ramipril and lisinopril
*   angiotensin receptor blockers like losartan
*   calcium channel blockers like amlodipine
*   medicines that make you pee more (diuretics) like indapamide

【100】The medicine your doctor prescribes first depends on your age and ethnicity. If you’re under 55 years old, you’ll usually be offered an ACE inhibitor or an angiotensin receptor blocker. If you’re 55 years old or over, or of African Caribbean or black African origin, you’ll usually be offered a calcium channel blocker.

【101】If you are bothered by side effects, you may have to try a different blood pressure medicine. Many people need to take a combination.

【102】How does it compare with other medicines for chest pain and angina?

【103】There are lots of other medicines to prevent angina attacks.

【104】They include:

【105】*   calcium channel blockers such as diltiazem and amlodipine
*   nitrates like isosorbide mononitrate
*   medicines such as ranolazine, nicorandil or ivabradine

【106】If carvedilol does not work for you, or you cannot take carvedilol or other beta blockers because of side effects, you may be able to switch to another medicine.

【107】Your doctor will be able to decide which medicine is best for you. Some people may need to take a combination of medicines to control their angina symptoms.

【108】How does it compare with other medicines that treat heart failure?

【109】Carvedilol is used with other medicines to treat heart failure and prevent complications, These can include ACE inhibitors (like ramipril and lisinopril) or angiotensin receptor blockers (like losartan).

【110】Other beta blockers like bisoprolol and nebivolol can be used instead of carvedilol in a similar way.

【111】Will I need to stop carvedilol before surgery?

【112】Tell your doctor you’re taking carvedilol if you’re going to be put to sleep (using general anaesthetic) or have any kind of major operation.

【113】Your doctor may advise you to stop taking carvedilol before surgery.

【114】This is because carvedilol can lower your blood pressure too much when it’s combined with some general anaesthetics.

【115】Can I drink alcohol?

【116】Drinking alcohol can increase the blood pressure-lowering effect of carvedilol. This can make you feel dizzy or lightheaded.

【117】During the first few days of taking carvedilol, or after an increase in your dose, it is best to stop drinking alcohol until you see how the medicine affects you.

【118】If you find carvedilol makes you feel dizzy it's best to stop drinking alcohol.

【119】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【120】You can eat and drink normally while taking carvedilol.

【121】Eating a healthy, balanced diet can help your heart condition.

【122】Will it affect my contraception?

【123】Carvedilol will not stop your contraception working.

【124】But some types of combined hormonal methods of contraception, such as the combined pill and contraceptive patch, are not usually recommended for women with high blood pressure.

【125】Talk to your doctor if you’re taking a combined hormonal contraceptive.

【126】If carvedilol makes you vomit, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy. Look on the pill packet to find out what to do.
删除7：<u>Read more about what to do if you're on the pill and you're being sick.</u>

【127】Will it affect my fertility?

【128】There’s no clear evidence to suggest that taking carvedilol will reduce fertility in either men or women.

【129】If you're trying for a baby or having problems getting pregnant while on carvedilol, speak to your doctor.

【130】Will it affect my sex life?

【131】Some people on carvedilol say their sex drive goes down and some men say they cannot get an erection.

【132】There’s not enough evidence to say that carvedilol causes this.

【133】If you’re having problems with your sex life, talk to your doctor.

【134】Do I need to avoid playing sports?

【135】You do not need to stop playing sports if you take carvedilol. But it’s a good idea not to push yourself too much.

【136】Regular exercise is good for you because it lowers blood pressure by keeping your heart and blood vessels in good condition.

【137】However, in some sports carvedilol may not be allowed if you’re competing at a very high level.

【138】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【139】Carvedilol can make you feel tired or dizzy, especially when you first start taking it or after increasing your dose.

【140】If this happens to you, do not drive a car, ride a bike, or use tools or machinery until you feel OK again.

【141】Can lifestyle changes help heart problems?

【142】If you have heart problems, you can boost the health of your heart by making some lifestyle changes.  

【143】It's a good idea to:

【144】*   quit smoking – not smoking will bring down your blood pressure and relieve heart failure symptoms.
*   cut down on alcohol – drinking too much alcohol raises blood pressure over time and makes heart failure worse. Drinking alcohol while you're taking carvedilol can make you feel dizzy or lightheaded.
*   exercise – regular exercise lowers blood pressure by keeping your heart and blood vessels in good condition. Even walking every day will help.
*   eat well and lower the salt in your diet – aim to eat plenty of fruit and veg, wholegrains, fat-free or low-fat dairy products and lean proteins. Eating too much salt is the biggest cause of high blood pressure – the more salt you eat, the higher your blood pressure will be.
*   deal with stress – when you're anxious or upset, your heart beats faster, you breathe more heavily and your blood pressure often goes up. This can make heart failure worse too. Finding ways to cope with stress will help to keep your blood pressure down.
删除11：<u>Related conditions
------------------

【145】*   Angina
*   Heart attack
*   Heart failure
*   High blood pressure (hypertension)
*   Stroke
</u>删除11：<u>Useful resources
----------------

【146】*   HealthUnlocked: carvedilol forum
*   Blood Pressure UK: charity
*   British Heart Foundation: charity
*   Heart attack: videos of real stories
*   NHS Health Check: free health check-up
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 10 March 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 10 March 2024</u>

source_info.title: Lymecycline
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take lymecycline
===================================

【1】Who can take lymecycline
------------------------

【2】Lymecycline can be taken by most adults and children over the age of 12.

【3】Who may not be able to take lymecycline
---------------------------------------

【4】Lymecycline is not suitable for some people. To make sure this medicine is safe for you, tell your doctor if you:

【5】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to lymecycline or any other medicine
*   have kidney problems
*   are pregnant, trying to get pregnant or breastfeeding
*   have liver problems
*   have an autoimmune disease called lupus
*   have myasthenia gravis – a rare muscle-weakening disease
删除11：<u>More in Lymecycline
-------------------

【6】*   About lymecycline
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking lymecycline with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 6 January 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 6 January 2025</u>

source_info.title: Cervical cancer
source_info.text:
【0】Causes \- Cervical cancer
=========================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Tests and next steps
5.  Treatment
6.  Help and support</u>

【2】Main causes of cervical cancer
------------------------------

【3】Nearly all cervical cancers are caused by an infection with certain high-risk types of human papillomavirus (HPV).

【4】You can get HPV from:

【5】*   any skin-to-skin contact of the genital area
*   vaginal, anal or oral sex
*   sharing sex toys

【6】Who is more likely to get cervical cancer
-----------------------------------------

【7】Cervical cancer mostly affects women under the age of 45. Anyone with a cervix can get it.

【8】You cannot get cervical cancer if you've had surgery to remove your womb and cervix (total hysterectomy).

【9】You might also be more likely to get cervical cancer if:

【10】*   you're under 45 – cervical cancer is more common in younger people
*   you have a weakened immune system, like if you have HIV or AIDS
*   you have given birth to multiple children or had children at an early age (under 17 years old)
*   your mother took the hormonal medicine diethylstilbestrol (DES) while pregnant with you – your GP can discuss these risks with you
*   you've had vaginal, vulval, kidney or bladder cancer in the past

【11】How to lower your chance of getting cervical cancer
---------------------------------------------------

【12】You cannot always prevent cervical cancer. But there are things you can do to lower your chances of getting cervical cancer.

【13】Cervical screening and HPV vaccination are the best ways to protect yourself from cervical cancer.

【14】*   All women and people with a cervix between the ages of 25 and 64 are invited for regular cervical screening. It helps find and treat any changes in the cells of the cervix before they can turn into cancer.
*   All children aged 12 to 13 are offered the HPV vaccine. It helps protect against all cancers caused by HPV, as well as genital warts.

【15】You can also lower your chance of getting cervical cancer by:

【16】*   using condoms, which lower your chance of getting HPV – but they do not cover all the skin around your genitals so you're not fully protected
*   quitting smoking – smoking can weaken your immune system and the chemicals in cigarettes can also cause cervical cancer
*   eating a balanced diet to help support your immune system

【17】Information:

【18】It's important to get any symptoms of cervical cancer checked by a GP.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 02 September 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 02 September 2024</u>

source_info.title: Doxycycline
source_info.text:
【0】About doxycycline
=================

【1】Doxycycline is an antibiotic that's used to treat infections including:

【2】*   chest and dental infections
*   skin infections and conditions like rosacea
*   sexually transmitted infections (STIs)
*   other rare infections

【3】It can also be used to prevent malaria if you're travelling abroad.

【4】Doxycycline is available on prescription. It comes as capsules, tablets and tablets which dissolve in water (dispersible).

【5】Key facts
---------

【6】*   For most infections, you'll start to feel better in a few days, but it's important to finish the course of medicine.
*   Doxycycline works more slowly to treat the condition rosacea. A doctor can review it after about 4 weeks to check how well it's working.
*   The most common side effects of doxycycline are headaches, feeling sick or being sick. It can also make your skin sensitive to the sun.
*   It's best not to drink alcohol while taking doxycycline because it can stop it working properly.
*   Doxycycline can sometimes cause thrush. If this happens, ask your doctor or pharmacist for advice.
删除11：<u>More in Doxycycline
-------------------

【7】*   About doxycycline
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking doxycycline with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 19 January 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 19 January 2025</u>

source_info.title: Limping in children
source_info.text:
【0】Limping in children
===================

【1】**Limping in children is not usually serious and could be caused by something minor like a sprain or strain. But you should see a GP if it's not obvious what's causing it.**

【2】Causes of limping in children
-----------------------------

【3】Limping in children is often caused by an obvious injury to the leg or foot, such as:

【4】*   a sprain or strain
*   a blister, cut or bruise
*   a broken bone

【5】Sometimes it may not be clear what's causing your child to limp. The symptoms might give you an idea of what the cause might be.

【6】But do not self-diagnose – a limp with no obvious cause should always be checked by a GP as it could be a sign of something serious.

【7】Other causes of limping in children

| Other symptoms | Possible cause |
| --- | --- |
| Sudden pain in the hip, knee or thigh, sometimes after a viral infection | Irritable hip |
| Pain in the groin, hip or knee, stiff hip, foot or leg turns inward | Slipped upper femoral epiphysis |
| Painful, swollen joints that lasts for longer than 6 weeks | Different types of juvenile arthritis |
| Pain in the groin, thigh or knee after exercise, stiff hip | Perthes' disease |
| A lump on your child's leg, weight loss, pain at night | A cancer, such as leukaemia, sarcoma or lymphoma |

【9】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【10】*   your child has a limp and you're not sure what's causing it

【11】Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E if:
----------------------------------------------------

【12】*   your child gets sudden pain in their hip, knee or thigh (hip problems can sometimes be felt in the thigh or knee)
*   your child cannot put any weight on their leg
*   the leg has changed shape or is pointing at an odd angle
*   your child feels generally unwell and has a high temperature or feels hot and shivery
*   your child also has severe pain in the lower part of their tummy
*   your child's symptoms get worse

【13】Find your nearest A&E

【14】What we mean by severe pain

【15】Severe pain:

【16】*   always there and so bad it's hard to think or talk
*   you cannot sleep
*   it's very hard to move, get out of bed, go to the bathroom, wash or dress

【17】Moderate pain:

【18】*   always there
*   makes it hard to concentrate or sleep
*   you can manage to get up, wash or dress

【19】Mild pain:

【20】*   comes and goes
*   is annoying but does not stop you doing daily activities

【21】Treatment from a GP
-------------------

【22】Treatment will depend on what's causing your child to limp. Sometimes it may get better on its own.

【23】A GP will examine your child and may arrange for more tests to find out what's causing your child to limp.

【24】They might:

【25】*   give you advice on how to treat a sprain or strain at home, such as rest and taking paracetamol or ibuprofen
*   refer you to hospital for an X-ray or to a specialist (for example, a paediatric orthopaedic surgeon) to help find the cause

source_info.title: Allopurinol
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking allopurinol \- Brand names: Zyloric, Uricto
===============================================================================================

【1】Allopurinol and pregnancy
-------------------------

【2】Allopurinol is not usually recommended during pregnancy. There is not enough evidence to say that it's safe.

【3】Talk to a doctor if you're thinking about trying for a baby. There may be other medicines that are more suitable for you to take during pregnancy.

【4】Allopurinol and breastfeeding
-----------------------------

【5】If your doctor or health visitor says your baby is healthy, you can take allopurinol while you're breastfeeding.

【6】There is not much information about using allopurinol while breastfeeding, but it is likely that allopurinol passes into breast milk in small amounts

【7】If you notice that your baby is not feeding as well as usual, is being sick (vomiting), has diarrhoea or a rash, or if you have any other concerns about your baby, then talk to your doctor, pharmacist, midwife or health visitor.

【8】Allopurinol and fertility
-------------------------

【9】There is no evidence to suggest that taking allopurinol reduces fertility in either men or women. However, talk to a doctor if you want to try for a baby while taking allopurinol.

【10】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【11】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding
删除7：<u>Find out more about how allopurinol can affect you and your baby during pregnancy on the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website.</u>
删除11：<u>More in Allopurinol
-------------------

【12】*   About allopurinol
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking allopurinol with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

source_info.title: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
source_info.text:
【0】Diagnosis \- Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
=========================================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Complications</u>

【2】**Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) tends to be diagnosed in adults over 30 years of age because symptoms do not usually start before then.**

【3】When making a diagnosis, your GP will ask about your symptoms and your family's medical history.

【4】If your kidneys are enlarged, your GP may be able to feel them in your tummy (abdomen).

【5】Your GP may also arrange for some tests to be carried out.

【6】Urine and blood tests
---------------------

【7】Your GP will measure your blood pressure to see whether it's higher than normal.

【8】They may also carry out other tests, such as:

【9】*   urine tests to check for blood or protein in your urine
*   blood tests so the rate your kidneys are filtering your blood can be estimated

【10】### GFR blood test

【11】An effective way of assessing how well your kidneys are working is to calculate your glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

【12】GFR is a measure of how many millilitres (ml) of blood your kidneys are able to filter out waste products from in a minute.

【13】A healthy pair of kidneys should be able to filter more than 90ml of blood a minute.

【14】Scans
-----

【15】Your GP will also arrange for you to have an ultrasound scan to look for cysts in your kidneys or other organs, such as your liver. 

【16】An ultrasound scan is a painless procedure where a small probe is passed across the skin over your kidneys.

【17】The probe emits high-frequency sound waves that are used to create an image of the inside of your body.

【18】In some cases, you may need to have a CT scan or MRI scan. These will show your kidneys in more detail.

【19】An MRI scan will be recommended if you have a family history of brain aneurysms.

【20】A brain aneurysm is a bulge in a blood vessel in the brain that's caused by a weakness in the blood vessel wall. 
删除7：<u>Find out more about diagnosing brain aneurysms</u>

【21】Screening
---------

【22】Screening people known to be at risk of developing ADPKD because they have a family history of the condition is a controversial issue in the medical community.

【23】Some argue that screening achieves little because there's currently no treatment to stop ADPKD developing.

【24】Telling a person that they have ADPKD and are likely to develop kidney failure later in life could also cause them stress and anxiety.

【25】Others argue that although you cannot prevent ADPKD, screening can help identify cysts, and it's possible to treat the high blood pressure (hypertension) associated with ADPKD, which may reduce the person's risk of developing cardiovascular disease.

【26】If the diagnosis is known, complications will not come as a surprise and can be treated promptly and appropriately.

【27】There's also now a treatment called tolvaptan, which can slow the growth of cysts and may be beneficial in some cases.

【28】If you're considering being screened for ADPKD or having your children screened, you should discuss the advantages and disadvantages of screening with your GP, partner and family.

【29】You may also want to ask for a referral to see a kidney specialist.

【30】### How screening is carried out

【31】There are 2 methods that can be used to confirm a diagnosis of ADPKD.

【32】They are:

【33】*   using an ultrasound, CT or MRI scan to check for kidney abnormalities
*   in special circumstances, using genetic blood tests to determine whether you have inherited one of the genetic faults known to cause ADPKD in your family – but as these genetic tests are expensive and can be difficult to interpret, they're not routinely carried out at present

【34】It's important to be aware that neither test is entirely accurate and may not always detect ADPKD, even if you have the condition.

【35】Imaging tests may miss very small cysts in younger people and will need to be repeated later in life.

【36】Genetic testing is more sensitive and accurate in diagnosing ADPKD, but may be negative in 10% of people with ADPKD.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 23 February 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 23 February 2026</u>
