source_info.title: Stroke
source_info.text:
【0】Diagnosis \- Stroke
===================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Recovery
7.  Prevention</u>

【2】**Strokes are usually diagnosed by doing physical tests and studying images of the brain produced during a scan.**

【3】When you first arrive at hospital with a suspected stroke, the doctor will want to find out as much as they can about your symptoms.

【4】A number of tests can be done to confirm the diagnosis and determine the cause of the stroke.

【5】These may include: 

【6】*   a blood test to find out your cholesterol and blood sugar level
*   checking your pulse for an irregular heartbeat
*   taking a blood pressure measurement

【7】Brain scans
-----------

【8】Even if the physical symptoms of a stroke are obvious, brain scans should also be done to determine:

【9】*   if the stroke has been caused by a blocked artery (ischaemic stroke) or burst blood vessel (haemorrhagic stroke)
*   which part of the brain has been affected
*   how severe the stroke is

【10】Everyone with suspected stroke should have a brain scan within 1 hour of arriving at hospital if possible.

【11】An early brain scan is especially important for people who:

【12】*   might benefit from medicine to clear blood clots (thrombolysis), such as alteplase or early anticoagulant treatment
*   are already taking anticoagulant treatments
*   have a lower level of consciousness

【13】This is why a stroke is a medical emergency and you should call 999 when a stroke is suspected – there's no time to wait for a GP appointment.

【14】The 2 main types of scans used to assess the brain in people who have had a suspected stroke are:

【15】*   a CT scan
*   an MRI scan

【16】### CT scans

【17】A CT scan is like an X-ray, but uses multiple images to build up a more detailed 3-dimensional picture of your brain to help your doctor identify any problem areas.

【18】During the scan, you may be given an injection of a special dye into one of the veins in your arm to help improve the clarity of the CT image and look at the blood vessels that supply the brain.

【19】If a stroke is suspected, a CT scan is usually able to show whether you have had an ischaemic stroke or a haemorrhagic stroke.

【20】It's generally quicker than an MRI scan and can mean you're able to receive appropriate treatment sooner.

【21】### MRI scans

【22】An MRI scan uses a strong magnetic field and radio waves to produce a detailed picture of the inside of your body.

【23】It's usually used in people with complex symptoms, where the extent or location of the damage is unknown. 

【24】It's also used in people who have recovered from a transient ischaemic attack (TIA). 

【25】An MRI scan shows brain tissue in greater detail, allowing smaller, or more unusually located, areas affected by a stroke to be identified.

【26】As with a CT scan, special dye can be used to improve MRI scan images.

【27】Swallow tests
-------------

【28】A swallow test is essential for anybody who has had a stroke, as the ability to swallow is often affected soon after having a stroke.

【29】When a person cannot swallow properly, there's a risk that food and drink may get into the windpipe and lungs, which can lead to chest infections such as pneumonia. This is called aspiration.

【30】The test is simple. The person is given a few teaspoons of water to drink. If they can swallow this without choking and coughing, they'll be asked to swallow half a glass of water.

【31】If they have any difficulty swallowing, they'll be referred to a speech and language therapist for a more detailed assessment.

【32】They usually will not be allowed to eat or drink normally until they have seen the therapist.

【33】Fluids or nutrients may need to be given directly into a vein in the arm (intravenously) or through a tube that's inserted through the nose and down into the stomach.

【34】Heart and blood vessel tests
----------------------------

【35】Further tests on the heart and blood vessels might be done later to confirm what caused your stroke.

【36】### Carotid ultrasound

【37】A carotid ultrasound scan can help to show if there's narrowing or blockages in the neck arteries leading to your brain.

【38】An ultrasound scan involves using a small probe (transducer) to send high-frequency sound waves into your body.

【39】When these sound waves bounce back, they can be used to create an image of the inside of your body.

【40】When carotid ultrasonography is needed, it should happen within 48 hours.

【41】### Echocardiography

【42】An echocardiogram makes images of your heart to check for any problems that could be related to your stroke.

【43】This usually involves moving an ultrasound probe across your chest (transthoracic echocardiogram).

【44】An alternative type of echocardiogram called transoesophageal echocardiography (TOE) may sometimes be used.

【45】An ultrasound probe is passed down your gullet (oesophagus), usually under sedation.

【46】As this allows the probe to be placed directly behind the heart, it produces a clear image of blood clots and other abnormalities that may not be seen with a transthoracic echocardiogram.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 13 September 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 13 September 2025</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Causes</u>删除1：<u>*   Next : Treatment</u>

source_info.title: Antidepressants
source_info.text:
【0】Cautions - Antidepressants
==========================

【1】**There are several important things to consider when taking antidepressants. You should discuss these with a GP or mental health professional.**

【2】Interactions with other medicines
---------------------------------

【3】Antidepressants can react unpredictably with other medicines, including some over-the-counter medicines such as ibuprofen. Always read the patient information leaflet that comes with your medicine to see if there are any other medicines you should avoid.

【4】If in doubt, your pharmacist or GP should be able to advise you.

【5】Pregnancy
---------

【6】As a precaution, antidepressants are not usually recommended for most pregnant women, especially during the early stages of a pregnancy.

【7】This is because there might be risks for you or your baby.

【8】But it's important that depression is well treated because it can affect both you and your baby's wellbeing. Depression and anxiety can sometimes get worse during pregnancy and after your baby is born.

【9】Speak to your doctor, who will help you understand the risks and benefits so you can decide on the best treatment for you and your baby.

【10】Breastfeeding
-------------

【11】Some antidepressants can be taken while breastfeeding if your doctor or health visitor says your baby is healthy.

【12】Speak to your doctor, who will help you understand the risks and benefits so you can decide on the best treatment for you and your baby.

【13】Children and young people
-------------------------

【14】The use of antidepressants is not usually recommended in children and young people under the age of 18. This is because there is some evidence that, in rare cases, they can trigger thoughts about suicide and acts of self-harm in this age group.

【15】Antidepressants are not recommended for the initial treatment of mild depression in children and young people.

【16】For moderate to severe depression, antidepressants may be used if both the following apply:

【17】*   the person being treated will also receive talking therapies in combination with antidepressants
*   the treatment is supervised by a child and adolescent psychiatrist (a doctor who specialises in treating mental health conditions in children)

【18】Alcohol
-------

【19】You should be wary of drinking alcohol if you're taking antidepressants, as alcohol is itself a depressant and drinking alcohol can make your symptoms worse.

【20】If you drink alcohol while taking types of antidepressants called tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) or monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs), you may become drowsy and dizzy.

【21】You're less likely to experience unpleasant or unpredictable effects if you drink alcohol while taking an SSRI or a serotonin-noradrenaline reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) antidepressant, but avoiding alcohol is often still recommended.

【22】Illegal drugs
-------------

【23】The use of illegal drugs is not recommended if you're taking antidepressants, particularly if you've been prescribed a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA). This is because they can cause unpredictable and unpleasant effects.

【24】In particular, you should avoid taking:

【25】*   cannabis – smoking cannabis while taking a TCA can make you feel very ill
*   amphetamines (speed)
*   cocaine
*   heroin
*   ketamine

【26】As with alcohol, illegal drugs can make symptoms of depression or other mental health conditions worse.

【27】Other antidepressants
---------------------

【28】You should only take 2 different types of antidepressants, such as an SSRI and a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA), if a doctor advises you to. This is because taking certain combinations of antidepressants can make you feel very ill and can be life-threatening.

【29】If a decision is taken to switch you from a particular type to another, the dosage of the first antidepressant will usually be gradually reduced before the second is started.

【30】St John's wort
--------------

【31】St John's wort is a popular herbal remedy promoted for the treatment of depression.

【32】While there's evidence of its effectiveness, many experts advise against its use, because the amount of active ingredient varies among individual brands and batches, making the effects unpredictable.

【33】Taking St John's wort with other medicines, such as antidepressants, anticonvulsants, anticoagulants and the contraceptive pill, can also cause serious health problems.

【34】You shouldn't take St John's wort if you're pregnant or breastfeeding, as it's unclear whether it's safe.

【35】Driving and operating machinery
-------------------------------

【36】Some antidepressants can cause dizziness, drowsiness and blurred vision, particularly when you first start taking them.

【37】If you do experience these problems, you should not drive or use tools and machinery.

【38】Cautions for specific antidepressants
-------------------------------------

【39】### SSRIs

【40】SSRIs may not be suitable if you have:

【41】*   bipolar disorder and you're in a manic phase (a period where you're extremely excitable), although they can be useful for depressive phases
*   a bleeding disorder
*   type 1 diabetes or type 2 diabetes
*   epilepsy – SSRIs should only be taken if your epilepsy is well controlled, and the medicine should be stopped if your epilepsy gets worse
*   kidney disease

【42】### SNRIs

【43】SNRIs may not be suitable if you have a history of heart disease or you have poorly controlled high blood pressure (hypertension).

【44】### Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs)

【45】TCAs may not be suitable if you have:

【46】*   a history of heart disease
*   recently had a heart attack
*   liver disease
*   an inherited blood disorder called porphyria
*   bipolar disorder
*   schizophrenia
*   a growth on your adrenal glands that is causing high blood pressure (pheochromocytoma)
*   an enlarged prostate gland (benign prostate enlargement)
*   glaucoma – increased pressure in the eye
*   epilepsy
删除11：<u>More in Antidepressants
-----------------------

【47】*   Overview - Antidepressants
*   Uses - Antidepressants
*   Cautions - Antidepressants
*   Dosage - Antidepressants
*   Side effects - Antidepressants
*   Alternatives - Antidepressants
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 4 November 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 4 November 2024</u>

source_info.title: Ulcerative colitis
source_info.text:
【0】Causes \- Ulcerative colitis
============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Causes
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Living with
6.  Complications</u>

【2】**The exact cause of ulcerative colitis is unknown, although it's thought to be the result of a problem with the immune system.**

【3】Autoimmune condition
--------------------

【4】The immune system is the body's defence against infection. Some experts believe ulcerative colitis is an autoimmune condition (when the immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue).

【5】The immune system normally fights off infections by releasing white blood cells into the blood to destroy the cause of the infection.

【6】This results in swelling and redness (inflammation) of body tissue in the infected area.

【7】In ulcerative colitis, a theory is that the immune system mistakes "friendly bacteria" in the colon, which aid digestion, as a harmful infection, leading to the colon and rectum becoming inflamed.

【8】Alternatively, some researchers believe a viral or bacterial infection triggers the immune system, but for some reason it does not "turn off" once the infection has passed and continues to cause inflammation.

【9】It's also been suggested that no infection is involved and the immune system may just malfunction, or that there's an imbalance between good and bad bacteria within the bowel.

【10】Genetics
--------

【11】It also seems inherited genes may be a factor in the development of ulcerative colitis.

【12】You may be more likely to have ulcerative colitis if you have a close relative with the condition.

【13】Researchers have identified several genes that seem to make people more likely to develop ulcerative colitis.

【14】It's believed many of these genes play a role in the immune system.

【15】Environmental factors
---------------------

【16】Where and how you live also seems to affect your chances of developing ulcerative colitis, which suggests environmental factors are important.

【17】For example, the condition is more common in urban areas of northern parts of western Europe and America.

【18】Various environmental factors that may be linked to ulcerative colitis have been studied, including air pollution, medicine and certain diets.

【19】Although no factors have so far been identified, countries with improved sanitation seem to have a higher population of people with the condition.

【20】This suggests that reduced exposure to bacteria may be an important factor.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 01 November 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 01 November 2025</u>

source_info.title: Glutaric aciduria type 1
source_info.text:
【0】Glutaric aciduria type 1
========================

【1】**Glutaric aciduria type 1 (GA1) is a rare but serious inherited condition. It means the body can't process certain amino acids ("building blocks" of protein), causing a harmful build-up of substances in the blood and urine.**

【2】Normally, our bodies break down protein foods like meat and fish into amino acids. Any amino acids that aren't needed are usually broken down and removed from the body.

【3】Babies with GA1 are unable to break down the amino acids lysine, hydroxylysine and tryptophan.

【4】Normally, these amino acids are broken down into a substance called glutaric acid, which is then converted into energy. Babies with GA1 don't have the enzyme that breaks down glutaric acid, leading to a harmfully high level of this and other substances in the body.

【5】Diagnosing GA1
--------------

【6】At around 5 days old, babies are now offered newborn blood spot screening to check if they have GA1. This involves pricking your baby's heel to collect drops of blood to test.

【7】If GA1 is diagnosed, treatment can be given straight away to reduce the risk of serious complications.

【8】With early diagnosis and the correct treatment, the majority of children with GA1 are able to live normal, healthy lives. However, treatment for GA1 must be continued for life.

【9】Without treatment, severe and life-threatening symptoms can develop, including seizures (fits) or falling into a coma. Some children with untreated GA1 are also at risk of brain damage, which can affect muscle movement. This may lead to problems with walking, talking and swallowing.

【10】Symptoms of GA1
---------------

【11】Symptoms of GA1 usually don't appear until a few months after birth, although some babies are born with a larger-than-average head (macrocephaly).

【12】Children with GA1 may develop some floppiness or weakness in their muscles (hypotonia) during their first year and there's a risk of developing bleeding around their brain (subdural haematoma). In rarer cases, bleeding can develop around the back of the eyes (retinal haemorrhage).

【13】Metabolic crisis
----------------

【14】Children with GA1 may have episodes known as a metabolic crisis, sometimes early in their life. Symptoms of a metabolic crisis include:

【15】*   poor feeding or loss of appetite
*   lack of energy
*   abnormal movements
*   vomiting
*   irritability
*   breathing difficulties

【16】It's important to get medical help immediately if your baby develops symptoms of a metabolic crisis. Your doctor will give you advice to help recognise the signs.

【17】In some cases, a metabolic crisis may be triggered later in childhood by an infection or illness. The hospital should provide you with emergency treatment instructions to follow if your child is ill, which helps to prevent these symptoms developing.

【18】Treating GA1
------------

【19】### Diet

【20】Children diagnosed with GA1 are referred to a specialist metabolic dietitian and given a low-protein diet. This is tailored to reduce the amount of amino acids your baby receives, especially lysine and tryptophan.

【21】High-protein foods need to be limited, including:

【22】*   meat
*   fish
*   cheese
*   eggs
*   pulses
*   nuts

【23】Your dietitian will provide detailed advice and guidance, as your baby still needs some of these foods for healthy growth and development.

【24】Breastfeeding and baby milk also need to be monitored and measured, as advised by your dietitian. Regular baby milk contains the amino acids that need to be restricted, so a special formula is used instead. This contains all the vitamins, minerals and other amino acids your baby needs.

【25】People with GA1 may need to follow a restricted protein diet for the rest of their life to reduce their risk of a metabolic crisis. As your child gets older, they'll need to learn how to control their diet and stay in contact with a dietitian for advice and monitoring.

【26】### Medication

【27】Your child will be prescribed a medication called L-carnitine, which helps to clear some of the excess glutaric acid.

【28】L-carnitine is given as a tablet and needs to be taken regularly, as directed by your doctor.

【29】### Emergency treatment

【30】If your baby develops an infection, such as a high temperature or cold, their risk of having a metabolic crisis increases. It's possible to reduce the risk by changing to an emergency diet while they're ill.

【31】Your dietitian will provide detailed instructions, but the aim is to replace milk and food containing protein with special high-sugar drinks. Medication should still be taken as normal.

【32】Your dietitian may provide you with a feeding tube (nasogastric tube) and show you how to use it safely. This can be useful in an emergency if your baby isn't feeding well while they are ill.

【33】Contact the metabolic team at the hospital when your baby becomes unwell, and let them know you have started the emergency diet.

【34】If your baby can't keep down their emergency feeds, has a high temperature that does not go down, or their symptoms are getting worse, take your baby straight to the accident and emergency (A&E) department.

【35】You should also have been provided with a leaflet to bring with you in case of an emergency, in case the doctors haven't seen GA1 before.

【36】Once in hospital, your baby can be monitored and treated with intravenous fluids (given directly into a vein).

【37】You should also take your baby to hospital if they develop symptoms of a metabolic crisis, such as irritability, loss of energy or breathing difficulties.

【38】How GA1 is inherited
--------------------

【39】The genetic cause (mutation) of GA1 is passed on by the parents, who usually don't have any symptoms of the condition.

【40】The way this mutation is passed on is known as autosomal recessive inheritance. This means a baby needs to receive 2 copies of the affected gene to develop the condition – 1 from their mother and 1 from their father. If the baby only receives 1 affected gene, they'll just be a carrier of GA1.

【41】If you're a carrier of the affected gene and you have a baby with a partner who's also a carrier, your baby has:

【42】*   a 25% chance of developing the condition
*   a 50% chance of being a carrier of GA1
*   a 25% chance of receiving a pair of unaffected genes

【43】Although it's not possible to prevent GA1, it's important to let your midwife and doctor know if you have a family history of the condition. Any further children you have can be tested for the condition as soon as possible and given appropriate treatment.

【44】You may also wish to consider genetic counselling for support, information and advice about genetic conditions.

【45】Information about you
---------------------

【46】If you or your child has GA1, your clinical team will pass information about you/your child on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

【47】This helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat this condition. You can opt out of the register at any time.
删除7：<u>Find out more about the NCARDRS on GOV.UK</u>
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 24 May 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 24 May 2025</u>

source_info.title: Benzoyl peroxide
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while using benzoyl peroxide \- Brand name: Acnecide
===========================================================================================

【1】Benzoyl peroxide and pregnancy
------------------------------

【2】You can use benzoyl peroxide during pregnancy. It is applied to the skin and the small amount that might pass to your baby should not cause any problems.

【3】Benzoyl peroxide and breastfeeding
----------------------------------

【4】It's OK to use benzoyl peroxide while you're breastfeeding. It is very unlikely that any will get into your breast milk.

【5】When using benzoyl peroxide, be careful that your baby does not come into contact with the areas of your body you have put it on. Wash your hands after you have applied it and before picking up your baby.

【6】It's best to avoid putting benzoyl peroxide on your chest area if possible, but if you do need to use it, wash it off before feeding your baby.

【7】Benzoyl peroxide and fertility
------------------------------

【8】There's no evidence that benzoyl peroxide affects fertility in either men or women.

【9】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【10】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding
删除11：<u>More in Benzoyl peroxide
------------------------

【11】*   About benzoyl peroxide
*   Who can and cannot use it
*   How and when to use it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility

source_info.title: Timolol eye drops
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about timolol eye drops \- Brand names: Eysano, Timoptol, Timoptol LA, Tiopex
==============================================================================================

【1】How do timolol eye drops work?

【2】Timolol eye drops are a type of medicine called a beta blocker. They're used to reduce high pressure in the eye that can cause glaucoma and ocular hypertension.

【3】It is thought to work by reducing the amount of fluid that fills the front part of your eye, which lowers the pressure within your eye and stops your sight from getting worse.

【4】Are there any long-term side effects?

【5】You can use timolol eye drops for a long time. Most people use them for many years with no problems.

【6】How does it compare with other medicines for glaucoma?

【7】Timolol eye drops work as well as other beta blockers for reducing pressure in your eye. Other beta blocker eye drops include betaxolol and levobunolol which may be used instead of timolol.

【8】There are other eye drops which work in different ways to timolol eye drops but can also be used to lower the pressure in your eye. They include:

【9】*   prostaglandin analogues – for example, latanoprost and bimatoprost
*   carbonic anhydrase inhibitors – for example brinzolamide and dorzolamide
*   sympathomimetics – for e click angina xample brimonidine and apraclonidine
*   miotics – for example pilocarpine

【10】Sometimes you might have to try other eye drops if you get side effects with timolol.

【11】Many people need to use a combination of different eye drops to reduce the pressure in the eye.

【12】Can timolol eye drops make heart problems worse?

【13】If you have an existing heart condition, there are no reports of timolol making it worse.

【14】But in rare cases, side effects of timolol can include chest pain (angina) or an irregular heart rate (palpitations).

【15】These side effects are unlikely to happen with timolol eye drops. This is because less, if any, of the medicine enters your body than if you were taking timolol tablets.

【16】Speak to your doctor or pharmacist before you start using timolol eye drops if you have a heart condition.

【17】Will it affect my contraception?

【18】Timolol eye drops do not stop any type of contraception from working, including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【19】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【20】Using timolol eye drops may cause side effects which affect your ability to drive, ride a bike or use tools or machinery. These side effects include feeling dizzy or tired, or changes in your eyesight such as blurred vision.

【21】If this happens to you, do not drive a car, ride a bike, or use tools or machinery until you feel well and you can see clearly again.

【22】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【23】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking timolol tablets删除7：<u> GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.</u>

【24】Many people with glaucoma can continue driving a car or motorbike, but their eyesight must meet the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency’s (DVLA) standards.

【25】Can I drink alcohol while using timolol eye drops?

【26】Yes, you can drink alcohol while using timolol eye drops.

【27】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【28】You can eat and drink normally while using timolol eye drops.
删除11：<u>More in Timolol eye drops
-------------------------

【29】*   About timolol eye drops
*   Who can and cannot use them
*   How and when to use them
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Using timolol eye drops with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 25 August 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 25 August 2025</u>

source_info.title: Epilepsy
source_info.text:
【0】Symptoms \- Epilepsy
====================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Living with</u>

【2】**The main symptom of epilepsy is repeated seizures. These are sudden bursts of electrical activity in the brain that temporarily affect how it works.**

【3】Seizures can affect people in different ways, depending on which part of the brain is involved.

【4】Some seizures cause the body to jerk and shake (a "fit"), while others cause problems like loss of awareness or unusual sensations. They typically pass in a few seconds or minutes.

【5】Seizures can occur when you're awake or asleep. Sometimes they can be triggered by something, such as feeling very tired.

【6】Read about what to do if someone has a seizure

【7】Types of seizures
-----------------

【8】### Simple partial (focal) seizures or 'auras'

【9】A simple partial seizure can cause:

【10】*   a general strange feeling that's hard to describe
*   a "rising" feeling in your tummy – like the sensation in your stomach when on a fairground ride
*   a feeling that events have happened before (déjà vu)
*   unusual smells or tastes
*   tingling in your arms and legs
*   an intense feeling of fear or joy
*   stiffness or twitching in part of your body, such as an arm or hand

【11】You remain awake and aware while this happens.

【12】These seizures are sometimes known as "warnings" or "auras" because they can be a sign that another type of seizure is about to happen.

【13】### Complex partial (focal) seizures

【14】During a complex partial seizure, you lose your sense of awareness and make random body movements, such as:

【15】*   smacking your lips
*   rubbing your hands
*   making random noises
*   moving your arms around
*   picking at clothes or fiddling with objects
*   chewing or swallowing

【16】You will not be able to respond to anyone else during the seizure and you will not have any memory of it.

【17】### Tonic-clonic seizures

【18】A tonic-clonic seizure, previously known as a "grand mal", is what most people think of as a typical epileptic fit.

【19】They happen in 2 stages – an initial "tonic" stage, shortly followed by a second "clonic" stage:

【20】1.  **tonic stage** – you lose consciousness, your body goes stiff, and you may fall to the floor
2.  **clonic stage** – your limbs jerk about, you may lose control of your bladder or bowel, you may bite your tongue or the inside of your cheek, and you might have difficulty breathing

【21】The seizure normally stops after a few minutes, but some last longer. Afterwards, you may have a headache or difficulty remembering what happened and feel tired or confused.

【22】### Absences

【23】An absence seizure, which used to be called a "petit mal", is where you lose awareness of your surroundings for a short time. They mainly affect children, but can happen at any age.

【24】During an absence seizure, a person may:

【25】*   stare blankly into space
*   look like they're "daydreaming"
*   flutter their eyes
*   make slight jerking movements of their body or limbs

【26】The seizures usually only last up to 15 seconds and you will not be able to remember them. They can happen several times a day.

【27】### Myoclonic seizures

【28】A myoclonic seizure is where some or all of your body suddenly twitches or jerks, like you've had an electric shock. They often happen soon after waking up.

【29】Myoclonic seizures usually only last a fraction of a second, but several can sometimes occur in a short space of time. You normally remain awake during them.

【30】### Clonic seizures

【31】Clonic seizures cause the body to shake and jerk like a tonic-clonic seizure, but you do not go stiff at the start.

【32】They typically last a few minutes and you might lose consciousness.

【33】### Tonic seizures

【34】Tonic seizures cause all your muscles to suddenly become stiff, like the first stage of a tonic-clonic seizure.

【35】This might mean you lose balance and fall over.

【36】### Atonic seizures

【37】Atonic seizures cause all your muscles to suddenly relax, so you may fall to the ground.

【38】They tend to be very brief and you'll usually be able to get up again straight away.

【39】### Status epilepticus

【40】Status epilepticus is the name for any seizure that lasts a long time, or a series of seizures where the person does not regain consciousness in between.

【41】It's a medical emergency and needs to be treated as soon as possible.

【42】You can be trained to treat it if you look after someone with epilepsy. If you have not had any training, call 999 for an ambulance immediately if someone has a seizure that has not stopped after 5 minutes.

【43】Seizure triggers
----------------

【44】For many people with epilepsy, seizures seem to happen randomly.

【45】But sometimes they can have a trigger, such as:

【46】*   stress
*   a lack of sleep
*   waking up
*   drinking alcohol
*   some medicines and illegal drugs
*   in women, monthly periods
*   flashing lights (this is an uncommon trigger)

【47】Keeping a diary of when you have seizures and what happened before them can help you identify and avoid some possible triggers.

【48】Read more advice about living with epilepsy.
删除6：<u>**Want to know more?**

【49】*   Epilepsy Action: common seizure triggers
*   Epilepsy Action: epileptic seizures explained
*   Epilepsy Society: epileptic seizures
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 18 September 2020  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 18 September 2023</u>
</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Epilepsy</u>删除1：<u>*   Next : Diagnosis</u>

source_info.title: What infections can I catch through oral sex?
source_info.text:
【0】What infections can I catch through oral sex?
=============================================

【1】Oral sex is the stimulation of the genitals using the mouth and tongue. It is one of the ways that sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are most frequently passed on.

【2】You can catch an STI if you have just one sexual partner. However, the more partners you have, the greater the risk of catching an infection.

【3】STIs commonly caught through oral sex are:

【4】*   gonorrhoea
*   genital herpes
*   syphilis
*   human papillomavirus (HPV)

【5】Infections less frequently passed on through oral sex include:

【6】*   chlamydia
*   HIV
*   hepatitis A, hepatitis B and hepatitis C
*   genital warts
*   pubic lice

【7】Symptoms of STIs
----------------

【8】The symptoms of an STI vary depending on the type of infection. However, most STIs are treatable if detected early enough.

【9】If you think you may have an infection, or if you have had unprotected sex, it's important to visit your GP or local sexual health or genitourinary medicine (GUM) clinic as soon as possible.

【10】If left untreated, STIs not only are uncomfortable and embarrassing but also can seriously affect your health and fertility.

【11】Preventing STIs
---------------

【12】You can reduce the risk of STI transmission during oral sex by making sure you or your partner wears a condom.

【13】You can use a dental dam to cover the anus or female genitals during oral sex. A dental dam is a latex or polyurethane (very thin, soft plastic) square, of about 15cm by 15cm. It acts as a barrier to help prevent STIs passing from one person to another.

【14】Read the answers to more questions about sexual health.
删除6：<u>Further information
-------------------

【15】*   Visiting an STI clinic
*   Sex activities and risk
*   Sexually transmitted infections (STIs)
*   Sexwise: oral sex and STIs
</u>
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 12 July 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 12 July 2024</u>

source_info.title: Mastocytosis
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Mastocytosis
========================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Treatment</u>

【2】**Mastocytosis is a rare condition caused by an excess number of mast cells gathering in the body's tissues.**

【3】There are 2 main types of mastocytosis:

【4】*   **cutaneous mastocytosis, which mainly affects children** – where mast cells gather in the skin, but are not found in large numbers elsewhere in the body
*   **systemic mastocytosis, which mainly affects adults** – where mast cells gather in body tissues, such as the skin, internal organs and bones

【5】There are also several subtypes of systemic mastocytosis, depending on the symptoms.

【6】Mast cells
----------

【7】Mast cells are produced in the bone marrow, the spongy tissue found in the hollow centres of some bones, and live longer than normal cells. They're an important part of the immune system and help fight infection.

【8】When mast cells detect a substance that triggers an allergic reaction (an allergen), they release histamine and other chemicals into the bloodstream.

【9】Histamine makes the blood vessels expand and the surrounding skin itchy and swollen. It can also create a build-up of mucus in the airways, which become narrower.

【10】Symptoms of mastocytosis
------------------------

【11】The symptoms of mastocytosis can vary depending on the type.

【12】### Cutaneous mastocytosis

【13】The most common symptom of cutaneous mastocytosis is abnormal growths (lesions) on the skin, such as bumps and spots, which can form on the body and sometimes blister.

【14】### Systemic mastocytosis

【15】Some people with systemic mastocytosis may experience episodes of severe symptoms, often with specific triggers such as physical exertion or stress. Many people do not have any problems.

【16】During an episode you may have:

【17】*   skin reactions – such as itching and flushing
*   gut symptoms – such as diarrhoea and vomiting
*   muscle and joint pain
*   mood changes, headaches and tiredness (fatigue)

【18】There are 3 main subtypes of systemic mastocytosis. They are:

【19】*   **indolent systemic mastocytosis** – symptoms are usually mild to moderate and vary from person to person; indolent systemic mastocytosis accounts for around 90% of adult systemic mastocytosis cases
*   **aggressive mastocytosis** – where mast cells multiply in organs, such as the spleen, liver and digestive system; the symptoms are more wide-ranging and severe, although skin lesions are less common
*   **systemic mastocytosis with associated blood (haematological) disease** – where a condition that affects the blood cells, such as chronic leukaemia, also develops

【20】### Severe allergic reaction

【21】People with mastocytosis have an increased risk of developing a severe and life-threatening allergic reaction. This is known as anaphylaxis.

【22】The increased risk of anaphylaxis is caused by the abnormally high number of mast cells and their potential to release large amounts of histamine into the blood.

【23】If you or your child has mastocytosis, you may need to carry an adrenaline auto-injector, which can be used to treat the symptoms of anaphylaxis. 
删除7：<u>Read more about the symptoms of mastocytosis.</u>

【24】Causes of mastocytosis
----------------------

【25】The cause or causes of mastocytosis are not fully known, but there's thought to be an association with a change in genes known as the KIT mutation.

【26】The KIT mutation makes the mast cells more sensitive to the effects of a signalling protein called stem cell factor (SCF).

【27】SCF plays an important role in stimulating the production and survival of certain cells, such as blood cells and mast cells, inside the bone marrow.  

【28】In very few cases of mastocytosis it appears the KIT mutation is passed down through families. However, in most cases the mutation happens for no apparent reason.

【29】Diagnosing mastocytosis
-----------------------

【30】A physical examination of the skin is the first stage in diagnosing cutaneous mastocytosis.

【31】Your GP or skin specialist (dermatologist) may rub the affected areas of skin to see if they become red, inflamed and itchy. This is known as Darier's sign.

【32】It's usually possible to confirm a diagnosis by carrying out a biopsy, where a small skin sample is taken and checked for mast cells.

【33】The following tests are commonly used to look for systemic mastocytosis:

【34】*   blood tests – including a full blood count (FBC) and measuring blood tryptase levels
*   an ultrasound scan to look for enlargement of the liver and spleen if it seems likely
*   a DEXA scan to measure bone density
*   a bone marrow biopsy test – where a local anaesthetic is used and a long needle is inserted through the skin into the bone underneath, usually in the pelvis

【35】A diagnosis of systemic mastocytosis is usually made by finding typical changes on a bone marrow biopsy.

【36】Treating mastocytosis
---------------------

【37】There's no cure for mastocytosis, so the aim of treatment is to try to relieve the symptoms.

【38】Treatment options will depend on the type of mastocytosis and the severity of the symptoms.

【39】Mild to moderate cases of cutaneous mastocytosis can be treated with steroid cream (topical corticosteroids) for a short time.

【40】Steroid cream reduces the number of mast cells that can release histamine and trigger swelling (inflammation) in the skin.

【41】Antihistamines can also be used to treat the symptoms of cutaneous or indolent mastocytosis, such as red skin and itchiness.

【42】Antihistamines are a type of medicine that block the effects of histamine and are often used to treat allergic conditions.
删除7：<u>Read more about treating mastocytosis.</u>

【43】Complications of mastocytosis
-----------------------------

【44】In children, the symptoms of cutaneous mastocytosis usually improve over time, but remain stable in adults.

【45】In many cases the condition gets better on its own by the time a child has reached puberty.

【46】The outlook for systemic mastocytosis can vary, depending on the type you have.

【47】Indolent systemic mastocytosis should not affect life expectancy, but other types can. 

【48】A few people develop a serious blood condition, such as chronic leukaemia, over their lifetime.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 30 December 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 30 December 2025</u>

source_info.title: Having an operation (surgery)
source_info.text:
【0】Before surgery \- Having an operation (surgery)
===============================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Seeing a specialist
3.  Before surgery
4.  On the day
5.  After surgery
6.  Getting back to normal</u>

【2】**In the days leading up to your surgery, you'll need to make travel arrangements for getting to and from the hospital and think about what to pack.**

【3】Make sure you give your family and friends plenty of notice about your operation so they can take time off work to be with you, if necessary.

【4】Check your hospital's policy on visiting times and let your family and friends know.
删除7：<u>Read more about visiting someone in hospital.</u>

【5】Your hospital should contact you with more information before you come in. Details of what you need to do will vary depending on the hospital.

【6】They might ask you to wear a face covering over your nose and mouth, test to check if you have COVID-19 or self-isolate before you go into hospital.

【7】Check the hospital's website for more information.

【8】Find the contact details of a hospital

【9】Pre-operative assessment
------------------------

【10】At some hospitals, you'll be asked to attend a pre-operative assessment. This is an appointment with a nurse, either in person or as a video or telephone call.

【11】You'll be asked questions about your health, medical history and home circumstances.

【12】If the assessment involves a visit to the hospital, some tests may be carried out.

【13】This is to check if you have any medical problems that might need to be treated before your operation, or if you'll need special care during or after the surgery.

【14】The tests you have will depend on what operation and the kind of anaesthetic you're having.

【15】These tests might include a COVID-19 test, blood tests, urine tests and pregnancy test for women.

【16】This assessment will usually happen one or more days before your operation.

【17】Make sure you know the results of any previous tests, as well as all the medicines, vitamins and herbal supplements you take.

【18】You'll be given clear information on:

【19】*   whether you need to stop eating and drinking in the hours before your operation
*   whether you should stop taking your usual medicines before going into hospital
*   what to bring with you into hospital
*   whether you'll need to stay in hospital overnight and, if so, for how long
删除3：<u>### Video: Pre-operative assessments

【20】Watch this video to find out what a pre-operative assessment involves.
删除1：<u>Media last reviewed: 1 April 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Media review due: 1 April 2024</u>

【21】</u>
Importance of not eating (fasting)
----------------------------------

【22】If your doctor has instructed you not to eat (fast) before the operation, it's important that you do not eat or drink anything – this includes light snacks, sweets and water.

【23】You need an empty stomach during surgery so you do not vomit while you're under anaesthetic.

【24】If you take insulin because of diabetes, you'll still need to avoid eating and drinking before surgery, but make sure your medical team is aware of your condition so appropriate precautions can be taken.

【25】Hygiene
-------

【26】You'll need to remove all body piercings, make-up and nail polish before your operation.

【27】This can help reduce unwanted bacteria being brought into the hospital. It also helps doctors to see your skin and nails to make sure your blood circulation is healthy.

【28】Some hospitals may request that you have a bath or shower before coming in for your surgery, or have one once you arrive.

【29】What to pack for hospital
-------------------------

【30】If you're staying in hospital, you may wish to pack:

【31】*   a nightdress or pyjamas
*   day clothes
*   clean underwear
*   dressing gown and slippers
*   small hand towel
*   toiletries – soap, toothbrush, toothpaste, shampoo, deodorant
*   sanitary towels or tampons
*   razor and shaving materials
*   comb or hairbrush
*   book or magazines
*   small amount of money
*   medicines you normally take, and a list of the doses for each medicine
*   glasses or contact lenses with case
*   notebook and pen
*   healthy snacks
*   address book and important phone numbers, including your GP's contact details

【32】You may want to check with your hospital about their policy on the use of mobile phones, MP3 players and laptops or tablets during your hospital stay.

【33】Remember to bring your appointment card or admission letter with you, too.

【34】Getting to and from hospital
----------------------------

【35】Think about how you'll get to the hospital and back again. You will not be able to drive yourself home, so you should arrange transport or ask a friend or relative to help.

【36】In some cases, the hospital may be able to arrange transport home for you.

【37】Some hospitals charge for parking. You may be able to check whether you have to pay for parking at your chosen hospital by finding your hospital and selecting "facilities".

【38】Cancelling
----------

【39】If you're unable to attend your hospital appointment or do not feel well enough to have your operation, let the hospital know as soon as possible. They'll be able to talk to you about rearranging the appointment.

【40】Let your surgeon know if you develop a cough, cold or high temperature a few days before surgery. They'll advise whether your operation can go ahead.
删除3：<u>Video: How to prepare for your child's hospital stay
----------------------------------------------------

【41】This video is a practical guide on how to prepare for your child going into hospital.
删除1：<u>Media last reviewed: 16 April 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Media review due: 16 April 2024</u>
