source_info.title: Simeticone
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take simeticone \- Brand names: Wind-eze, WindSetlers, Infacol, Dentinox Colic Drops
=======================================================================================================

【1】Who can take simeticone
-----------------------

【2】Most adults and children, including newborn babies, can take simeticone.

【3】Who may not be able to take simeticone
--------------------------------------

【4】Simeticone is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you or your child, tell a pharmacist or doctor if you (or your child):

【5】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to simeticone or any ingredients it is combined with
*   are having treatment for a thyroid problem

【6】Simeticone often comes combined with other ingredients. It's important to read the leaflet that comes with the medicine, or the information printed on the box or bottle, to make sure the medicine is suitable for you or your child.

【7】If you're not sure, ask a doctor or a pharmacist for advice.
删除11：<u>More in Simeticone
------------------

【8】*   About simeticone
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 13 October 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 13 October 2025</u>

source_info.title: Laryngeal (larynx) cancer
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Laryngeal (larynx) cancer
=====================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Causes
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Recovery
6.  Prevention</u>

【2】**Laryngeal cancer is a type of cancer that affects the larynx (voice box).**

【3】The larynx is part of the throat found at the entrance of the windpipe (trachea). It plays an important role in helping you breathe and speak.

【4】In the UK, there are more than 2,000 new cases of laryngeal cancer each year.

【5】The condition is more common in people over the age of 60. It's more common in men than women.

【6】Symptoms of laryngeal cancer
----------------------------

【7】The main symptom of laryngeal cancer is having a hoarse voice for more than 3 weeks.

【8】Other symptoms include:

【9】*   a change in your voice, such as sounding hoarse
*   pain when swallowing or difficulty swallowing
*   a lump or swelling in your neck
*   a long-lasting cough or breathlessness
*   a persistent sore throat or earache
*   a high-pitched wheezing noise when you breathe
*   in severe cases, difficulty breathing

【10】Some people may also experience bad breath, unintentional weight loss, or fatigue (extreme tiredness).

【11】When to see your GP
-------------------

【12】You should see a GP if you have had a hoarse voice for more than 3 weeks.

【13】These symptoms are often caused by less serious conditions, such as laryngitis, but it's a good idea to get them checked out.

【14】If necessary, your GP can refer you to a hospital specialist for further tests to confirm or rule out cancer.
删除7：<u>Read more about diagnosing laryngeal cancer.</u>

【15】What causes laryngeal cancer
----------------------------

【16】It's not clear exactly what causes laryngeal cancer, but your risk of getting the condition is increased by:

【17】*   smoking tobacco
*   regularly drinking large amounts of alcohol
*   having family members (such as a parent, brother, sister or child) who have had laryngeal cancer
*   having an unhealthy diet low in fruit and vegetables
*   exposure to certain chemicals and substances, such as asbestos and coal dust

【18】By adopting a healthy lifestyle, including avoiding alcohol and tobacco, you can significantly reduce your chances of developing laryngeal cancer.
删除7：<u>Read more about the causes of laryngeal cancer and preventing laryngeal cancer.</u>

【19】How laryngeal cancer is treated
-------------------------------

【20】The main treatments for laryngeal cancer are radiotherapy, surgery, chemotherapy and targeted cancer medicines.

【21】Radiotherapy or surgery to remove the cancerous cells from the larynx can often cure laryngeal cancer if it's diagnosed early.

【22】If the cancer is advanced, a combination of surgery to remove part or all of the larynx, radiotherapy and chemotherapy can be used.

【23】If you have surgery to remove your larynx, you'll no longer be able to speak or breathe in the usual way.

【24】Instead, you will breathe through a permanent hole in your neck (stoma) and will need additional treatment and speech and language therapy to help you communicate.

【25】This may include a valve being placed in your throat, or using an electrical device you hold against your throat to produce sound.
删除7：<u>Read more about treating laryngeal cancer and recovering from laryngeal cancer surgery.</u>

【26】Outlook
-------

【27】The outlook for laryngeal cancer depends on the extent of the cancer when it's diagnosed and treated.

【28】Fortunately, most laryngeal cancers are diagnosed at an early stage, which means the outlook is generally better than some other types of cancer.

【29】Overall, about 65 out of every 100 people will live for 5 years or more after diagnosis, and about 55 out of every 100 people will live for 10 years or more.

【30】If you smoke, stopping smoking after being diagnosed with laryngeal cancer may improve your outlook.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 21 October 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 21 October 2024</u>
删除1：<u>*   Next : Causes</u>

source_info.title: Letrozole
source_info.text:
【0】About letrozole \- Brand name: Femara
=====================================

【1】Letrozole is a medicine used to treat breast cancer and help to prevent breast cancer coming back.

【2】It's mainly prescribed for women who have been through the menopause and have a type of cancer called hormone-dependent breast cancer.

【3】Most people who take letrozole will have had primary treatment such as surgery, radiotherapy or sometimes chemotherapy to treat their breast cancer first. Letrozole is an additional (adjuvant) treatment which helps stop the cancer coming back.

【4】Letrozole is sometimes given alongside another breast cancer medicine, called tamoxifen.

【5】Letrozole is available on prescription only and comes as tablets.

【6】It can also be used:

【7】*   to prevent breast cancer if you're high risk and have been through the menopause
*   to treat cancer if you cannot have surgery, or to shrink the cancer before surgery if you cannot have chemotherapy

【8】It can sometimes be used to treat breast cancer in men, or in women who have not reached the menopause.

【9】Letrozole can occasionally be used as a fertility treatment if you have polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). If you're taking it as a fertility treatment and you need more information, speak to your specialist.
删除7：<u>Find out more about medicines used as fertility treatments.</u>
删除7：<u>Find out more about polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).</u>

【10】Key facts
---------

【11】*   You'll usually take letrozole once a day. Try to take it at the same time each day.
*   Most people take letrozole for 5 years, but some will take it for up to 10 years.
*   Common side effects include symptoms similar to the menopause such as hot flushes, tiredness and low mood. Side effects usually improve after a few months.
*   Your doctor will monitor your blood pressure, cholesterol levels and bone density during your treatment.
*   If letrozole makes you feel tired or dizzy, or if you get blurred vision, do not drive a car, ride a bike, or use tools or machinery until you feel better.
删除11：<u>More in Letrozole
-----------------

【12】*   About letrozole
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 24 November 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 24 November 2026</u>

source_info.title: Varicose veins
source_info.text:
【0】Complications \- Varicose veins
===============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Causes
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Complications</u>

【2】**Varicose veins can cause complications because they stop your blood flowing properly.**

【3】Most people who have varicose veins will not develop complications. If they do, it's usually several years after varicose veins first appear.

【4】Bleeding
--------

【5】Varicose veins near the surface of your skin can sometimes bleed if you cut or bump your leg. The bleeding may be difficult to stop.

【6】You should lie down, raise your leg and apply direct pressure to the wound. Seek immediate medical advice if this does not stop the bleeding.

【7】Blood clots
-----------

【8】If blood clots form in veins located just under the surface of your skin (superficial veins), it could lead to conditions such as: 

【9】*   **thrombophlebitis** – swelling (inflammation) of the veins in your leg
*   **deep vein thrombosis** – which can cause pain and swelling in the leg, and may lead to serious complications like pulmonary embolism
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 07 May 2020  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 07 May 2023</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Treatment</u>

source_info.title: Levothyroxine
source_info.text:
【0】Levothyroxine \- Brand name: Eltroxin
=====================================
删除10：<u>On this page
------------

【1】1.  About levothyroxine
2.  Key facts
3.  Who can and cannot take levothyroxine
4.  How and when to take levothyroxine
5.  Side effects
6.  Pregnancy and breastfeeding
7.  Cautions with other medicines
8.  Common questions about levothyroxine</u>

【2】1\. About levothyroxine
-----------------------

【3】Levothyroxine is a medicine used to treat an underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism).

【4】The thyroid gland makes thyroid hormones which help to control energy levels and growth. Levothyroxine is taken to replace the missing thyroid hormone thyroxine.

【5】Levothyroxine is only available on prescription. It comes as tablets or as a liquid that you swallow.

【6】2\. Key facts
-------------

【7】*   Levothyroxine is a synthetic version of a hormone called thyroxine. It replaces thyroxine if your thyroid gland cannot produce it and prevents the symptoms of hypothyroidism.
*   Levothyroxine starts working straight away, but it may be several weeks before your symptoms start to improve.
*   The most common side effects of levothyroxine are caused by taking a bigger dose than you need. Your doctor can lower your dose to help reduce any side effects.
*   Before you start taking levothyroxine, your doctor will do a blood test. Once you start taking the medicine you'll have regular blood tests to see how well it's working.
*   Levothyroxine doses need to be carefully monitored during pregnancy. If you're planning to become pregnant or think you may be pregnant, it's important to talk to your doctor to get the right care for you and your baby.

【8】3\. Who can and cannot take levothyroxine
-----------------------------------------

【9】Levothyroxine can be taken by most adults and children. However, it’s not suitable for some people.

【10】Check with your doctor before taking levothyroxine if you:

【11】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to levothyroxine or any other medicine
*   you have an overactive thyroid that produces too much thyroid hormone (thyrotoxicosis)
*   have a health problem that affects your adrenal glands (your doctor will be able to tell you if you're not sure)
*   have a heart problem including angina, heart disease or heart failure
*   have high blood pressure
*   have ever had a heart attack
*   have diabetes – the dose of your diabetes medicine may need to change because levothyroxine can raise blood sugar levels

【12】4\. How and when to take levothyroxine
--------------------------------------

【13】Take levothyroxine once a day in the morning, ideally at least 30 minutes before having breakfast or a drink containing caffeine, like tea or coffee.

【14】Food and caffeinated drinks can both stop your body taking in levothyroxine properly so it does not work as well.

【15】If you stop taking levothyroxine, your symptoms are likely to come back.

【16】### Dosage and strength

【17】The dose of levothyroxine varies from person to person.

【18】You may need to take several different tablets to make up your dose. Your doctor will tell you how many tablets to take each day.

【19】Levothyroxine comes in 12.5 microgram, 25 microgram, 50 microgram, 75 microgram and 100 microgram tablets.

【20】If you're taking levothyroxine as a liquid, 5ml can have 25 micrograms, 50 micrograms, 100 micrograms or 125micrograms in it.

【21】Although starting doses are usually the same, the dose of levothyroxine you end up taking, or how quickly the dose is increased, depends on your symptoms, hormone levels, age and whether you have any other health problems.

【22】Adults usually start with a dose between 50 micrograms and 100 micrograms taken once a day. This may be increased gradually over a few weeks to between 100 micrograms and 200 micrograms taken once a day.

【23】Some people, such as over-50s or people with heart disease, may start on a lower dose.

【24】### How to take levothyroxine

【25】Swallow the tablets whole with a drink of water.

【26】Levothyroxine is available as a liquid for children and people who find it difficult to swallow tablets. It’s available in different strengths.

【27】If you or your child are taking levothyroxine as a liquid, it will usually come with a plastic syringe or spoon to help you measure out the right dose.

【28】If you do not have a syringe or measuring spoon, ask your pharmacist for one. Do not use a kitchen teaspoon as it will not give the right amount.

【29】### If you forget to take it

【30】If you forget to take a dose, take it as soon as you remember, unless it's almost time for your next dose. In this case just skip the forgotten dose and take the next one at the usual time.

【31】Do not take 2 doses together to make up for a missed dose.

【32】If you often forget doses, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to take your medicine.

【33】### If you take too much

【34】Taking more than your prescribed dose of levothyroxine can give you symptoms such as a racing heartbeat (palpitations).

【35】#### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【36】*   you take more than 1 extra dose of levothyroxine

【37】Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111

【38】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 if:

【39】*   you get chest pains – these may not happen immediately, it can be several days before they begin

【40】### Having regular blood tests

【41】Your doctor will do regular blood tests to check the levels of thyroid hormones in your body before and after starting levothyroxine.

【42】These will allow your doctor to adjust the dose to suit you.

【43】At the start of treatment you can expect to have blood tests quite often but once your hormone levels are stable and your symptoms are under control, your levels will usually be checked once a year.

【44】You may need blood tests more often if you:

【45】*   are pregnant
*   start or stop a medicine that can affect the way levothyroxine works
*   have any symptoms that could mean your dose is not quite right

【46】5\. Side effects
----------------

【47】Like all medicines, levothyroxine can cause side effects, although not everyone gets them. Once you are on the right dose of levothyroxine, side effects should go away.

【48】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you have switched to a different brand of levothyroxine and start to get:

【49】*   symptoms of an underactive thyroid including feeling tired, weight gain or feeling depressed
*   symptoms of an overactive thyroid (similar to the common side effects below)

【50】You may be sensitive to the new brand of levothyroxine you have been prescribed and may need to stay on the one you were taking before.

【51】### Common side effects

【52】The common side effects of levothyroxine usually happen because the dose you're taking is more than you need. These side effects usually go away after you go on to a lower dose of levothyroxine or stop treatment.

【53】Common side effects are the same as the symptoms of an overactive thyroid. There are things you can do to help cope with them.

【54】Feeling sick (nausea)

【55】Stick to simple meals and do not eat rich or spicy food.

【56】Being sick (vomiting)

【57】If you're being sick try to take small, frequent sips of fluids, such as water or squash, to prevent dehydration. Speak to a pharmacist if you have signs of dehydration, such as peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee. If you are vomiting due to a stomach bug or illness, tell your doctor. Do not take any other medicines to treat vomiting without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor first.

【58】If you take contraceptive pills and you're being sick, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet for advice.

【59】Diarrhoea

【60】Drink plenty of water to prevent dehydration. Speak to a pharmacist if you have signs of dehydration, such as peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee. If you get severe diarrhoea from a stomach bug or illness, tell your doctor. Do not take any other medicines to treat diarrhoea without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor first.

【61】If you take contraceptive pills and you have severe diarrhoea for over 24 hours, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet for advice.

【62】Headaches

【63】Make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Do not drink too much alcohol. Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller. Talk to your doctor if they last longer than a week or are severe.

【64】Feeling restless or excitable, or problems sleeping

【65】These symptoms should improve as your body gets used to levothyroxine. If it does not go away, or if it's causing you problems, contact your doctor.

【66】Flushing or sweating

【67】Try cutting down on coffee, tea and alcohol. It might help to keep the room cool and use a fan. You could also spray your face with cool water or sip cold or iced drinks. If it does not go away, contact your doctor as they may need to review your dose .

【68】Muscle cramps

【69】If you get unusual muscle aches, which is not from exercise or hard work, talk to your doctor. You may need a blood test to find the cause.

【70】Shaking, usually of the hands

【71】Talk to your doctor as you may need to have your dose reduced.

【72】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if these side effects bother you or do not go away.

【73】### Serious side effects

【74】It happens rarely, but some people may have serious side effects when taking levothyroxine.

【75】Tell your doctor or call 111 now if:

【76】*   you get fast or irregular heartbeats (palpitations)

【77】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【78】*   you get chest pain

【79】Find your nearest A&E

【80】#### Serious allergic reaction

【81】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to levothyroxine.

【82】##### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【83】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【84】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【85】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【86】These are not all the side effects of levothyroxine. For a full list see the leaflet inside your medicines packet.
删除5：<u>Information:

【87】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.
删除12：<u>Visit Yellow Card for further information.</u></u>

【88】6\. Pregnancy and breastfeeding
-------------------------------

【89】### Levothyroxine and pregnancy

【90】Levothyroxine is safe to take in pregnancy.

【91】It's important to carry on taking levothyroxine throughout your pregnancy. Having too low or too high levels of thyroid hormone in pregnancy can cause problems for you and your baby.

【92】You'll need to have regular blood tests during pregnancy to make sure you're on the right dose of levothyroxine. Your doctor may need to increase your dose of levothyroxine while you’re pregnant.

【93】### Levothyroxine and breastfeeding

【94】It's OK to breastfeed while you're on levothyroxine. Thyroid hormones are a normal part of breast milk. When taken as a supplement they only pass into breast milk in tiny amounts that are too small to affect your baby.

【95】If you're breastfeeding, it's important that you continue to take levothyroxine, as this is replacing what your body would normally be making. Your body needs good levels of thyroid hormones to make enough breast milk for your baby.

【96】If you notice that your baby is not feeding as well as usual, or if you have any other concerns about your baby, talk to your midwife, health visitor, pharmacist or doctor as soon as possible.

【97】### Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:

【98】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【99】7\. Cautions with other medicines
---------------------------------

【100】Some medicines can affect thyroid hormones, so the dose of levothyroxine may need to be changed. They include:

【101】*   epilepsy medicines like carbamazepine and phenytoin
*   rifampicin
*   amiodarone
*   oestrogens – such as in combined contraceptive pills or hormone replacement therapy (HRT)

【102】Levothyroxine can affect how other medicines work, so their doses may need to be changed. These medicines include:

【103】*   medicines for diabetes – either insulin or tablets
*   warfarin, used to prevent blood blots

【104】Some medicines should not be taken at the same time of day as levothyroxine as they can reduce the amount of levothyroxine your body takes in, including:

【105】*   antacids
*   calcium salts
*   iron salts
*   orlistat, a medicine used for weight loss
*   sucralfate, a medicine used to treat stomach ulcers
*   some cholesterol-lowering medicines such as colestyramine, colestipol or colesevelem
删除7：<u>Find out more from the information leaflets that come with the medicines. Or get your pharmacist's advice on how much time to leave between taking these medicines and taking levothyroxine.</u>

【106】### Mixing levothyroxine with herbal remedies and supplements

【107】There's very little information about taking herbal remedies and supplements with levothyroxine.

【108】However, biotin supplements can affect the accuracy of thyroid function tests. Do not take biotin without talking to your doctor.

【109】Kelp (a type of seaweed) can contain high levels of iodine, which sometimes makes an underactive thyroid worse. Do not take supplements containing kelp if you're taking levothyroxine.

【110】### Important: Medicine safety

【111】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal medicines, vitamins or supplements.

【112】8\. Common questions about levothyroxine
----------------------------------------

【113】How does levothyroxine work?

【114】The thyroid gland in your neck makes a hormone called thyroxine. Thyroxine controls how much energy your body uses (the metabolic rate). It's also involved in digestion, how your heart and muscles work, brain development and bone health.

【115】When the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroxine (called hypothyroidism), many of the body's functions slow down. Some of the most common symptoms of an underactive thyroid gland are:

【116】*   tiredness
*   feeling cold
*   difficulty concentrating
*   weight gain
*   feeling depressed

【117】Levothyroxine is a synthetic version of thyroxine. You take levothyroxine tablets to replace the thyroxine that your thyroid gland cannot produce and prevent the symptoms of hypothyroidism.

【118】How long does levothyroxine take to work?

【119】Levothyroxine starts working straight away, but it may be several weeks before your symptoms start to improve and you feel any different.

【120】How long will I take levothyroxine for?

【121】Treatment with levothyroxine is usually lifelong. If you stop taking levothyroxine your symptoms are likely to come back.

【122】Are there any long term side effects?

【123】Yes, it's safe to take levothyroxine for a long time, even many years. However, high doses of levothyroxine over a long time can sometimes cause weakening of the bones (osteoporosis).

【124】This should not happen if you are on the right dose. It's important to have regular blood tests to make sure your dose is not too high.

【125】Will it affect my fertility?

【126】There's no evidence to suggest that taking levothyroxine reduces fertility in either men or women.

【127】However, speak to a pharmacist or your doctor if you're trying to get pregnant as they may want to review your treatment.

【128】Can I drink alcohol with it?

【129】Yes, you can drink alcohol while taking levothyroxine. Alcohol does not affect how this medicine works.

【130】However, if you have side effects such as headaches, flushing or sweating with levothyroxine, alcohol may make these worse.

【131】Will it make me lose weight?

【132】One of the symptoms of an underactive thyroid gland is weight gain. So, once you start taking levothyroxine, you may lose weight as your body's hormones rebalance. Losing weight can also be a sign that your dose of levothyroxine is too high.

【133】Once your thyroid hormone levels have returned to normal, your tendency to gain or lose weight is the same as for people who do not have thyroid problems.

【134】Can I drive or ride a bike with it?

【135】Yes, levothyroxine does not affect your ability to drive or ride a bike.

【136】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【137】There are some foods and drinks that do not mix well with levothyroxine:

【138】*   **drinks containing caffeine**, like coffee, tea and some fizzy drinks, can reduce the amount of levothyroxine your body takes in. Leave at least 30 minutes after taking levothyroxine before you drink them.
*   **calcium-rich foods**, such as milk, cheese, yoghurt and broccoli, can reduce the amount of levothyroxine your body takes in. Leave at least 4 hours between taking levothyroxine and eating calcium-rich foods.
*   **soya in food and supplements** may stop levothyroxine working properly. If you regularly eat soya or take soya supplements your doctor might need to do extra blood tests to make sure you're getting enough levothyroxine.
*   **kelp (a type of seaweed)** can contain high levels of iodine, which sometimes makes an underactive thyroid worse. Do not take supplements containing kelp if you're taking levothyroxine.

【139】Can I get thyroid medicines for free?

【140】If you have an underactive thyroid, you're entitled to free prescriptions for all of your medicines (not just your levothyroxine). To claim your free prescriptions you'll need to have a medical exemption certificate.

【141】The application form for the medical exemption certificate is called FP92A. You can get this from your doctor's surgery. You will need to fill in the form, then your doctor will sign it and send it off.

【142】Will it affect my contraception?

【143】Levothyroxine does not affect any types of contraception, including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【144】However, the combined pill contains oestrogen which can reduce the amount of levothyroxine in your body.

【145】Speak to your doctor if you start or stop taking the Pill as your dose of levothyroxine may need to change.

【146】If levothyroxine makes you sick (vomit) or you have severe diarrhoea for over 24 hours while you’re taking levothyroxine, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy.

【147】If this happens, follow the instructions in the leaflet that comes with your contraceptive pills.
删除7：<u>Find out more about what to do if you're on the pill and you're being sick or you have diarrhoea.</u>

【148】Will I lose my hair?

【149】It's having an underactive thyroid that causes hair loss – not treatment with levothyroxine.

【150】Because the natural hair growth cycle takes several months, hair loss related to thyroid disease might only be seen months after the condition has begun. If treatment with levothyroxine has already started, it may seem like the medicine – rather than the underlying illness – is causing the hair loss.

【151】Hair usually regrows after treatment with levothyroxine, but it may take many months.
删除11：<u>Related conditions
------------------

【152】*   Underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism)
</u>删除11：<u>Useful resources
----------------

【153】*   British Thyroid Foundation: charity
*   Thyroid UK: charity
*   You and your hormones: medical information
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 17 December 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 17 December 2024</u>

source_info.title: Dementia (frontotemporal), see Frontotemporal dementia
source_info.text:
【0】Dementia (frontotemporal), see Frontotemporal dementia
Treatment \- Frontotemporal dementia
====================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Treatment</u>

【2】**There's currently no cure for frontotemporal dementia, but there are treatments that can help manage some of the symptoms.**

【3】Care plans
----------

【4】Before treatment starts, your current and future health and social care needs will be assessed, and a care plan drawn up.

【5】This is a way of ensuring you receive the right treatment for your needs. It involves identifying areas where you may need some assistance.

【6】These may be:

【7】*   what support you or your carer need for you to remain as independent as possible – including whether you might need care at home or in a nursing home
*   whether there are any changes that need to be made to your home to make it easier to live in
*   whether you need any financial assistance
删除7：<u>Read more about care plans.</u>

【8】Medicine
--------

【9】Medicines cannot stop frontotemporal dementia getting worse, but it can help reduce some of the symptoms for some people.

【10】The following medicines may help:

【11】*   antidepressants – antidepressants called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) may help control the loss of inhibitions, overeating and compulsive behaviours seen in some people
*   antipsychotics – these are rarely used, but are sometimes needed if SSRIs have not worked, as they can help control severely challenging behaviour that's putting the person with dementia or others around them at risk of harm

【12】Support and other therapies
---------------------------

【13】In addition to medicines, there are a number of therapies and practical measures that can help make everyday living easier for someone with dementia.

【14】These include:

【15】*   occupational therapy – to identify problem areas in everyday life, such as getting dressed, and help work out practical solutions
*   speech and language therapy – to help improve any communication or swallowing problems
*   physiotherapy – to help with movement difficulties
*   relaxation techniques – such as massage, and music or dance therapy
*   social interaction, leisure activities and other dementia activities – such as memory cafes, which are drop-in sessions for people with memory problems and their carers to get support and advice
*   **s**trategies for challenging behaviour – such as distraction techniques, a structured daily routine, and activities like doing puzzles or listening to music
*   incontinence products if needed

【16】It may also be helpful to get in touch with a support group, such as Rare Dementia Support, the Alzheimer's Society or Dementia UK.
删除7：<u>Read more about living well with dementia.</u>

【17】End of life and legal issues
----------------------------

【18】If you've been diagnosed with dementia, you might want to make arrangements for your care that take into account the decline in your mental abilities.

【19】This may include ensuring your wishes are upheld if you're not able to make decisions for yourself.

【20】You may want to consider:

【21】*   drawing up an advance decision – this makes your treatment preferences known in case you're unable to do this in the future
*   having a plan for where you want to receive treatment as your condition becomes more advanced
*   giving a relative lasting power of attorney – this is the power to make decisions about you if you're unable to
删除7：<u>Read more about managing legal affairs for someone with dementia and end of life planning.</u>

【22】Help and advice for carers
--------------------------

【23】If you care for someone with dementia, you may find it helpful to read more about:

【24】*   Looking after someone with dementia
*   Respite care – this can allow you to take breaks from caring
*   Benefits for carers – such as allowances and tax credits that may be available
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 29 June 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 29 June 2026</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Symptoms</u>

source_info.title: You and your baby at 8 weeks pregnant
source_info.text:
【0】You and your baby at 8 weeks pregnant
=====================================

【1】Your baby at 8 weeks
--------------------

【2】By the time you're 8 weeks pregnant, your baby is called a foetus, which means offspring.

【3】The legs are getting longer. The different parts of the leg are not properly distinct yet. It'll be a bit longer before the knees, ankles, thighs and toes develop.

【4】The foetus is still inside its amniotic sac and the placenta is continuing to develop, forming structures that help attach the placenta to the wall of the womb.

【5】At this stage, the foetus still gets its nourishment from the yolk sac.

【6】You at 8 weeks
--------------

【7】Your womb has grown to the size of a lemon by the time you're around 7 or 8 weeks pregnant.

【8】You're probably feeling tired. Your breasts might feel sore and enlarged, and you're probably needing to pee more often than usual.

【9】You'll probably have missed your second period. But you may experience a little bleeding in pregnancy from your vagina.

【10】Always mention any bleeding in pregnancy to your midwife or GP, particularly if it continues and you get stomach pain.

【11】Things to think about
---------------------

【12】*   Find out about the pregnancy (antenatal) care appointments you'll be offered, including your first midwife appointment.
*   Get teenage pregnancy support if you need it.
*   Learn about infections that can harm your baby in pregnancy and how to protect yourself.
*   Find out about exercise and keeping fit in pregnancy.
*   Make and save a pregnancy to-do list to help you stay organised删除7：<u>

【13】Start4Life has more about you and your baby at 8 weeks of pregnancy</u>

【14】You can sign up for Start4Life's weekly emails for expert advice, videos and tips on pregnancy, birth and beyond.
删除3：<u>Video: How can I cope with morning sickness?
--------------------------------------------

【15】In this video, a midwife gives advice on how to deal with morning sickness during your pregnancy.
删除1：<u>Media last reviewed: 25 January 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Media review due: 25 January 2026</u>

source_info.title: Heart transplant
source_info.text:
【0】Waiting list \- Heart transplant
================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Who can have one
3.  Waiting list
4.  What happens
5.  Living with
6.  Risks</u>

【2】**Because of the lack of available hearts, it's rarely possible to have a heart transplant as soon as it's needed, so you'll usually be placed on a waiting list.**

【3】It may be several months, or possibly years, before a donor heart of the right size and blood group becomes available.

【4】Many people are well enough to stay at home until a heart becomes available, although some people will need to remain in hospital.

【5】The transplant centre can offer support, guidance and information while you wait for a suitable donor to be found.

【6】They'll be fully aware that many people find this a frustrating and frightening experience.

【7】Waiting for a suitable donor
----------------------------

【8】While waiting for a donated heart to become available, it's important to stay as healthy as possible by:

【9】*   having a healthy diet
*   taking regular exercise, if possible
*   not smoking or drinking excessive amounts of alcohol

【10】The transplant centre will need to be able to contact you at short notice, so you should inform staff if your contact details change.

【11】You should also let staff know if your health changes – for example, if you develop an infection.

【12】Prepare an overnight bag and make arrangements with your friends, family and employer so you can go to the transplant centre as soon as a donor heart becomes available.

【13】Coping with being on the waiting list
-------------------------------------

【14】Living with a serious heart condition can be strenuous enough, and the added anxiety of waiting for a heart to become available can make the situation even more difficult.

【15】This can have an effect on both your physical and mental health. Contact your GP or the transplant centre for advice if you're struggling to cope emotionally with the demands of waiting for a transplant.

【16】You may also find it useful to contact a support group, such as the British Heart Foundation or Little Hearts Matter, a charity for children with heart defects.

【17】Getting the call
----------------

【18】When a suitable donor heart is found, the transplant centre will contact you and ask you to go to the centre.

【19】When you hear from the transplant centre:

【20】*   do not eat or drink anything
*   take all current medicines with you
*   take a bag of clothes and essentials for your hospital stay

【21】At the transplant centre, you'll be reassessed quickly to make sure no new medical conditions have developed.

【22】When the medical team has confirmed that you and the donor heart are suitable, you'll be given a general anaesthetic.

【23】The procedure must be carried out as quickly as possible to have the best chance of success.
删除7：<u>Find out more about what happens during a heart transplant</u>

【24】Transplant centres
------------------

【25】Heart transplants are carried out at a specialist heart transplant centre.

【26】UK heart transplant centres are located in:

【27】*   Great Ormond Street Hospital for Children and the Royal Brompton and Harefield Hospital in London
*   Royal Papworth Hospital in Cambridge
*   University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust
*   Wythenshawe Hospital in Manchester
*   Freeman Hospital in Newcastle
*   Golden Jubilee National Hospital in Glasgow

source_info.title: Sertraline
source_info.text:
【0】Side effects of sertraline
==========================

【1】Like all medicines, sertraline can cause side effects in some people, but many people have no side effects or only minor ones.

【2】Some of the common side effects of sertraline will gradually improve as your body gets used to it.

【3】Some people who take sertraline for panic attacks find their anxiety gets worse during the first few weeks of treatment. This usually wears off after a few weeks, but speak to your doctor if it bothers you. A lower dose may help reduce your symptoms.

【4】Common side effects
-------------------

【5】These common side effects of sertraline happen in more than 1 in 100 people. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【6】Feeling sick (nausea)

【7】Try taking sertraline with or after food. It may also help if you avoid rich or spicy food.

【8】Headaches

【9】Make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. It's best not to drink too much alcohol. Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller. Headaches should usually go away after the first week of taking sertraline. Talk to your doctor if they last longer than a week or are severe.

【10】Being unable to sleep

【11】Take sertraline first thing in the morning.

【12】Feeling sleepy

【13】Take sertraline in the evening and cut down the amount of alcohol you drink. Do not drive, ride a bike or use tools or machinery if you're feeling sleepy. If this does not help, talk to your doctor.

【14】Diarrhoea

【15】Drink plenty of water or other fluids to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual and having dark, strong-smelling pee. Do not take any other medicines to treat diarrhoea without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.

【16】If you take contraceptive pills and you have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet for advice.

【17】Dry mouth

【18】Chew sugar-free gum or suck sugar-free sweets.

【19】Feeling dizzy

【20】If sertraline makes you feel dizzy, stop what you're doing and sit or lie down until you feel better.

【21】Feeling tired or weak

【22】If sertraline makes you feel tired or weak, stop what you're doing and sit or lie down until you feel better. Do not drive, ride a bike or use tools or machinery if you're feeling tired.

【23】It's best not to drink alcohol as it will make you feel worse. If these symptoms do not go away after 1 or 2 weeks, ask your pharmacist or doctor for advice.

【24】Keep taking the medicine, but speak to a doctor or pharmacist if the advice on how to cope does not help and a side effect is still bothering you or does not go away.

【25】Serious side effects
--------------------

【26】It happens rarely (in less than 1 in 100 people), but some people may have serious side effects when taking sertraline.

【27】Book an appointment with your doctor if you get:

【28】*   changes in your periods, such as heavy bleeding, spotting or bleeding between periods
*   weight gain or weight loss without trying

【29】Call a doctor or call 111 now if:

【30】*   you have feelings of overwhelming happiness (euphoria), excessive enthusiasm or excitement, or a feeling of restlessness that means you cannot sit or stand still
*   the whites of your eyes turn yellow, or your skin turns yellow (this may be less noticeable on brown or black skin) – these can be signs of liver problems
*   you cough up blood or have blood in your pee
*   you have black or red poo or blood in your vomit – these can be signs of bleeding from the gut
*   you are bleeding from the gums, or get bruises that appear without a reason or that get bigger

【31】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E now if you:

【32】*   get chest pain or pressure, or shortness of breath
*   get headaches, have trouble focusing, have memory problems, cannot think clearly, have weakness, have a seizure or fit, or lose your balance – these can be signs of low sodium levels
*   have thoughts about harming yourself or ending your life
*   get severe dizziness or pass out
*   get painful erections that last longer than 2 hours – this may happen even when you're not having sex
*   get any heavy bleeding or bleeding that you cannot stop, such as cuts or nosebleeds that do not stop within 10 minutes

【33】### Serious allergic reaction

【34】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to sertraline.

【35】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【36】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【37】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【38】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【39】**Long-term side effects**
--------------------------

【40】A few people may get sexual side effects, such as problems getting an erection or a lower sex drive. In some cases these can continue even after stopping the medicine. Speak to your doctor if you are worried.

【41】If you have diabetes, sertraline can affect your blood sugar levels. Your doctor may monitor you to check that you're on the right dose of diabetes medicine.

【42】**Other side effects**
----------------------

【43】These are not all the side effects of sertraline. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.
删除5：<u>Information:

【44】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.
删除12：<u>Visit Yellow Card for further information.</u></u>
删除11：<u>More in Sertraline
------------------

【45】*   About sertraline
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking sertraline with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 2 February 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 2 February 2025</u>

source_info.title: Lercanidipine
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking lercanidipine
=================================================================

【1】Lercanidipine and pregnancy
---------------------------

【2】Lercanidipine can be taken during pregnancy, although it is not commonly used.

【3】If you are taking lercanidipine to treat high blood pressure you will usually be switched to a different medicine. This can be done by your doctor or specialist.

【4】Lercanidipine and breastfeeding
-------------------------------

【5】If your doctor or midwife says your baby is healthy you can take lercanidipine while you're breastfeeding.

【6】If you are breastfeeding, or planning to breastfeed, talk to your doctor or pharmacist as other medicines might be better for you.

【7】It's not known how much lercanidipine gets into breast milk, but it's likely to be a small amount which is unlikely to harm your baby.

【8】If you notice that your baby is not feeding as well as usual, or seems unusually sleepy, seems much paler than usual or if you have any other concerns about your baby, then talk to your health visitor, midwife, pharmacist or doctor as soon as possible.

【9】Lercanidipine and fertility
---------------------------

【10】There's no evidence to suggest that taking lercanidipine reduces fertility in either men or women.

【11】If you're trying for a baby or are having problems conceiving while on lercanidipine, speak to your doctor.

【12】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【13】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【14】通用删除3(英):<u>For more information about how calcium channel blockers such as lercanidipine can affect you and your baby during pregnancy, visit the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website.</u>

source_info.title: Lumbar decompression surgery
source_info.text:
【0】Risks \- Lumbar decompression surgery
=====================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  When it's used
3.  How it's performed
4.  Recovery
5.  Risks</u>

【2】**Like all surgical procedures, lumbar decompression surgery carries some risk of complications.**

【3】Recurrent or continuing symptoms
--------------------------------

【4】Lumbar decompression surgery is generally effective in relieving symptoms such as leg pain and numbness. However, some people continue to have symptoms after surgery, or develop symptoms again within a few years of surgery.

【5】Recurrent symptoms can be caused by a weakened spine, another slipped disc, or the formation of new bone or thickened ligament that puts pressure on your spinal cord. Scarring around the nerves can also sometimes develop after surgery, which can cause similar symptoms to nerve compression.

【6】Non-surgical treatments, such as physiotherapy, will usually be tried first if your symptoms recur, but further surgery may sometimes be needed. Repeat operations have a higher risk of complications than first-time operations.

【7】Unfortunately, there's no effective treatment for scarring around the nerves. However, you can reduce your risk of scarring by doing regular exercises as advised by your physiotherapist after surgery.

【8】Infection
---------

【9】One of the most common complications is an infection where the incision was made. It can usually be treated successfully with antibiotics. Infection can be more likely in patients who have diabetes or use steroids.

【10】Blood clots
-----------

【11】There's a risk of developing a blood clot after lumbar decompression surgery, particularly in your leg. This is known as deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  

【12】DVT can cause pain and swelling in your leg and, in rare cases, may lead to a serious problem called a pulmonary embolism. This is where a piece of the blood clot breaks off and blocks one of the blood vessels in the lungs.

【13】The risk of developing a blood clot can be significantly reduced by staying active during your recovery or wearing compression stockings to help improve your blood flow.删除7：<u>Read more about preventing DVT.</u>

【14】Dural tear
----------

【15】There's a risk of a dural tear occurring during all types of spinal surgery, including lumbar decompression surgery. The dura is a watertight sac of tissue that covers the spinal cord and spinal nerves.

【16】If the tear isn't identified and repaired at the time of surgery, it can lead to cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leaking after the procedure.

【17】Your surgeon will be aware of the risk of a dural tear, and if it does occur they will close the tear with stitches. In most cases, the repair is successful and no further problems or issues arise. However, further corrective surgery may be required in a small number of cases.

【18】Leakage of cerebrospinal fluid
------------------------------

【19】During lumbar decompression surgery, there's a risk of accidental damage to the lining of the nerve, which can lead to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). 

【20】If this is discovered during the operation, it will be patched and repaired. However, small leaks can sometimes only become apparent after the operation, causing problems such as a headache and the wound to leak. Further surgery to repair this may be needed.

【21】Facial sores and loss of vision
-------------------------------

【22】As you're positioned face down during lumbar decompression surgery, you'll be resting on your forehead and chin while the operation is carried out.

【23】The anaesthetist will check regularly to make sure this isn't causing any problems, but many people will wake up with a slightly puffed up face. In some cases, a red sore can develop over the forehead or chin, which could last several days.

【24】Nerve injury and paralysis
--------------------------

【25】Some patients who have lumbar decompression surgery will develop new numbness or weakness in one or both legs as a result of the operation.

【26】Paralysis is an uncommon, but serious, complication that can occur as a result of lumbar decompression surgery.

【27】Nerve injuries and paralysis can be caused by a number of different problems, including:

【28】*   bleeding inside the spinal column (extradural spinal haematoma)
*   leaking of spinal fluid (incidental durotomy)
*   accidental damage to the blood vessels that supply the spinal cord with blood
*   accidental damage to the nerves when they're moved during surgery

【29】Death
-----

【30】As with all types of surgery, there's a risk of dying during or after lumbar decompression surgery, although this is rare. A blood clot, a bad reaction to the anaesthetic and blood loss can all be life-threatening.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 28 April 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 28 April 2025</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Recovery</u>

source_info.title: Latanoprost
source_info.text:
【0】How and when to use latanoprost \- Brand names: Xalatan, Monopost
=================================================================

【1】Always use latanoprost eye drops exactly as your doctor tells you.

【2】Dosage
------

【3】There are 50 micrograms of latanoprost in 1ml.

【4】The usual dose for adults and children is 1 drop into the affected eye or eyes, once a day.

【5】It comes as a multiple dose eye-drop bottle or a single-dose dropper. Always read the instructions that come with your medicine.

【6】It's important to use latanoprost every day for it to work properly.

【7】How to use eye drops
--------------------

【8】It's best to use your eye drops in the evening as latanoprost works better then.

【9】If you wear contact lenses, make sure you remove them before using your eye drops. Wait 15 minutes before putting your lenses back in.

【10】1.  Wash your hands.
2.  If you're using a bottle, remove the lid. If you're using the single-use dropper, twist off the tip.
3.  Use your finger to gently pull down your lower eyelid and tilt your head back.
4.  Make sure the tip of the dropper does not touch your eye, eyelashes, eyelid.
5.  Hold the dropper over your eye, and squeeze the bottle or single dose dropper gently so one drop goes into your eye.
6.  Release your lower eyelid and close your eye. Gently press your finger over the inside corner of your eye (over the eyelid) for about a minute. This helps keep the drops in your eye.
7.  Wipe away any extra liquid with a clean tissue.
8.  Repeat in your other eye if the doctor has told you to do this. There is enough liquid in 1 single-dose dropper to put a drop in both eyes if needed.
9.  Put the cap back on the bottle or if you're using the single-dose dropper, throw it away.

【11】If you use latanoprost with other eye drops wait at least 5 minutes before using the other eye drops. The second eye drops can wash the latanoprost out and it may not work as well.

【12】### Expiry dates

【13】Use the latanoprost eye drops within the expiry date on the bottle and within 4 weeks of opening. This will help to prevent the risk of eye infections and the eye drops not working as they should.

【14】Using your eye drops within their expiry dates is important to help reduce the risk of eye infections and the eye drops not working as well as they should.

【15】The single-dose droppers come in sachets. Once you open the packet, use the droppers within 10 days. Do not use the droppers after the expiry date.

【16】You could write the date you opened the bottle or packet on the label or the box. This will help you know when you need to start using a new one.

【17】How long to use it for
----------------------

【18】You'll usually use latanoprost for the rest of your life. However, if it does not work well enough, your doctor may recommend a different or additional treatment.

【19】It's important to use your eye drops regularly and go for check-ups, to stop your eyesight getting worse.

【20】If you stop using latanoprost, the pressure inside your eye may go up. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist before stopping latanoprost.

【21】If you forget to use it
-----------------------

【22】If you forget to use your drops at the usual time, skip the missed dose and use your eyedrops as usual the next day.

【23】Never use 2 doses at the same time. Never use an extra dose to make up for a forgotten one.

【24】If you often forget doses, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to remember your medicines.

【25】If you use too much
-------------------

【26】Using too many drops can irritate your eye and make it water and turn red. If you get too much latanoprost in your eye, rinse it all out with water. Do not put any more drops in until it’s time for your next dose.

【27】Any irritation, watering or redness should get better, but if you're worried about it ask your doctor or pharmacist for advice.

【28】### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【29】*   you swallow latanoprost and feel unwell

【30】Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111. Call 111 if you're asking about a child under the age of 5 years.

【31】If you need to go to A&E, do not drive yourself. Get someone else to drive you or call for an ambulance.

【32】Take the medicine packet or leaflet inside it, plus any remaining medicine, with you.
删除11：<u>More in Latanoprost
-------------------

【33】*   About latanoprost
*   Who can and cannot use it
*   How and when to use it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Using latanoprost with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 20 February 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 20 February 2026</u>

source_info.title: Kawasaki disease
source_info.text:
【0】Diagnosis \- Kawasaki disease
=============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications</u>

【2】**There's no single test to diagnose Kawasaki disease, but there are some key signs that suggest a child may have this condition.**

【3】The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) states that your child may have Kawasaki disease if they have:

【4】*   a high temperature for 5 days or longer
*   at least 1 other key symptom

【5】These symptoms include:

【6】*   **conjunctival infection in both eyes** – where the whites of your child's eyes are red and swollen without fluid leaking from their eyes
*   **changes to the mouth or throat** – such as dry, red, cracked lips, a red, swollen tongue, or red inside the mouth or at the back of the throat
*   **changes to the hands and feet** – such as swollen or painful hands or feet, or red or peeling skin on the palms of the hands or the soles of the feet
*   **a rash**
*   **swollen lymph nodes in the neck**

【7】The skin on your child's fingers or toes may become red or hard, and their hands and feet may swell up.

【8】Your child's hands and feet may also be tender and painful to touch or put weight on, so they may be reluctant to walk or crawl.

【9】**Children under 1 year of age may not have as many of the key symptoms compared with older children.**
删除7：<u>Read more about the symptoms of Kawasaki disease.</u>

【10】Sometimes, a child may be diagnosed with Kawasaki disease if they have a high temperature and only 1 key symptom, or if the high temperature has only lasted 4 days.

【11】It’s also possible for a child with Kawasaki disease to have symptoms that appear and disappear throughout the illness.

【12】Tell the doctor assessing your child if your child has recently had symptoms of Kawasaki disease but no longer has them.

【13】Tests
-----

【14】Your child may need to have tests to rule out other conditions that could be causing their symptoms.

【15】Possible conditions your child could have include:

【16】*   **scarlet fever** – a bacterial infection that causes a distinctive pink-red rash
*   **toxic shock syndrome** – a rare, life-threatening bacterial infection
*   **measles** – a highly infectious viral illness that causes a fever and distinctive red-brown spots
*   **glandular fever** – a viral infection that can cause a fever and swollen lymph glands
*   **Stevens-Johnson syndrome** – a very severe allergic reaction to medicine
*   **viral** **meningitis** – an infection of the protective membranes that surround the brain and spinal cord (meninges)
*   **lupus** – an autoimmune condition that can cause a range of symptoms, including fatigue, joint pain and a rash

【17】Several tests can also be carried out to help support a diagnosis of Kawasaki disease.

【18】These include:

【19】*   **a urine sample** – to see whether it contains white blood cells
*   **blood tests** – such as a white blood cell count or platelet count
*   **a** **lumbar puncture** – a sample of cerebrospinal fluid is taken by inserting a needle between the vertebrae of the lower spine

【20】Individually, these tests may not be conclusive, but when combined with some of the key symptoms of Kawasaki disease, they can help confirm a diagnosis.

【21】Heart problems
--------------

【22】Complications of Kawasaki disease usually affect the heart. This means your child may need some tests to check their heart is functioning normally.

【23】These must include:

【24】*   **an** **electrocardiogram (ECG)** – which measures the heart's electrical activity using flat metal discs (electrodes) attached to the arms, legs and chest; an ECG can identify damage to the heart or problems with the heart's rhythm
*   **an** **echocardiogram** – where high-frequency sound waves are used to produce images of the heart, which can confirm whether there are any problems with the heart's structure or function

【25】During the acute phase of Kawasaki disease (weeks 1 to 2), several heart abnormalities may be identified.

【26】These could include:

【27】*   a rapid heart rate (tachycardia)
*   a collection of fluid in the heart (pericardial effusion)
*   inflammation of the heart muscle (myocarditis)
*   coronary artery swelling (aneurysms)
删除7：<u>Read more about the complications of Kawasaki disease.</u>

source_info.title: Macrogol
source_info.text:
【0】About macrogol \- Brand names: Movicol, Laxido, CosmoCol, Molaxole
==================================================================

【1】Macrogol (or macrogols) is a laxative taken to treat constipation (difficulty pooing).

【2】You can also use it to help clear a build-up of hard poo in your bowel, which can happen if you've been constipated for a long time (faecal impaction).

【3】It can also be given before a colonoscopy (a test to check inside your bowels) to empty your bowels before the test.

【4】Macrogol comes as sachets of powder that you mix with water to make a drink, a ready-mixed liquid to drink, or a liquid that you dilute before drinking.

【5】It's available on prescription and to buy from pharmacies.

【6】Children under 12 years can only take certain brands of macrogol and it must be prescribed for them. Brands prescribed for children include CosmoCol Paediatric and Movicol Paediatric.

【7】Key facts
---------

【8】*   Macrogol relieves constipation by making your poo slightly bigger and softer. This helps poo travel through your bowels more easily.
*   Macrogol can take 1 to 2 days to work. Talk to a doctor if you're still constipated after 3 days.
*   The most common side effects are stomach pain, diarrhoea, wind and a sore bottom (anus). These are usually mild and do not last long.
*   Most macrogol sachets contain sodium chloride, potassium chloride and sodium bicarbonate (known as electrolytes).
*   The powder sachets are usually flavoured, but if you do not like the flavour you can add fruit squash to the drink.
删除11：<u>More in Macrogol
----------------

【9】*   About macrogol
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

source_info.title: Vaginismus
source_info.text:
【0】Vaginismus
==========

【1】**Vaginismus is when the vagina suddenly tightens up when you try to insert something into it. It can be painful and upsetting, but it can be treated.**

【2】What is vaginismus?
-------------------

【3】Vaginismus is the body's automatic reaction to the fear of some or all types of vaginal penetration.

【4】Whenever penetration is attempted, your vaginal muscles tighten up on their own.

【5】You have no control over it.

【6】Occasionally, you can get vaginismus even if you have previously enjoyed painless penetrative sex.

【7】Vaginismus does not necessarily affect your ability to get aroused and enjoy other types of sexual contact.

【8】Other things that can cause women pain during sex include:

【9】*   vulvodynia
*   thrush
*   sexually transmitted infections (STIs)
*   menopause
*   a bad reaction to condoms, soap or shampoo
*   pelvic inflammatory disease
*   endometriosis

【10】Non-urgent advice: See a GP or go to a sexual health clinic if:
---------------------------------------------------------------

【11】*   you find it hard inserting a tampon into your vagina
*   you struggle with vaginal penetration during sex
*   you feel burning or stinging pain during sex

【12】These are common signs of vaginismus.

【13】### What happens at your appointment

【14】You can ask to be seen by a female doctor, and you can bring someone you trust along for support.

【15】Your doctor will ask you about your symptoms and may ask to examine your vagina.

【16】The examination is usually very quick. Your doctor will take a quick look to rule out other conditions, like an infection.

【17】It's unlikely they'll need to perform an internal examination of your vagina.

【18】If your doctor thinks you have vaginismus, you may be referred to a specialist, such as a sex therapist.

【19】Treatment for vaginismus
------------------------

【20】Treatment usually focuses on:

【21】*   managing your feelings around penetration
*   exercises to gradually get you used to penetration

【22】Treatments for vaginismus

| Possible treatment | What treatment covers |
| --- | --- |
| Psychosexual therapy | A type of talking therapy that aims to help you understand and change your feelings about your body and sex |
| Relaxation techniques | Mindfulness, breathing and gentle touching exercises to help you learn to relax the vaginal muscles |
| Pelvic floor exercises | Squeezing and releasing exercises to gain control of the vaginal muscles |
| Sensate focus | Exercises to help with your relaxation during sex and increase your sex drive (libido) |
| Vaginal trainers | Tampon-shaped objects in different sizes to help you gradually get used to having something put into your vagina |

【24】Treatment is initially done under the guidance of specialised therapists. You'll then usually be expected to practise some of the exercises at home.

【25】If you're in a relationship, you can choose to involve your partner.

【26】Treatment usually works and you may see progress in a matter of weeks.

【27】Important: Surgery
------------------

【28】Sometimes vaginismus is mistaken for a physical problem with your vagina, which can lead to needless surgery. Very few cases of vaginismus require surgery.

【29】Causes of vaginismus
--------------------

【30】The reasons for vaginismus are not always clear, but some things thought to cause it include:

【31】*   fearing that your vagina is too small
*   a bad first sexual experience
*   an unpleasant medical examination
*   believing sex is shameful or wrong
*   a painful medical condition, like thrush

source_info.title: Urinary catheter
source_info.text:
【0】Risks \- Urinary catheter
=========================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Types
3.  Living with
4.  Risks</u>

【2】**The main risk of using a urinary catheter is that it can sometimes allow bacteria to enter your body.**

【3】This can cause an infection in the urethra, bladder or, less commonly, in the kidneys. These types of infection are known as urinary tract infections (UTIs).

【4】Urinary tract infections (UTIs)
-------------------------------

【5】UTIs caused by using a catheter are one of the most common types of infection that affect people staying in hospital. This risk is particularly high if your catheter is left in place continuously (an indwelling catheter).

【6】Symptoms of a UTI associated with using a catheter include:

【7】*   pain low down in your tummy or around your groin
*   a high temperature
*   feeling cold and shivery
*   confusion

【8】Contact your GP or community nurse if you think you have a UTI. You may need a course of antibiotics.

【9】Other risks and side effects
----------------------------

【10】Bladder spasms, which feel like stomach cramps, are quite common when you have a catheter in your bladder. The pain is caused by the bladder trying to squeeze out the balloon. You may need medicine to reduce the frequency and intensity of the spasms.

【11】Leakage around the catheter is another problem associated with indwelling catheters. This can happen as a result of bladder spasms or when you poo. Leakage can also be a sign that the catheter is blocked, so it's essential to check that it's draining.

【12】Blood or debris in the catheter tube is also common with an indwelling catheter. This could become a problem if the catheter drainage system becomes blocked.

【13】Get medical advice as soon as possible if you think your catheter may be blocked, or if you're passing large pieces of debris or blood clots.

【14】Other (less common) potential problems include:

【15】*   injury to the urethra (the tube that carries urine out of your body) when the catheter is inserted
*   narrowing of the urethra because of scar tissue caused by repeated catheter use
*   injury to the bladder caused by incorrectly inserting the catheter
*   bladder stones (although these usually only develop after years of using a catheter)
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 03 February 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 03 February 2026</u>
