source_info.title: Mental health services
source_info.text:
【0】Mental health services
======================

【1】Find out how to access NHS mental health services and where to get urgent help.

【2】Urgent advice: If it's an emergency or you need urgent help
-----------------------------------------------------------

【3】*   If you or someone else is in danger, call 999 or go to A&E now
*   If you need help urgently for your mental health, but it's not an emergency, get help from NHS 111 online or call 111

【4】Your mental health is as important as your physical health. You will not be wasting anyone's time.

【5】NHS urgent mental health helplines
----------------------------------

【6】Get 24-hour advice and support from a mental health professional, for anyone of any age

【7】NHS therapy and counselling services
------------------------------------

【8】NHS talking therapies services are for people in England aged 18 or over. You can speak to your GP about talking therapies or get in touch with the talking therapies service directly without going to your GP. Talking therapies can treat conditions like:

【9】*   depression
*   generalised anxiety
*   social anxiety
*   panic and agoraphobia
*   other phobias
*   obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)
*   post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)
*   body dysmorphic disorder

【10】Get NHS therapy and counselling

【11】How to find local mental health services
----------------------------------------

【12】The support you can get and how you access it depends on where you are

【13】Find local mental health charities
----------------------------------

【14】You can visit Hub of Hope to search for mental health charities where you live. It's run by a national charity called Chasing the Stigma.

【15】Mental health services for children and young people
----------------------------------------------------

【16】Find out about support for mental health for children, young people, parents and carers

【17】### Find care for your mental health before, during and after pregnancy

【18】Find out how to get help with your mental health if you're planning to have a baby, if you're pregnant, or after you've given birth

source_info.title: Furosemide
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take furosemide
==================================

【1】Who can take furosemide
-----------------------

【2】Most adults and children (including babies) can take furosemide.

【3】Who may not be able to take furosemide
--------------------------------------

【4】Furosemide is not suitable for everyone. To make sure it’s safe for you, tell your doctor if you have:

【5】*   ever had an allergic reaction to furosemide or any other medicine
*   low blood pressure (hypotension)
*   signs of dehydration, such as being thirsty, having a dry mouth and dark pee
*   liver disease
*   diabetes
*   any difficulty peeing
*   Addison's disease, a rare disorder of the adrenal glands
*   gout

【6】Tell your doctor that you are taking furosemide if you're going to have:

【7】*   a glucose test
*   a test (such as an X-ray or scan) that involves using a dye containing iodine being injected into your blood
*   a major operation or a general anaesthetic to put you to sleep
删除11：<u>More in Furosemide
------------------

【8】*   About furosemide
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking furosemide with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 21 February 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 21 February 2025</u>

source_info.title: Carbamazepine
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking carbamazepine
=================================================================

【1】Carbamazepine and pregnancy
---------------------------

【2】Carbamazepine has been linked to an increased risk of problems for your baby if you take it in pregnancy.

【3】You'll usually only be advised to take carbamazepine if your doctor thinks the benefits of the medicine outweigh the risks.

【4】If you take carbamazepine for epilepsy, it's important that this is controlled during pregnancy, as seizures can harm you and your baby. If you become pregnant, keep taking carbamazepine, but talk to your doctor straight away. It is likely that you will need to be seen in a specialist epilepsy clinic, and they may want to change your medicine.

【5】If you're trying to get pregnant or have become pregnant while taking carbamazepine, it's recommended you take a high dose of folic acid (5mg a day). You can get this from your doctor or midwife.

【6】Ideally, it's best to take high dose folic acid for 3 months before you start trying to get pregnant and for the first 12 weeks of pregnancy. Do not worry if you have not taken it before you get pregnant, but start taking it as soon as possible once you know that you are pregnant. It helps your baby to grow normally.

【7】Your baby may need extra monitoring for a few days after they're born. This is because they can sometimes have withdrawal symptoms from carbamazepine.

【8】Carbamazepine and breastfeeding
-------------------------------

【9】If your doctor or health visitor says your baby is healthy, it's OK to take carbamazepine while you're breastfeeding.

【10】Carbamazepine does pass into breast milk. Most babies do not get any side effects, but some babies might be more sleepy or not feed as well as usual. Taking other medicines while you're taking carbamazepine may mean your baby gets side effects, although this is still rare.

【11】It's important to keep taking carbamazepine to keep you well. Do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. Breastfeeding will also benefit both you and your baby.

【12】Talk to your doctor, midwife or health visitor as soon as possible if:

【13】*   your baby is not feeding as well as usual
*   your baby seems unusually sleepy
*   your baby has an upset stomach
*   the whites or your baby's eyes turn yellow, or their skin turns yellow (this may be less noticeable on brown or black skin) – this could be a sign of jaundice
*   you have any other concerns about your baby

【14】Carbamazepine and fertility
---------------------------

【15】Carbamazepine does not affect female fertility, however, there have been rare reports of problems with male fertility.

【16】Speak to your doctor if you have any concerns.

【17】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【18】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【19】通用删除3(英):<u>For more information about how carbamazepine can affect you and your baby during pregnancy, visit the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website.</u>
删除11：<u>More in Carbamazepine
---------------------

【20】*   About carbamazepine
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking carbamazepine with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 4 March 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 4 March 2025</u>

source_info.title: Stop smoking in pregnancy
source_info.text:
【0】整页删除
Stop smoking in pregnancy
=========================

【1】Smoking and your unborn baby
----------------------------

【2】Protecting your baby from tobacco smoke is one of the best things you can do to give your child a healthy start in life. It can be difficult to stop smoking, but it's never too late to quit.

【3】Every cigarette you smoke contains over 4,000 chemicals, many of which are dangerous, so smoking when you are pregnant harms your unborn baby. Cigarettes can restrict the essential oxygen supply to your baby. As a result, their heart must beat harder every time you smoke.

【4】Benefits of stopping smoking in pregnancy
-----------------------------------------

【5】Stopping smoking will help both you and your baby immediately. Harmful gases, such as carbon monoxide, and other damaging chemicals will clear from your body. When you stop smoking:

【6】*   you will reduce the risk of complications in pregnancy and birth
*   you are more likely to have a healthier pregnancy and a healthier baby
*   you will reduce the risk of stillbirth
*   your baby is less likely to be born too early and have to face the breathing, feeding and health problems that often go with being premature
*   your baby is less likely to be born with a low birth weight. Babies of smokers are, on average, lighter than other babies, which can cause problems during and after labour. For example, they are more likely to have problems keeping warm and are more likely to get infections
*   you will reduce the risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS), also known as "cot death"

【7】Stopping smoking now will also help your baby later in life. Children whose parents smoke are more likely to suffer from asthma and other serious illnesses that may need hospital treatment.

【8】The sooner you stop smoking, the better. But even if you stop in the last few weeks of your pregnancy this will benefit you and your baby.

【9】Secondhand (passive) smoke harms your baby
------------------------------------------

【10】If your partner or anyone else who lives with you smokes, their smoke can affect you and your baby before and after their birth. You may also find it more difficult to stop if someone around you smokes.

【11】Secondhand smoke can also reduce your baby's birthweight and increase the risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS), also known as "cot death". Babies whose parents smoke are more likely to be admitted to hospital for bronchitis and pneumonia during their first year.

【12】To find out more about quitting and to get support, your partner can call the National Smokefree helpline on 0300 123 1044 from 9am to 8pm Monday to Friday, and 11am to 4pm Saturday and Sunday.

【13】Nicotine replacement therapy
----------------------------

【14】You can use nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) during pregnancy if it will help you stop smoking and you're unable to stop without it. Stop smoking tablets such as bupropion (Zyban) are not recommended during pregnancy.

【15】NRT contains only nicotine and none of the damaging chemicals found in cigarettes, so it is a much better option than continuing to smoke. It helps you by giving you the nicotine you would have had from a cigarette.

【16】You can be prescribed NRT during pregnancy by a GP or an NHS stop smoking adviser. You can also buy it over the counter without a prescription from a pharmacy.

【17】NRT is available as:

【18】*   patches
*   gum
*   inhalator
*   nasal spray
*   mouth spray
*   oral strips
*   lozenges
*   microtabs

【19】If you have pregnancy-related nausea and vomiting, patches may be a better solution.

【20】NRT patches should be used for no more than 16 hours in any 24-hour period. The best way to remember this is to remove the patch at bedtime.

【21】Before using any of these products, speak to a midwife, GP, a pharmacist or a specialist stop smoking adviser.

【22】By getting this specialist advice you can be sure that you're doing the best for your baby and for you.

【23】Call the National Smokefree helpline on 0300 123 1044 from 9am to 8pm Monday to Friday, and 11am to 4pm Saturday and Sunday.

【24】Remember, you are twice as likely to be successful at quitting if you get some support from a trained adviser.

【25】### Liquorice-flavoured nicotine products

【26】Pregnant women are advised to avoid liquorice-flavoured nicotine products. Although there is no known risk with small amounts of liquorice flavouring, the manufacturers advise caution.

【27】This caution is based on information about the adverse effects associated with excessive amounts of liquorice root. As other flavours are available, pregnant women are advised to choose an alternative, such as fruit or mint.
删除7：<u>Find out more about stop smoking treatments.</u>

【28】E-cigarettes in pregnancy
-------------------------

【29】E-cigarettes are fairly new and there are still some things we do not know. However, current evidence on e-cigarettes indicates they are much less risky than smoking.

【30】Cigarettes deliver nicotine along with thousands of harmful chemicals. E-cigarettes allow you to inhale nicotine through a vapour rather than smoke. By itself, nicotine is relatively harmless.

【31】E-cigarettes do not produce tar or carbon monoxide, the 2 main toxins in cigarette smoke. Carbon monoxide is particularly harmful to developing babies. The vapour from an e-cigarette does contain some of the potentially harmful chemicals found in cigarette smoke, but at much lower levels.

【32】If using an e-cigarette helps you to stop smoking, it is much safer for you and your baby than continuing to smoke.

【33】Unlike nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), such as patches or gum, e-cigarettes are not available on an NHS prescription. If you want to use an e-cigarette, you can still get free expert help from a stop smoking adviser.

【34】Call the National Smokefree helpline on 0300 123 1044 for more information, or ask a midwife to refer you.
删除7：<u>Find out more about using e-cigarettes to stop smoking.</u>

【35】National Smokefree helpline
---------------------------

【36】The National Smokefree helpline offers free help, support and advice on stopping smoking and can give you details of local support services.

【37】You can also sign up to receive ongoing advice and support at a time that suits you.

【38】Information:

【39】National Smokefree helpline: 0300 123 1044

【40】9am to 8pm Monday to Friday, and 11am to 4pm Saturday and Sunday.

【41】To find your nearest NHS Stop Smoking service talk to:

【42】*   a midwife
*   a health visitor
*   a nurse at your GP surgery
*   a pharmacist

【43】NHS Stop Smoking services can offer 1-to-1 or group sessions with trained stop smoking advisers and may have a pregnancy stop smoking specialist.

【44】They can also offer advice about dealing with stress, weight gain and support the use of NRT (such as patches or gum), if appropriate, to help you manage your cravings.
删除7：<u>Find out more about the effects of smoking in pregnancy, and getting support to quit, at Better Health: Start for Life</u>

【45】Find stop smoking services near you.

【46】Get Better Health: Start for Life's pregnancy and baby emails
-------------------------------------------------------------

【47】Sign up for Better Health: Start for Life’s emails for expert advice, videos and tips on pregnancy, birth and beyond.
删除3：<u>Video: should I give up smoking?
--------------------------------

【48】In this video, a midwife explains how smoking can harm your baby.
删除1：<u>Media last reviewed: 1 February 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Media review due: 1 February 2026</u>

【49】</u>删除11：<u>More in Keeping well in pregnancy
---------------------------------

【50】*   Have a healthy diet in pregnancy
*   Vegetarian or vegan and pregnant
*   Foods to avoid in pregnancy
*   Vitamins, supplements and nutrition in pregnancy
*   Exercise in pregnancy
*   Medicines in pregnancy
*   Mental health in pregnancy
*   Depression in pregnancy
*   Sex in pregnancy
*   Travelling in pregnancy
*   Work and pregnancy
*   Your baby's movements
*   Reducing the risk of stillbirth
*   Drinking alcohol while pregnant
*   Stop smoking in pregnancy
*   Illegal drugs in pregnancy
*   Vaccinations in pregnancy
*   The flu jab in pregnancy
*   Whooping cough vaccination in pregnancy
*   Infections in pregnancy that may affect your baby
*   Pregnancy and COVID-19
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 10 January 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 10 January 2026</u>

source_info.title: Clonidine
source_info.text:
【0】About clonidine \- Brand name: Catapres
=======================================

【1】Clonidine is a type of medicine called a vasodilator.

【2】Clonidine has many uses. It's mainly used to:

【3】*   prevent migraine or other similar types of headache
*   treat hot flushes or sweats that may happen during the menopause

【4】It's also sometimes used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension).

【5】It helps to relax and widen blood vessels in the heart so blood can pass through them more easily.

【6】Clonidine is only available on prescription.

【7】It comes as tablets or as a liquid that you swallow. It's also available as an injection, but this is only given in hospital for emergency treatment of high blood pressure.

【8】Key facts
---------

【9】*   Clonidine may take 2 to 4 weeks to work fully and for you to start to feel better.
*   You'll take it 1 to 3 times a day for as long as you need it. It's safe to take clonidine for a long time.
*   Common side effects of clonidine include feeling sleepy, low blood pressure when you stand up, and constipation.
*   If clonidine makes you feel sleepy or dizzy, do not drive, cycle or use machinery or tools until you feel better.
*   Stopping clonidine suddenly can cause a dangerous increase in your blood pressure and withdrawal side effects. Do not stop taking it without talking to a doctor.
删除11：<u>More in Clonidine
-----------------

【10】*   About clonidine
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking clonidine with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 10 February 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 10 February 2026</u>

source_info.title: Aripiprazole
source_info.text:
【0】Taking aripiprazole with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand name: Abilify
======================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】There are many medicines that can affect the way aripiprazole works, or that increase the risk of side effects.

【3】It's very important to check a medicine is safe to take with aripiprazole before you start taking it.

【4】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including:

【5】*   medicines for problems with your heart rhythm, such as quinidine, amiodarone or flecainide
*   medicines to lower your blood pressure
*   medicines that make you feel sleepy, including benzodiazepines such as diazepam, opioid painkillers such as morphine, pethidine or tramadol, or drowsy antihistamines such as chlorphenamine – aripiprazole can increase the effects of these medicines and make you feel more sleepy
*   ketoconazole or itraconazole, medicines for fungal infections
*   medicines for depression such as fluoxetine, paroxetine or venlafaxine
*   some medicines to treat HIV infection such as efavirenz, nevirapine, indinavir or ritonavir
*   rifabutin or rifampicin, medicines for tuberculosis (TB)
*   carbamazepine, phenytoin or phenobarbital, medicines for epilepsy
*   triptans such as sumatriptan or zolmitriptan, for migraines

【6】Mixing aripiprazole with herbal remedies and supplements
--------------------------------------------------------

【7】There might be a problem taking some herbal remedies and supplements with aripiprazole, especially ones that make you feel sleepy or dizzy. Ask a pharmacist for advice.

【8】Do not take St John's wort, a herbal remedy for depression. It may stop aripiprazole working as well as it should.

【9】There's not enough information to say that other complementary medicines, herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with aripiprazole. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【10】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【11】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.
删除11：<u>More in Aripiprazole
--------------------

【12】*   About aripiprazole

*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility

source_info.title: Morphine
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking morphine
============================================================

【1】Morphine and pregnancy
----------------------

【2】Morphine can be safely given in hospital by a doctor or midwife for severe pain if you need it while you're pregnant. However, long-term use of morphine is not generally recommended in pregnancy.

【3】If you are taking morphine long term discuss this with your doctor or midwife, as coming off morphine or finding a different medicine may be possible.

【4】Morphine may affect your baby's development in the first trimester, so it's best to avoid taking it in early pregnancy if possible.

【5】If you take morphine at the end of pregnancy there's a risk that your baby will get withdrawal symptoms when they're born. Morphine is often given for pain relief in labour and generally does not cause a problem for the baby, however your baby will be monitored closely once they're born to look for drowsiness or any breathing problems.

【6】It's important to treat pain in pregnancy. For some people with severe pain, morphine might be the best option. Your doctor is the best person to help you decide what's right for you and your baby.

【7】Morphine and breastfeeding
--------------------------

【8】If your doctor or health visitor says your baby is healthy, you can take morphine while breastfeeding. However, it is best to only take morphine for a few days and at low doses. If you need to take it for longer, talk to your doctor. Your doctor may also recommend a different painkiller for you to use while breastfeeding.

【9】Morphine passes into breast milk in fairly small amounts, although the amount does vary. When taken at low doses and for a short time, it is unlikely to cause side effects in your baby.

【10】If your baby is not feeding as well as usual, has constipation, seems unusually pale, or if you have any other concerns about your baby, talk to your doctor, pharmacist, health visitor or midwife as soon as possible.

【11】### Immediate action required: Call 111 for advice or go to A&E now if:

【12】*   your baby is unusually sleepy
*   your baby has breathing problems

【13】Find your nearest A&E

【14】Morphine and fertility
----------------------

【15】There's no clear evidence to suggest that taking morphine will reduce fertility in men.

【16】However, it might affect your periods (menstrual cycle) if you're a woman.

【17】Speak to a pharmacist or your doctor if you're trying to get pregnant. They may want to review your treatment.

【18】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【19】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【20】通用删除3(英):<u>For more information about how morphine can affect you and your baby during pregnancy, visit the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website.</u>
删除11：<u>More in Morphine
----------------

source_info.title: Auditory processing disorder (APD)
source_info.text:
【0】Auditory processing disorder (APD)
==================================

【1】**Auditory processing disorder (APD) is where you have difficulty understanding sounds, including spoken words. There are things you can do that can help.**

【2】Check if you or your child have auditory processing disorder (APD)
------------------------------------------------------------------

【3】Auditory processing disorder (APD) often starts in childhood, but some people develop it later.

【4】If you or your child have APD, you may find it difficult to understand:

【5】*   people speaking in noisy places
*   people with strong accents or fast talkers
*   similar sounding words
*   spoken instructions

【6】APD is not a hearing problem. People with the condition usually have normal hearing.

【7】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【8】*   you or your child find it hard to hear or understand speech

【9】The GP may refer you to a hearing specialist.

【10】Tests for auditory processing disorder (APD)
--------------------------------------------

【11】To test for auditory processing disorder (APD) you or your child may be asked to:

【12】*   listen to speech with background noise
*   spot small changes in sounds
*   fill in missing parts of words

【13】Other tests may include:

【14】*   having electrodes on your head to measure how your brain reacts to sound
*   speech and language tests
*   memory, problem-solving and concentration tests

【15】Testing for APD is not usually done on children under 7 years old.

【16】Treating auditory processing disorder (APD)
-------------------------------------------

【17】There's no cure for auditory processing disorder (APD) but there are things that can help.

【18】Treatment usually involves activities to improve listening and concentration. This is called auditory training. You can do it with a hearing specialist or in your own time online.

【19】To reduce background noise, schoolchildren with APD may be advised to wear a wireless earpiece that connects to a tiny microphone worn by their teacher.

【20】Things you can do to help with auditory processing disorder (APD)
-----------------------------------------------------------------

【21】There are things that you and other people can do to help with your or your child's auditory processing disorder (APD).

【22】### Do

【23】*   talk face to face

【24】*   use pictures and text

【25】*   repeat or rephrase things if necessary

【26】*   use carpet and soft furnishings to reduce room noise

【27】### Don’t

【28】*   do not cover your mouth when talking

【29】*   do not talk in long complicated sentences

【30】*   do not speak too fast or too slow

【31】*   do not have background noise, like TV and radio

【32】Information:

【33】APD Support UK provides information and online support groups for parents and adults with APD

【34】Causes of auditory processing disorder (APD)
--------------------------------------------

【35】It's not always clear what causes auditory processing disorder (APD).

【36】Possible causes include:

【37】*   regular ear infections
*   genetics
*   head injury
*   complications at birth

【38】APD is often found in people with attention, language and learning difficulties, such as dyslexia and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 31 July 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 31 July 2026</u>

source_info.title: Huntington's disease
source_info.text:
【0】Tests \- Huntington's disease
=============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Tests
4.  Treatment and support</u>

【2】**A test to look for the genetic change that causes Huntington's disease can be used to diagnose the condition or check if you or your child will develop it later in life.**

【3】Test to find out if you'll get Huntington's disease
---------------------------------------------------

【4】If you have a history of Huntington's disease in your family (especially if a parent or grandparent had it), you can have a test to see if you'll also get it.

【5】It's up to you to decide if you want to have the test. Lots of people at risk of Huntington's disease decide they'd rather not know until any symptoms appear.

【6】If you do want to know, ask your GP for a referral to a genetic counsellor. You'll have several appointments with the counsellor. It's only done once all the benefits and risks have been explained.

【7】The test involves checking a sample of your blood for the genetic fault that causes the condition. It can take a few weeks to get the result删除7：<u>

【8】The Huntington's Disease Association has more information about genetic testing for Huntington's disease.</u>

【9】Tests before or during pregnancy
--------------------------------

【10】Speak to your GP if you're planning a pregnancy and:

【11】*   you have a family history of Huntington's disease
*   a test has shown you have the genetic fault that causes the condition

【12】This might mean your child is at risk of developing Huntington's disease.

【13】Your GP can refer you to a genetic counsellor to discuss your options.

【14】These may include:

【15】*   having a child with a donor egg or sperm
*   adopting a child
*   having a test during pregnancy (chorionic villus sampling) to see if your baby will get Huntington's disease
*   pre-implantation genetic diagnosis – where eggs are fertilised in a laboratory and tested to make sure they don't have the Huntington's disease gene, before being implanted into the womb

【16】Tests to diagnose Huntington's disease
--------------------------------------

【17】If you have symptoms of Huntington's disease, your GP may refer you to a specialist for tests.

【18】The specialist will ask about your symptoms to see if it's likely you have Huntington's disease and rule out similar conditions.

【19】They may examine you and test things like your thinking, balance and walking ability. Sometimes you might also have a brain scan.

【20】A blood test to check for the Huntington's disease gene can confirm if you have the condition.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 29 March 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 29 March 2024</u>

source_info.title: Tranexamic acid
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take tranexamic acid \- Brand name: Cyklokapron
==================================================================

【1】Who can take tranexamic acid
----------------------------

【2】Most adults and children of all ages can take tranexamic acid.

【3】Who may not be able to take tranexamic acid
-------------------------------------------

【4】Tranexamic acid is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell your doctor before taking this medicine if you:

【5】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to tranexamic acid or any other medicine
*   have ever had a blood clot in a vein (deep vein thrombosis) or in your lungs (pulmonary embolism)
*   have had a coagulopathy – a rare condition where lots of small blood clots form in your blood followed by abnormal bleeding
*   have epilepsy
*   have kidney problems
*   are pregnant or trying to get pregnant
*   have irregular periods – this is so your doctor can check what is causing the irregular bleeding and recommend the best treatment for you

source_info.title: Nystatin
source_info.text:
【0】How and when to take or use nystatin \- Brand name: Nystan
==========================================================

【1】It's important to take or use nystatin for as long as your doctor recommends. If you stop taking it too soon, the infection can come back.

【2】Dosage for nystatin liquid
--------------------------

【3】The usual dose of nystatin for adults, babies and children is:

【4】*   to treat oral thrush – 1ml, taken 4 times a day. Leave at least 3 hours between doses. If your doctor gives you different instructions, follow their advice
*   to prevent oral thrush – 1ml, taken once or twice a day

【5】How to take nystatin liquid
---------------------------

【6】It's best to take nystatin liquid after a meal or some food. However, do not mix it with food or water or any other drink.

【7】1.  Shake the bottle well.
2.  Take the lid off and measure out the right amount using an oral syringe, medicine spoon or dropper. Do not use a kitchen teaspoon as it will not measure the right amount.
3.  Put the medicine in your mouth.
4.  Keep it in your mouth for at least 30 seconds if possible, swilling it around your mouth like a mouthwash before you swallow it.
5.  Do not eat or drink anything for 30 minutes after taking it. This stops you washing the medicine out of your mouth too soon.

【8】It may be difficult to get your child to keep it in their mouth, but encourage them to do this if they can. Do not worry if they cannot. The medicine will still help even if they swallow it quickly.

【9】Nystatin cream or ointment
--------------------------

【10】Nystatin is also available mixed with other ingredients in creams and ointments. Your doctor will advise you on which is best for you.

【11】You'll usually apply a cream or ointment 2 or 3 times a day. The amount you use will depend on the skin condition you have. Your doctor or pharmacist will tell you how much to use.

【12】How long to take or use it for
------------------------------

【13】It usually takes nystatin liquid around a week to treat oral thrush, but you'll need to continue taking it for 2 days after this to make sure all the fungus has been killed. Take it for as long as your doctor advises.

【14】If you're using nystatin to prevent oral thrush, your doctor will tell you how long to take it for.

【15】If you're using cream or ointment containing nystatin mixed with other ingredients, you may only need to use it for 7 to 14 days but it will depend on your skin condition. Your doctor will tell you how long to use it for.

【16】If you forget to take or use it
-------------------------------

【17】If you forget a dose, take or use it as soon as you remember, unless it's less than 3 hours until your next dose. In this case, just skip the missed dose and have your next one at the usual time.

【18】Do not take or use 2 doses to make up for a missed dose.

【19】If you forget doses often, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to remember your medicines.

【20】If you take or use too much
---------------------------

【21】Nystatin is generally very safe. Taking too much liquid or using too much cream or ointment is unlikely to harm you or your child.

【22】If you're worried, speak to your pharmacist or doctor.

【23】If your nystatin cream or ointment contains a strong steroid called clobetasol, talk to your pharmacist or doctor. They'll be able to tell you if you've used too much.
删除11：<u>More in Nystatin
----------------

*   Side effects

source_info.title: Mebendazole
source_info.text:
【0】Side effects of mebendazole \- Brand names: Ovex, Vermox
========================================================

【1】Like all medicines, mebendazole can cause side effects, although not everyone gets them.

【2】Common side effects
-------------------

【3】These common side effects of mebendazole happen in more than 1 in 100 people. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【4】Stomach pain

【5】Try to rest. It can help to eat and drink slowly and have smaller and more frequent meals. Placing a heat pad or covered hot water bottle on your stomach may also help.

【6】If you're in a lot of pain, speak to a doctor or pharmacist.

【7】Stomach discomfort including bloating and wind

【8】Stick to simple meals and avoid rich or spicy food. It might help to take mebendazole after you've eaten to see if that helps ease the symptoms.

【9】Diarrhoea

【10】Drink plenty of water or other fluids to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee.

【11】Do not take any other medicines to treat diarrhoea without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor first.

【12】If you take contraceptive pills and you have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet to find out what to do.

【13】Speak to a doctor or pharmacist if the advice on how to cope does not help and a side effect is still bothering you or does not go away.

【14】Serious side effects
--------------------

【15】Stop taking mebendazole and call a doctor or call 111 straight away if the whites of your eyes turn yellow, or your skin turns yellow although this may be less obvious on brown or black skin. These can be signs of liver problems.

【16】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E if:

【17】*   you or your child has a fit or seizure

【18】Find your nearest A&E

【19】### Serious allergic reaction

【20】It happens rarely but it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to mebendazole.

【21】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【22】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【23】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【24】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【25】Other side effects
------------------

【26】These are not all the side effects of mebendazole. For a full list see the leaflet inside your medicines packet.
删除5：<u>Information:

【27】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.
删除12：<u>Visit Yellow Card for further information.</u></u>
删除11：<u>More in Mebendazole
-------------------

source_info.title: Nosebleeds in pregnancy
source_info.text:
【0】Nosebleeds in pregnancy
=======================

【1】Nosebleeds are quite common in pregnancy because of hormonal changes.

【2】They can be frightening, but there's nothing to worry about as long as you don't lose a lot of blood, and they can often be treated at home.

【3】During a nosebleed, blood flows from one or both nostrils. It can be heavy or light and last from a few seconds to more than 10 minutes.

【4】Nosebleeds can happen when you're asleep. You might feel liquid in the back of your throat before blood comes out of your nose if you're lying down.

【5】During pregnancy, you may also find that your nose gets more blocked up than usual.

【6】**How to stop a nosebleed**
---------------------------

【7】*   Sit down and firmly pinch the soft part of your nose, just above your nostrils, for 10 to 15 minutes without releasing the pressure.
*   Lean forward and breathe through your mouth. This will drain blood down your nose instead of down the back of your throat.
*   Sit or stand upright, rather than lying down, as this reduces the blood pressure in the veins of your nose and will discourage further bleeding.
*   Holding a covered ice pack, or a packet of frozen peas wrapped in a tea towel, on the top of your nose may help reduce blood flow. But the evidence to show it works is not very strong.

【8】If the bleeding doesn't stop, seek medical advice – call your midwife or GP urgently.

【9】Avoid blowing your nose, bending down and strenuous activity for at least 24 hours after a nosebleed.

【10】Talk to your midwife or GP if you're worried about your nosebleeds.

【11】Learn more about nosebleeds, including tips for preventing nosebleeds, and read about other common pregnancy problems.
删除11：<u>More in Common symptoms in pregnancy

source_info.title: Lidocaine for mouth and throat
source_info.text:
【0】About lidocaine for mouth and throat \- Brand names: Bonjela, Anbesol, Iglu, Calgel, Covonia
============================================================================================

【1】Lidocaine is a local anaesthetic that numbs the area where you use it. It's used in some medicines to treat:

【2】*   mouth ulcers
*   sore throats
*   teething
*   soreness caused by false teeth (dentures)

【3】Lidocaine treatments for mouth and throat come as gels, ointments, liquids, sprays and lozenges.

【4】You can buy them from a pharmacy. Some treatments are also available to buy in shops.

【5】Nearly all lidocaine mouth and throat treatments contain other active ingredients, such as antiseptics to help kill germs.

【6】There are different types of lidocaine for other conditions, including medicated plasters, skin creams and suppositories.
删除7：<u>Find out more about using lidocaine skin cream and lidocaine for piles and itchy bottom.</u>

【7】Key facts
---------

【8】*   Lidocaine numbs pain quickly. You should start to feel better within 30 minutes.
*   It's generally a safe medicine and side effects are rare.
*   If your baby is teething, check the instructions carefully before giving them lidocaine. Not all treatments are suitable for young children.
*   For teething, it's best to try other things such as teething rings first before using a medicine. Read about tips for helping your teething baby.
*   Be careful of having hot food and drinks after using lidocaine. The numbing effect means you could burn your mouth.
删除11：<u>More in Lidocaine for mouth and throat
--------------------------------------

source_info.title: Chemotherapy
source_info.text:
【0】Side effects \- Chemotherapy
============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  What happens
3.  Side effects</u>

【2】**Chemotherapy can cause unpleasant side effects, although many can be treated or prevented, and most will pass once your treatment stops.**

【3】It's difficult to predict what side effects you'll get.

【4】Here's a list of many of the common side effects, but it's unlikely you'll have all of these.

【5】Tiredness
---------

【6】Tiredness (fatigue) is one of the most common side effects of chemotherapy.

【7】Many people having treatment feel tired a lot of the time or get tired very easily doing everyday tasks.

【8】It can help to:

【9】*   get plenty of rest
*   avoid doing tasks or activities that you do not feel up to
*   do light exercise, such as walking or yoga, if you're able to – this can boost your energy level, but be careful not to push yourself too hard
*   ask your friends and family for help with everyday tasks

【10】If you're working, you may want to ask your employer for time off or arrange to work part-time until your treatment has finished.

【11】Contact your care team if you suddenly feel very tired and out of breath. This can be a sign of anaemia.

【12】Feeling and being sick
----------------------

【13】Many people having chemotherapy will have periods where they feel sick (nausea) or are sick (vomit).

【14】Your care team can give you anti-sickness (antiemetic) medicine to reduce or prevent this.

【15】This is available as:

【16】*   tablets or capsules that you swallow
*   tablets that dissolve in your mouth
*   injections or a drip into a vein
*   suppositories – capsules you put into your bottom
*   a skin patch

【17】Side effects of anti-sickness medicines include constipation, indigestion, problems sleeping (insomnia) and headaches.

【18】Tell your care team if your medicine does not help, or it causes too many side effects. There may be a different one that works better for you.

【19】Hair loss
---------

【20】Hair loss is a common side effect of chemotherapy, although it does not happen to everyone. Ask your care team if it's likely to be a side effect of the medicines you're taking.

【21】If you do lose hair, it usually starts within a few weeks of your first treatment session. If you lose lots of hair, this typically happens within 1 to 2 months.

【22】It's most common to lose hair from your head, but you can also lose it from other parts of your body, including your arms, legs and face.

【23】The hair loss is almost always temporary. Your hair should start to grow back soon after your treatment has finished.

【24】But sometimes the hair that grows back is a slightly different colour or it may be curlier or straighter than it used to be.

【25】### Coping with hair loss

【26】Hair loss can be upsetting. Talk to your care team if you're finding it difficult to cope with losing your hair.

【27】They understand how distressing it can be and can support you and discuss your options with you.

【28】For example, you may decide you want to wear a wig. Synthetic wigs are available free of charge on the NHS for some people, but you'll usually have to pay for a wig made from real hair.

【29】Other options include headwear, such as a headscarf.
删除7：<u>Read more about advice about cancer and hair loss.</u>

【30】### Preventing hair loss

【31】It may be possible to reduce the chances of hair loss by wearing a cold cap while you're having chemotherapy.

【32】A cold cap looks like a bicycle helmet and is designed to cool your scalp during a treatment session. This reduces blood flow to your scalp, reducing the amount of medicine that reaches it.

【33】Whether you can use a cold cap depends on the type of cancer you have. Cold caps also work better with certain types of chemotherapy medicine, and they do not always work.

【34】Ask your care team whether a cold cap might help you.

【35】Infections
----------

【36】Chemotherapy can reduce your body's ability to fight infection. This makes you more likely to get infections that could make you seriously ill.

【37】It's a good idea to take precautions to protect yourself against infection by:

【38】*   washing your hands regularly with soap and water – particularly after going to the toilet, before preparing food and eating, and after touching pets or other animals (as they can have infections that can be dangerous)
*   trying to avoid close contact with people who have an infection – such as chickenpox or flu
*   having the annual flu jab
*   getting vaccinated against COVID-19 – your specialist can give more advice

【39】A course of antibiotics may sometimes be prescribed to reduce your risk of getting an infection.

【40】Anaemia
-------

【41】Chemotherapy lowers your amount of red blood cells, which carry oxygen around the body.

【42】If your red blood cell count drops too low, you'll develop anaemia.

【43】Symptoms of anaemia include:

【44】*   tiredness and lack of energy – this tends to be more severe than the general fatigue associated with chemotherapy
*   shortness of breath
*   noticeable heartbeats (heart palpitations)
*   a pale complexion

【45】Contact your care team as soon as possible if you have any of these symptoms. You may need treatment to increase your number of red blood cells.

【46】### Preventing anaemia

【47】Including a high amount of iron in your diet can help reduce your risk of anaemia, as iron helps the body make red blood cells.

【48】Foods high in iron include:

【49】*   meat, such as beef, pork and lamb
*   beans and nuts
*   dried fruit, such as dried apricots
*   wholegrains, such as brown rice
*   fortified breakfast cereals
*   dark-green leafy vegetables, such as watercress and curly kale
删除7：<u>Read more about iron deficiency anaemia.</u>

【50】Bruising and bleeding
---------------------

【51】Chemotherapy can reduce the number of cells called platelets in your blood. These help stop severe bleeding when you cut or injure yourself.

【52】If you have a low number of platelets, you may have:

【53】*   skin that bruises easily
*   severe nosebleeds
*   bleeding gums

【54】Tell your care team if you experience these problems. You may need treatment to increase the number of platelets in your blood.

【55】Sore mouth
----------

【56】Sometimes chemotherapy can make the lining of the mouth sore and irritated. This is known as mucositis.

【57】Symptoms tend to develop a few days after treatment starts and include:

【58】*   the inside of your mouth feeling sore, as if you've burned it by eating very hot food
*   mouth ulcers, which can become infected
*   discomfort when eating, drinking and/or talking
*   a dry mouth
*   reduced sense of taste
*   bad breath

【59】Tell your care team if you have any of these problems. They may recommend painkillers or a special mouthwash that can help.

【60】Avoiding spicy, salty or sharp foods can also help.

【61】Laser therapy, where low-levels lasers are used to stimulate healing, have proved effective in treating or preventing mucositis. But as this is a new type of treatment, access to it may be limited.

【62】Mucositis usually gets better a few weeks after chemotherapy finishes.

【63】Loss of appetite
----------------

【64】You may lose your appetite while you're having chemotherapy, but you should try to drink plenty of fluids and eat what you can.

【65】It may help to:

【66】*   eat smaller meals more often instead of 3 larger meals each day
*   eat healthy snacks regularly
*   eat light meals on the day of your treatment
*   sip drinks slowly through a straw, rather than drinking them straight from a glass

【67】Tell your care team if you're worried about your diet or lack of appetite.

【68】Skin and nail changes
---------------------

【69】Some chemotherapy medicines can cause temporary changes to your skin.

【70】For example, it may become:

【71】*   dry
*   slightly discoloured (this may be patchy)
*   more sensitive to sunlight
*   red and sore
*   itchy

【72】Talk to your care team if you have any problems with your skin. They can advise you about creams that can help and how to protect your skin from the sun.

【73】Chemotherapy can also make your nails become brittle or flaky, and white lines may develop across them. This should go back to normal after your treatment has finished.

【74】Using moisturiser on your nails may help and nail varnish can be used to cover your nails during treatment if you like. Avoid using quick drying varnish or false nails as these have an increased risk of infection.

【75】Memory and concentration problems
---------------------------------

【76】Some people have problems with their short-term memory, concentration and attention span during chemotherapy. You may find that routine tasks take much longer than usual.

【77】It's unclear why this happens, but the symptoms usually improve once treatment is finished.

【78】Things such as using lists, post-it notes, calendars and your mobile phone for reminders can help. Doing some mental exercises, eating well, and getting enough rest may also be useful.

【79】Sleep problems
--------------

【80】Some people having chemotherapy have difficulty falling asleep, or wake up in the middle of the night and cannot get back to sleep. This is known as insomnia.

【81】The following may help to improve your sleep:

【82】*   set regular times for going to bed and waking up
*   relax before bedtime – try taking a warm bath or listening to calming music
*   use thick curtains or blinds, an eye mask and earplugs to stop you being woken up by light and noise
*   avoid caffeine, nicotine, alcohol, heavy meals and exercise for a few hours before going to bed
*   avoid watching TV or using a phone, tablet or computer shortly before going to bed
*   write a list of your worries, and any ideas about how to solve them, before going to bed, to help you forget about them until the morning

【83】Contact your care team if this advice does not work, as you may need additional treatment.
删除7：<u>Read more about insomnia.</u>

【84】Sex and fertility issues
------------------------

【85】Many people find that they lose interest in sex during chemotherapy. This is usually temporary, and your sex drive should gradually return after your treatment has finished.

【86】Some chemotherapy medicines can also reduce fertility in men and women. This is often temporary, but it can be permanent in some cases.

【87】Before starting treatment, ask your care team whether your fertility may be affected. If you're at risk of infertility, they will discuss your options with you.

【88】Women may be able to have their eggs frozen to be used later in IVF. Men may be able to have a sample of their sperm frozen so it can be used for artificial insemination at a later date.

【89】You should avoid becoming pregnant or fathering a child during your treatment, as chemotherapy medicines could harm the baby. Use a barrier method of contraception, such as a condom.

【90】Diarrhoea and constipation
--------------------------

【91】You may have diarrhoea or constipation a few days after you begin chemotherapy.

【92】Your care team can recommend suitable medicines and diet changes that can help.

【93】Emotional issues
----------------

【94】Having chemotherapy can be a frustrating, stressful and traumatic experience. It's natural to feel anxious and to wonder if your treatment will be successful.

【95】Stress and anxiety can also increase your risk of getting depression.

【96】Speak to your care team if you're struggling to cope emotionally. They can offer support and discuss possible treatment strategies.

【97】Joining a cancer support group may also help. Talking to other people in a similar situation can often reduce feelings of isolation and stress.

【98】The charity Macmillan Cancer Support has a directory of local support groups. You can also call the Macmillan Support Line free on 0808 808 00 00 (every day, 8am-8pm).

【99】When to get urgent medical advice
---------------------------------

【100】While the side effects of chemotherapy can be distressing, most are not serious.

【101】Infections can be very serious if not treated immediately. Contact your care team immediately if you have any symptoms of an infection, these include:

【102】*   a temperature of above 37.5C or below 36C
*   your skin feels warm to touch, or you feel hot and shivery
*   breathing difficulties
*   flu-like symptoms, such as muscle aches and pain
*   a sore mouth
*   pain when swallowing
*   being sick
*   diarrhoea
*   pain, swelling, redness, heat and /or a discharge of liquid at the site of a wound (such as a surgical scar) or where an intravenous or catheter line has been put into one of your veins (usually your upper arm)

【103】You should have been given a card with emergency phone numbers to call. Contact a GP or use NHS 111 if you do not have a card or cannot find it.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 25 May 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 25 May 2026</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : What happens</u>

source_info.title: Testicle lumps and swellings
source_info.text:
【0】Testicle lumps and swellings
============================

【1】**Lumps and swellings in the testicles (balls) are not usually caused by anything serious, but you should always get them checked by a GP.**

【2】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if you have:
----------------------------------------

【3】*   a lump in your testicles
*   swollen testicles
*   a change in the shape of your testicles
*   a change in the way your testicles feel
*   1 testicle that has become bigger than the other
*   aching or discomfort in your testicles that does not go away

【4】Lumps in the testicles can be a sign of testicular cancer. This is easier to treat if it's found early.

【5】Immediate action required: Go to A&E immediately or call 999 if you have any of these symptoms:
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

【6】*   sudden, severe pain in a testicle
*   testicle pain along with feeling sick, being sick or pain in your tummy
*   testicle pain that has lasted more than an hour or continues when you're resting

【7】These can be signs of a serious problem that needs to be treated in hospital as soon as possible.

【8】Find your nearest A&E

【9】What happens at your GP appointment
-----------------------------------

【10】To find out what the cause of the lump or swelling in your testicle is, the GP may:

【11】*   look at and feel your testicles
*   shine a torch through the bag of skin containing your testicles (scrotum) to check for a build-up of fluid
*   refer you for an ultrasound scan

【12】Treatment for a lump or swelling depends on the cause. You might not need treatment if it does not cause any problems and is not getting worse.

【13】If the lump or swelling is painful or very big, the GP may refer you to a specialist for an operation to drain, shrink or remove it.

【14】Causes of testicle lumps and swellings
--------------------------------------

【15】Lumps and swellings in the testicles can have lots of different causes.

【16】Most are caused by something less serious, such as a build-up of fluid (cyst) or swollen veins in the testicles (varicocele).

【17】But sometimes they can be a sign of something serious, such as testicular cancer.

【18】Do not try to self-diagnose the cause of your lump – always see a GP.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 18 July 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 18 July 2026</u>

source_info.title: NHS screening
source_info.text:
【0】NHS screening
=============

【1】**Screening is a way of finding out if people have a higher chance of having a health problem, so that early treatment can be offered or information given to help them make informed decisions.**

【2】This page gives an overview of screening, with links to the different types of screening offered by the NHS in England.

【3】What is screening?
------------------

【4】Screening is a way of identifying apparently healthy people who may have an increased risk of a particular condition. The NHS offers a range of screening tests to different sections of the population.

【5】The aim is to offer screening to the people who are most likely to benefit from it. For example, some screening tests are only offered to newborn babies, while others such as breast screening and abdominal aortic aneurysm screening are only offered to older people.

【6】### Screening results

【7】If you get a normal result (a screen negative result) after a screening test, this means you are at low risk of having the condition you were screened for. This does not mean you will never develop the condition in the future, just that you are low risk at the moment.

【8】If you have a higher-risk result (a screen positive result), it means you may have the condition that you've been tested for. At this point, you will be offered further tests (called diagnostic tests) to confirm if you have the condition. You can then be offered treatment, advice and support.

【9】Finding out about a problem early can mean that treatment is more effective. However, screening tests are not perfect and they can lead to difficult decisions about having further tests or treatment.

【10】Read on to find out about the benefits, risks and limitations of screening.

【11】What types of screening are offered by the NHS in England?
----------------------------------------------------------

【12】An independent expert group called the UK National Screening Committee (UK NSC) advises the NHS, in all 4 UK countries, on which screening programmes to offer.

【13】The NHS screening programmes currently offered in England are listed below. For more detailed information on each type of screening, follow the links.

【14】You can view screening timelines.

【15】Information:

【16】You can also watch animations about NHS screening:

【17】*   female lifetime NHS screening pathway (Youtube)
*   male lifetime NHS screening pathway (Youtube)

【18】### Screening in pregnancy

【19】The screening tests offered in pregnancy are:

【20】*   screening for infectious diseases (hepatitis B, HIV and syphilis)
*   screening for Down's syndrome, Patau's syndrome and Edwards' syndrome
*   screening for sickle cell disease and thalassaemia
*   screening to check the physical development of the baby (known as the 20-week scan or mid-pregnancy scan)
*   diabetic eye screening if you are pregnant and have type 1 or type 2 diabetes

【21】### Screening for newborn babies

【22】Newborn babies are offered:

【23】*   a physical examination, which includes the eyes, heart, hips and testes
*   a hearing test
*   a blood spot test to check if the baby has any of 9 rare conditions

【24】### Diabetic eye screening

【25】From the age of 12, all people with diabetes are offered an annual diabetic eye test to check for early signs of diabetic retinopathy.

【26】### Cervical screening

【27】Cervical screening is offered to all women and people with a cervix aged 25 to 64 to check the health of cells in the cervix. It is offered every 3 years for those aged 25 to 49, and every 5 years from the ages of 50 to 64.

【28】### Breast screening

【29】Breast screening is offered to women aged 50 to 70 to detect early signs of breast cancer. Women over 70 can self-refer.

【30】### Bowel cancer screening

【31】Everyone aged 60 to 74 is offered a bowel cancer screening home test kit every 2 years.

【32】If you're 75 or over, you can ask for a kit every 2 years by phoning the free bowel cancer screening helpline on 0800 707 60 60.

【33】### Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) screening

【34】AAA screening is offered to men during the screening year (1 April to 31 March) that they turn 65 to detect abdominal aortic aneurysms (a dangerous swelling in the aorta). Men over 65 can self-refer.

【35】Benefits, risks and limitations of screening
--------------------------------------------

【36】### Making an informed choice

【37】Before having any screening test, it's worth finding out about the test itself and what would happen next if you found out you have a higher risk of a particular condition.

【38】Deciding whether or not to have a screening test is a personal choice and one which only you can make. When you are invited for screening, you will receive an information leaflet about the screening test.

【39】You can discuss any aspect of the screening test with your health professional and decide whether or not it's right for you.

【40】Different types of screening have different benefits and risks. Some of these are listed below.

【41】### The benefits of having a screening test include:

【42】*   Screening can detect a problem early, before you have any symptoms.
*   Finding out about a problem early can mean that treatment is more effective.
*   Finding out you have a health problem or an increased chance of a health problem can help people make better informed decisions about their health.
*   Screening can reduce the chance of developing a condition or its complications.
*   Some deaths from abdominal aortic aneurysms, bowel cancer, breast cancer and cervical cancer can be prevented.

【43】### The risks and limitations of screening include:

【44】*   Screening tests are not 100% accurate. You could be told you have a problem when you do not – this is called a "false positive" and may lead to some people having unnecessary further tests or treatment as a result of screening. A screening test could also miss a problem – this is called a "false negative" and could lead to people ignoring symptoms in the future.
*   Some screening tests can lead to difficult decisions. For example, if a pregnancy screening test tells you your baby has a higher chance of having a particular condition, you may then be faced with a decision about having further diagnostic tests that involve a risk to your pregnancy. If the diagnostic test is positive, you may then need to decide whether to continue with your pregnancy.
*   Finding out you may have a health problem can cause considerable anxiety.
*   Even if your screening test result is normal or negative (meaning you are not at high risk), you could still go on to develop the condition.

【45】### How does the NHS decide which types of screening to offer?

【46】An expert group called the UK National Screening Committee **(**UK NSC) advises the NHS on which screening programmes to offer.

【47】When considering who to screen and which conditions to screen for, the benefits of offering a screening programme are weighed up against the harms. The UK NSC only recommends screening when it believes the benefits to the group offered screening outweigh the harms.

【48】The UK NSC regularly reviews its recommendations on screening for different conditions as new research becomes available. This is usually done every 3 years.

【49】Find out how the UK NSC reviews evidence and monitors the quality of screening programmes.

【50】### Private screening

【51】All screening tests provided by the NHS are free. Private companies offer a range of screening tests that you have to pay for. Some of the tests on offer are not recommended by the UK NSC because it is not clear that the benefits outweigh the harms.

【52】The UK NSC has produced a downloadable leaflet on private screening.

【53】Confidentiality and use of data
-------------------------------

【54】By law, everyone working in, or on behalf of, the NHS must respect your privacy and keep all information about you safe. The NHS Constitution sets out how the NHS should handle your records to protect your privacy. There are also laws in place to ensure that confidentiality is maintained.

【55】Screening records are only shared with staff who need to see them, such as technicians carrying out screening, your GP and any clinicians involved in follow-up tests and treatment. They are also shared with the Government who uses them to check that local screening services are safe and effective. Screening records are sometimes also shared with researchers looking at how to improve the screening programmes.
删除7：<u>Read more about screening data and confidentiality.</u>

【56】Further information about screening
-----------------------------------

【57】### Questions about screening results

【58】*   For pregnancy or baby screening results, contact your midwife or health visitor.
*   For abdominal aortic aneurism or diabetic eye screening, contact a GP or your local screening programme.
*   For breast screening, cervical screening or bowel cancer screening, contact a GP, who should receive a copy of your results. You can also contact your local breast screening unit, or call the bowel cancer screening helpline on 0800 707 6060.

【59】### Questions about symptoms

【60】Speak to a GP if you have any concerns about your health or need to ask about a family history of cancer.

【61】### Questions about screening practice and policy (England only)

【62】Contact the national screening helpdesk using the online enquiry form, or email PHE.screeninghelpdesk@nhs.net
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 20 July 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 20 July 2024</u>
