If the diagnostic test is positive, you may then need to decide whether to continue with your pregnancy.
*   Finding out you may have a health problem can cause considerable anxiety.
*   Even if your screening test result is normal or negative (meaning you are not at high risk), you could still go on to develop the condition.

【45】### How does the NHS decide which types of screening to offer?

【46】An expert group called the UK National Screening Committee **(**UK NSC) advises the NHS on which screening programmes to offer.

【47】When considering who to screen and which conditions to screen for, the benefits of offering a screening programme are weighed up against the harms. The UK NSC only recommends screening when it believes the benefits to the group offered screening outweigh the harms.

【48】The UK NSC regularly reviews its recommendations on screening for different conditions as new research becomes available. This is usually done every 3 years.

【49】Find out how the UK NSC reviews evidence and monitors the quality of screening programmes.

【50】### Private screening

【51】All screening tests provided by the NHS are free. Private companies offer a range of screening tests that you have to pay for. Some of the tests on offer are not recommended by the UK NSC because it is not clear that the benefits outweigh the harms.

【52】The UK NSC has produced a downloadable leaflet on private screening.

【53】Confidentiality and use of data
-------------------------------

【54】By law, everyone working in, or on behalf of, the NHS must respect your privacy and keep all information about you safe. The NHS Constitution sets out how the NHS should handle your records to protect your privacy. There are also laws in place to ensure that confidentiality is maintained.

【55】Screening records are only shared with staff who need to see them, such as technicians carrying out screening, your GP and any clinicians involved in follow-up tests and treatment. They are also shared with the Government who uses them to check that local screening services are safe and effective. Screening records are sometimes also shared with researchers looking at how to improve the screening programmes.
删除7：<u>Read more about screening data and confidentiality.</u>

【56】Further information about screening
-----------------------------------

【57】### Questions about screening results

【58】*   For pregnancy or baby screening results, contact your midwife or health visitor.
*   For abdominal aortic aneurism or diabetic eye screening, contact a GP or your local screening programme.
*   For breast screening, cervical screening or bowel cancer screening, contact a GP, who should receive a copy of your results. You can also contact your local breast screening unit, or call the bowel cancer screening helpline on 0800 707 6060.

【59】### Questions about symptoms

【60】Speak to a GP if you have any concerns about your health or need to ask about a family history of cancer.

【61】### Questions about screening practice and policy (England only)

【62】Contact the national screening helpdesk using the online enquiry form, or email PHE.screeninghelpdesk@nhs.net
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 20 July 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 20 July 2024</u>

source_info.title: Being discharged from hospital
source_info.text:
【0】Being discharged from hospital
==============================

【1】Each hospital has its own discharge policy. You should be able to get a copy from the ward manager or the hospital's Patient Advice and Liaison Service (PALS).

【2】Once you're admitted to hospital, your treatment plan, including details for discharge or transfer, will be developed and discussed with you.

【3】A discharge assessment will determine whether you need more care after you leave hospital.

【4】You should be fully involved in the assessment process. With your permission, family or carers will also be kept informed and given the opportunity to contribute.

【5】If you need help putting your views across, an independent advocate may be able to help.

【6】Find out about getting back to normal after an operation

【7】Minimal and complex discharge
-----------------------------

【8】If the discharge assessment shows you'll need little or no care, it's called a minimal discharge.

【9】If you need more specialised care after leaving hospital, your discharge or transfer procedure is referred to as a complex discharge.

【10】If you need this type of care, you'll receive a care plan detailing your health and social care needs.

【11】You should be fully involved in this process.

【12】A care plan should include:

【13】*   details of the treatment and support you'll get when discharged
*   who will be responsible for providing support and how to contact them
*   when and how often support will be provided
*   how the support will be monitored and reviewed
*   the name of the person co-ordinating the care plan
*   who to contact if there's an emergency or things do not work as they should
*   information about any charges that will need to be paid (if applicable)
删除7：<u>Find out more about care and support plans</u>

【14】You'll also be given a letter for your GP, providing information about your treatment and future care needs. Give this letter to your GP as soon as possible.

【15】Medicine
--------

【16】If you're given any medicine to take home, you'll usually be given enough for the following 7 days. The letter to your GP will include information about your medicine.

【17】If you need to keep taking your medication, make sure you arrange to get a repeat prescription from your GP before your hospital supply runs out.

【18】Some surgeries require up to 2 working days (48 hours) notice for repeat prescriptions.

【19】If you're registered for patient online services with your GP, you could order your repeat prescription through the NHS website. Simply look up the GP practice using find services.
删除7：<u>Find out more about health and prescription services</u>

【20】Your local pharmacy can help you get on top of your new medicines.

【21】Simply arrange a chat and ask for the New Medicine Service (NMS).

【22】Medical devices
---------------

【23】If you're sent home with a medical device, make sure you know how to set it up and have been taught how to use it.

【24】Also, make sure you know where to get any supplies you need to use the device and who to call if you need help.

【25】Organising transport
--------------------

【26】If you're being discharged, arrange for a relative or friend to collect you, or let the staff know if they need to make other transport arrangements for you.

【27】Returning home
--------------

【28】If you're returning home, make sure you have everything you need for your recovery.

【29】It may be helpful to ask a friend or relative to stay with you or visit regularly.

【30】If this is not possible, make sure you have plenty of food, drink and other essentials at home.

【31】Sick notes
----------

【32】You may need a sick note or information for insurance companies or your employer.

【33】Speak to the nurse in charge of your ward if you need a form to be completed.

【34】Find out when you may need a fit note

【35】Remember
--------

【36】Do not forget to:

【37】*   provide a forwarding address for any post
*   collect your hospital discharge letter for your GP or arrange to have it sent directly to them
*   ensure you have the medicine you need
*   get a copy of your care plan (if applicable) – if you're being discharged to a care home, the home should be told the date and time of your discharge, and have a copy of the care plan
*   arrange your follow-up appointment, if you need one
*   ask for any medical certificates you may need

【38】Feedback and complaints
-----------------------

【39】Talk to hospital staff if you're unhappy about your suggested discharge or transfer date.

【40】You have the right to discharge yourself from hospital at any time during your stay in hospital.

【41】If you want to complain about how a hospital discharge was handled, speak to the staff involved to see if the problem can be resolved informally.

【42】Alternatively, speak to a PALS member at the hospital. PALS offers confidential advice, support and information on health-related matters.

【43】Find your local PALS

【44】You could contact an NHS Complaints Advocacy service. Your local council will be able to tell you who the local advocacy provider is.

【45】GOV.UK: find your local council

【46】If you wish to raise a formal complaint, follow the NHS complaints procedure.

【47】You can also rate or review a hospital. Simply find the hospital you wish to comment on and leave an overall star rating or post a review for other patients to read.
删除11：<u>More in Going into hospital
---------------------------

【48】*   Outpatients and day patients
*   Going into hospital as a patient
*   Staying in hospital as an inpatient
*   Visiting someone in hospital
*   Being discharged from hospital
*   How to organise transport to and from hospital
*   Staying with my child in hospital
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 6 April 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 6 April 2026</u>

source_info.title: Androgen insensitivity syndrome
source_info.text:
【0】Symptoms \- Androgen insensitivity syndrome
===========================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Living with</u>

【2】**Babies with androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) will have XY (usual male pattern) chromosomes. Their external genitals will either appear as female or have an appearance that is not usual for a boy or girl.**

【3】There are 2 main types of AIS, which affect people in different ways:

【4】*   complete androgen insensitivity (CAIS)
*   partial androgen insensitivity (PAIS)

【5】Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS)
-----------------------------------------------

【6】CAIS is not usually obvious from birth because affected babies have female genitals, including a vagina and labia (folds of skin either side of the vaginal opening).

【7】They'll also have undescended testicles, but this will usually go unnoticed unless they cause a hernia (where they push through a weakness in the surrounding tissue).

【8】The first signs usually begin at puberty, which starts at around the age of 11 or 12.

【9】When a girl with CAIS reaches puberty, she will:

【10】*   develop breasts and have growth spurts as normal, although she may end up slightly taller than usual for a girl
*   not start having periods
*   develop little or no pubic and underarm hair

【11】Girls with CAIS do not have a womb or ovaries, so are unable to get pregnant. Their vagina will also be shorter than normal, which may make some sexual acts difficult.

【12】Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome (PAIS)
----------------------------------------------

【13】The development of children with PAIS can vary.

【14】In many cases, the genitalia at birth is the first sign and affected babies may have:

【15】*   an enlarged clitoris (the sexual organ that allows women to have an orgasm)
*   partially undescended testicles
*   hypospadias – where the hole through which urine passes out of the body is on the underside of the penis, rather than at the end

【16】Children with PAIS are often raised as boys, although they will continue to have a small penis and may develop some breast tissue at puberty.

【17】Some children with PAIS are raised as girls.

【18】Like those with CAIS, people with PAIS do not have a womb or ovaries and will be infertile.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 17 March 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 17 March 2024</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Androgen insensitivity syndrome</u>删除1：<u>*   Next : Causes</u>

source_info.title: Pityriasis rosea
source_info.text:
【0】Pityriasis rosea
================

【1】**Pityriasis rosea is a relatively common skin condition that causes a temporary rash of raised red scaly patches on the body.**

【2】It can affect anyone, but it's more common in older children and young adults (aged 10 to 35).

【3】Symptoms of pityriasis rosea
----------------------------

【4】### Feeling unwell

【5】Some people feel unwell for a few days before they get the rash, with symptoms such as a headache, high temperature and joint pain.

【6】### The herald patch
删除9：<u>Credit:

【7】DR H.C.ROBINSON / SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/260599/view</u>

【8】A single pink or red oval patch of scaly skin, called the "herald patch", usually appears at least 2 days before a more widespread rash develops.

【9】The herald patch ranges in size from 2cm to 10cm. It can appear on your tummy, chest, back or neck, and less often on your face or scalp, or near your genitals.

【10】### Widespread rash
删除9：<u>Credit:

【11】ISM/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/694054/view</u>

【12】Up to 2 weeks after the herald patch appears, a more widespread rash develops, which may continue to spread over the following 2 to 6 weeks.

【13】This rash is small, raised, scaly patches that usually range in size up to 1.5cm. Most people get many patches on their chest, back, tummy, neck, upper arms and upper thighs. The face is not usually affected.

【14】The rash is not painful, but it can be itchy.

【15】In light-skinned people the patches are usually a pinkish-red. In dark-skinned people the patches can sometimes be grey, dark brown or black.

【16】Both the herald patch and rash usually last for 2 to 12 weeks, although they can last for up to 5 months.

【17】After the rash has gone, you may have some darker or lighter areas of skin. These should return to normal within a few months and will not leave permanent scarring.

【18】When to see a GP
----------------

【19】See a GP if you have an unexplained rash. They'll usually be able to confirm whether it's pityriasis rosea, or another skin condition such as eczema, psoriasis or ringworm.

【20】If the GP is uncertain, they may refer you to a skin specialist (dermatologist).

【21】Treating pityriasis rosea
-------------------------

【22】Pityriasis rosea usually gets better without treatment within 12 weeks. Treatment is not needed unless you experience discomfort and itching.

【23】Possible treatments for pityriasis rosea include:

【24】*   emollients – creams that moisturise and soothe the skin. Some emollients can be used as soap, and are often recommended, because normal soap can irritate the rash. You can buy these over the counter from most pharmacists
*   steroid creams or ointments – such as hydrocortisone and betamethasone cream. These are prescribed by a GP and can reduce swelling and relieve itching
*   antihistamines – if you're having trouble sleeping because of the itching, a GP may prescribe an antihistamine that will make you feel sleepy, such as hydroxyzine or chlorphenamine
*   UVB light therapy – if other treatments do not work, you may be referred for UVB light therapy

【25】What causes pityriasis rosea?
-----------------------------

【26】It's not known what causes pityriasis rosea. One theory is that the rash may be caused by a viral infection.

【27】Pityriasis rosea is not contagious and cannot be spread to other people through physical contact.

【28】Pityriasis versicolor
---------------------

【29】Pityriasis versicolor is another common skin condition that can be confused with pityriasis rosea, as the rash may look similar.

【30】But there are important differences between these 2 conditions. Pityriasis versicolor is caused by a yeast infection and can be treated with antifungal medicines, including antifungal creams and antifungal shampoos.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 13 March 2020  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 13 March 2023</u>

source_info.title: Encephalitis
source_info.text:
【0】Symptoms \- Encephalitis
========================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications</u>

【2】**Symptoms of encephalitis may be mild to begin with, but can become more serious over hours or days.**

【3】Occasionally the symptoms may develop gradually over several weeks or even months.

【4】Early symptoms
--------------

【5】The first symptoms of encephalitis can be similar to flu, such as:

【6】*   a high temperature
*   a headache
*   feeling and being sick
*   aching muscles and joints

【7】Some people may also have a spotty or blistery rash on their skin.

【8】But these early symptoms do not always appear and sometimes the first signs of encephalitis may be more serious symptoms.

【9】Serious symptoms
----------------

【10】More severe symptoms develop when the brain is affected, such as:

【11】*   confusion or disorientation
*   drowsiness
*   seizures or fits
*   changes in personality and behaviour, such as feeling very agitated
*   difficulty speaking
*   weakness or loss of movement in some parts of the body
*   seeing and hearing things that are not there (hallucinations and hearing voices)
*   loss of feeling in certain parts of the body
*   uncontrollable eye movements, such as side-to-side eye movement
*   eyesight problems
*   loss of consciousness

【12】There may also be symptoms of meningitis, such as a severe headache, sensitivity to bright lights, a stiff neck and a spotty rash that does not fade when a glass is pressed against it.

【13】When to get medical advice
--------------------------

【14】Dial 999 immediately to request an ambulance if you or someone else has serious symptoms of encephalitis.

【15】It's a medical emergency that needs to be seen in hospital as soon as possible.

【16】Read about how encephalitis is diagnosed and how encephalitis is treated.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 15 May 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 15 May 2026</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Encephalitis</u>删除1：<u>*   Next : Causes</u>

source_info.title: Essential tremor, see Tremor or shaking hands
source_info.text:
【0】Essential tremor, see Tremor or shaking hands
Tremor or shaking hands
=======================

【1】**A tremor is when you're not able to control shaking or trembling in part of your body. See a GP if a tremor is affecting your life as treatment may help to reduce it.**

【2】When a tremor is normal
-----------------------

【3】It's normal to have a slight tremor. For example, if you hold your hands or arms out in front of you, they will not be completely still.

【4】Sometimes a tremor becomes more noticeable.

【5】This often happens:

【6】*   as you get older
*   when you're stressed, tired, anxious or angry
*   after drinking caffeine (for example, in tea, coffee or cola), drinking alcohol, or smoking
*   if you're very hot or cold

【7】Some medicines and conditions can also cause a tremor. Speak to your GP before you stop taking any prescribed medicine.

【8】### Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:

【9】You have a tremor or shaking hands and:

【10】*   it's getting worse over time
*   it's affecting your daily activities

【11】Your doctor will want to make sure the tremor is not caused by another condition. They may also be able to offer treatment.

【12】What happens at your GP appointment
-----------------------------------

【13】To find out what might be causing your tremor, a GP may examine you and ask:

【14】*   if you have any other symptoms
*   if you're taking any medicine
*   about your and your family's medical history – some types of tremor run in families

【15】A mild tremor that's not caused by another condition does not usually need any treatment. The GP may want to monitor you to make sure it does not get any worse.

【16】You may be referred to a specialist for further tests if your tremor could be a symptom of a condition like Parkinson's disease or multiple sclerosis.

【17】Treating a severe tremor
------------------------

【18】If you have a tremor that's affecting your life, your GP may prescribe medicine. Medicine will not cure the tremor, but it often helps to reduce the shaking or trembling.

【19】You may need to take medicine all the time, or only when you need it – for example, before a stressful situation that causes your tremor to get worse.

【20】If a tremor is affecting your head or voice, you may be offered injections to block the nerves and relax the muscles.

【21】Rarely, brain surgery may be an option to treat a severe tremor that is not helped by medicine.

【22】Information:
删除4：<u>### More information

【23】*   National Tremor Foundation: surgery and tremor
*   National Tremor Foundation: daily living
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 14 November 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 14 November 2026</u></u>

source_info.title: Timolol tablets
source_info.text:
【0】Taking timolol tablets with other medicines and herbal supplements
==================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】There are some medicines that may affect the way timolol tablets work. Timolol can also affect other medicines.

【3】Tell your doctor if you're taking any of these medicines:

【4】*   any other medicines for high blood pressure - the combination with timolol tablets can sometimes lower your blood pressure too much. This may make you feel dizzy or faint. If this keeps happening to you, tell your doctor – they may change your dose
*   other medicines for an irregular heartbeat, such as amiodarone or verapamil
*   other medicines which can lower your blood pressure, including some antidepressants, nitrates (for chest pain), baclofen (a muscle relaxant), medicines for an enlarged prostate gland, like tamsulosin or Parkinson's disease medicines such as co-careldopa or levodopa
*   medicines for asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
*   medicines for diabetes, particularly insulin or medicines that can cause low blood sugar (hypoglycaemia) – timolol may make it more difficult to recognise the warning signs of low blood sugar. Speak to your doctor if you have low blood sugar levels without getting any of the usual warning signs. Check your blood sugar after exercise, and follow usual advice about checking it before driving, or operating machinery
*   medicines to treat nose or sinus congestion, or other cold remedies (including those you can buy in a pharmacy)
*   medicines for allergies, such as ephedrine, noradrenaline or adrenaline

【5】Mixing timolol tablets with herbal remedies and supplements
-----------------------------------------------------------

【6】Some herbal remedies, such as cod liver oil, hawthorn and garlic, may cause low blood pressure (hypotension).

【7】There's not enough information to say that other complementary medicines and herbal remedies are safe to take with timolol. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【8】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【9】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.
删除11：<u>More in Timolol tablets
-----------------------

【10】*   About timolol tablets
*   Who can and cannot take them
*   How and when to take them
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking timolol tablets with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 26 August 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 26 August 2025</u>

source_info.title: Ferrous sulfate
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about ferrous sulfate \- Brand name: Ironorm Drops
===================================================================

【1】How does ferrous sulfate work?

【2】Ferrous sulfate is a type of iron. Iron helps make healthy red blood cells, which carry oxygen around your body.

【3】When your body does not have enough iron (iron deficiency anaemia), you can feel tired and lacking in energy. Other symptoms may include paler than usual skin, feeling out of breath and heart palpitations.

【4】Taking ferrous sulfate will increase the iron levels in your blood and improve or prevent the symptoms of iron deficiency anaemia.

【5】When will I feel better?

【6】Most people begin to feel better after 3 to 4 weeks, but it may take up to 2 to 4 months for the medicine to work fully.

【7】If you're taking ferrous sulfate to prevent anaemia you probably will not feel any different but that does not mean it's not working.

【8】If you're taking ferrous sulfate on prescription, it's important to take it for as long as your doctor tells you to.

【9】Are there any long-term side effects?

【10】It's safe to take ferrous sulfate for as long as you need to, provided your doctor has said that it's OK and you are not having any side effects.

【11】How does it compare with other medicines for iron deficiency anaemia?

【12】There are other types of iron, including ferrous fumarate and ferrous gluconate. There is little difference in how well they work when you take the same dose of iron.

【13】If you have a side effect with one type of iron, it may not happen with another type.

【14】Iron injections can also be used if tablets or drops do not help, or if your iron levels are very low. These would usually be given in hospital.

【15】Your doctor or pharmacist can advise you on the right treatment for you.

【16】Will it give me more energy?

【17】Lack of energy is a common symptom when you have iron deficiency anaemia. Having too little iron means your blood cannot carry enough oxygen around your body. This makes you feel tired.

【18】Taking ferrous sulfate can give you more energy by boosting your iron levels. Your doctor may recommend a blood test within the first 4 weeks to see if it's working.

【19】If you feel tired, but have not been diagnosed with iron deficiency anaemia, it's important to talk to your doctor or pharmacist before taking ferrous sulfate. This is because there may be other reasons why you lack energy.

【20】A simple blood test will confirm whether you are anaemic, and your doctor will be able to discuss your results and any treatment with you.

【21】Will it affect my contraception?

【22】Ferrous sulfate will not stop any type of contraception working, including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【23】However, if ferrous sulfate makes you sick (vomit) or have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy. Look on the pill packet to find out what to do.
删除7：<u>Find out more about what to do if you're on the pill and you're being sick or have diarrhoea.</u>

【24】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【25】Yes, you can. Ferrous sulfate does not affect you being able to drive or cycle.

【26】Can I drink alcohol while taking ferrous sulfate?

【27】Yes, you can drink alcohol while taking ferrous sulfate.

【28】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【29】Some food and drink can make it harder for your body to absorb iron. These include:

【30】*   tea and coffee
*   milk and dairy products – such as yoghurt and cheese
*   eggs

【31】When you take ferrous sulfate (or when you eat foods that are high in iron), make sure you leave a 2 hour gap before having tea or coffee or any of these foods.

【32】This will help your body take in the iron from ferrous sulfate or from food.

【33】Can lifestyle changes help with iron deficiency?

【34】If your diet is partly causing your iron deficiency anaemia, eating more foods that are rich in iron can help.

【35】Good sources of iron include:

【36】*   dark-green leafy vegetables like watercress and curly kale
*   fortified cereals and bread (with added iron)
*   meat
*   pulses such as beans, peas and lentils
*   nuts
*   dried fruit such as dried apricots, prunes and raisins
*   wholegrains such as brown rice
删除11：<u>More in Ferrous sulfate
-----------------------

【37】*   About ferrous sulfate
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 9 February 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 9 February 2026</u>

source_info.title: Multiple myeloma
source_info.text:
【0】Symptoms \- Multiple myeloma
============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment</u>

【2】**Multiple myeloma may not cause any symptoms in the early stages, but eventually leads to a wide range of problems. It's often diagnosed after a routine blood test or, sometimes, a urine test.**

【3】See a GP if you have any of the symptoms of multiple myeloma. While they're unlikely to be caused by cancer, it's best to be sure by getting a proper diagnosis.

【4】Bone pain
---------

【5】Multiple myeloma can cause pain in affected bones – usually the back, ribs or hips.

【6】The pain is frequently a persistent dull ache, which may be made worse by movement.

【7】Bone fractures and spinal cord compression
------------------------------------------

【8】Multiple myeloma can weaken the bones and make them more likely to break (fracture). The spine and long bones (arms and legs) are most often affected.

【9】Fractures of the spine can cause the sections of the spine to collapse, leading to pain and, occasionally, compression of the spinal cord (the main column of nerves running down the back).

【10】Compression of the spinal cord can cause:

【11】*   pins and needles
*   numbness and weakness in the legs and feet
*   problems controlling your bladder and bowels

【12】You should seek immediate medical help if you have symptoms of spinal cord compression. It's an emergency and needs immediate investigation and treatment.

【13】Anaemia
-------

【14】Multiple myeloma can affect the production of blood cells in the bone marrow, which can lead to a lack of red blood cells (anaemia). This can also occur as a side effect of myeloma treatment.

【15】If you have anaemia, you may feel very tired, weak and breathless.

【16】Repeated infections
-------------------

【17】People with multiple myeloma are particularly vulnerable to infection because the condition interferes with the immune system, the body's natural defence against infection and illness.

【18】You may find you get frequent infections that last for a long time.

【19】Raised calcium levels in the blood
----------------------------------

【20】A high level of calcium in the blood (hypercalcaemia) can develop in people with multiple myeloma because too much calcium is released from affected bones into the bloodstream.

【21】Symptoms of hypercalcaemia can include:

【22】*   extreme thirst
*   feeling sick
*   stomach pain
*   needing to urinate frequently
*   constipation
*   confusion and drowsiness

【23】You should seek immediate medical help if you have symptoms of hypercalcaemia, as they need quick investigation and treatment.

【24】Unusual bleeding
----------------

【25】Some people with multiple myeloma have bruising and unusual bleeding (haemorrhage), such as frequent nosebleeds, bleeding gums and heavy periods.

【26】This is because the cancer cells in your bone marrow can stop blood-clotting cells called platelets from being made.

【27】Thickened blood
---------------

【28】In some people, multiple myeloma can cause the blood to become thicker than normal. This is due to the excess proteins that myeloma cells often produce.

【29】This is known as hyperviscosity and can cause problems such as:

【30】*   blurred vision
*   headaches
*   dizziness
*   bleeding from the gums or nose
*   shortness of breath

【31】Kidney problems
---------------

【32】Kidney damage can occur in people with multiple myeloma. Eventually, the kidneys may stop working properly.

【33】This is known as kidney or renal impairment, or kidney or renal failure.

【34】Signs of kidney failure can include:

【35】*   weight loss and poor appetite
*   swollen ankles, feet or hands
*   tiredness and a lack of energy
*   shortness of breath
*   itchy skin
*   feeling sick
*   hiccups that won't go away

【36】You should seek immediate medical help if you have symptoms of kidney failure. It's an emergency and needs quick investigation and treatment.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 02 June 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 02 June 2024</u>

source_info.title: Jaundice in newborns, see Newborn jaundice
source_info.text:
【0】Jaundice in newborns, see Newborn jaundice
Treatment \- Newborn jaundice
=============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Kernicterus</u>

【2】**Speak to your midwife, health visitor or GP if your baby develops jaundice. They'll be able to assess whether treatment is needed.**

【3】Treatment is usually only needed if your baby has high levels of a substance called bilirubin in their blood, so tests need to be carried out to check this.
删除8：<u>See diagnosing jaundice in babies for more information about the tests used.</u>

【4】Most babies with jaundice do not need treatment because the level of bilirubin in their blood is found to be low.

【5】In these cases, the condition usually gets better within 10 to 14 days and will not cause any harm to your baby.

【6】If treatment is not needed, you should continue to breastfeed or bottle feed your baby regularly, waking them up for feeds if necessary. 

【7】If your baby's condition gets worse or does not disappear after 2 weeks, contact your midwife, health visitor or GP.

【8】Newborn jaundice can last longer than 2 weeks if your baby was born prematurely or is solely breastfed. It usually improves without treatment.

【9】But further tests may be recommended if the condition lasts this long, to check for any underlying health problems.

【10】If your baby's jaundice does not improve over time, or tests show high levels of bilirubin in their blood, they may be admitted to hospital and treated with phototherapy or an exchange transfusion.

【11】These treatments are recommended to reduce the risk of a rare but serious complication of newborn jaundice called kernicterus, which can cause brain damage.

【12】Phototherapy
------------

【13】Phototherapy is treatment with a special type of light (not sunlight). 

【14】It's sometimes used to treat newborn jaundice by making it easier for your baby's liver to break down and remove the bilirubin from your baby's blood.

【15】Phototherapy aims to expose your baby's skin to as much light as possible.

【16】Your baby will be placed under a light either in a cot or incubator with their eyes covered.

【17】It will usually be stopped for 30 minutes so you can feed your baby, change their nappy and give them a cuddle.

【18】If your baby's jaundice does not improve, intensified phototherapy may be offered. 

【19】This involves increasing the amount of light used or using another source of light, such as a light blanket, at the same time.

【20】Treatment cannot be stopped for breaks during intensified phototherapy, so you will not be able to breastfeed or hold your baby. But you can give your baby expressed milk.

【21】During phototherapy, you baby's temperature will be monitored to make sure they're not getting too hot, and they'll be checked for signs of dehydration.

【22】Intravenous fluids may be needed if your baby is becoming dehydrated and they are not able to drink enough.

【23】The bilirubin levels will be tested every 4 to 6 hours after phototherapy has started, to check if the treatment is working.

【24】Once your baby's bilirubin levels have stabilised or started to fall, they will be checked every 6 to 12 hours.

【25】Phototherapy will be stopped when the bilirubin levels fall to a safe level, which usually takes a day or two.

【26】Phototherapy is generally very effective for newborn jaundice and has few side effects.

【27】Exchange transfusion
--------------------

【28】If your baby has a very high level of bilirubin in their blood or phototherapy has not been effective, they may need a complete blood transfusion, known as an exchange transfusion.

【29】During an exchange transfusion, your baby's blood will be removed through a thin plastic tube placed in blood vessels in their umbilical cord, arms or legs.

【30】The blood is replaced with blood from a suitable matching donor (someone with the same blood group).

【31】As the new blood will not contain bilirubin, the overall level of bilirubin in your baby's blood will fall quickly.

【32】Your baby will be closely monitored throughout the transfusion process, which can take several hours to complete. Any problems that may arise, such as bleeding, will be treated.

【33】Your baby's blood will be tested within 2 hours of treatment to check if it's been successful.

【34】If the level of bilirubin in your baby's blood remains high, the procedure may need to be repeated.

【35】Other treatments
----------------

【36】If jaundice is caused by an underlying health problem, such as an infection, this usually needs to be treated.

【37】If the jaundice is caused by rhesus disease (when the mother has rhesus-negative blood and the baby has rhesus-positive blood), intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) may be used.

【38】IVIG is usually only used if phototherapy alone has not worked and the level of bilirubin in the blood is continuing to rise.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 03 February 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 03 February 2025</u>

source_info.title: Macrogol
source_info.text:
【0】Taking macrogol with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand names: Movicol, Laxido, CosmoCol, Molaxole
===============================================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Some medicines, such as epilepsy medicines like levetiracetam or phenytoin, may not work as well if you take macrogol at the same time.

【3】Check with your pharmacist or doctor if you're taking epilepsy medicines.

【4】Taking macrogol with other laxatives
------------------------------------

【5】For most people, 1 laxative will be enough to relieve constipation.

【6】Occasionally, you may need to take 2 different types of laxatives at the same time to get your bowels moving again.

【7】Only take 2 laxatives together if a doctor recommends it as there's more risk of getting side effects.

【8】Mixing macrogol with herbal remedies and supplements
----------------------------------------------------

【9】There's not enough information to say that complementary medicines, herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with macrogol. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【10】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【11】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.
删除11：<u>More in Macrogol
----------------

【12】*   About macrogol
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 21 October 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 21 October 2025</u>

source_info.title: Paget's disease of the nipple
source_info.text:
【0】Reducing the risk \- Paget's disease of the nipple
==================================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Diagnosis
3.  Treatment
4.  Reducing the risk</u>

【2】**A number of things may help reduce your risk of developing breast cancer.**

【3】Diet and lifestyle
------------------

【4】Exercising regularly and eating a healthy, balanced diet are known to help prevent many forms of cancer, as well as other serious health conditions, such as heart disease and diabetes.

【5】Studies have looked at the link between breast cancer and diet and, although there are no definite conclusions at the moment, there are benefits for women who maintain a healthy weight, take regular exercise and who have a low intake of saturated fat and alcohol.
删除7：<u>Read more about the physical activity guidelines for adults.</u>

【6】If you've experienced the menopause (when your monthly periods stop), it's very important you're not overweight or obese. This is because these conditions cause more oestrogen to be produced, which can increase the risk of breast cancer.
删除7：<u>Read more about preventing breast cancer.</u>

【7】Breastfeeding
-------------

【8】Studies have shown that women who breastfeed are statistically less likely to develop breast cancer than those who do not.

【9】The reasons for this are not fully understood, but it could be because women do not ovulate as regularly while they're breastfeeding and their oestrogen levels remain stable.

【10】Medicine
--------

【11】Medicines called tamoxifen and raloxifene are available on the NHS for women with an increased risk of developing breast cancer. They are usually only given by breast cancer specialists.

【12】These medicines may not be suitable if you've had blood clots or womb cancer in the past, or if you have an increased risk of developing these problems in the future. If you've already had a mastectomy to remove both breasts you will not be offered these medicines because your risk of developing breast cancer is very small.

【13】Either tamoxifen or raloxifene can be used in women who've had the menopause.

【14】A course of treatment with tamoxifen or raloxifene will usually involve taking a tablet every day for 5 years.

【15】Raloxifene can cause side effects including flu-like symptoms, hot flushes and leg cramps. Side effects of tamoxifen can include hot flushes and sweats, changes to your periods and nausea and vomiting.

【16】Tamoxifen and raloxifene can increase your risk of developing blood clots, so you should stop taking them before any planned surgery.

【17】Raloxifene is not currently licensed for reducing the chances of getting breast cancer in women with an increased risk of developing it. However, it can still be given by a specialist.

【18】Breast screening
----------------

【19】Breast screening can pick up breast cancer before it forms a lump. The procedure uses mammograms, where X-rays are taken, to create an image of the inside of your breasts.

【20】The NHS Breast Screening Programme provides free breast screening every 3 years for all women in the UK who are aged 50 years to 70. In some areas, women aged 47 to 49 and 71 to 73 are also invited for screening as part of a trial looking at whether the screening age range should be extended.

【21】NHS breast screening is not usually available for women under 47 years of age. This is because younger women tend to have denser breast tissue, which makes mammograms less effective at identifying abnormalities.

【22】Speak to your GP if you're below screening age and worried about changes in your breasts, or you have a family history of breast cancer.
删除7：<u>Read more about breast cancer screening.</u>
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 06 April 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 06 April 2026</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Treatment</u>

source_info.title: Chemotherapy
source_info.text:
【0】What happens \- Chemotherapy
============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  What happens
3.  Side effects</u>

【2】**Chemotherapy can be carried out in many different ways, depending on your circumstances.**

【3】Before treatment starts
-----------------------

【4】### Deciding to have treatment

【5】If you're diagnosed with cancer, you'll be cared for by a team of specialists. Your care team will recommend chemotherapy if they think it's the best option for you, but the final decision is yours.

【6】Making this decision can be difficult. You may find it useful to write a list of questions to ask your care team.

【7】For example, you may want to find out:

【8】*   what the aim of treatment is, for example, is it being used to cure the cancer, relieve your symptoms or make other treatments more effective
*   about possible side effects and what can be done to prevent or relieve them
*   how effective chemotherapy is likely to be
*   whether any other treatments could be tried instead

【9】If you agree with your care team's recommendation, they'll start to plan your treatment once you've given your consent to treatment.

【10】### Tests and checks

【11】Before chemotherapy begins, you'll have tests to check your general health and make sure the treatment is suitable for you.

【12】The tests you'll have may include:

【13】*   blood tests to check things such as how well your liver and kidneys are working, and how many blood cells you have
*   X-rays and scans to check the size of your cancer
*   measurements of your height and weight to help your team work out the correct dose

【14】During treatment you'll also have tests to monitor your progress.

【15】### Your treatment plan

【16】Chemotherapy involves several treatment sessions, typically spread over a few months.

【17】Before treatment starts, your care team will make a plan that outlines:

【18】*   the type of chemotherapy you'll have
*   how many treatment sessions you'll need
*   how often you'll need treatment – after each treatment you'll have a break before the next session, to allow your body to recover

【19】Your treatment plan will depend on things such as the type of cancer you have and what the aim of treatment is.
删除6：<u>**Further information**

【20】*   Cancer Research UK: planning chemotherapy
*   Macmillan: chemotherapy explained

【21】</u>
How chemotherapy is given
-------------------------

【22】### Into a vein (intravenous chemotherapy)

【23】In most cases, chemotherapy is given directly into a vein. This is known as intravenous chemotherapy.

【24】This usually involves medicine being given slowly from a bag of fluid that's attached with a tube to one of your veins.

【25】This can be done using:

【26】*   a cannula – a small tube that's placed into a vein in the back of your hand or lower arm for a short time
*   a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line – a small tube inserted into a vein in your arm that usually stays in place for several weeks or months
*   a central line – similar to a PICC, but inserted into your chest and connected to one of the veins near your heart
*   an implanted port – a small device inserted under your skin that's kept in place until your treatment course finishes; medicine is given using a needle inserted into the device through the skin

【27】The time it takes to get a dose of intravenous chemotherapy can range from a few minutes, to several hours, to several days.

【28】You usually go into hospital for the treatment and go home when it's finished.

【29】### Tablets (oral chemotherapy)

【30】Sometimes chemotherapy is given as tablets. This is known as oral chemotherapy.

【31】You'll need to go into hospital at the start of each treatment session to get the tablets and have a check-up, but you can usually take the medicine at home.

【32】Make sure you follow the instructions given by your care team. Taking too much or not enough medicine may reduce its effectiveness and could be dangerous.

【33】Contact your care team if you have any problems with your medicine, such as forgetting to take a tablet or being sick shortly after taking one.

【34】### Other types of chemotherapy

【35】Less commonly, chemotherapy may be given as:

【36】*   injections under the skin, known as subcutaneous chemotherapy
*   injections into a muscle, known as intramuscular chemotherapy
*   injections into the spine, known as intrathecal chemotherapy
*   a skin cream
删除6：<u>**Further information**

【37】*   Cancer Research UK: how you have chemotherapy
*   Macmillan: how chemotherapy can be given

【38】</u>
Issues during treatment
-----------------------

【39】During chemotherapy treatment, there are some important things to be aware of.

【40】### Pregnancy and contraception

【41】Women should avoid becoming pregnant while having chemotherapy, as many chemotherapy medicines can cause birth defects.

【42】Use a barrier method of contraception, such as a condom, and contact your care team immediately if you think you may have become pregnant.

【43】Men having chemotherapy should use condoms throughout their course of treatment, even if their partner is using contraception删除7：<u>

【44】Cancer Research UK has more about sex and chemotherapy.</u>

【45】### Taking other medicines

【46】While you're having chemotherapy, check with your care team before you take any other medicine – including over-the-counter medicines and herbal remedies.

【47】Other medicines could react unpredictably with your chemotherapy medicine, which may affect how well it works and could cause dangerous side effects.

【48】### Side effects

【49】Chemotherapy can cause a range of unpleasant side effects.

【50】### Deciding to stop treatment

【51】Some people decide that the benefits of chemotherapy are not worth the poor quality of life due to the side effects.

【52】If you're struggling with the treatment and are having doubts about whether to continue, it's a good idea to speak to your care team.

【53】Your care team can give you advice about the likely benefits of continuing with treatment, but the final decision to continue or stop is yours.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 25 May 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 25 May 2026</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Chemotherapy</u>删除1：<u>*   Next : Side effects</u>

source_info.title: Zolpidem
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take zolpidem
================================

【1】Who can take zolpidem
---------------------

【2】Most adults aged 18 and over can take zolpidem.

【3】Who may not be able to take zolpidem
------------------------------------

【4】Zolpidem is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell a doctor if you:

【5】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to zolpidem or any other medicine
*   have liver or kidney problems
*   have myasthenia gravis, a condition that causes muscle weakness
*   have breathing problems or sleep apnoea, where you stop breathing for short periods while sleeping
*   have ever had mental health problems
*   have ever had issues with alcohol or drugs
*   are trying to get pregnant, already pregnant, or breastfeeding
删除11：<u>More in Zolpidem
----------------

source_info.title: Chronic kidney disease
source_info.text:
【0】Symptoms \- Chronic kidney disease
==================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Living with
6.  Prevention</u>

【2】**Many people with chronic kidney disease (CKD) will not have symptoms because it does not usually cause problems until it reaches an advanced stage.**

【3】Early stages of CKD
-------------------

【4】Kidney disease does not tend to cause symptoms when it's at an early stage.

【5】This is because the body is usually able to cope with a significant reduction in kidney function.

【6】Kidney disease is often only diagnosed at this stage if a routine test for another condition, such as a blood or urine test, detects a possible problem.

【7】If it's found at an early stage, medicine and regular tests to monitor it may help stop it becoming more advanced.

【8】Later stages of CKD
-------------------

【9】A number of symptoms can develop if kidney disease is not found early or it gets worse despite treatment.

【10】Symptoms can include:

【11】*   weight loss and poor appetite
*   swollen ankles, feet or hands – as a result of water retention (oedema)
*   shortness of breath
*   tiredness
*   blood in your pee (urine)
*   an increased need to pee – particularly at night
*   difficulty sleeping (insomnia)
*   itchy skin
*   muscle cramps
*   feeling sick
*   headaches
*   erectile dysfunction in men

【12】This stage of CKD is known as kidney failure, end-stage renal disease or established renal failure. It may eventually require treatment with dialysis or a kidney transplant.

【13】When to get medical advice
--------------------------

【14】See a GP if you have persistent or worrying symptoms that you think could be caused by kidney disease.

【15】The symptoms of kidney disease can be caused by many less serious conditions, so it's important to get a proper diagnosis.

【16】If you do have CKD, it's best to get it diagnosed as soon as possible. Kidney disease can be diagnosed by having blood and urine tests.
删除7：<u>Find out more about how CKD is diagnosed.</u>
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 22 March 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 22 March 2026</u>

source_info.title: Diabetic eye screening
source_info.text:
【0】Your result \- Diabetic eye screening
=====================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  What is diabetic eye screening?
2.  How to book a test
3.  What happens
4.  Your result</u>

【2】You'll get a letter about your result within 6 weeks of having an eye screening test.

【3】Tell your GP surgery if you do not get a letter within 6 weeks.

【4】There are 3 types of result.

【5】No eye changes
--------------

【6】This is called no retinopathy.

【7】This means:

【8】*   no changes to your eyes were found
*   you'll be asked to come back for another test in 1 to 2 years

【9】Some changes to your eyes
-------------------------

【10】This is called background retinopathy.

【11】This means:

【12】*   diabetes has caused some small changes to your eyes (called diabetic retinopathy)
*   your sight is not affected, but it might get worse if you do not follow advice about how to prevent eye damage from diabetes
*   you'll be asked to come back for another test in a year

【13】Eye damage that could affect your sight
---------------------------------------

【14】This is called referable retinopathy.

【15】This means:

【16】*   diabetes has damaged your eyes
*   your sight could be affected
*   you'll be referred to a specialist to talk about what happens next
*   you may need to have screening tests more often
*   you may need treatment for eye damage from diabetes

【17】Information:

【18】Sometimes the pictures of your eyes may not be clear enough to give a result. If this happens, you'll be asked to have another test.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 07 September 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 07 September 2025</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : What happens</u>

source_info.title: Mirabegron
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about mirabegron \- Brand name: Betmiga
========================================================

【1】How does mirabegron work?

【2】Mirabegron is a type of medicine called a beta-3-adrenergic-receptor agonist.

【3】It works by relaxing the muscles around your bladder. This increases the amount of pee that your bladder can hold and reduces your need to pee as frequently or as urgently.

【4】When will I feel better?

【5】Mirabegron starts to work after about 3 to 4 hours to relax the muscles around your bladder.

【6】However, it can take up to 4 to 8 weeks for you to notice any improvements in your symptoms.

【7】Are there any long-term side effects?

【8】Mirabegron is generally safe to take long term, as long as you're not bothered by side effects.

【9】Many people take it for several months or even years without any problems.

【10】What will happen if I stop taking it?

【11】Do not stop taking mirabegron without talking to your doctor first.

【12】If you stop taking this medicine, it will take about 10 days for it to be completely out of your body.

【13】Your symptoms of an overactive bladder may come back or get worse.

【14】How does mirabegron compare with other medicines for bladder problems?

【15】Mirabegron is not usually the first choice of treatment for an overactive bladder.

【16】Your doctor will usually try you on a type of medicine called an antimuscarinic first.

【17】Antimuscarinics include:

【18】*   darifenacin
*   fesoterodine
*   oxybutynin
*   propiverine
*   solifenacin
*   tolterodine
*   trospium

【19】If antimuscarinics are not suitable for you, do not help, or give you side effects, your doctor may want to try you on mirabegron. It works in a slightly different way to antimuscarinics.

【20】Will it affect my contraception?

【21】Mirabegron does not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【22】But if mirabegron makes you have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy. Look on the pill packet to find out what to do.
删除7：<u>Read more about what to do if you're on the pill and you have diarrhoea.</u>

【23】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【24】Yes, you can usually drive or cycle while taking mirabegron.

【25】However, if you feel dizzy, do not drive, ride a bike or operate machinery until you feel OK again.

【26】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【27】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking mirabegron删除7：<u> GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.</u>

【28】Can I drink alcohol while taking mirabegron?

【29】Drinking alcohol does not affect the way mirabegron works.

【30】However, drinking alcohol can make your symptoms worse, such as needing to pee more often or needing to pee urgently. It can also affect your sleep and make you more likely to have to get up in the night to pee.

【31】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【32】You can eat normally while taking mirabegron.

【33】However, some drinks may irritate your bladder and make your urinary symptoms worse.

【34】These drinks include:

【35】*   drinks with caffeine, such as coffee, tea, hot chocolate, cola and energy drinks
*   alcohol
*   fizzy drinks
*   drinks with artificial sweeteners including diet drinks
*   citrus fruit juices, such as orange, grapefruit and lime juice

【36】Cutting back on or avoiding these drinks may help your urinary symptoms.

【37】Can lifestyle changes help with an overactive bladder?

【38】There are a number of lifestyle changes that may help your symptoms. It's a good idea to:

【39】*   cut back on or avoid drinks that can irritate your bladder, such as drinks containing caffeine
*   not drink too much or too little fluid during the day, as this can make incontinence worse
*   lose any excess weight if you need to, by eating a healthy diet and exercising regularly

【40】Treatments for urinary incontinence such as bladder training and pelvic floor muscle training can help with your symptoms.

【41】There are also incontinence products to help you manage your symptoms while you're waiting for treatment to start working.

【42】Speak to your doctor if you'd like more information about these treatments or products.
删除11：<u>More in Mirabegron
------------------

【43】*   About mirabegron
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility

</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 21 July 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 21 July 2026</u>

source_info.title: Benign prostate enlargement
source_info.text:
【0】Symptoms \- Benign prostate enlargement
=======================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment</u>

【2】**Symptoms of an enlarged prostate include:**

【3】*   finding it difficult to start peeing
*   straining to pee
*   having a weak flow of urine
*   "stop-start" peeing
*   needing to pee urgently and/or frequently
*   needing to get up frequently in the night to pee
*   accidentally leaking urine (urinary incontinence)

【4】Leaking urine can happen when you feel a sudden need to pee and cannot stop some pee leaking out before you get to a toilet. This is called urge incontinence.

【5】Leaking urine can also happen when you strain. For example, when you cough, sneeze or lift a heavy object. This is called stress incontinence.

【6】The most common form of leaking is when a small amount of urine dribbles into your underwear after peeing.
删除7：<u>Find out more about urinary incontinence.</u>

【7】When to seek medical advice
---------------------------

【8】See a GP if you have any of the symptoms of an enlarged prostate.

【9】Even if the symptoms are mild, they could be caused by a condition that needs to be investigated.

【10】Any blood in your urine must be investigated by a GP to rule out other more serious conditions.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 08 June 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 08 June 2026</u>

source_info.title: Tuberous sclerosis
source_info.text:
【0】Diagnosis \- Tuberous sclerosis
===============================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Features
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment</u>

【2】**To diagnose tuberous sclerosis, you'll be asked about your family's medical history. You'll also have a number of tests to look for signs of the condition.**

【3】Healthcare professionals use a checklist of the characteristic features of tuberous sclerosis – such as abnormal areas of skin, or tumours in your eyes, brain, heart, lungs or kidneys – to confirm a diagnosis. Several tests will be needed to check for these features.

【4】Finding out about your family's medical history is also important because tuberous sclerosis can sometimes run in families.

【5】Tests for tuberous sclerosis
----------------------------

【6】Tests you may have to check for tuberous sclerosis include:

【7】*   an eye examination – to check for eye tumours
*   a skin examination – to look for abnormal growths or patches of pale or thickened skin
*   an MRI scan – to detect tumours in the brain or kidneys
*   a CT scan or ultrasound scan – to detect tumours in the kidneys, heart or lungs
*   an electroencephalogram (EEG) – to detect abnormal electrical activity within the brain associated with epilepsy
*   an electrocardiogram (ECG) – to detect abnormal electrical activity in the heart that could be caused by heart tumours

【8】A genetic blood test to look for the faulty genes that cause tuberous sclerosis can also help make a diagnosis, although it isn't always reliable.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 09 August 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 09 August 2024</u>

source_info.title: Mirtazapine
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about mirtazapine
==================================

【1】How does mirtazapine work?

【2】Mirtazapine is a type of antidepressant medicine.

【3】It works by increasing the activity of mood-enhancing chemicals called noradrenaline and serotonin in your brain.

【4】When will I feel better?

【5】You may see an improvement in your symptoms after a week although it usually takes between 4 and 6 weeks before you feel the full benefits. That's because it takes around a week for mirtazapine levels to build up in your body, and then a few weeks longer for your body to adapt and get used to it.

【6】Do not stop taking mirtazapine just because you feel it is not helping your symptoms. Give the medicine at least 6 weeks to work.

【7】How will it make me feel?

【8】Antidepressants like mirtazapine help to gradually lift your mood so you feel better.

【9】You may notice that you sleep better and get on with people more easily because you're less anxious. You'll hopefully be more relaxed about things that used to worry you.

【10】Mirtazapine will not change your personality, it will simply help you feel like yourself again.

【11】Do not expect to feel better overnight, though. Some people feel worse during the first few weeks of treatment before they begin to feel better.

【12】Are there any long-term side effects?

【13】Mirtazapine is generally safe to take for a long time. There do not seem to be any lasting harmful effects from taking it for many months or years.

【14】What will happen if I stop taking it?

【15】If you've been feeling better for 6 months or more, your doctor may suggest coming off mirtazapine.

【16】Your doctor will probably recommend reducing your dose gradually over several weeks, or longer if you've been taking mirtazapine for a long time.

【17】This is to help prevent you getting any withdrawal symptoms as you come off the medicine.

【18】Side effects can include:

【19】*   feeling anxious, dizzy or sick
*   numbness or tingling in your hands or feet
*   headaches
*   shaking

【20】### Important

【21】Do not stop taking mirtazapine suddenly, or without talking to your doctor first.

【22】How does mirtazapine compare with other antidepressants?

【23】Mirtazapine is not any better or worse than other antidepressants. Sometimes people get on better with one antidepressant than another.

【24】If you're not feeling any better after 6 weeks, talk to your doctor. They may suggest that you try a different medicine.

【25】Are there other treatments for depression?

【26】Taking antidepressants, including mirtazapine, is just one of many ways to treat depression.

【27】Other treatments that may help include:

【28】*   talking therapy such as cognitive behavioural therapy
*   exercise programmes
*   help to get a good night's sleep

【29】Choosing a treatment that's most suitable for you depends on:

【30】*   how long you've had depression
*   your symptoms
*   whether you've had depression before
*   whether previous treatment has worked
*   how likely you are to stick with your treatment
*   the potential side effects
*   your preferences and priorities

【31】Will it affect my contraception?

【32】Mirtazapine will not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【33】However, if mirtazapine makes you sick (vomit) or have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy. Look on the pill packet to find out what to do.
删除7：<u>Read more about what to do if you're on the pill and you're being sick or have diarrhoea.</u>

【34】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【35】Some people cannot concentrate properly while they are taking mirtazapine. It can also make you feel sleepy.

【36】When you first start taking mirtazapine, it's a good idea to stop driving and cycling for the first few days until you know how this medicine makes you feel.

【37】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【38】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking mirtazapine删除7：<u> GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.</u>

【39】Can I drink alcohol while taking mirtazapine?

【40】You can drink alcohol while taking mirtazapine but it may make you feel sleepy and unsteady on your feet.

【41】It might be best to stop drinking alcohol for the first few days of treatment until you see how the medicine affects you.

【42】Drinking alcohol every day or in large amounts can make your symptoms worse. It also makes it harder for mirtazapine to work properly.

【43】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【44】You can eat and drink normally while taking mirtazapine.

【45】Will I gain or lose weight?

【46】Mirtazapine can make you feel more hungry than usual, so you may put on weight.

【47】If you start to have problems with your weight while taking mirtazapine, talk to your doctor or pharmacist.

【48】Will recreational drugs affect it?

【49】Taking cannibis with mirtazapine can make you feel very sleepy, especially if you've just started taking mirtazapine.

【50】It can be dangerous to take mirtazapine with:

【51】*   methadone
*   stimulants like MDMA (ecstasy) or cocaine
*   hallucinogens like LSD
*   novel psychoactive substances (which used to be known as legal highs) like mephedrone

【52】Find out about the side effects of some recreational drugs on the Frank website.

【53】### Important

【54】Mirtazapine has not been properly tested with recreational drugs. Talk to your doctor if you think you might use recreational drugs while taking mirtazapine.
删除11：<u>More in Mirtazapine
-------------------

【55】*   About mirtazapine
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking mirtazapine with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 15 February 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 15 February 2025</u>

source_info.title: Remdesivir (Veklury)
source_info.text:
【0】Side effects of remdesivir
==========================

【1】Like all medicines, remdesivir can cause side effects in some people, although not everyone gets them.

【2】Common side effects
-------------------

【3】These common side effects of remdesivir happen in up to 1 in 10 people. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【4】Headache

【5】Make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. It's best not to drink too much alcohol. Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller.

【6】Speak to your doctor if this does not help or your headaches are severe.

【7】Feeling sick or being sick (nausea or vomiting)

【8】Stick to simple meals and do not eat rich or spicy food. It might help to take your medicine after you have eaten.

【9】If you're being sick, try small, frequent sips of water to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee.

【10】If you take contraceptive pills and you're being sick, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet to find out what to do.

【11】Serious side effects
--------------------

【12】Tell your doctor or call 111 now if you feel that your heart is beating slower than normal. This may make you feel dizzy, short of breath or very tired.

【13】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E if you:

【14】*   feel confused
*   have chest pain
*   faint or pass out
*   have difficulty breathing

【15】### Blood tests

【16】You may be asked to take blood tests before being treated with remdesivir and while you're having the treatment. This is to check if you have early signs of side effects.

【17】Your blood tests will check:

【18】*   how quickly your blood clots – if your test shows your blood is taking longer to clot than usual your doctor will talk to you about whether remdesivir is suitable for you
*   how well your liver is working – if your test shows early signs of harm to your liver your doctor will talk to you about whether remdesivir is suitable for you
*   how well your kidneys are working – if your test shows early signs of harm to your kidneys your doctor will talk to you about whether remdesivir is suitable for you

【19】### Serious allergic reaction

【20】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to remdesivir.

【21】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【22】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【23】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【24】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【25】Other side effects
------------------

【26】These are not all the side effects of remdesivir. Ask your healthcare professional for further advice.

【27】Check the remdesivir (Veklury) patient information leaflet to find out more.
删除5：<u>Information:

【28】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.
删除12：<u>Visit Yellow Card for further information.</u></u>
删除11：<u>More in Remdesivir (Veklury)
----------------------------

【29】*   About remdesivir

*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Having remdesivir with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 18 May 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 18 May 2025</u>

source_info.title: Ezetimibe
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about ezetimibe \- Brand name: Ezetrol
=======================================================

【1】How does ezetimibe work?

【2】Cholesterol is a fatty substance in your blood that can block your blood vessels if levels become too high. This can make you more likely to have heart problems or a stroke.

【3】Ezetimibe works by reducing the amount of cholesterol your body takes in from your food.

【4】It's usually prescribed alongside a cholesterol-lowering diet.

【5】Ezetimibe can often be prescribed together with a statin to further lower your cholesterol levels.

【6】When will I feel better?

【7】You may not have symptoms of high cholesterol, so you may not feel any different, but this does not mean the medicine is not working. If you take your medicine as prescribed, your cholesterol levels should drop within 2 weeks.

【8】What happens if I stop taking it?

【9】If you stop taking ezetimibe without starting a different treatment, your cholesterol levels may go up again.

【10】Talk to a doctor if you're thinking about stopping this medicine.

【11】How does it compare with similar medicines for lowering cholesterol?

【12】There are other types of medicines that can help lower cholesterol.

【13】Statins are the most commonly prescribed medicines. A doctor may decide to prescribe ezetimibe together with a statin. Statins include:

【14】*   simvastatin
*   atorvastatin
*   pravastatin
*   rosuvastatin

【15】Other cholesterol-lowering medicines include bezafibrate (and other fibrates) and colestyramine. These are usually prescribed by a specialist.

【16】Will ezetimibe affect my contraception?

【17】Ezetimibe does not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【18】However, if ezetimibe makes you have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet to find out what to do.
删除7：<u>Find out more about what to do if you're on the pill and you're being sick or have diarrhoea.</u>

【19】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【20】Yes, you can drive or ride a bike while taking ezetimibe.

【21】Can I drink alcohol while taking ezetimibe?

【22】Yes, you can drink alcohol while taking ezetimibe.

【23】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【24】You can eat and drink normally while taking ezetimibe.

【25】Eating a healthy, balanced diet can help if you have high cholesterol.

【26】Can lifestyle changes help lower my cholesterol?

【27】There are lifestyle changes you can make that will help lower your cholesterol:

【28】*   make sure you're a healthy weight
*   eat a healthy, well balanced diet – reduce saturated fat and increase fibre, fruits, vegetables, wholegrains and fish
*   quit smoking
*   cut down on alcohol
*   try to exercise every day
删除11：<u>More in Ezetimibe
-----------------

source_info.title: Co-dydramol
source_info.text:
【0】About co-dydramol \- Brand names: Paramol, Remedeine, Remedeine Forte
=====================================================================

【1】Co-dydramol is a mixture of 2 different painkillers: paracetamol and dihydrocodeine. Dihydrocodeine belongs to a group of medicines called opiates.

【2】It's used to treat aches and pains, including headaches, migraines, muscle and joint pain, period pain and toothache.

【3】Paracetamol and dihydrocodeine work by blocking messengers in the nerves and brain that tell your body that you're in pain.

【4】You'll usually take co-dydramol when everyday painkillers such as aspirin, ibuprofen and paracetamol have not worked on their own.

【5】Co-dydramol comes in 4 different strengths. You can buy lower-strength tablets from pharmacies. Higher-strength tablets are only available on prescription.

【6】Co-dydramol usually comes as tablets.

【7】Key facts
---------

【8】*   Co-dydramol takes up to 1 hour to work and keeps working for about 5 hours.
*   The most common side effects of co-dydramol are constipation and feeling sick or sleepy.
*   If you've bought co-dydramol from a pharmacy, do not use it for more than 3 days without talking to your doctor.
*   It's possible to become addicted to the dihydrocodeine in co-dydramol, but your doctor will explain how to reduce the risks of becoming addicted.
*   If you need to take co-dydramol for more than a few weeks, your treatment plan may include details of how and when to stop taking this medicine.
删除11：<u>More in Co-dydramol
-------------------

</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 9 August 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 9 August 2026</u>

source_info.title: Lidocaine skin cream
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while using lidocaine skin cream \- Brand names: Denela, EMLA, LMX4, Nulbia
==================================================================================================================

【1】Lidocaine skin cream and pregnancy
----------------------------------

【2】Lidocaine is considered safe to use during pregnancy.

【3】Lidocaine skin cream and breastfeeding
--------------------------------------

【4】Lidocaine is OK to use while breastfeeding. It is only likely to pass into breast milk in tiny amounts, which are very unlikely to cause side effects in your baby.

【5】Always wash your hands after using a lidocaine treatment and before picking up your baby. Be careful to ensure lidocaine cream does not get onto your breast or nipple area. Wash it off thoroughly if it does and before feeding your baby.

【6】Some lidocaine creams contain other ingredients such as prilocaine, which are also OK to use while breastfeeding. Always check the ingredients.

【7】Ask a pharmacist for advice. They will be able to recommend the best treatment for you.

【8】Lidocaine skin cream and fertility
----------------------------------

【9】There's no evidence that lidocaine skin cream affects fertility in either men or women.

【10】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【11】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding
