source_info.title: Giant cell arteritis, see Temporal arteritis
source_info.text:
【0】Giant cell arteritis, see Temporal arteritis
Temporal arteritis
==================

【1】**Temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis) is where the arteries, particularly those at the side of the head (the temples), become inflamed. It's serious and needs urgent treatment.**

【2】Symptoms of temporal arteritis
------------------------------

【3】The symptoms of temporal arteritis depend on which arteries are affected.

【4】The main symptoms are:

【5】*   frequent, severe headaches
*   pain or tenderness at the side of your head (temples) or on the scalp
*   jaw pain while eating or talking
*   vision problems, such as double vision or loss of vision in 1 or both eyes

【6】More general symptoms are also common – for example, flu-like symptoms, unintentional weight loss, depression and tiredness.

【7】Some people with temporal arteritis also develop polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR). This causes pain, stiffness and inflammation in the muscles around the shoulders, neck and hips.

【8】Urgent advice: Ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

【9】*   you think you might have temporal arteritis

【10】It can lead to serious problems like stroke and blindness if not treated quickly.

【11】You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.

【12】Tests for temporal arteritis
----------------------------

【13】If you see a GP about temporal arteritis, they’ll ask about your symptoms and examine your temples.

【14】After having some blood tests, you'll be referred to a specialist.

【15】They may carry out further tests to help diagnose temporal arteritis.

【16】You may have:

【17】*   an ultrasound scan of your temples
*   a biopsy under local anaesthetic – where a small piece of the temporal artery is removed and checked for signs of temporal arteritis

【18】If you have problems with your vision, you should have a same-day appointment with an eye specialist (ophthalmologist) at a hospital eye department.

【19】Treatment for temporal arteritis
--------------------------------

【20】Temporal arteritis is treated with steroid medicine, usually prednisolone.

【21】Treatment will be started before temporal arteritis is confirmed because of the risk of vision loss if it's not dealt with quickly.

【22】There are 2 stages of treatment:

【23】1.  An initial high dose of steroids for a few weeks to help bring your symptoms under control.
2.  A lower steroid dose (after your symptoms have improved) given over a longer period of time, possibly several years.

【24】A small number of people may need to take steroids for the rest of their life.

【25】You'll have regular follow-ups to see how you're doing and check for any side effects you may have.

【26】### Important: Steroids

【27】Do not suddenly stop taking steroids unless your doctor tells you to. Stopping a prescribed course of medicine could make you very ill.

【28】### Other treatments

【29】You may also need to take other types of medicine if you have temporal arteritis, including: :

【30】*   **low-dose aspirin** – to reduce the risk of a stroke or heart attack, which can happen if the arteries to your heart are affected
*   **proton pump inhibitors (PPIs)** – to lower your risk of getting a stomach problem like indigestion or a stomach ulcer, which can be a side effect of taking prednisolone
*   **bisphosphonate therapy** – to reduce the risk of osteoporosis when taking prednisolone
*   **immunosuppressants** – to allow steroid medicine to be reduced and help prevent temporal arteritis coming back
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 14 August 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 14 August 2026</u>

source_info.title: Tiotropium inhalers
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about tiotropium inhalers \- Brand names: Braltus, Spiriva, Spiriva Respimat
=============================================================================================

【1】How do tiotropium inhalers work?

【2】Tiotropium is a bronchodilator medicine. It's not a steroid.

【3】Bronchodilators work by relaxing the muscles of the airways into the lungs. This makes it easier to breathe.

【4】Tiotropium may also be called an anticholinergic (or antimuscarinic), which is a type of bronchodilator. Anticholinergics widen the airways by blocking certain nerves that can cause the muscles lining the airways to tighten.

【5】When will I feel better?

【6】A tiotropium inhaler does not work straight away.

【7】You'll usually start to find it easier to breathe after using a tiotropium inhaler for 3 to 7 days.

【8】It's a long-acting medicine, which means that once you use your inhaler, the medicine is slowly released in your body. This means that you can use the inhaler just once a day. It's important to use it regularly to help prevent symptoms.

【9】Once your symptoms have improved, you may find you need to use your other inhaler (called a reliever) less often.

【10】If your shortness of breath or wheezing does not get better after 7 days of using a tiotropium inhaler, or if it gets worse, let your doctor or nurse know as soon as possible.

【11】Are there any long-term side effects?

【12】Tiotropium is a safe medicine. There's no evidence that it causes any lasting problems even if you use it for many years.

【13】What will happen if I stop using it?

【14】Do not stop using your tiotropium inhaler without speaking to your doctor first.

【15】If you have an inhaler to control your asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), your breathing problems may return if you suddenly stop using it.

【16】You might feel wheezy or short of breath. Your chest may feel tight and you could start to cough.

【17】How does it compare with other medicines for breathing problems?

【18】As well as tiotropium inhalers there are other preventer inhalers that contain a similar type of medicine, such as glycopyrronium and umeclidinium. There are also other types of long-acting bronchodilator inhalers such as formoterol and salmeterol.

【19】Other types of inhalers that can help prevent symptoms of COPD or asthma are steroid inhalers, such as beclometasone or fluticasone.

【20】They may be used in different combinations to help you breathe more easily and prevent other symptoms.

【21】Will it affect my contraception?

【22】Tiotropium does not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【23】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【24】For most people, using a tiotropium inhaler will not affect their ability to drive a car or cycle.

【25】However, if your eyesight is affected in any way or you are dizzy, do not drive or cycle.

【26】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【27】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while using tiotropium删除7：<u> GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.</u>

【28】Can I drink alcohol while using tiotropium inhalers?

【29】Yes, you can drink alcohol while using tiotropium inhalers.

【30】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【31】You can eat and drink normally while using tiotropium inhalers.

【32】Can lifestyle changes help with asthma or COPD?

【33】There are several things you can do to help your condition when you're living with asthma or living with COPD. These include:

【34】*   quitting smoking – not smoking can significantly reduce how severe and frequent your symptoms are
*   exercising regularly – exercise is unlikely to trigger your symptoms once you're on appropriate treatment
*   eating healthily – aim for a healthy, balanced diet and lose excess weight if you need to
*   getting vaccinated – it's a good idea to have the annual flu vaccine and the pneumococcal vaccine when offered, and the COVID-19 vaccine if you're eligible
*   trying an air filter – they do not remove all the allergens but some people find they help their symptoms
删除11：<u>More in Tiotropium inhalers
---------------------------

【35】*   About tiotropium inhalers

*   How and when to use them
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility

source_info.title: Tadalafil
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take tadalafil \- Brand names: Cialis, Adcirca
=================================================================

【1】Who can take tadalafil
----------------------

【2】Most men aged 18 and over can take tadalafil for erectile dysfunction.

【3】Most adults aged 18 and over can take it for pulmonary hypertension.

【4】Who may not be able to take tadalafil
-------------------------------------

【5】Tadalafil is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell your doctor if you:

【6】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to tadalafil or any other medicine
*   are taking medicines called nitrates for chest pain (angina)
*   have a serious heart and liver problem
*   have recently had a stroke or a heart attack
*   have low blood pressure (hypotension) or uncontrolled high blood pressure (hypertension)
*   have ever lost your vision due to reduced blood flow to the eye
*   have sickle cell anaemia (an abnormality of red blood cells)
*   have leukaemia (cancer of blood cells)
*   have multiple myeloma (cancer of bone marrow)
*   have Peyronie's disease (curved penis) or a similar problem with your penis
*   have a liver or kidney condition
*   have a heart condition – your doctor will advise you whether your heart can take the additional strain of having sex
删除11：<u>More in Tadalafil
-----------------

【7】*   About tadalafil
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking it with other medicines and herbal supplements

source_info.title: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
source_info.text:
【0】Diagnosis \- Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
==========================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Diagnosis
3.  Treatment</u>

【2】**Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) can be hard to diagnose because its symptoms are similar to other lung conditions, such as** **chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)****.**

【3】A GP can refer you to hospital specialists for a number of tests to help rule out other conditions and confirm the diagnosis.

【4】Medical history and examination
-------------------------------

【5】Your doctor will ask about your medical history and whether there are other factors that could be causing a problem with your lungs, such as whether you:

【6】*   smoke or have smoked in the past
*   have been exposed to harmful substances at work, such as asbestos
*   have other medical conditions

【7】They may also:

【8】*   check the sound of your breathing through a stethoscope – a crackling sound can suggest lung scarring (fibrosis)
*   look at your fingers to see if the ends are swollen (finger clubbing)
*   ask you to walk around for a few minutes to see if you become breathless

【9】Breathing and blood tests
-------------------------

【10】Lung function tests (also called pulmonary function tests) assess how well your lungs work and can help indicate what the problem may be.

【11】These tests measure:

【12】*   how quickly you can move air in and out of your lungs
*   how much air your lungs can hold
*   how well your lungs transfer oxygen into your blood and remove carbon dioxide from it (this can be checked using a blood test)

【13】A commonly used lung function test is spirometry. During the test, you breathe into a mouthpiece that's attached to a monitor.

【14】Chest X-ray and CT scan
-----------------------

【15】A chest X-ray does not show the lungs in much detail, but can help doctors spot some more obvious problems that could be causing your symptoms, such as cancer or a build-up of fluid.

【16】If IPF is suspected, the chest X-ray will be followed by a CT scan.

【17】A CT scan is similar to an X-ray, but lots more images are taken and these are put together by a computer to create a more detailed image of your lungs.

【18】This can help your doctor spot signs of scarring in your lungs.

【19】Bronchoscopy
------------

【20】If doctors are still not sure what the problem is after these tests, they may suggest having a bronchoscopy.

【21】This is a test where a narrow, flexible tube with a camera (bronchoscope) is passed down into your airways.

【22】Your doctor will look for anything abnormal and may take small tissue samples for testing.

【23】You'll usually be awake during a bronchoscopy and it may cause coughing.

【24】Local anaesthetic will be used to numb your throat so it does not hurt, and you may also be given a sedative injection that will make you feel sleepy during the procedure.

【25】Lung biopsy
-----------

【26】If other tests are not conclusive, a lung biopsy may need to be carried out.

【27】This involves keyhole surgery to remove a small sample of lung tissue so it can be analysed for signs of scarring.

【28】This is performed under a general anaesthetic, where you're asleep. 

【29】Your surgeon makes several small cuts in your side and an endoscope, a thin tube with a camera and a light at the end, is inserted into the area between the lungs and the chest wall.

【30】The surgeon can see the lung tissue through the endoscope and is able to obtain a small sample.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 18 October 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 18 October 2025</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis</u>删除1：<u>*   Next : Treatment</u>

source_info.title: Severe vomiting in pregnancy
source_info.text:
【0】Severe vomiting in pregnancy
============================

【1】Sickness in pregnancy (sometimes called morning sickness) is common. Around 8 out of every 10 pregnant women feel sick (nausea), are sick (vomiting) or both during pregnancy. This does not just happen in the morning.

【2】For most women, this improves or stops completely by around weeks 12 to 20, although for some women it can last longer.

【3】Some pregnant women experience very bad nausea and vomiting. They might be sick many times a day and be unable to keep food or drink down, which can impact on their daily life.

【4】This excessive nausea and vomiting is known as hyperemesis gravidarum (HG), and often needs hospital treatment.

【5】Exactly how many pregnant women get HG is not known as some cases may go unreported, but it's thought to be around 1 to 3 in every 100.

【6】If you are being sick frequently and cannot keep food down, tell your midwife or doctor, or contact the hospital as soon as possible. There is a risk you may become dehydrated, and your midwife or doctor can make sure you get the right treatment.

【7】Symptoms of hyperemesis gravidarum
----------------------------------

【8】HG is much worse than the normal nausea and vomiting of pregnancy.

【9】Signs and symptoms of HG include:

【10】*   prolonged and severe nausea and vomiting
*   dehydration – symptoms include feeling thirsty, tired, dizzy or lightheaded, not peeing very much, and having dark yellow and strong-smelling pee
*   weight loss

【11】Unlike regular pregnancy sickness, HG may not get better by 16 to 20 weeks. It may not clear up completely until the baby is born, although some symptoms may improve at around 20 weeks.

【12】See your GP or midwife if you have severe nausea and vomiting. Getting help early can help you avoid dehydration and weight loss.

【13】There are other conditions that can cause nausea and vomiting, and your doctor will need to rule these out first.

【14】See videos and written interviews of women talking about their experiences of hyperemesis gravidarum on the healthtalk website.

【15】What causes hyperemesis gravidarum?
-----------------------------------

【16】It's not known exactly what causes HG, or why some women get it and others do not. There is evidence that it is linked to the changing hormones in your body that occur during pregnancy.

【17】There is some evidence that it runs in families, so if you have a mother or sister who has had HG in a pregnancy, you may be more likely to get it yourself.

【18】If you have had HG in a previous pregnancy, you are more likely to get it in your next pregnancy than women who have never had it before, so it's worth planning in advance.

【19】Treating hyperemesis gravidarum
-------------------------------

【20】There are medicines that can be used in pregnancy, including the first 12 weeks, to help improve the symptoms of HG. These include anti-sickness (anti-emetic) drugs, steroids, or a combination of these.

【21】You may need to try different types of medicine until you find what works best for you.

【22】You can visit the Bumps website to find out which medicines are safe to use in pregnancy.

【23】If your nausea and vomiting cannot be controlled, you may need to be admitted to hospital. This is so doctors can assess your condition and give you the right treatment to protect the health of you and your baby.

【24】Treatment can include intravenous fluids, which are given directly into a vein through a drip. If you have severe vomiting, the anti-sickness drugs may also need to be given into a vein or a muscle.

【25】The charity Pregnancy Sickness Support has information and tips on coping with nausea and vomiting, including HG.

【26】Will hyperemesis gravidarum harm my baby?
-----------------------------------------

【27】HG can make you feel very unwell, but it's unlikely to harm your baby if treated effectively.

【28】However, if it causes you to lose weight during pregnancy, there is an increased risk that your baby may be born smaller than expected (have a low birthweight).

【29】How you might feel
------------------

【30】The nausea and vomiting of HG can impact your life at a time when you were expecting to be enjoying pregnancy and looking forward to the birth of your baby.

【31】It can affect you both emotionally and physically. The symptoms can be hard to cope with. Without treatment HG may also lead to further health complications, such as depression or tears in your oesophagus.

【32】Severe sickness can be exhausting and stop you doing everyday tasks, such as going to work or even getting out of bed.

【33】In addition to feeling very unwell and tired, you might also feel:

【34】*   anxious about going out or being too far from home in case you need to vomit
*   isolated because you do not know anyone who understands what it's like to have HG
*   confused as to why this is happening to you
*   unsure about how to cope with the rest of the pregnancy if you continue to feel very ill

【35】If you feel any of these, do not keep it to yourself. Talk to your midwife or doctor, and explain the impact HG is having on your life and how it is making you feel. You could also talk to a partner, family members and friends if you want to.

【36】If you want to talk to someone who has been through HG, you can contact Pregnancy Sickness Support's help section. They have a support network across the UK and can put you in touch with someone who has had HG.

【37】Bear in mind that HG is much worse than regular pregnancy sickness. It is not the result of anything you have or have not done, and you do need treatment and support.

【38】Another pregnancy
-----------------

【39】If you have had HG before, it's likely you will get it again in another pregnancy.

【40】If you decide on another pregnancy, it can help to plan ahead, such as arranging child care so you can get plenty of rest.

【41】You could try doing things that helped last time.

【42】Talk to your doctor about starting medicine early.

【43】Blood clots and hyperemesis gravidarum
--------------------------------------

【44】Because HG can cause dehydration, there's also an increased risk of having a blood clot (deep vein thrombosis), although this is rare. 

【45】If you are dehydrated and immobile, there is treatment that you can be given to prevent blood clots.
删除7：<u>Read more about how to prevent deep vein thrombosis.</u>
删除11：<u>More in Pregnancy complications
-------------------------------

【46】*   Deep vein thrombosis in pregnancy
*   High blood pressure (hypertension) and pregnancy
*   Itching and intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy
*   Severe vomiting in pregnancy
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 11 January 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 11 January 2026</u>

source_info.title: Glimepiride
source_info.text:
【0】Common questions about glimepiride
==================================

【1】How does glimepiride work?

【2】Glimepiride is a type of medicine known as a sulfonylurea.

【3】Sulfonylureas increase the amount of insulin that your pancreas makes. Insulin is the hormone that controls the level of sugar in your blood.

【4】When will I feel better?

【5】You may not feel any different when taking glimepiride as you may not have any symptoms with type 2 diabetes. This does not mean that the medicine is not working. It's important to keep taking it.

【6】Glimepiride reduces blood sugar levels in 2 to 3 hours.

【7】It helps keep your blood sugar level stable and will reduce your chance of getting health problems due to diabetes in the future.

【8】Are there any long-term side effects?

【9】Glimepiride is safe to take for a long time. There's no evidence that it harms your general health or your pancreas.

【10】However, glimepiride may stop working properly after a while. Your doctor may want to try you on a different medicine, or start prescribing another diabetes medicine along with glimepiride.

【11】Are there other medicines that treat type 2 diabetes?

【12】Glimepiride belongs to a group of medicines called sulfonylureas. These include gliclazide, glibenclamide, glipizide and tolbutamide.

【13】There are several other types of medicines that also treat type 2 diabetes including:

【14】*   metformin
*   DPP-4 inhibitors, like saxagliptin
*   SGLT2 inhibitors, like dapagliflozin
*   GLP-1 agonists, like exenatide (given by injection)
*   insulin (given by injection)

【15】Metformin is usually the first choice of medicine used for treating type 2 diabetes.

【16】Glimepiride can be prescribed on its own or together with other diabetes medicines.

【17】It's usually prescribed if you cannot take metformin, or if metformin on its own is not keeping your blood sugar under control.

【18】Can I get diabetes medicines for free?

【19】If you have diabetes, you're entitled to free prescriptions for all of your medicines, not just your diabetes ones.

【20】To claim your free prescriptions, you'll need to have a medical exemption certificate (FP92A). You can get an application form at your GP surgery. Once you've filled in the form, ask your doctor to sign it.

【21】Can I take glimepiride before surgery?

【22】If you're going to have an operation, tell your doctor beforehand that you're taking glimepiride.

【23】They may switch you to insulin for a few days before and after your surgery.

【24】This is because glimepiride increases your risk of low blood sugar during the operation. Low blood sugar can be difficult to detect when you're put to sleep with general anaesthetic.

【25】Will it affect my contraception?

【26】Glimepiride does not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【27】But talk to your doctor before starting to take contraceptive pills if you're already taking glimepiride. They may change your dose of glimepiride. This is because contraceptive pills change how your body handles sugar.

【28】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【29】If your blood sugar levels are stable, taking glimepiride should not affect your ability to drive, cycle or use machinery or tools.

【30】However, if your blood sugar levels become too low, this can reduce your concentration. If this happens to you, do not drive, cycle, or use machines or tools until you feel better.

【31】If your eyesight if affected by changes in your blood sugar, do not drive or use machinery until you can see clearly again. See your doctor or optician if your vision does not get better.

【32】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【33】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking glimepiride删除7：<u> GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.</u>

【34】Can I drink alcohol while taking glimepiride?

【35】Yes, you can drink alcohol while taking glimepiride. But it's best to drink no more than 2 units a day. Drinking more than this can increase your risk of low blood sugar.

【36】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【37】It's a good idea to cut down on foods with added sugar. Check the nutrition labels as many foods and drinks are high in sugar, such as:

【38】*   sweets
*   cakes
*   biscuits
*   chocolate
*   some fizzy drinks
*   juice drinks

【39】However, it's important to always carry a fast-acting carbohydrate with you, like sugar cubes, fruit juice or some sweets, in case your blood sugar level gets low. Artificial sweeteners will not help.

【40】You may also need to eat a starchy carbohydrate, like a sandwich or a biscuit, to maintain your blood sugar for longer.

【41】Be careful when eating food and drink that contains karela (also called bitter gourd). This is because it can lower your blood sugar levels which means your diabetes is not controlled as well as it should be. Karela is used to flavour foods such as curries. It has a bitter taste and is also made into juice and tea.

【42】Will I put on weight or lose weight?

【43】Glimepiride can make you feel more hungry and some people find they put on weight.

【44】Try to eat a healthy balanced diet without increasing your portion sizes. Regular exercise will also help you to keep your weight stable.

【45】If you are already overweight, talk to your doctor about the best way to avoid putting on any more weight.

【46】Glimepiride will not help you lose weight.

【47】Can lifestyle changes help to control diabetes?

【48】There are some lifestyle changes you can make to help control the symptoms of type 2 diabetes. These include:

【49】*   eating a healthy diet
*   losing any excess weight
*   not smoking
*   cutting down on alcohol – try to keep to the recommended guidelines of no more than 14 units of alcohol a week. A standard glass of wine (175ml) is 2 units. A pint of lager or beer is usually 2 to 3 units of alcohol
*   exercising – 30 minutes a day, 5 times a week is ideal

【50】Glimepiride is usually prescribed when diet and exercise alone have not been enough to control your blood sugar levels.
删除11：<u>More in Glimepiride
-------------------

【51】*   About glimepiride
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking glimepiride with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 14 March 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 14 March 2025</u>

source_info.title: Stroke
source_info.text:
【0】Prevention \- Stroke
====================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Recovery
7.  Prevention</u>

【2】**The best way to help prevent a stroke is to eat a healthy diet, exercise regularly, and avoid smoking and drinking too much alcohol.**

【3】These lifestyle changes can reduce your risk of problems like:

【4】*   arteries becoming clogged with fatty substances (atherosclerosis)
*   high blood pressure
*   high cholesterol levels

【5】If you have already had a stroke, making these changes can help reduce your risk of having another one in the future.

【6】Diet
----

【7】An unhealthy diet can increase your chances of having a stroke because it may lead to an increase in your blood pressure and cholesterol levels.

【8】A low-fat, high-fibre diet is usually recommended, including plenty of fresh fruit and vegetables (5 A Day) and wholegrains.

【9】Ensuring a balance in your diet is important. Do not eat too much of any single food, particularly foods high in salt and processed foods.

【10】You should limit the amount of salt you eat to no more than 6g (0.2oz) a day as too much salt will increase your blood pressure: 6g of salt is about 1 teaspoonful.
删除7：<u>Read more about eating well and healthy weight.</u>

【11】Exercise
--------

【12】Combining a healthy diet with regular exercise is the best way to maintain a healthy weight.

【13】Regular exercise can also help lower your cholesterol and keep your blood pressure healthy.

【14】For most people, at least 150 minutes (2 hours and 30 minutes) of moderate-intensity aerobic activity, such as cycling or fast walking, every week is recommended.

【15】If you're recovering from a stroke, you should discuss possible exercise plans with the members of your rehabilitation team.

【16】Regular exercise may not be possible in the first weeks or months after a stroke, but you should be able to begin exercising once your rehabilitation has progressed.
删除7：<u>Find out more about exercise</u>

【17】Stop smoking
------------

【18】Smoking significantly increases your risk of having a stroke. This is because it narrows your arteries and makes your blood more likely to clot.

【19】You can reduce your risk of having a stroke by stopping smoking.

【20】Not smoking will also improve your general health and reduce your risk of developing other serious conditions, such as lung cancer and heart disease.

【21】The National Smokefree Helpline can offer advice and encouragement to help you quit smoking. Call 0300 123 1044 (England only), or visit Better Health: quit smoking.
删除7：<u>Find out more about how to quit smoking</u>

【22】Cut down on alcohol
-------------------

【23】Excessive alcohol consumption can lead to high blood pressure and trigger an irregular heartbeat (atrial fibrillation), both of which can increase your risk of having a stroke.

【24】Because alcoholic drinks are high in calories, they also cause weight gain. Heavy drinking multiplies the risk of stroke by more than 3 times.

【25】If you choose to drink alcohol and have fully recovered, you should try not to exceed the recommended limits:

【26】*   men and women are advised not to regularly drink more than 14 units a week
*   spread your drinking over 3 days or more if you drink as much as 14 units a week

【27】If you have not fully recovered from your stroke, you may find you have become particularly sensitive to alcohol and even the recommended safe limits may be too much for you. 

【28】Find more alcohol advice

【29】Managing underlying conditions
------------------------------

【30】If you have been diagnosed with a condition known to increase your risk of stroke, ensuring the condition is well controlled is also important for helping prevent strokes.

【31】Making the lifestyle changes described on this page can help control these conditions to a large degree, but you may also need to take regular medicine.

【32】通用删除3(英):<u>For more information, see:</u>

【33】*   treating atrial fibrillation
*   treating high blood pressure
*   medicines for high cholesterol
*   type 1 diabetes and treating type 2 diabetes
*   treating transient ischaemic attacks (TIA)
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 13 September 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 13 September 2025</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Recovery</u>

【0】Prevention \- Stroke
====================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Recovery
7.  Prevention</u>

【2】**The best way to help prevent a stroke is to eat a healthy diet, exercise regularly, and avoid smoking and drinking too much alcohol.**

【3】These lifestyle changes can reduce your risk of problems like:

【4】*   arteries becoming clogged with fatty substances (atherosclerosis)
*   high blood pressure
*   high cholesterol levels

【5】If you have already had a stroke, making these changes can help reduce your risk of having another one in the future.

【6】Diet
----

【7】An unhealthy diet can increase your chances of having a stroke because it may lead to an increase in your blood pressure and cholesterol levels.

【8】A low-fat, high-fibre diet is usually recommended, including plenty of fresh fruit and vegetables (5 A Day) and wholegrains.

【9】Ensuring a balance in your diet is important. Do not eat too much of any single food, particularly foods high in salt and processed foods.

【10】You should limit the amount of salt you eat to no more than 6g (0.2oz) a day as too much salt will increase your blood pressure: 6g of salt is about 1 teaspoonful.
删除7：<u>Read more about eating well and healthy weight.</u>

【11】Exercise
--------

【12】Combining a healthy diet with regular exercise is the best way to maintain a healthy weight.

【13】Regular exercise can also help lower your cholesterol and keep your blood pressure healthy.

【14】For most people, at least 150 minutes (2 hours and 30 minutes) of moderate-intensity aerobic activity, such as cycling or fast walking, every week is recommended.

【15】If you're recovering from a stroke, you should discuss possible exercise plans with the members of your rehabilitation team.

【16】Regular exercise may not be possible in the first weeks or months after a stroke, but you should be able to begin exercising once your rehabilitation has progressed.
删除7：<u>Find out more about exercise</u>

【17】Stop smoking
------------

【18】Smoking significantly increases your risk of having a stroke. This is because it narrows your arteries and makes your blood more likely to clot.

【19】You can reduce your risk of having a stroke by stopping smoking.

【20】Not smoking will also improve your general health and reduce your risk of developing other serious conditions, such as lung cancer and heart disease.

【21】The National Smokefree Helpline can offer advice and encouragement to help you quit smoking. Call 0300 123 1044 (England only), or visit Better Health: quit smoking.
删除7：<u>Find out more about how to quit smoking</u>

【22】Cut down on alcohol
-------------------

【23】Excessive alcohol consumption can lead to high blood pressure and trigger an irregular heartbeat (atrial fibrillation), both of which can increase your risk of having a stroke.

【24】Because alcoholic drinks are high in calories, they also cause weight gain. Heavy drinking multiplies the risk of stroke by more than 3 times.

【25】If you choose to drink alcohol and have fully recovered, you should try not to exceed the recommended limits:

【26】*   men and women are advised not to regularly drink more than 14 units a week
*   spread your drinking over 3 days or more if you drink as much as 14 units a week

【27】If you have not fully recovered from your stroke, you may find you have become particularly sensitive to alcohol and even the recommended safe limits may be too much for you. 

【28】Find more alcohol advice

【29】Managing underlying conditions
------------------------------

【30】If you have been diagnosed with a condition known to increase your risk of stroke, ensuring the condition is well controlled is also important for helping prevent strokes.

【31】Making the lifestyle changes described on this page can help control these conditions to a large degree, but you may also need to take regular medicine.

【32】通用删除3(英):<u>For more information, see:</u>

【33】*   treating atrial fibrillation
*   treating high blood pressure
*   medicines for high cholesterol
*   type 1 diabetes and treating type 2 diabetes
*   treating transient ischaemic attacks (TIA)
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 13 September 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 13 September 2025</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Recovery</u>

source_info.title: Dementia with Lewy bodies
source_info.text:
【0】Treatment \- Dementia with Lewy bodies
======================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Treatment</u>

【2】**There's currently no cure for dementia with Lewy bodies, but there are treatments that can help manage the symptoms.**

【3】Care plans
----------

【4】Before treatment starts, your current and future health and social care needs will be assessed and a care plan drawn up.

【5】This is a way of ensuring you receive the right treatment for your needs. It involves identifying areas where you may need some assistance, such as:

【6】*   what support you or your carer need for you to remain as independent as possible, including whether you might need care at home or in a care home
*   whether there are any changes that need to be made to your home to make it easier to live in
*   whether you need any financial assistance
删除7：<u>Read more about care plans</u>

【7】Medicine
--------

【8】Medicine cannot stop dementia with Lewy bodies getting worse, but for some people it can help reduce some of the symptoms.

【9】### Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors

【10】Acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitors, such as donepezil (Aricept), rivastigmine (Exelon) and galantamine (Reminyl), may help improve hallucinations, confusion and sleepiness in some people.

【11】These work by increasing levels of a chemical called acetylcholine in the brain, which improves the ability of the brain cells to send signals to each other.

【12】Common side effects include feeling and being sick, diarrhoea, headaches, tiredness and muscle cramps.

【13】### Memantine

【14】This medicine is not an AChE inhibitor. It works by blocking the effects of a large amount of a chemical in the brain called glutamate.

【15】Memantine is used for moderate or severe dementia with Lewy bodies. It's suitable for those who cannot take AChE inhibitors.

【16】Side effects can include headaches, dizziness and constipation, but these are usually only temporary.

【17】通用删除3(英):<u>For more information about the possible side effects of your specific medicine, read the patient information leaflet that comes with it and speak to a doctor.</u>

【18】### Other medicines

【19】Other medicines that may help control some symptoms of dementia with Lewy bodies include:

【20】*   levodopa – this can help with movement problems, but it can also worsen other symptoms and needs to be carefully monitored by a doctor
*   antidepressants – these may be given if you're depressed
*   clonazepam – this can help if you experience a particular type of rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behaviour disorder
*   antipsychotics (such as quetiapine) – these may help with behaviour that's putting you or others at risk of harm, but they can cause serious side effects and should be avoided whenever possible

【21】Support and other therapies
---------------------------

【22】In addition to medicine, there are a number of therapies and practical measures that can help make life easier for someone with dementia.

【23】These include:

【24】*   occupational therapy to identify problem areas in everyday life, such as getting dressed, and help make life easier
*   speech and language therapy to help improve communication or dysphagia (swallowing problems)
*   physiotherapy to help with movement
*   psychological therapies, such as cognitive stimulation (activities and exercises designed to improve memory, problem solving skills and language ability)
*   relaxation techniques, such as massage, and music or dance therapy
*   social interaction, leisure activities and other dementia activities, such as memory cafes (drop-in sessions for people with memory problems and their carers to get support and advice)
*   home modifications, such as removing trip hazards, ensuring the home is well lit, and adding grab bars and handrails

【25】It may be helpful to get in touch with a support group, such as The Lewy Body Society, the Alzheimer's Society or Dementia UK.
删除7：<u>Read more about living well with dementia</u>

【26】End of life and legal issues
----------------------------

【27】If you've been diagnosed with dementia, you might want to make arrangements for your care that take into account the decline in your mental abilities.

【28】This may include ensuring that your wishes are upheld if you're not able to make decisions for yourself.

【29】You may want to consider:

【30】*   drawing up an advance decision, which makes your treatment preferences known in case you're unable to do this in the future
*   having a plan for where you want to receive treatment as your condition becomes more advanced
*   giving a relative lasting power of attorney, enabling them to make decisions about you if you're unable to
删除7：<u>Read more about managing legal affairs for someone with dementia and end of life planning.</u>

【31】Help and advice for carers
--------------------------

【32】If you care for someone with dementia, you may find it helpful to read more about:

【33】*   Looking after someone with dementia
*   Carers' breaks and respite care – this can allow you to take breaks from caring
*   Benefits for carers, such as allowances and tax credits that may be available
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 24 March 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 24 March 2026</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Symptoms</u>

source_info.title: Knee pain
source_info.text:
【0】Knee pain
=========

【1】**Knee pain can often be treated at home. You should start to feel better in a few days. Call 111 if the pain is very bad.**

【2】How to ease knee pain and swelling
----------------------------------

【3】If you have knee pain, try these things at first:

【4】*   put as little weight as possible on your knee – for example, avoid standing for a long time
*   use an ice pack or bag of frozen peas wrapped in a tea towel on your knee for up to 20 minutes every 2 to 3 hours
*   use painkillers such as paracetamol or ibuprofen gel or tablets

【5】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【6】*   knee pain does not improve within a few weeks

【7】Urgent advice: Get advice from 111 now if:
------------------------------------------

【8】*   your knee is very painful
*   you cannot move your knee or put any weight on it
*   your knee is badly swollen or has changed shape
*   your knee locks, gives way or painfully clicks – painless clicking is normal
*   you have a very high temperature, feel hot and shivery, and have redness or heat around your knee – this can be a sign of infection

【9】111 will tell you what to do. They can tell you the right place to get help if you need to see someone.

【10】Get help from NHS 111 online or call 111.

【11】Other ways to get help

【12】You can also go to an urgent treatment centre if you need to see someone now.

【13】They're also called walk-in centres or minor injuries units.

【14】You may be seen quicker than you would at A&E.

【15】Find an urgent treatment centre

【16】Treatments for knee pain
------------------------

【17】A doctor can suggest treatment based on what's causing your knee pain.

【18】They might:

【19】*   prescribe medicine or physiotherapy
*   refer you to hospital for a scan or specialist treatment (for example, surgery)

【20】Information:

【21】### Self-refer for treatment

【22】If you have knee pain, you might be able to refer yourself directly to services for help with your condition without seeing a GP.

【23】To find out if there are any services in your area:

【24】*   ask the reception staff at your GP surgery
*   check your GP surgery's website
*   contact your integrated care board (ICB) – find your local ICB
*   search online for NHS treatment for knee pain near you

【25】Common causes of knee pain
--------------------------

【26】Knee pain can be a symptom of many different conditions.

【27】This information might give you an idea of what the cause might be. But do not self-diagnose – see a GP if you're worried.

【28】Knee pain after an injury

| Knee symptoms | Possible cause |
| --- | --- |
| Knee symptomsPain after overstretching, overusing or twisting, often during exercise  | Possible causeSprains and strains  |
| Knee symptomsPain between your kneecap and shin, often caused by repetitive running or jumping  | Possible causeTendonitis  |
| Knee symptomsUnstable, gives way when you try to stand, unable to straighten, may hear a popping sound during injury  | Possible causeTorn ligament, tendon or meniscus, cartilage damage  |
| Knee symptomsKneecap changes shape after a collision or sudden change in direction  | Possible causeDislocated kneecap  |

【30】Knee pain with no obvious injury

| Knee symptoms | Possible causes |
| --- | --- |
| Knee symptomsPain and stiffness in both knees, mild swelling, more common in older people  | Possible causesOsteoarthritis  |
| Knee symptomsWarm and red, kneeling or bending makes pain and swelling worse  | Possible causesBursitis  |
| Knee symptomsSwelling, warmth, bruising, more likely while taking anticoagulants  | Possible causesBleeding in the joint  |
| Knee symptomsHot and red, sudden attacks of very bad pain  | Possible causesGout or septic arthritis  |
| Knee symptomsTeenagers and young adults with pain and swelling below kneecap  | Possible causesOsgood Schlatter's disease  |
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 21 December 2023  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 21 December 2026</u>

source_info.title: Benefits for carers
source_info.text:
【0】Benefits for carers
===================

【1】You might not think of yourself as a carer. But you probably are if you're looking after someone regularly, including your spouse or a family member, because they're ill or disabled.

【2】As a carer, you may be entitled to one or more state benefits to help you with the costs.

【3】Carer's Allowance
-----------------

【4】### What it is

【5】Carer's Allowance is the main state benefit for carers. It's £67.25 a week.

【6】### You can get it if

【7】You look after someone for more than 35 hours a week.

【8】### You cannot get it if

【9】You get more than £67.25 a week from some other benefits. But it's still worth applying as you may have what's called an underlying entitlement to Carer's Allowance. This can help increase other benefits you're getting.

【10】How to claim Carer's Allowance

【11】Carer's Credit
--------------

【12】### What it is

【13】A National Insurance (NI) contribution to help make sure you do not lose out on some social security benefits, such as the State Pension, because of gaps in your NI record.

【14】### You can get it if

【15】You look after someone for more than 20 hours a week and you do not get Carer's Allowance.

【16】How to claim Carer's Credit

【17】Carer Premium
-------------

【18】### What it is

【19】An allowance you get on top of some benefits.

【20】### You can get it if

【21】You already get a benefit, such as Income Support or Housing Benefit.

【22】### How to claim Carer Premium

【23】Ask about it at your local Jobcentre Plus or Jobs and Benefits Office.

【24】Disability Living Allowance for children
----------------------------------------

【25】### What it is

【26】Between £23.60 and £151.40 a week.

【27】### You can get it if

【28】You're the parent carer of a disabled child.

【29】How to claim Disability Living Allowance for children

【30】Check what benefits you can get
-------------------------------

【31】Check if you're entitled to Carer's Allowance and other benefits with the entitled to benefits calculator.

【32】Use the entitled to benefits calculator

【33】Get a carer's assessment
------------------------

【34】As a carer, you may be eligible for support from your local council. Before you receive any help from your local council, you need to have a carer's assessment.

【35】Find out how to get a carer's assessment

【36】Get help and advice
-------------------

【37】Get expert benefits advice, plus help filling in claim forms, from:

【38】*   Carers UK helpline on 0808 808 7777
*   Carers Direct helpline on 0300 123 1053
*   Age UK on 0800 678 1602
*   Citizens Advice on 0800 144 8848
*   Gingerbread (for single parents) on 0808 802 0925
*   Family Rights Group on 0808 801 0366

【39】How to challenge a benefit decision
-----------------------------------

【40】You can challenge a benefit decision if:

【41】*   your benefit payment is stopped
*   your claim for a benefit is refused

【42】You can find out how to challenge a benefit decision on the Carers UK website
删除11：<u>More in Support and benefits for carers
---------------------------------------

【43】*   Carer's assessments
*   Carers' breaks and respite care
*   Benefits for carers
*   Help for young carers
*   Being a young carer: your rights
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 25 March 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 25 March 2024</u>

source_info.title: Neurofibromatosis type 2
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Neurofibromatosis type 2
====================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Treatment</u>

【2】**Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is a genetic condition that causes tumours to grow along your nerves. The tumours are usually non-cancerous (benign) but may cause a range of symptoms.**

【3】Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is covered separately because it has different symptoms and causes. It's also much more common than NF2.

【4】Symptoms of neurofibromatosis type 2
------------------------------------

【5】Almost everyone with NF2 develops tumours along the nerves responsible for hearing and balance. These usually cause symptoms such as:

【6】*   hearing loss that gradually gets worse over time
*   hearing ringing or buzzing in the ears (tinnitus)
*   balance problems – particularly when moving in the dark or walking on uneven ground

【7】You can also get other tumours inside the brain or spinal cord, or along the nerves to the arms and legs. This can lead to symptoms such as weakness in the arms and legs, and persistent headaches.
删除7：<u>Read more about the symptoms of NF2</u>

【8】Causes of neurofibromatosis type 2
----------------------------------

【9】Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is caused by a faulty gene. If the NF2 gene is faulty, it leads to uncontrolled growths (tumours) developing in the nervous system.

【10】In half of all cases of NF2, the faulty gene is passed from a parent to their child. Only 1 parent needs to have the faulty gene for their child to be at risk of developing the condition.

【11】If either the mother or father has the faulty gene, there's a 1 in 2 chance that each child they have will develop NF2.

【12】In other cases, the faulty gene appears to develop spontaneously. It's unclear why this happens.

【13】If you have a child who develops NF2 spontaneously, it's highly unlikely any further children you have will also develop the condition. However, your child with NF2 could pass on the condition to any children that they have.

【14】### Mosaic NF2

【15】About 1 in 3 people with NF2 have a form of the disease called mosaic NF2. The symptoms of mosaic NF2 are milder and often restricted to a certain area or side of the body.

【16】People with mosaic NF2 have lower than the usual 50% risk of having a child with NF2. However, if their child does have NF2, it will be the more common type and not mosaic NF2.

【17】Diagnosing neurofibromatosis type 2
-----------------------------------

【18】It's usually easy to diagnose NF2 in adults and older children by checking for the typical symptoms.

【19】It may be diagnosed in babies who show symptoms of NF2 from birth. However, it's not always possible to make a firm diagnosis before a child is 5 years old because some symptoms take years to develop.

【20】If NF2 is suspected, further tests – such as scans, hearing tests, sight tests or blood tests – may be recommended. This is to assess whether your child has other symptoms or conditions associated with NF2.

【21】If there's uncertainty about the diagnosis, your child may be able to have a blood test to see whether they have the faulty NF2 gene. However, the test is not completely reliable and may not find an alteration in the NF2 gene in all people with NF2 symptoms.

【22】### Before and during pregnancy

【23】Couples with a family history of NF2 may wish to consider their options before having a baby. A GP can refer you to a genetic counsellor to discuss your options, which may include:

【24】*   having a child with a donor egg or sperm
*   adopting a child
*   having a test during pregnancy – either chorionic villus sampling or amniocentesis to see if your baby will have NF2
*   pre-implantation genetic diagnosis – where eggs are fertilised and tested in a laboratory, and only eggs without the faulty NF2 gene are implanted in the womb.

【25】Treatment for neurofibromatosis type 2
--------------------------------------

【26】There's currently no cure for NF2. Treatment involves regular monitoring and treating any problems as they occur.

【27】Surgery can be used to remove most tumours, although it carries a risk of causing problems, such as complete deafness or facial weakness. Therefore, the risks and potential benefits need to be carefully considered before treatment.

【28】Most people with NF2 eventually develop significant hearing loss and often benefit from using a hearing aid or learning to lip read. Special implants can sometimes be inserted to improve a person's hearing.

【29】NF2 tends to get worse over time, although the speed at which this happens varies considerably. However, most people with NF2 eventually lose their hearing completely, and some people require a wheelchair or other type of mobility device.

【30】Tumours developing inside the brain and spinal cord can place a strain on the body and shorten life expectancy.
删除7：<u>Read more about treating NF2</u>

【31】Support from Nerve Tumours UK
-----------------------------

【32】Nerve Tumours UK is a charity that aims to improve the lives of people with either type of neurofibromatosis.

【33】通用删除3(英):<u>For more information, you can visit the Nerve Tumours UK website, call its helpline on 07939 046 030 or email info@nervetumours.org.uk.</u>

【34】Information about you
---------------------

【35】If you or your child has NF2, your clinical team will pass information about you/your child on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS). This helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat this condition.

【36】You can opt out of the register at any time.
删除7：<u>Find out more about the register</u>
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 27 April 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 27 April 2024</u>
删除1：<u>*   Next : Symptoms</u>

source_info.title: Complex regional pain syndrome
source_info.text:
【0】Symptoms \- Complex regional pain syndrome
==========================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment</u>

【2】**The main symptom of complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) is pain, which can sometimes be severe, continuous and debilitating.**

【3】It's usually confined to 1 limb, but can sometimes spread to other parts of the body.

【4】Chronic pain
------------

【5】The pain of CRPS is usually triggered by an injury. But the pain is a lot more severe and long-lasting than would normally be expected.

【6】The pain may feel like a mix of burning, stabbing or stinging. There may also be tingling and numbness.

【7】You may have periods of pain lasting a few days or weeks, called flare-ups, where the pain gets worse.

【8】Stress in particular can lead to flare-ups, which is why relaxation techniques and mindfulness training can be an important part of treating CRPS.

【9】If you have CRPS, your skin in the affected area can become very sensitive.

【10】Even the slightest touch, bump or change in temperature can cause intense pain.

【11】You may hear this described in the following medical terms:

【12】*   hyperalgesia – feeling more pain than usual to something that is painful
*   allodynia – feeling pain from something that does not usually cause pain, such as a light touch or pressure to the skin

【13】Other symptoms
--------------

【14】In addition to chronic pain, CRPS can also cause a range of other symptoms.

【15】These can include:

【16】*   strange sensations in the affected limb – it may feel as if it does not belong to the rest of your body, or it may feel bigger or smaller than the opposite unaffected limb
*   alternating changes to your skin – sometimes your skin in the affected limb may be hot, red and dry, whereas other times it may be cold, blue and sweaty – changes to skin colour may be harder to see on brown and black skin
*   hair and nail changes – your hair and nails in the affected limb may grow unusually slowly or quickly and your nails may become brittle or grooved
*   joint stiffness and swelling in the affected limb (oedema)
*   tremors and muscle spasms (dystonia)
*   difficulty moving the affected body part
*   difficulty sleeping (insomnia)
*   small patches of fragile bones (osteoporosis) in the affected limb – although there's no evidence this could lead to fractures

【17】Very rarely, CRPS can also lead to further physical complications, such as:

【18】*   skin infections and open sores (ulcers)
*   muscle atrophy, where the muscles begin to waste away
*   muscle contractures, where the muscles shorten and lose their normal range of movement

【19】Some of these problems can make it very difficult for people with CRPS to move around.

【20】Psychology in CRPS
------------------

【21】The emotional strain of living with chronic pain can sometimes lead to psychological problems, such as depression and anxiety.

【22】During periods of extreme pain, some people may even have suicidal thoughts.

【23】See a GP as soon as possible if you have been experiencing depression or had suicidal thoughts. They'll be able to provide help and support.

【24】Or you can call the Samaritans on 116 123 or email jo@samaritans.org.

【25】They're available 24 hours a day to talk through any issues you may be experiencing in total confidence.

【26】When to see a GP
----------------

【27】You should see a GP if you have persistent pain that's preventing you from carrying out everyday activities.

【28】CRPS can be difficult to diagnose. It's best to get help as soon as possible because early treatment can help reduce your painful symptoms.
删除7：<u>Find out more about diagnosing CRPS.</u>
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 27 October 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 27 October 2025</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Complex regional pain syndrome</u>删除1：<u>*   Next : Causes</u>

text.text: 【24】Or you can call the Samaritans on 116 123 or email jo@samaritans.org.

4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment</u>

【15】These can include:

【16】*   strange sensations in the affected limb – it may feel as if it does not belong to the rest of your body, or it may feel bigger or smaller than the opposite unaffected limb
*   alternating changes to your skin – sometimes your skin in the affected limb may be hot, red and dry, whereas other times it may be cold, blue and sweaty – changes to skin colour may be harder to see on brown and black skin

*   difficulty sleeping (insomnia)
*   small patches of fragile bones (osteoporosis) in the affected limb – although there's no evidence this could lead to fractures

【17】Very rarely, CRPS can also lead to further physical complications, such as:

【18】*   skin infections and open sores (ulcers)
*   muscle atrophy, where the muscles begin to waste away
*   muscle contractures, where the muscles shorten and lose their normal range of movement

【19】Some of these problems can make it very difficult for people with CRPS to move around.

【20】Psychology in CRPS
------------------

【21】The emotional strain of living with chronic pain can sometimes lead to psychological problems, such as depression and anxiety.

【22】During periods of extreme pain, some people may even have suicidal thoughts.

【23】See a GP as soon as possible if you have been experiencing depression or had suicidal thoughts. They'll be able to provide help and support.

【24】Or you can call the Samaritans on 116 123 or email jo@samaritans.org.

【25】They're available 24 hours a day to talk through any issues you may be experiencing in total confidence.

【26】When to see a GP
----------------

【27】You should see a GP if you have persistent pain that's preventing you from carrying out everyday activities.

【28】CRPS can be difficult to diagnose. It's best to get help as soon as possible because early treatment can help reduce your painful symptoms.
删除7：<u>Find out more about diagnosing CRPS.</u>

source_info.title: Nifedipine
source_info.text:
【0】Taking nifedipine with other medicines and herbal supplements
=============================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】If you take other medicines that lower blood pressure with nifedipine, the combination can sometimes lower your blood pressure too much. This may make you feel dizzy or faint. If this keeps happening to you, tell your doctor as your dose may need to be changed.

【3】Some medicines can affect the way nifedipine works.

【4】Tell your doctor if you're taking any of these medicines before starting nifedipine:

【5】*   the antibiotics clarithromycin, erythromycin or rifampicin
*   calcium channel blockers like diltiazem or verapamil
*   the antifungal medicines fluconazole or itraconazole
*   medicines for HIV or hepatitis C
*   the epilepsy medicines carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital (phenobarbitone), sodium valproate, valproic acid or primidone
*   tacrolimus, a medicine used for preventing rejection of organ transplants or for treating conditions caused by an overactive immune system
*   cimetidine, an acid-suppressing medicine
*   the antidepressants fluoxetine or nefazodone
*   digoxin, a medicine for heart problems

【6】Mixing nifedipine with herbal remedies and supplements
------------------------------------------------------

【7】St John's wort, a herbal medicine taken for depression, is thought to affect the way nifedipine works. Talk to your doctor if you're thinking about taking St John's wort.

【8】Ginkgo biloba and ginseng are popular supplements that may also affect nifedipine.

【9】There's not enough information to say that other herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with nifedipine. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【10】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【11】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.
删除11：<u>More in Nifedipine
------------------

【12】*   About nifedipine
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking nifedipine with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

source_info.title: Group B strep
source_info.text:
【0】Group B strep
=============

【1】Group B strep is a type of bacteria called streptococcal bacteria.

【2】It's very common in both men and women and usually lives in the bottom (rectum) or vagina. It affects 2 to 4 women in 10.

【3】Group B strep is normally harmless and most people will not realise they have it.

【4】It's usually only a problem if it affects:

【5】*   pregnant women – it could spread to the baby
*   young babies – it can make them very ill
*   elderly people or those who are already very ill – it can cause repeated or serious infections

【6】This page focuses on group B strep in pregnancy and babies.

【7】Group B strep in pregnancy
--------------------------

【8】Group B strep is common in pregnant women and rarely causes any problems.

【9】It's not routinely tested for, but may be found during tests carried out for another reason, such as a urine test or vaginal swab.

【10】### Risks in pregnancy

【11】If you have group B strep while you're pregnant:

【12】*   your baby will usually be healthy
*   there's a small risk it could spread to your baby during labour and make them ill – this happens in about 1 in 1,750 pregnancies
*   there's an extremely small risk you could miscarry or lose your baby

【13】### What to do if you're worried

【14】If you're worried about group B strep, speak to your midwife or GP for advice.

【15】Talk to them about the risks to your baby and ask their advice about whether to get tested.

【16】Routine testing is not currently recommended and tests are rarely done on the NHS, but you can pay for one privately.
删除7：<u>Find out more about getting tested for group B strep on the Group B Strep Support website</u>

【17】### What happens if you have group B strep

【18】If tests find group B strep, or you've had a baby that's been affected by it before, you may need extra care and treatment.

【19】You may be advised to:

【20】*   speak to your midwife about your birth plan – they may recommend giving birth in hospital
*   contact your midwife as soon as you go into labour or your waters break
*   have antibiotics into a vein during labour – this can significantly reduce the risk of your baby getting ill
*   stay in hospital for at least 12 hours after giving birth so your baby can be monitored – this is not always necessary

【21】Group B strep in babies
-----------------------

【22】If you had group B strep during pregnancy, there's a small risk it could spread to your baby and make them very ill.

【23】If this happens, it's usually soon after they're born. Your baby may be monitored in hospital for up to 12 hours to check for any problems.

【24】They'll be given antibiotics into a vein if they develop symptoms.

【25】### What to look for after leaving hospital

【26】Occasionally, symptoms of a group B strep infection can develop up to 3 months after birth.

【27】Call 999 or go to A&E if your baby gets any of these symptoms:

【28】*   being floppy or unresponsive
*   grunting when breathing, or working hard to breathe when you look at their chest or stomach
*   very fast or slow breathing
*   an unusually high or low temperature
*   changes in their skin colour or blotchy skin
*   not feeding well or vomiting milk up
*   an unusually fast or slow heart rate

【29】They may need treatment with antibiotics in hospital immediately.

【30】### Risks in babies

【31】Most babies with a group B strep infection make a full recovery if treated.

【32】Some babies may develop serious problems like sepsis or meningitis.

【33】This can cause lasting problems like hearing loss or loss of vision. Sometimes it can be fatal.
删除4：<u>More information
----------------

【34】*   RCOG: group B streptococcus in pregnancy and newborn babies
*   Group B Strep Support: group B strep and pregnancy
*   Tommy’s: group B strep (strep B) and pregnancy
