source_info.title: Benign brain tumour (non-cancerous)
source_info.text:
【0】Recovery \- Benign brain tumour (non-cancerous)
===============================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Recovery</u>

【2】**After being treated for a benign (non-cancerous) brain tumour, you may need additional care to monitor and treat any further problems.**

【3】Follow-up appointments
----------------------

【4】Non-cancerous brain tumours can sometimes grow back after treatment, so you'll have regular follow-up appointments to check for signs of this.

【5】Your appointments may include a discussion of any new symptoms you experience, a physical examination, and, occasionally, a brain scan.

【6】It's likely you'll have follow-up appointments at least every few months to start with, but they'll probably be needed less frequently if no problems develop.

【7】Side effects of treatment
-------------------------

【8】Some people who have had a brain tumour can develop side effects of treatment months or years later, such as:

【9】*   cataracts
*   problems with thinking, memory, language or judgement
*   epilepsy
*   hearing loss
*   infertility
*   migraine attacks
*   a tumour developing somewhere else
*   numbness, pain, weakness or loss of vision resulting from nerve damage (but these complications are rare)
*   a stroke (this is rare)

【10】If you or someone you care for has any worrying symptoms that develop after brain tumour treatment, see your doctor.

【11】If you think it's a stroke, dial 999 immediately and ask for an ambulance.

【12】Supportive treatment
--------------------

【13】Problems caused by a brain tumour do not always resolve as soon as the tumour is removed or treated.

【14】For example, some people have persistent weakness, epileptic fits (seizures), difficulty walking and speech problems.

【15】Extra support may be needed to help you overcome or adapt to any problems you have.

【16】This may include therapies such as:

【17】*   **physiotherapy** to help with any movement problems you have
*   **occupational therapy** to identify any problems you're having with daily activities, and arrange for any equipment or alterations to your home that may help
*   **speech and language therapy** to help you with communication or swallowing problems

【18】Some people may also need to continue taking medicine for seizures for a few months or more after their tumour has been treated or removed.

【19】The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) has made recommendations about the standards of care people with brain tumours should receive.
删除8：<u>See the NICE guidance about improving outcomes for people with brain and other central nervous system tumours.</u>

【20】Driving and travelling
----------------------

【21】You may not be allowed to drive for a while after being diagnosed with a brain tumour.

【22】How long you'll be unable to drive will depend on factors such as:

【23】*   whether you have had epileptic fits (seizures)
*   the type of brain tumour you have
*   where it is in your brain
*   what symptoms you have
*   what type of surgery you have had

【24】If you're unsure whether or not you should be driving, do not drive until you have had clarification from the DVLA, your GP or specialist. 

【25】Driving against medical advice is both dangerous and against the law.

【26】If you need to give up your driving licence, the DVLA will speak to your GP or specialist to determine when you can drive again.

【27】With up-to-date scans and advice from your medical team, you may be allowed to drive after an agreed period.

【28】This is usually after you have successfully completed medical tests to determine your ability to control a vehicle, and when the risk of having seizures is low删除7：<u>

【29】The Cancer Research UK website has more information about brain tumours and driving.</u>

【30】Flying is usually possible when you have recovered from surgery, but you should let your travel insurance company know about your condition.

【31】Lifestyle advice
----------------

【32】If you have had radiotherapy, it's important to follow a healthy lifestyle to lower your risk of stroke.

【33】This means stopping smoking if you smoke, eating a balanced diet and doing regular exercise.

【34】However, there are limits to the exercise you should do.

【35】### Sports and activities

【36】After being treated for a brain tumour, you might be advised to permanently avoid contact sports, such as rugby and boxing.

【37】You can start other activities again, with the agreement of your doctor, once you have recovered.

【38】Swimming unsupervised is not recommended for about a year after treatment because there's a risk you could have a seizure while in the water.

【39】Sex and pregnancy
-----------------

【40】It's safe to have sex after treatment for a non-cancerous brain tumour.

【41】Women may be advised to avoid becoming pregnant for 6 months or more after treatment. 

【42】If you're planning to become pregnant, you should discuss this with your medical team.

【43】Going back to work
------------------

【44】Tiredness is a common symptom after receiving treatment for a brain tumour. This often restricts your ability to return to work.

【45】Although you may want to return to work and normal life as soon as possible, it's probably a good idea to work part time to begin with and only go back full time when you feel ready.

【46】If you have had seizures, you should not work with machinery or at heights.

【47】Help and support
----------------

【48】A brain tumour is often life changing. You may feel angry, frightened and emotionally drained.

【49】Your doctor or specialist may be able to refer you to a social worker or counsellor for help with the practical and emotional aspects of your diagnosis.

【50】There are also a number of organisations that can provide help and support, such as The Brain Tumour Charity and Brain Tumour Research.
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 21 April 2020  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 21 April 2023</u>
删除1：<u>*   Previous : Treatment</u>

source_info.title: Laxatives
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Laxatives
=====================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Considerations</u>

【2】**Laxatives are a type of medicine that can treat** **constipation****.**

【3】They're often used if lifestyle changes, such as increasing the amount of fibre in your diet, drinking plenty of fluid and taking regular exercise, have not helped.

【4】Laxatives are available to buy from pharmacies and supermarkets. They're also available on prescription from a doctor.

【5】Types of laxatives
------------------

【6】There are 4 main types of laxatives.

【7】### Bulk-forming laxatives

【8】Bulk-forming laxatives work by increasing the "bulk" or weight of poo, which in turn stimulates your bowel.

【9】They take 2 or 3 days to work.

【10】Bulk-forming laxatives include:

【11】*   Fybogel (ispaghula husk)
*   methylcellulose

【12】### Osmotic laxatives 

【13】Osmotic laxatives draw water from the rest of the body into your bowel to soften poo and make it easier to pass.

【14】They take 2 or 3 days to work.

【15】They include:

【16】*   lactulose (also called by the brand names Duphalac and Lactugal)
*   macrogol (also called by the brand names Movicol, Laxido, CosmoCol, Molaxole and Molative)
*   polyethylene glycol

【17】### Stimulant laxatives

【18】These stimulate the muscles that line your gut, helping them to move poo along to your back passage.

【19】They take 6 to 12 hours to work.

【20】They include:

【21】*   bisacodyl (also called by the brand name Dulcolax)
*   senna (also called by the brand name Senokot)
*   sodium picosulfate

【22】### Poo-softener laxatives

【23】This type of laxative works by letting water into poo to soften it and make it easier to pass.

【24】They include:

【25】*   arachis oil
*   docusate

【26】Which laxative should I use?
----------------------------

【27】It's difficult to know whether a particular laxative will work better than another. It depends on the person.

【28】Unless there's a reason why a type of laxative may be more suitable for you than another:

【29】*   start with a bulk-forming laxative
*   if your poo remains hard, try using an osmotic laxative in addition to, or instead of, a bulk-forming laxative
*   if your poo is soft but is still difficult to pass, try taking a stimulant laxative in addition to a bulk-forming laxative

【30】Speak to a GP or pharmacist if you're unsure which laxative to use.

【31】Also see a GP if you're still constipated after trying all of the different types of laxative, or you think your child might benefit from taking laxatives.

【32】Things to consider
------------------

【33】Laxatives are not suitable for everyone.

【34】They're not usually recommended for:

【35】*   children (unless advised by a doctor)
*   people with certain health conditions, such as Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis

【36】Before using a laxative, read about it in our Medicines guide or the patient information leaflet that comes with the medicine to make sure it's safe for you to take.
删除7：<u>Find out more about the considerations about laxatives</u>

【37】How to take laxatives
---------------------

【38】How you take a laxative depends on the form it comes in.

【39】They're commonly available as:

【40】*   tablets or capsules you swallow
*   sachets of powder you mix with water and then drink
*   a capsule you place inside your bottom (rectum), where it'll dissolve (suppositories)
*   liquids or gels that you place directly into your bottom

【41】Some laxatives have to be taken at certain times of the day, such as first thing in the morning or last thing at night.

【42】Ask a pharmacist for advice if you're not sure how to take your laxative.

【43】If you're taking bulk-forming or osmotic laxatives, it's important to drink plenty of fluids. This is because these laxatives can cause dehydration.

【44】Never take more than the recommended dose of laxatives as this can be harmful and cause side effects.

【45】How long should I take laxatives for?
-------------------------------------

【46】Ideally, only take laxatives occasionally and for up to a week at a time.

【47】Stop taking a laxative when your constipation improves.

【48】If your constipation has not improved after taking laxatives for a week, speak to a GP.

【49】After taking a laxative, you can make certain lifestyle changes to help stop getting constipated again, such as:

【50】*   drinking plenty of water
*   exercising regularly
*   including more fibre in your diet

【51】These are better ways of preventing constipation than using laxatives.

【52】Do not take laxatives every day to ease your constipation as this can be harmful.

【53】Speak to a GP if you're still constipated after making lifestyle changes.

【54】In some cases, you may be prescribed a laxative to use regularly, but this should always be supervised by a GP or gastroenterologist (a specialist in gut problems).

【55】The side effects of laxatives
-----------------------------

【56】Like most medicines, laxatives can cause side effects. They're usually mild and should pass once you stop taking the laxative.

【57】The side effects you may get will depend on the type of laxative you're taking, but common side effects of most laxatives include:

【58】*   bloating
*   farting
*   tummy cramps
*   feeling sick
*   dehydration, which can make you feel lightheaded, have headaches and have pee that's a darker colour than normal

【59】Ask a GP for advice if you get any particularly troublesome or persistent side effects while taking laxatives.

【60】Using laxatives too often or for too long can also cause diarrhoea, the bowel becoming blocked by large, dry poo (intestinal obstruction), and unbalanced salts and minerals in your body.

【61】Self-help alternatives to laxatives
-----------------------------------

【62】It's often possible to improve constipation without using laxatives.

【63】It may help to:

【64】*   increase your daily intake of fibre – try to eat about 30g of fibre a day; read about how to increase the fibre in your diet
*   add bulking agents, such as wheat bran, to your diet – these will help make your poo softer and easier to pass, although bran and fibre can sometimes make bloating worse
*   drink plenty of water
*   exercise regularly
删除7：<u>Find out more about preventing constipation</u>
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 11 October 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 11 October 2025</u>
删除1：<u>*   Next : Considerations</u>

source_info.title: Lymecycline
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking lymecycline
===============================================================

【1】Lymecycline and pregnancy
-------------------------

【2】Lymecycline is not recommended during pregnancy

【3】It can affect the teeth and bone development in your baby.

【4】Your doctor will be able to talk to you about prescribing a different antibiotic.

【5】Lymecycline and breastfeeding
-----------------------------

【6】Lymecycline is not one of the preferred antibiotics to use while you're breastfeeding, however it might be OK to take. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist first.

【7】We do not know how much lymecycline passes into breast milk. However, it is likely to be a small amount. It is best to use lymecycline for as short a time as possible when breastfeeding, ideally for no longer than 3 weeks.

【8】There is a small chance that lymecycline can affect your baby's teeth and bone development when used for a long time. However, this is very unlikely to happen when babies have lymecycline through breast milk.

【9】Contact your doctor, pharmacist, health visitor or midwife if:

【10】*   your baby is not feeding as well as usual or has an upset stomach
*   your baby has a rash or oral thrush (a fungal infection in their mouth)
*   you have any other concerns about your baby

【11】Lymecycline and fertility
-------------------------

【12】There's no evidence to suggest that taking lymecycline reduces fertility in either men or women.

【13】Speak to a pharmacist or doctor before taking it if you're trying to get pregnant as they may recommend alternative treatment for you.

【14】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【15】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【16】通用删除3(英):<u>For more information about how lymecycline can affect you and your baby during pregnancy, visit the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website.</u>
删除11：<u>More in Lymecycline
-------------------

【17】*   About lymecycline
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking lymecycline with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 6 January 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 6 January 2025</u>

source_info.title: Dwarfism, see Restricted growth (dwarfism)
source_info.text:
【0】Dwarfism, see Restricted growth (dwarfism)
Overview \- Restricted growth (dwarfism)
========================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Treatment</u>

【2】**Restricted growth, sometimes known as dwarfism, is a condition characterised by unusually short height.**

【3】There are 2 main types of restricted growth:

【4】*   proportionate short stature (PSS) – a general lack of growth in the body, arms and legs
*   disproportionate short stature (DSS) – where the arms and legs are particularly short

【5】As well as being short, some people with restricted growth also have other physical problems, such as bowed legs or an unusually curved spine.

【6】But most people don't have any other serious problems and are able to live a relatively normal life, with a normal life expectancy.
删除7：<u>Read more about the symptoms of restricted growth.</u>

【7】What causes restricted growth?
------------------------------

【8】### Causes of PSS

【9】The most common cause of PSS is being born to small parents, but it's sometimes the result of the body not producing enough growth hormone.

【10】Certain genetic syndromes, such as Turner syndrome, Noonan syndrome and Prader-Willi syndrome, can also cause PSS.

【11】### Causes of DSS

【12】A rare genetic condition called achondroplasia is the most common cause of DSS.

【13】It causes poor bone growth, resulting in short upper arms and thighs.

【14】It doesn't always run in the family – many children with achondroplasia have parents of normal height删除7：<u>

【15】The Restricted Growth Association UK has more information about achondroplasia and other rare types of restricted growth.</u>

【16】Diagnosing restricted growth
----------------------------

【17】Restricted growth may be diagnosed before a child is born, soon afterwards, or when growth problems become more obvious as they get older.

【18】Growth hormone deficiency is usually diagnosed using growth hormone stimulation tests.

【19】Medicine is injected into a vein or muscle to cause an increase in growth hormone levels in the blood. A lower than normal level indicates a deficiency in growth hormone.

【20】A brain scan will be needed to look at the pituitary gland (which produces growth hormone) if blood tests show low levels of growth hormone.

【21】If one or both parents have a family history of a condition that causes short stature, their baby can be tested for this during pregnancy (prenatal diagnosis).
删除7：<u>Read more about screening tests in pregnancy.</u>

【22】Treatment for restricted growth
-------------------------------

【23】Treatment with growth hormone injections may benefit some people with restricted growth and can help a child with the condition grow more than they otherwise would.

【24】In cases of DSS where the legs are particularly short, a leg-lengthening procedure is sometimes used, but there's some uncertainty about its safety and effectiveness.
删除7：<u>Read more about treatments for restricted growth.</u>
删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 30 March 2021  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 30 March 2024</u>
删除1：<u>*   Next : Symptoms</u>

source_info.title: Warfarin
source_info.text:
【0】About warfarin
==============

【1】Warfarin is a type of medicine known as an anticoagulant.

【2】It makes your blood flow through your veins more easily. This means your blood will be less likely to make a dangerous blood clot.

【3】Warfarin is used to treat blood clots and help prevent future blood clots if you've had one previously, such as:

【4】*   a blood clot in the leg (deep vein thrombosis, or DVT)
*   a blood clot in the lungs (pulmonary embolism)

【5】It's also used to prevent blood clots if you're at high risk of having them in the future.

【6】This includes people with:

【7】*   an irregular heartbeat (atrial fibrillation)
*   a replacement or mechanical heart valve
*   a blood clotting disorder, such as thrombophilia
*   a higher chance of having a blood clot after an operation

【8】Warfarin is only available on prescription. It comes as tablets and as a liquid that you swallow.

【9】Key facts
---------

【10】*   You'll usually take warfarin once a day in the evening.
*   The most common side effect of warfarin is bleeding more easily than normal, such as having nosebleeds, bleeding gums, heavier periods and bruising. This is most likely to happen if you're unwell.
*   You need to have blood tests at least every 12 weeks while you're taking warfarin to make sure your dose is right.
*   It's normal for your warfarin dose to go up or down. The dose can depend on lots of different things, including what you eat and drink, what other medicines you're taking, and if you become unwell.
*   Your doctor or pharmacist will give you an anticoagulant alert card. Always carry this with you. Show it to your doctor or dentist before you have any medical or dental procedures, including vaccinations and routine appointments with the dental hygienist.
删除11：<u>More in Warfarin
----------------

【11】*   About warfarin
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Advice about food and drink
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking warfarin with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions
</u>删除1：<u>Page last reviewed: 22 April 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Next review due: 22 April 2025</u>

source_info.title: Prednisolone tablets and liquid
source_info.text:
【0】Who can and cannot take prednisolone tablets and liquid
=======================================================

【1】Who can take prednisolone tablets and liquid
--------------------------------------------

【2】Most adults and children can take prednisolone tablets and liquid.

【3】**Who may not be able to take prednisolone tablets and liquid**
---------------------------------------------------------------

【4】To make sure prednisolone is safe for you, tell your doctor or pharmacist before taking it if you:

【5】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to prednisolone or any other medicine
*   have an infection (including eye infections) or any unhealed wounds
*   are trying to get pregnant, are already pregnant or you are breastfeeding
*   have recently been in contact with someone with shingles, chickenpox or measles
*   have recently had, or are about to have, any vaccinations
*   have liver problems
*   have ever had or any close family members have had mental health problems
*   have heart failure or have had a recent heart attack
*   have high blood pressure (hypertension)
*   have diabetes
*   have epilepsy
*   have glaucoma
*   have an underactive thyroid
*   have thinning bones (osteoporosis)
*   have ever had a stomach ulcer
删除11：<u>More in Prednisolone tablets and liquid
---------------------------------------

【6】*   About prednisolone
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking prednisolone with other medicines and herbal supplements
*   Common questions

source_info.title: Lactulose
source_info.text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking lactulose
=============================================================

【1】Lactulose and pregnancy
-----------------------

【2】Lactulose can be taken during pregnancy and is not harmful to your baby.

【3】Lactulose and breastfeeding
---------------------------

【4】If your doctor or midwife says your baby is healthy, it's OK to take lactulose while you are breastfeeding.

【5】Lactulose does not pass into breast milk so it's very unlikely to cause any side effects in your baby. However, it is always better to treat constipation without taking a medicine first.

【6】If your baby is not feeding as well as usual, or has diarrhoea, or if you have any other concerns about your baby, then talk to your health visitor, midwife, pharmacist or doctor.

【7】Lactulose and fertility
-----------------------

【8】There's no evidence to suggest that taking lactulose should cause any fertility problems in either men or women.

【9】通用删除3(英):<u>For more information about how laxatives can affect you and your baby during pregnancy, visit the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website.</u>

source_info.title: Prader-Willi syndrome
source_info.text:
【0】Overview \- Prader-Willi syndrome
=================================
删除10：<u>Contents
--------

【1】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Management</u>

【2】**Prader-Willi syndrome is a rare genetic condition that causes a wide range of physical symptoms, learning difficulties and behavioural challenges. It's usually noticed shortly after birth.**

【3】Symptoms of Prader-Willi syndrome
---------------------------------

【4】Typical symptoms of Prader-Willi syndrome include:

【5】*   an excessive appetite and overeating, which can easily lead to dangerous weight gain
*   restricted growth (children are much shorter than average)
*   floppiness caused by weak muscles (hypotonia)
*   learning difficulties
*   lack of sexual development
*   behavioural challenges, such as emotional outbursts and physical aggression
删除7：<u>Read more about symptoms of Prader-Willi syndrome.</u>

【6】Causes of Prader-Willi syndrome
-------------------------------

【7】Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by some missing genetic material in a group of genes on chromosome number 15.

【8】This leads to a number of problems and is thought to affect part of the brain called the hypothalamus, which produces hormones and regulates growth and appetite.

【9】This may explain some of the typical features of Prader-Willi syndrome, such as delayed growth and persistent hunger.

【10】The genetic cause happens purely by chance, and boys and girls of all ethnic backgrounds can be affected.

【11】It's extremely rare for parents to have more than 1 child with Prader-Willi syndrome.
删除7：<u>Read more about the causes of Prader-Willi syndrome.</u>

【12】Diagnosing Prader-Willi syndrome
--------------------------------

【13】Prader-Willi syndrome can usually be confirmed by carrying out genetic testing.

【14】Genetic testing may be recommended if a child has the symptoms of Prader-Willi syndrome. Babies who are very floppy at birth may also be tested.
删除7：<u>Read more about diagnosing Prader-Willi syndrome.</u>

【15】Managing Prader-Willi syndrome
------------------------------

【16】There's no cure for Prader-Willi syndrome, so treatment aims to manage the symptoms and associated difficulties.

【17】This includes managing the person's excessive appetite and behavioural challenges.

【18】One of the most important parts of caring for someone with Prader-Willi syndrome is to try to maintain a normal weight.

【19】They should have a healthy, balanced diet, avoiding sweet treats and high-calorie items right from the start.

【20】If someone with Prader-Willi syndrome is allowed to eat as much as they want, they'll quickly become dangerously overweight.

【21】Someone with the syndrome can eat much more than other people and still feel hungry.

【22】Limiting food intake can be very challenging. People with Prader-Willi syndrome may become frustrated when they want extra food, and their hunger can make them hide or steal food.
删除7：<u>Read more about managing Prader-Willi syndrome.</u>

【23】Long-term problems caused by Prader-Willi syndrome
--------------------------------------------------

【24】Prader-Willi syndrome itself is not life-threatening. But compulsive eating and weight gain can cause young adults with the syndrome to develop serious obesity-related conditions such as:

【25】*   type 2 diabetes
*   heart failure
*   breathing difficulties

【26】If their diet is well controlled and they do not become overweight, adults can have a good quality of life and probably a normal life expectancy.

【27】Many adults with Prader-Willi syndrome take part in activities such as voluntary or part-time work but it's unlikely they'll be able to live fully independent lives.

【28】The increased appetite also means there's a higher risk of choking on food, so carers are advised to learn what to do if someone is choking.

【29】PWSA UK
-------

【30】The Prader-Willi Syndrome Association UK (PWSA UK) provides information and support for people whose lives are affected by the syndrome. You can call the PWSA UK helpline on 01332 365676.

【31】National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service
-----------------------------------------------------------------

【32】If your child has Prader-Willi syndrome, your clinical team will pass information about them on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

【33】The NCARDRS helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat Prader-Willi syndrome. You can opt out of the register at any time.
删除3：<u>Video: Prader-Willi syndrome
----------------------------

【34】In this video, a psychiatrist explains the different symptoms of Prader-Willi syndrome.
删除1：<u>Media last reviewed: 1 March 2022  </u>删除1：<u>Media review due: 1 March 2025</u>

source_info.title: Arthritis
source_info.text: 【0】Overview \- Arthritis ===================== 删除10：Contents -------- 【1】1. Overview 2. Living with arthritis 【2】**Arthritis is a common condition that causes pain and inflammation in a joint.** 【3】In the UK, millions of people have arthritis or other, similar conditions that affect the joints. 【4】Arthritis affects people of all ages, including children. 【5】Types of arthritis ------------------ 【6】Osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis are the 2 most common types of arthritis. 【7】### Osteoarthritis 【8】Osteoarthritis is the most common type of arthritis in the UK. 【9】It most often develops in people in their mid-40s or older. 【10】It's also more common in women and people with a family history of the condition. 【11】But it can occur at any age as a result of an injury or be associated with other joint-related conditions, such as gout or rheumatoid arthritis. 【12】Osteoarthritis initially affects the smooth cartilage lining of the joint. This makes movement more difficult than usual, leading to pain and stiffness. 【13】Once the cartilage lining starts to roughen and thin out, the tendons and ligaments have to work harder. 【14】This can cause swelling and the formation of bony spurs called osteophytes. 【15】Severe loss of cartilage can lead to bone rubbing on bone, altering the shape of the joint and forcing the bones out of their normal position. 【16】The most commonly affected joints are those in the: 【17】* hands * spine * knees * hips 删除7：Find out more about osteoarthritis 【18】### Rheumatoid arthritis 【19】Rheumatoid arthritis is less common than osteoarthritis. 【20】It often starts when a person is between 30 and 50 years old. Women are more likely to be affected than men. 【21】In rheumatoid arthritis, the body's immune system targets affected joints, which leads to pain and swelling. 【22】The outer covering (synovium) of the joint is the first place affected. 【23】This can then spread across the joint, leading to further swelling and a change in the joint's shape. This may cause the bone and cartilage to break down. 【24】People with rheumatoid arthritis can also develop problems with other tissues and organs in their body. 删除7：Find out more about rheumatoid arthritis 【25】### Other types of arthritis and related conditions 【26】* **ankylosing spondylitis** – a long-term inflammatory condition that mainly affects the bones, muscles and ligaments of the spine, leading to stiffness and joints fusing together. Other problems can include the swelling of tendons, eyes and large joints * **cervical spondylosis** – also known as degenerative osteoarthritis, cervical spondylitis affects the joints and bones in the neck, which can lead to pain and stiffness * **fibromyalgia** – causes pain in the body's muscles, ligaments and tendons * **lupus** – an autoimmune condition that can affect many different organs and the body's tissues * **gout** – a type of arthritis caused by too much uric acid in the body. This can be left in joints (usually affecting the big toe), but can develop in any joint. It causes intense pain, redness and swelling * **psoriatic arthritis** – an inflammatory joint condition that can affect people with psoriasis * **enteropathic arthritis** – a form of chronic inflammatory arthritis associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), the 2 main types being ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. The most common areas affected by inflammation are the lower limb joints and the spine * **reactive arthritis** – this can cause pain and swelling of the joints, sore eyes and extreme tiredness. It develops shortly after an infection of the gut, bowel or throat * **secondary arthritis** – a type of arthritis that can develop after a joint injury and sometimes occurs many years afterwards * **polymyalgia rheumatica** – a condition that almost always affects people over 50 years of age, where the immune system causes muscle pain and stiffness, usually across the shoulders and tops of the legs. It can also cause joint inflammation 【27】Symptoms of arthritis --------------------- 【28】There are lots of different types of arthritis. 【29】The symptoms you experience will vary depending on the type you have. 【30】This is why it's important to have an accurate diagnosis if you have: 【31】* joint pain, tenderness and stiffness * inflammation in and around the joints * restricted movement of the joints * warm red skin over the affected joint * weakness and muscle wasting 【32】Arthritis and children ---------------------- 【33】Arthritis is often associated with older people, but it can also affect children. 【34】Most types of childhood arthritis are known as juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). 【35】JIA causes pain and inflammation in 1 or more joints for at least 6 weeks. 【36】Although the exact cause of JIA is unknown, the symptoms often improve as a child gets older, meaning they can lead a normal life. 【37】### Oligo-articular JIA (oligoarthritis) 【38】Oligo-articular JIA is the most common type of JIA. It affects up to 4 joints in the body, most commonly in the knees, ankles and wrists. 【39】Oligo-articular JIA often goes away without causing long-term joint damage. 【40】But there's a risk that children with the condition may develop eye problems, so regular eye tests with an eyecare specialist called an ophthalmologist are recommended. 【41】### Polyarticular JIA (polyarthritis) 【42】Polyarticular JIA, or polyarthritis, is the second most common type of JIA and affects 5 or more joints. 【43】It can affect a child of any age and may come on suddenly or develop gradually. 【44】The symptoms of polyarticular JIA are similar to the symptoms of adult rheumatoid arthritis. 【45】A child with the condition may also feel unwell and may occasionally have a high temperature of 38C or above. 【46】### Systemic onset JIA 【47】Systemic onset JIA begins with symptoms such as a fever, rash, a lack of energy and enlarged glands. Later on, joints can become swollen and inflamed. 【48】Like polyarticular JIA, systemic onset JIA can affect children of any age. 【49】### Enthesitis-related arthritis 【50】Enthesitis-related arthritis is a type of juvenile arthritis that often affects the joints of the leg and spine, causing inflammation where the tendons attach to the bone. 【51】It can cause stiffness in the neck and lower back in the teenage years. 【52】It's also linked to a painful eye condition called acute uveitis. 删除6：### Find out more 【53】Versus Arthritis: juvenile idiopathic arthritis 【54】 Treating arthritis ------------------ 【55】There's no cure for arthritis, but there are many treatments that can help slow it down. 【56】Osteoarthritis treatments include lifestyle changes, medicines and surgery. 【57】Treatment for rheumatoid arthritis aims to slow the condition's progress and minimise joint inflammation. This helps prevent joint damage. 【58】Treatments include medicine, physiotherapy and surgery. 【59】Information: 【60】### Self-refer for treatment 【61】If you have arthritis, you might be able to refer yourself directly to services for help with your condition without seeing a GP. 【62】To find out if there are any services in your area: 【63】* ask the reception staff at your GP surgery * check your GP surgery's website * contact your integrated care board (ICB) – find your local ICB * search online for NHS treatment for arthritis near you 【64】Further information, help and support ------------------------------------- 【65】Versus Arthritis provides help and support for people in the UK with arthritis, plus their families and friends. 【66】They have a free helpline you can call for further information and support on 0800 5200 520, Monday to Friday, 9am to 6pm. The helpline is closed from 12pm on the last Friday of every month for training. 【67】You can also look up arthritis services near where you live. 删除7：Find out more about living with arthritis 【68】Information: 【69】### Social care and support guide 【70】If you: 【71】* need help with day-to-day living because of illness or disability * care for someone regularly because they're ill, elderly or disabled, including family members 【72】Our guide to care and support explains your options and where you can get support. 删除14：Community content from HealthUnlocked 删除1：Page last reviewed: 08 September 2022 删除1：Next review due: 08 September 2025 删除1：* Next : Living with arthritis

source_info.title: Aspirin – low-dose, see Low-dose aspirin
source_info.text:
【0】Aspirin – low-dose, see Low-dose aspirin
Common questions about low-dose aspirin
=======================================

【1】How does low-dose aspirin work?

【2】Aspirin slows the blood's clotting action by making platelets less sticky.

【3】Platelets are blood cells that stick together and block cuts and breaks in blood vessels, so they're important in normal health. But in people at risk of heart attacks and stroke, platelets can stick together inside already narrowed blood vessels to form a clot. The clot can stop blood flowing to the heart or brain and cause a heart attack or stroke.

【4】If you take it every day, low-dose aspirin stops platelets clumping together to form unwanted blood clots, and helps to prevent heart attacks and stroke.

【5】When will I feel better?

【6】You may not notice any difference in how you feel after you start taking low-dose aspirin. This does not mean that it's not working.

【7】Carry on taking daily low-dose aspirin even if you feel well, as you'll still be getting the benefits.

【8】Are there any long term side effects?

【9】Low-dose aspirin is generally safe to take for a long time. In fact, it works best if you take it for many months or years.

【10】Occasionally, low-dose aspirin can cause an ulcer in your stomach or gut if you take it for a long time.

【11】If you're at risk of getting a stomach ulcer, your doctor may prescribe a medicine to help protect your stomach.

【12】Does aspirin cause stomach ulcers?

【13】Aspirin can cause ulcers in your stomach or gut, especially if you take it for a long time or in big doses.

【14】Your doctor may tell you not to take aspirin if you have a stomach ulcer, or if you've had one in the past.

【15】If you're at risk of getting a stomach ulcer and you need a painkiller, take paracetamol instead of aspirin as it's gentler on your stomach.

【16】Are there other medicines like low-dose aspirin?

【17】If you cannot take low-dose aspirin, you may be able to take another medicine that helps prevent blood clots, such as clopidogrel, instead.

【18】Like aspirin, these medicines prevent blood clots from forming and reduce the chances of heart attack and stroke in people at high risk of them.

【19】Can we all take low-dose aspirin to prevent heart attacks and strokes?

【20】No, this is not recommended.

【21】If you have had a heart attack or stroke, or you're at high risk of either, studies have shown that the benefits of taking daily low-dose aspirin far outweigh the risk of side effects.

【22】But if you do not have heart disease and are not considered to be at high risk of developing it, the risk of side effects (particularly the risk of bleeding) outweighs the benefit of preventing blood clots.

【23】Will it affect my contraception?

【24】Aspirin does not affect any contraception, including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【25】Can I drink alcohol with it?

【26】Yes, you can drink alcohol while taking low-dose aspirin.

【27】But drinking too much alcohol while you're taking aspirin can irritate your stomach.

【28】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【29】You can eat and drink normally while taking low-dose aspirin.

【30】Can lifestyle changes help my health?

【31】*   Quit smoking – smoking increases your heart rate and blood pressure and increases your risk of heart attack and stroke. Try to avoid secondhand smoke, too.
*   Cut down on alcohol – try to keep to the recommended guidelines.
*   Exercise – regular exercise keeps your heart and blood vessels in good condition. It does not need to be too energetic, walking every day is enough.
*   Eat well – aim to eat a diet that includes plenty of fruit and veg, wholegrains, fat-free or low-fat dairy products and lean proteins. It's a good idea to cut down on salt, too. Aim for no more than 6g of salt a day.
*   Deal with stress – when you're anxious or upset, your heart beats faster, you breathe more heavily, and your blood pressure often goes up. This raises your risk of heart attack and stroke. Find ways to reduce stress in your life. To give your heart a rest, try napping or putting your feet up when possible. Spend time with friends and family to be social and help keep stress at bay.
*   Vaccinations – if you have heart failure, it's recommended that you have the flu vaccine every year and the pneumococcal vaccine as recommended by your GP. Ask your doctor about these vaccinations. You can have them free on the NHS. Coronavirus (COVID-19) vaccination is recommended for most people. Make sure you’ve had all the doses that you are eligible for. Talk to your doctor if you think you might be in one of the at risk groups.
删除11：<u>More in Low-dose aspirin
------------------------
